The Duke-Edinburgh edition of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle has now reached its thirty-sixth volume, and is moving into the 1860s, the decade in which Jane Welsh Carlyle died. We began publishing the letters in 1970 with a set of four volumes covering 1812–28, Charles Richard Sanders having begun the project at Duke University in 1952 (see CL 1:xxiv). In 1996, with volume 25 reaching 1850, we changed from intermittent publication in sets of two or three volumes to an annual production of a single volume. Since then, we have continued our slow and detailed progress through the nineteenth century and the letters and lives of Thomas Carlyle (TC) and Jane Welsh Carlyle (JWC). With the launch of the Carlyle Letters Online by Duke University Press now giving online access to the edition, the volumes of the Collected Letters truly join the twenty-first century.

Before considering the contents of this particular volume, it seems appropriate to look back at the aims and intentions of the edition and consider how practices may have changed over the more than fifty years the project has been in existence. It continues to be an example of international scholarly cooperation, now enabled by modern communications by email and easy transfer of electronic files. The texts of the letters of the Carlyles were mainly transcribed at Duke by Hilary Smith, our outstanding textual editor for many years, and the vast archive of typescript pages provides the basis of the textual edition, checked against originals, with only newly found letters transcribed directly into an electronic file. We are as dependent as we were in volume 1 on the skills of the production department of Duke University Press for their transformation of these typescripts into printed text. Where previously all editorial matter was also in typescript, the Press now incorporates into the print version the electronic files that make up the footnotes and front and back matter of each volume. Carlyle Letters Online has been taken from these volumes and will add each new one as it appears, as well as any material found too late to appear in the print edition. It represents a great move forward into the flexibility of electronic search engines, allowing the reader to roam by subject through the volumes and search many volumes electronically in pursuit of particular interests: individuals the Carlyles knew, themes thrown up in their day-to-day living in nineteenth-century Scotland or England, or all the details of the production of TC’s writings.

C. R. Sanders’s introduction to the first volume is a wide-ranging assessment of the purpose of the edition and of the supreme nature of the Carlyles’
letter-writing talents. He gives a summary of previous editors (including Carlyle himself), editions of the letters, and the whereabouts of the manuscripts of the letters. He lays out the details of editorial practice in relation to textual reproduction (1:xxviii—xxix); to a large extent the current editors still follow this practice. From volume 19, a “Note on the Text” has been included at the beginning of the letters to explain editorial practice, with the intention of making editorial practices transparent to the reader. Have the principles of editing changed over the thirty-eight years since the publication of the first four volumes in 1970? In many ways they have remained surprisingly constant. A decision was taken by Sanders about reproducing the texts as accurately as possible. But only an edition reproducing the manuscript form of the letters would be entirely accurate, and even that, without the feel of the paper, could not be authentic. In his 1831 review of John Wilson Croker’s edition of Boswell’s Life of Johnson, TC wrote about Croker’s editing practices:
div1.q: Nay, let us say that the spirit of Diligence, exhibited in this department, seems to attend the Editor honestly throughout: he keeps everywhere a watchful outlook on his Text; reconciling the distant with the present, or at least indicating and regretting their irreconcilability; elucidating, smoothing down; in all ways exercising, according to ability, a strict editorial superintendence. Any little Latin or even Greek phrase rendered into English, in general with perfect accuracy; citations are verified, or else corrected.TC’s “Boswell’s Life of Johnson,” “Fraser’s Magazine, no. 28.—The Life of Samuel Johnson, LL.D.; including a Tour to the Hebrides. By James Boswell, Esq.—A new Edition, with numerous Additions and Notes, by John Wilson Croker, LL.D., F.R.S. 5 vols. London, 1831” (Works 28:62). (Works 28:64)
div1.p: These editing principles (about a book, rather than an edition of letters) expressed at an early stage in TC’s career have also, to an extent, illuminated the editing of the Collected Letters. Unlike the late Victorian editions, we do not “smooth down” the texts of the Carlyles’ letters, preferring to print them in their complexity, mistakes and all, evoking a kind of authenticity of experience, however illusory this may seem, given the intense editorial substructure that accompanies the letters.

Conventions of reproduction, of addresses, salutations and farewells, the underlining of words, were established in volume 1. Punctuation is regularized up to a point while retaining as much as possible a record of what the Carlyles actually wrote. American spellings and grammatical conventions were used in the editorial matter from the beginning, and use of Modern Language Association rules of citation was formalized from volume 12. Notes have become longer and more frequent, partly because assumptions of general
knowledge in the 1960s can no longer be made so confidently. But also knowledge can be more accessible now; genealogical information in particular is now more easily found, meaning that many previously unidentified women, men, or children can be traced and noted. Where Shakespeare and Milton titles were always published without the author’s name attached, now only Shakespeare has this accolade, as we reluctantly concede that Milton no longer has such a high recognition factor. An appendix of biographical notes to each volume was introduced in volume 25, at the instigation of Clyde de L. Ryals, senior editor, with K. J. Fielding, from volume 12 until his death in 1998. These biographical notes mutate with each volume, often containing genealogical additions. Fluidity of name spelling persists in some cases, stemming from inconsistencies in nineteenth-century practice, whether by the Carlyles themselves or in listings in genealogical and other records. If JWC is our source, then a choice has to be made (as in the several servants called Ann or Anne), attempting consistency in our editorial references while accurately following changing spellings in JWC’s letters; we do explain and gloss. TC provides a warning for all editors in his tart reaction to Croker: “[F]or example, the Editor will punctually explain what is already sun-clear; and then anon, not without frankness, declare frequently enough that ‘the Editor does not understand,’ that ‘the Editor cannot guess,’ while, for the most part, the Reader cannot help both guessing and seeing” (Works 28:65). We try always to tread this delicate line between over- and underexplaining that TC found Croker to be transgressing.

The letters of this particular volume cover November 1859 to September 1860; it also includes an appendix of letters to TC’s family from summer 1859, letters that were found too late to include in volume 35; they will be included at their correct dates in Carlyle Letters Online. They refer both to the events surrounding the death of Isabella Carlyle, June 1859, and to the Carlyles’ summer stay in Fife. That holiday of 1859 was unusual, as it found them both in the same place for several weeks. The narrative of volume 36 is the more customary one. It begins with a winter spent together in Cheyne Row with TC working on and complaining about Frederick and JWC socializing, being ill (although to a lesser extent than other winters), and complaining about Frederick. This is then followed by a summer apart, with the Carlyles going to different destinations and providing commentary in their letters to each other and to others on what they find at those destinations. This summer, because of JWC’s misinterpretation of TC’s projected plans and her precipitate return to London instead of taking a planned trip to Scotland, there is a rich seam of commentary from each on their inadequacies as correspondents. Nero the dog, JWC’s old friend George Rennie, and Jess and Jean Donaldson, her old correspondents in Haddington, all die in 1860. The details
of this eleven-month period, as always, are in the letters, and a summary can be found in the chronology. From November 1859 to September 1860, TC writes 125 letters to JWC’s 87, but many of TC’s are short notes and JWC often writes letters of several pages, so the length of text written by JWC in this volume is nearly as much as that written by TC. Their views of the world are thus well balanced in this volume, with JWC’s longer letters allowing for expansion of her customarily ironic take on her life, as well as expressions of grief about the loss of her dog and her old friends and of irritation with TC during their summer travels apart.

TC’s first letter in this volume is appropriately about Frederick, to Joseph Neuberg, still faithfully pursuing books and facts for TC with booksellers and in libraries: “I write up to the chin in detestable Imbroglios: out of whh it will perhaps please Heaven, in its infinite mercy, to deliver me to all Eternity before very long!” (TC to JN, [1 Nov. 1859]). For the next three months, TC attempts to write volume 3 of Frederick at the same time as the printer was working on it, Neuberg correcting and researching for him as they went. In January 1860, TC describes the method:
div1.q: [H]ere has the Printer made his appearance; and he is eager to be at work! / I can see nothing for it but that after reading carefully some 10 or 12 of the first leaves (and making your jottings about them) you give them up to Robson; taking the rest more at leisure,—for he will not be in a very great hurry of speed; and is certain to waste a few days at the very first, in making adjustments, and settling preliminaries. / I shall not correct anything till I see the whole Book in slips;—if you could get yr leaves back from Robson for me, in a printed state; and let me have the whole (with yr remarks) on Sunday night next, that wd be the utmost I could expect, and indeed wd do well enough. (TC to JN, 16 Jan. 1860)
div1.p: By February, TC has called a halt to this frantic method, describing this to Lord Ashburton in imagery of the Crimean War:
div1.q: I myself am rather below par,—and very greatly bothered and hunted by this sad Book of mine; which, like the Siege of Sebastopol to Sir Jn Burgoyne, seems always the more impossible the longer one gazes on it! I attempted lately to do it by coup de main (or continuous storm, to last for 12 months!)—that is to say, I set the Printers to work to chace me thro’ it at a slow rate;—but have been obliged to call Halt in that, and go back to my trenches with heavy loss! (TC to Lord ALOA, 4 Feb. 1860)
div1.p:
In the headnotes that TC wrote later to JWC’s letters of this time, he remembers that he stopped at JWC’s insistence: “This first attempt of October–February, 1859–1860 (after dreadful tugging at the straps), was given up by her serious advices, which I could not but admit to be true as well as painful
and humiliating!” (Froude, LM 3:18). No hint of this appears in the letters, although JWC comments to TC’s sister Mary Austin that her better health this winter had helped “to keep up my heart in this weary passage thro’ The Valley of the Shadow of Frederick the Great!— Whom I am as sick of as I ever was of any thing in this world. And his unlucky Biographer, would, I dare say, tell the same story” (JWC to MCA, [ca. 16 Feb. 1860]). She had clearly also complained to Thomas Erskine, as he defends TC in his reply: “So the valley of the shadow of Frederick gets sometimes a little dark & rough! … I have no doubt it will pay the world for the trouble which it costs its author” (Thomas Erskine to JWC, 6 Feb. [1860]). It is clear that JWC is more concerned with its toll on herself than with the rewards the world was going to get from another work by Thomas Carlyle.

TC continues to struggle with volume 3 of Frederick, using both Henry Larkin and Neuberg as researchers. On 16 May 1860 he writes to Larkin asking for Friedrich books, while also acknowledging the importance to him of Larkin’s “right trade, that of the Maps” (for Larkin’s previous work on maps for Frederick, see 33:28TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1857, 34:57JWC to TC, 19 July 1858, and 35:26TC to HL, 8 Feb. 1859). On the same day, he also writes to Neuberg: “I have a bit of partly simple, partly very abstruse Copying for you here … in whh if you can succeed, as you have sometimes done, there will be a bit of real service rendered.” On 7 June, he again writes notes to both of them with requests for help, illustrating the complementary use that he makes of their willingness to help. His own feelings about Frederick continue to be negative; he describes the book as “a most undoable problem … whh I have got chained to, for my sins. Never in my life did there turn up for me so intolerable a burden as this whh I look upon as the finale. Certainly either it must finish, or else I!” (TC to [Sir GS or UC][SGS], 24 May 1860). In August, while in Thurso and struggling with positioning material he had already written, he returns to his military imagery about the writing of Frederick and comments: “This week has gone well with me, in all points except the Friedrich-Book one (sorrow on it!) Work wd not go on at all in the new section: however, I took it in the flank today, and did get some small way made again. A considerable comfort,—in this wettest of days” (TC to JWC, 24 Aug. 1860). By the end of this volume of the Collected Letters there is little real sense of progress. Volumes 3 and 4 of Frederick were not published until 1862 and 1863, with JWC’s attitude remaining unchanged. Only after her death does TC articulate recognition of her forbearance in his exaggerated later commentary on JWC’s letter to Mary Russell[MR], 28 January 1860:
div1.q:
My darling must have suffered much in all this; how much! I sometimes thought how cruel it was on her, to whom ‘Frederick’ was literally nothing except through me, so cruel, alas, alas, and yet inevitable! Never once in her deepest misery did she hint, by word or sign, what she too
was suffering under that score; me only did she ever seem to pity in it, the heroic, the thrice noble, and wholly loving soul!” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:18)
div1.p: It seems surprising if JWC did not even “hint” that “she too was suffering” to TC, given the extent to which she writes about her feelings in her letters to others.

Many of the letters of the second half of this volume are the usual summer exchange between TC and JWC while on their respective travels. JWC describes herself to TC’s sister Mary as now having “time to listen to my own sufferings, which had been drowned in the eloquence of his!” (JWC to MCA, [23 Aug. 1860]). Since TC spends six weeks in Thurso in the north of Scotland while JWC stays in Chelsea, visits Alderley, and then returns to London, the extended length of time that the postal services take in their exchange of letters allows for much misunderstanding and irritation between the two. TC feels himself entirely innocent when JWC misinterprets a letter about his plans and rushes back to London instead of traveling on to Dumfriesshire. JWC is furious with TC and punishes him by making her feelings clear (as well as describing them to her other correspondents): “As for your indignations at my not writing—I don’t quarrel with that—only beg to remind you that the reciprocity is not all on one side!” (JWC to TC, [3 Sept. 1860]). He had already written to his brother John that her movements are “a provoking enigma to me” (TC to JAC, 29 Aug. 1860), and he defends himself vigorously to JWC:
div1.q: [A] postal burble; the obstinate refusal, on the part of the female mind, to recognise as facts the unalterable laws of time and distance, and loyally conform to them in epistolary procedure. Your interpretations and hypotheses about my neglect of writing to you &c are as distracted as ever;—but I forget all that, nor will recognise any sin in you, you perverse creature, now that I hear at last that you are not in worse health than usual! … Adieu dear Anti-Geometress of Goodies. (TC to JWC, 5 Sept. 1860)
div1.p: He writes to John the next day that she has “at last written: Nothing the matter, after all my alarms; considers herself the aggrieved party, good soul, obstinately ignoring the inexorable regulations of mail-time in this country!” (TC to JAC, 6 Sept. 1860). JWC provides a forthright analysis of TC’s failure of tone and of understanding:
div1.q:
Not one letter you have written to me since you went away has hit the right state of things! Do the best that ever you could!—your “sheeps head” and your “coffin” have been equally out of time! Such being, I suppose, the natural result of going where an answer to ones letters
cannot be received in less than six days—in a world where nothing keeps still. … For the rest; all that has been said and written about my turning back and about my not starting again is kindly meant; but being said or written in total ignorance of the subject, quite over-shoots or under-shoots the mark! (JWC to TC, [9 Sept. 1860])
div1.p: After this critique of TC’s “total ignorance,” both Carlyles draw back, and the tone of their letters until TC returns to Chelsea at the end of the month is noticeably kinder. What is unusual in this exchange of letters is the extent to which they each comment (quite critically) on the other to relatives and friends and each feel aggrieved and justified in their position, providing an open and equal expression of feelings between them.

The survival of many letters to the Carlyles means that we have a fund of material at our disposal that can both explain a particular letter and expand on our understanding of a particular area. JWC’s letter to Mary Russell[MR], 28 January 1860, contains references to Isabelle Duncan’s Pre-Adamite Man; Or, The Story of Our Old Planet and Its Inhabitants, told by Scripture & Science, published anonymously in 1860 with five further editions to 1866, when she finally puts her name to it. JWC couples Duncan’s less well-known work with Darwin’s On the Origin of Species, published in November 1859:

But even when Darwin, in a Book that all the scientific world is in ecstasy over, proved the other day, that we are all come from shell-fish! it didn’t move me to the slightest curiosity whether we are or not! I did not feel that the slightest light would be thrown on my practical life for me by having it ever so logically made out, that my first ancestor millions of millions of ages back had been or even had not been an oyster!— It remained a plain fact that I was no oyster! nor had no grandfather oyster within my knowledge and for the rest, there was nothing to be gained for this world or the next by going into the oyster-question till all more pressing questions were exhausted! So—if I can’t read Darwin—! it may be feared I shall break down in Mrs Duncan! (JWC to Mary Russell[MR], [28 Jan. 1860])

Any reference to oysters is untraceable in Origin of Species, although Darwin did write that since early forms of marine creatures “have transmitted modified descendants to the present day … . [t]hey may metaphorically be called cousins to the … millionth degree” (Origin [1859] 420–21). A possible source for JWC’s extension of the descent from shellfish to oysters can be traced to Edward Twisleton’s letter to TC from Malvern, 1 January 1860; here Twisleton calls Origin of Species “the most remarkable and original work in its line” and then reports that his wife has been ordered “to lead the life of her
hundredth million million, million, million Cousin, the Oyster” so as not to injure her health “by an intemperate use of [her] brains.” Ellen Twisleton was being treated by Dr. James Gully (who had also treated Darwin and the Carlyles), and the entertaining possibility exists that the identification of our “cousins to the … millionth degree” with oysters might have been suggested by Darwin himself in conversation with Gully. What is certain is that the use of oysters as ancestors in reviews was used by reviewers in 1860, but not in any 1859 review that we have found. TC’s copy of On the Origin of Species in the National Library of Scotland contains no marginalia. Since TC was a frequent commentator in the margins of his books (for his comments in the margins of Ruskin’s copy of Barrett Browning’s Aurora Leigh, see 33:224–42; for his marginalia on Historical Memoirs of His Late Royal Highness William-Augustus, Duke of Cumberland [1767], see 35:87TC to SLA, 5 May, 1859), the inference has to be that he did not read Darwin’s book.

The letters provide some sharp details about the specifics of the Carlyles’ lives. Much has been written of TC’s concentration on the troubles of his digestion; in this volume his instructions to Sir George Sinclair before his trip to Thurso provide an illustration of his dietary habits that is based on an assertion of peasant simplicity:
div1.q: [M]y domestic habits are all for simplicity and composure (simplex munditiis the motto in all things), that I live, with clear preference where possible, on rustic farm-produce,— “milk and meal,” eggs, chickens, moor-mutton; white fish (salmon, veal, lamb, three things tabooed to me); reckon an innocent bread-pudding the very acme of culinary art … “the Cow is the friend of man, and the French cook his enemy,” and not one day in ten drink beyond a single glass of wine. (TC to Sir GS[SGS], 24 July 1860)
div1.p:
But he also provides a dramatic image (appropriately to Thackeray, a fellow writer aware of the effectiveness of exaggeration) to underline the relationship between his state of mind and his capacity for particular foods: “Alas, dear Thackeray, I durst as soon undertake to dance a hornpipe on the top of Bond Steeple, as to eat white-bait dinner in my present low and lost state!” (TC to WMT, 24 May 1860). We are given the most specific detail on JWC’s clothing when she makes a jacket for herself in January 1860 and then describes and illustrates its trimming in detail to Mary Russell: “The one I made of black silk is corded all round with scarlet-silk and then, about half an inch from the edge, a tartan velvet ribbon is run on plain” (JWC to Mary Russell[MR], 24 Feb. 1860; for the drawings, see 76). In this volume the Carlyles each develop a new relationship with Lady Louisa Ashburton, Lord Ashburton’s second wife, and JWC expresses extraordinary enthusiasm for the Ashburton baby (JWC to Lady ALLA, 11 July 1860, and JWC to Lady SLST, [ca. 16 Aug. 1860]).
TC extends his own aristocratic contacts with his long stay in Thurso with Sir George Sinclair, son of the great statistician Sir John Sinclair. And, as always, there is evidence in this volume of TC’s affectionate generosity to his family.

Meanwhile, further evidence appears of letters that JWC wrote but which have been lost. We know that JWC tried to write weekly (on a Wednesday) to the Donaldson sisters in Haddington (see 33:99JWC to MR, 8 Oct. 1857, and JWC to Grace DinningGDI, [31 March 1860]) but very few of the letters survive. In this volume we have JWC’s last letter to Jess Donaldson, 2 June 1860, in fact written after Jess died, 1 June. This death and the death of her sister Jean, 30 March, severed another link with Haddington for JWC. JWC also apparently wrote, late 1859, to Samuel Smiles (inextricably linked for us with notions of Victorian thrift and duty), as Smiles writes two letters to JWC in December 1859. These came out of links of friendship rooted in Haddington, Smiles writing in his second letter: “My Dear Mrs Carlyle / I am glad to find that my note has brought up in your mind so many associations of delightful girlhood.” Smiles continues that it was “positively the first time in which I was ever regarded in the light of a small lion. But a Haddington animal of this sort, even of the very smallest, is such a rarity, that I feel it is possible to be a curiosity, & at the same time a very ordinary creature after all” (S. Smiles to JWC, 13 Dec. 1859). JWC does not mention Smiles in her letters, but, as is our customary practice, we provide quotations from them by attaching them to the nearest dated letter, thus allowing us to illustrate the widespread connections of JWC as well as TC.

Liz Stanley writes in 2004 that “until relatively recently letters have been used mainly as a resource and treated as referential of a person’s life and its historical and relational context, with the focus on content and its recording of factual information.” She then suggests that there has been a move “over the last two decades or so” to an “emphasis … on the performative, textual and rhetorical aspects of letters.”Liz Stanley, “The Epistolarium: On Theorizing Letters and Correspondences,” Auto/ Biography 12 (2004): 201–35 (quotations on 211). But awareness of the value of the Carlyles’ letters in these terms existed from much earlier than the last two decades of the twentieth century. JWC’s letters were always appreciated as performative and rhetorical; however much JWC’s and TC’s biographers were to use them as source material for the lives, their literary qualities were recognized, ensuring that from the first publication of her letters in 1883 there was recognition that there were “two writers in the house” (as Townsend Scudder put it in 1931).Townsend Scudder, Letters of Jane Welsh Carlyle to Joseph Neuberg, 1848–1862 (1931) xiii. C. R. Sanders’s final section of the introduction to volume 1 considers the “Characteristics, Value, and Significance of the Letters” (1:xxx–xliv).
This remains a model of analysis as to why the Carlyles’ letters should be published and the ways in which they can be approached as literature, discussing the skill of both Carlyles in narrative, description, and portraiture. Inevitably, as a senior male academic of that time, Sanders concentrates on TC’s responses to the world around him. But, having taken the decision that both sets of letters had to be published together, because JWC’s “letters were essentially and vitally complementary to his” (1:xxvi), Sanders provides a brief description of JWC’s high literary skills: “Her resources of language were remarkable, involving abundant use of metaphor and great variety and cleverness in making use of the principle of association” (1:xxxi). Sanders also highlights TC’s own view of the editor’s craft, summarizing TC’s response to Oliver Cromwell, John Sterling, Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, Sir Walter Scott, Horace Walpole, and Voltaire (1:xi—xv), implicitly underlining the possibility of letters as literature, rather than as just biographical or historical source material. Sanders’s conclusion underlines this view: “Taken as a whole, the letters have a vital unity and unfold a story resembling that of an enormous multi-volumed, crowded-canvas, cross-section-of-life, realistic novel, swarming with major and minor characters, containing much dialogue, and having a moving and complex plot with subplots and auxiliary anecdotes, and with many bright comic colors providing relief for some deeply tragic shadows” (1:xliii—iv). K. J. Fielding, the senior editor with the project from the mid-1960s until 2001, never wavered in his long commitment to the Carlyles’ letters. Yet in 1987 he felt obliged to show a more defensive attitude to the genre of “Letters “: “Letters in general have been losing their status as literature or even part of the biographical record, perhaps because though highly expressive their context makes them resistant to reinterpretation” (13:xiii13:introduction). This response was perhaps inevitable at a time more devoted to theory in the study of literature than to scholarly editions of “great” writers’ letters. But with the return of the appreciation of letters as a literary form and a new understanding of the importance of life writing and testimony, the success, interest, and usefulness of a great scholarly edition of letters can be asserted without apology.

div1.p: November 1859–September 1860
November 1859–September 1860

1859 November. JWC thanks Julia Sterling for her gift ([8]). TC sends James Liddell a gift of books (10), thanking him for allowing him and JWC the free use of Auchtertool House in August. TC consults with Edward Chapman about prints of Frederick the Great (11) and asks Jean Aitken to knit him “sock boots” for riding (13). He writes James Marshall to acknowledge the grand duke of Weimar’s intention of conferring on him the title of Knight of the White Falcon (14). He recommends his neighbor Gilchrist’s biography of Blake to Edward Chapman (28). JWC congratulates Lady Airlie on the birth of her daughter, and confesses her apprehension about visiting The Grange under the new Lady Ashburton, who is also expecting a child ([28 Nov. or 5 Dec.]). JWC’s dog, Nero, is now confined to the house after being run over by a butcher’s cart in October. TC welcomes the resumption of correspondence with Edward FitzGerald (30). JWC writes to William Dods about Haddington news and tells him of a visit from her old admirer George Rennie ([>30]).

December. TC’s title Knight of the White Falcon is announced in the newspapers (6); he gives the insignia to JWC. Nero’s asthma is worse. John Carlyle is looking for a house to buy (10 [11]). TC has a cold, toothache, and “an ugly fixed pain in the brow” ([15]). The Carlyles spend Christmas in Chelsea. TC continues to struggle with his work (29). JWC sends a rubber hot water bottle to Janet Davidson, who has evidently been ill; JWC’s letters to Scotland for New Year’s Day are delayed by visitors, but are written ([31]).

1860 January. TC sends New Year’s gifts to his relatives (2). JWC goes shopping for new clothes (2) for the Carlyles’ visit to The Grange (5–13). TC calls on Lady Sandwich (3) and gives Neuberg work to do in his absence (4) and (7). JWC’s health improves at The Grange, but she worries about Nero ([10]), while TC tells sister Jean that he was “decidedly wretched” at first but felt better by the end of the visit (14). John A. Carlyle exercises TC’s horse, Fritz, while TC is away (14); JWC sends a pheasant to Isabella Barnes, an unwanted gift from The Grange ([14]). TC’s printers begin work on vol. 3 of Frederick (16) but TC stops sending them work by the beginning of February; the printers do not resume until November. Eggs, fowls, and cakes arrive from Scotland. JWC describes the second Lady Ashburton as “kindness’s self” ([16]). Larkin and Neuberg are still helping TC with small commissions, while TC is “busy almost to delirium” (24).

February. JWC is devastated by the death of Nero, “my inseparable Companion during eleven years” (1); she asks Robert Tait for copies of some of his photographs of Nero ([6]). Prompted by Lord Ashburton ([2]), TC returns W. V. Vernon’s Francke portrait of Frederick (11). JWC writes the Dods about Charlotte’s valentine card, and of her own delight in receiving a photograph of them (15); TC also had a valentine gift from a female admirer ([16]). Frederick is proceeding slowly; TC complains that he is “in the bottom of the Slough of Despond” (20). JWC advises Mary Russell on dressmaking (24). TC declines an invitation to Vernon Lushington’s birthday party (26) and thanks Charles Butler for his help with American investments (28).

March. Ruskin had already lent TC a copy of one Dürer print and now lends him another (15); TC remains very busy with his “unprofitable, hideously undoable task” (27). JWC sits with George Rennie as he dies (22) and writes to tell his Aunt Grace about the death (23). Jean Donaldson dies (30).

April. TC and JWC are given a private viewing of Holman Hunt’s The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple, which TC calls “a really grand Picture” (13). TC, having bought the stereotype plates of his works, derives a steady income from their use for reprint editions; he sends £50 to his brother Alick in Canada (13) and offers to help Alick’s son Tom if necessary. He visits Lord Sandwich and, his mother, Lady Sandwich, at Hinchinbrook (26–28), though he finds the company too stimulating (27). He sends £10 to his sister Jenny in Canada (30). He corresponds with Emerson about American and German editions of his works (30).

May. JWC has a fall and breaks a rib, but asks Jane Dods whether she should visit the gravely ill Jess Donaldson in Haddington ([9]); she is convinced by Jane Dods’s reply that she should not go ([17]). TC refuses to write on the proposed Reform Bill for Thomas Ballantyne’s Manchester Review (9). Neuberg and Larkin continue working steadily for TC. He loses patience with the Examiner and changes to the Observer (16); his impatience with Frederick means “certainly either it must finish, or else I!” (24). He sends his brother James the final payment for the refurbishment of the family plot in Ecclefechan graveyard (23). He accepts an invitation from Sir William Payne-Gallwey to visit Chequers (26–28). Thackeray asks TC for an article for the Cornhill, but TC refuses (26). JWC is recovering from her accident (30).

June. JWC writes affectionately to Jess Donaldson, not having heard of her death on 1 June; she hears of the death of her childhood friend Robert McTurk in Dumfriesshire ([2]). TC thanks Lady Payne-Gallwey for photographs of the Cromwells from Chequers (5). He complains of sleeplessness and of heavy summer rain (7). JWC thanks Lady Ashburton for a kind letter,
asks her for copies of some photographs, and comments on the strain TC is under with Frederick (16). She plans an expedition to Southend with Neuberg (22). She congratulates Lady Ashburton on the birth (26) of her daughter, Mary Florence ([29]).

July. JWC visits the Ashburton baby (13). The Carlyles and Neuberg go to Brighton for a week (2–9), but TC still has trouble sleeping. They visit Kate Ross, who is ill. JWC continues in good health and visits Lady Ashburton (13). TC accepts an invitation to visit Sir George Sinclair in Thurso (24).

August. Charlotte Southam is dismissed and “Old Jane” employed (early Aug.). TC, feeling generally run down, embarks with his brother John for Aberdeen (1) and then to Sir George Sinclair in Thurso Castle (4), leaving behind JWC, who prefers to remain in Chelsea. She visits Kate Ross, who is in lodgings in London (4), and embarks on general cleaning and repairs at Cheyne Row. She thanks Lady Stanley for the gift of her portrait; William and Jane Dods visit (8) as do Andrew and Mary Symington (11). JWC’s nerves are still bad, and she sleeps little. In Thurso TC writes, walks, bathes, and relaxes; he sends Lady Sandwich a groatie buckie and a twig of heather (12). TC, hearing of JWC’s ill health, advises her to leave London for the country (13), specifically to Mary Austin at The Gill. JWC accepts Lady Stanley’s invitation to Alderley and makes plans to travel on to Scotland from there. Before leaving London she visits Lady Sandwich ([17]) and is visited by Lady Ashburton (21). TC and Sir George visit John o’ Groats (22); TC’s sleep has greatly improved, but he finds family visitors to Thurso Castle (especially grandchildren) trying. Having finished book 3 of vol. 3 of Frederick (22 [21]), he plans to leave Thurso and travel to Annandale via Linlathen (24 [23]). JWC goes to Alderley (22) and writes to Mary Austin and Mary Russell, arranging to visit them; she misinterprets TC’s confusing letter (22 [21]) as meaning he is leaving for Chelsea at once; JWC decides she should give up her own travel plans and return to prepare the house for his return. TC writes to say she has misunderstood him (28), too late to prevent her return (28). She asks William Dods to tell her who has bought Sunny Bank (Tenterfield) in Haddington. Charlotte Southam is taken back for occasional days, “Old Jane” proving incompetent.

September. TC, still in Thurso, writes to Lady Sandwich telling her the legend of John o’ Groat, and to Lady Ashburton regretting that he cannot come and visit them at Kinlochluichart (2). He plans to recommence the printing of Frederick (7). Neuberg invites JWC to Margate for an excursion, but she declines ([3]). She goes to Norwood with Geraldine Jewsbury for the day (7), after which she becomes ill; she is visited in her sickroom by Countess von Usedom (8). The servant “Old Jane” is dismissed, and “Tall Charlotte”
employed. TC leaves Thurso (7) and stays with Erskine at Linlathen (8–11), then takes the train to Scotsbrig (11). JWC recovers sufficiently to go out for a drive to Bath House ([12]). TC finds Scotsbrig lonely and is irritable. He moves to The Gill, where a family reunion takes place (16). He visits Dumfries, climbs the Mid-Steeple, and sees the old townhouse originally belonging to JWC’s family. JWC is bedridden with influenza for several days. A second servant, Sarah, arrives (18). Mrs. Wedgwood visits bringing grapes (18), and JWC recovers enough to invite John Barlow to tea (20). TC returns to Chelsea, declining a visit to Alderley en route (22). He thanks Charles Ward for his poem “A Sutherland Clearance” (24) and summons Neuberg (who is away) to start work again on Frederick (28).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [early Nov. 1859?]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Dated approximately by JWC’s early friendship with Isabella Barnes, when she still addressed her as Miss Barnes; by JWC’s good health since her return from Scotland in Sept., which would eliminate the need for a visit from Doctor Barnes; and by the jocular reference to Nero who was to be put down on 1 Feb. 1860. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has be assigned a document date of 1 November 1859.]
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. BARNES

docBody.p: I havnt time to go in to see you, being on my way to Barnsbury Park Islington,Probably to visit Stavros Dilberoglue and Sarah Anderton, who had lived at 13 Barnsbury Park since their marriage in Sept.; see 35:195TC to JAC, 6 Sept. which lies, I take it, somewhere other side the Moon! But I take the opportunity of having a “neat Fly”JWC had a “neat Fly” from John Silvester, livery stables, Upper Church St., Chelsea, twice a week; see 34:257JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1858; TC paid Silvester £6 10s., 29 Nov.: “(Horse and Flies till this night)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). for the expedition; to hand you in a box of Portugal PlumsPresumably Elvas plums, harvested in the autumn and preserved in sugar, a traditional Portuguese specialty often given as a gift.—come to me “by electric Telegraph”! (as a Manchester shopkeeper advertised certain goods “just received” by him from the place they were manufactured at!) I suppose your Father has forgotten utterly, that in Chelsea there is a street called Cheyne Row and in Cheyne Row a House No 5, and in No 5 a remarkably intelligent woman, extremely well disposed towards him; altho he has, decidedly, no respect for Canine Life!
Would you mildly remind him of the fact?
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [1 Nov.]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 1 Nov. 1859. MS: NLS 553.205. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
I wish you wd write to Heberle,J. M. Héberlé, Cologne booksellers. and say that I shall be glad of his Kuster’s SaldernKarl Daniel Küster, Characterzüge des preussischen General-Lieutenants von Saldern (Berlin, 1793); TC’s copy: HCC. In Frederick, TC refers to Küster as “a reliable creature, reporting for us on Saldern’s behalf” (Works 18:345). (likely enough to be worth so many groschen to me at present!)—
and that I wish him earnestly to set abt getting me the following two Books: 1° Helden-Staats &c Geschichte,Helden-, Staats-, und Lebens-Geschichte des allerdurchlauchtigsten und grossmächtigsten Fürsten und Herrns, Friedrichs des Andern, 11 vols. (Frankfurt, 1758–64); see 33:22TC to KAVE, 12 Aug. 1857; TC’s copy: HCC. all the volumes that are of it after vol V (Leipzig & Frkft 1760; goes to & thro’ “553”) (whh is the last I have here). All that follows of this Book I much want to have. The Herr He [Héberlé] is not to count groschen in this affair; but to advertise for it, bestir himself, and get it (within a few months, say 6, will still do,—after whh I had rather not have it;—quàm primùm [as soon as possible], or instantly, were best of all): he shall be paid for his trouble and outlay.

2° The 3 last volumes of Adelung’s Prage Gesche:Johann Christoph Adelung, Pragmatische Staatsgeschichte Europens von dem Ableben Kaiser Carls 6 an bis auf die gegenwärtigen Zeiten, 9 vols. (Gotha, 1762–67). TC had received vols. 1–8 from Williams & Norgate in May 1859; see 35:99TC to JN, 26 May. He noted: “I had a 9th vol., but it consisted only of Documents, State-papers &c., & was of no use. Herr Tauchnitz of Leipzig, who searched out for me that 9th vol., asserted confidently that no other had ever been published” (TC’s copy: HCC). See also 30:84TC to JN, 20 Oct. 1855. I have vol 8 & preceeding (which gives ‘year 1757’ of Seven-yrs War), but I believe there are 3 others, making 11 voll. in all, whh carry us down to 1763: these last 3 voll. too he must advertise for, and get them if possible!— I have of course no use at all for Duplicates of voll. 8, 7 &c; but if these are attached to the copies offered, I will stand one or two of them,—and these Herr He may keep meinetwegen [for all I care], with my blessing on them! Dasselbe gilt [the same worth] of Helden-Staats &c. Adelg’s Indexes are a precious point to me.TC concluded his note on Adelung’s Pragmatische Staatsgeschichte in Frederick: “It cannot help being dull, waste, dreary, but is everywhere intelligible (excellent Indexes too)” (Works 14:391). By real endeavour of He I think both these Books may be got; and it is pity if I cannot get them, for money down,—now that the Preuss Oracle has taken the sulks! In one hour (indexless as it is) I can dig more out of that frightful Helden-Stts Imbroglio than the living Preuss wd have yielded me to the end of our mutual lives.Johann David Erdmann Preuss (1785–1868), author of several books on this period; see 30:139TC to JN, 12 Dec. 1855, and Works 12:324. So prosecute this new vein, I beg of you!—

Here are yr Postage-Stamps at least, for these two adventures, the late sorrowful and the prest still hopeful one.— I write up to the chin in detestable Imbroglios:“In October, after getting home, there was a determined onslaught made on ‘Frederick,’ an attempt (still in the way of youth—16 rather than 60!) to vanquish by sheer force the the immense masses of incondite or semi-recondite rubbish which had accumulated on ‘Frederick,’ that is, to let the printer straightway drive me through it!—a most fond and foolish notion, which indeed I myself partly knew, durst I have confessed it, to be foolish and even impossible! But this was the case all along; I never once said to myself, ‘All those chaotic mountains, wide as the world, high as the stars, dismal as Lethe, Styx, and Phlegethon, did mortal ever see the like of it for size and for quality in the rubbish way? All this thou wilt have to take into thee, to roast and smelt in the furnace of thy own poor soul till thou fairly do smelt the grains of gold out of it!’ No, though dimly knowing all this, I durst not openly know it (indeed, how could I otherwise ever have undertaken such a subject?); and I had got far on with the unutterable enterprise, before I did clearly admit that such was verily proving, and would, on to the finis, prove to have been the terrible part of this affair, affair which I must now conquer tale quale, or else perish!” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:17–18). out of whh it will perhaps please Heaven, in its infinite mercy, to deliver me to all Eternity before very long!

closer.salute: Yours ever truly,—in very great haste

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS [JMS], [8 Nov.]. Addr: The Revd F. Maurice’s / Russell Square. PM: London, 9 Nov. 1859. MS: NLS 3823.188. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JULIA STERLING

docBody.p: What a charming surprise you had managed for me, when after what the servants call “cleaning myself”Coterie speech; see 8:223JWC to TC, 12 Oct. 1835, and 27:162JWC to WHB, 10 July 1852. (which you will allow was needed), with only a thin closet door between me and the man,Unexplained. I returned to the drawingroom and sat down to write the weekly letter to my two ninety-year old LadiesJWC’s godmother, Jean, and her sister, Jess Donaldson. at Home—(Haddington-Scotland) My eyes then took in the little box; and next the writing on it; and I unfolded the contents half in childish delight over my present, half in provocation that you were gone without being kissed for it—specifically.

I am more pleased with it than you can well imagine—considering my years, and philosophic turn of mind! It is pretty—very! and if such a thing had dropt out of the moon into my lap, I should have admired it, and put it on, and looked at myself in the glass! But besides the intrinsic prettiness; you had brought it me from IrelandJohn George Cooke had written to JWC, 7 Sept., that Julia Sterling and her sister Hester and brother Edward were visiting their uncle Hugh Barton (1800–70) in Ireland: “they do not return for some weeks” (MS: NLS 1774.163).—ergo you had been remembering me when I was not believing myself anything but clean forgotten! The pleasure of that to a woman who loves you, and is more sensitive than she chooses to show, and has more pride than faith, unhappily, is not to be put into any phrase of thanks— But, if you were beside me, I could, I think, put it into a “hug,” for all that I havnt the strength in my arms I had when you knew me first, and I could pull your Aunt CharlotteCharlotte Sterling, Anthony Sterling’s wife. off the floor with a poker.

Do come soon again Dear! at as early an hour as you like—ten—nine would not be too early for me—if it made it easier for you to come. Your bright face always does me good. If you laid that well to heart you would feel it a Christian duty to come often / Your ever affectionate / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JL] [JLI], 10 Nov. MS: Carlyle House, The National Trust. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified by the reference to Auchtertool House in Fife, where the Carlyles had stayed during the summer.
div3.head: TC TO [JAMES LIDDELL]

docBody.p: The other day I did myself the pleasure of despatching (to the care of Menzies Bookseller, Edinr)John Menzies (1808–79;ODNB), wholesale bookseller and publisher of Scottish guidebooks; he opened his first railway bookstall in 1857. His warehouse premises were at 2 S. Hanover St., Edinburgh. a Packet of Books for Auchtertool,James Liddell lent the Carlyles Auchtertool House (next to Auchtertool Manse) rent-free from 6 Aug. until 10 Sept. which have probably arrived, or ought to be arriving, about this date. I cannot hope they will be of much use to you, nor are you bound to look into them at all; but I must beg you to accept them, and give them houseroom, as a small memorial of my sentiment upon your very great civilities to us in Fife last summer; a kindness and politeness on your part, which it will be long before we be tempted to forget!

I was unluckily so driven, at the time of my departure, that I had to go on the sudden, and leave to my Wife the charge of bidding you individually farewell at the time.For JWC’s relief at TC’s departure, see 35:207JWC to LST, 18 Sept. But there will be other seasons, I hope, for repairing that omission. And repaired or not, you will know to interpret it, not too deeply to my discredit. Auchtertool, it is very certain, will continue pleasantly memorable to me all my days, for your sake, were there no other’s.

Bookseller Menzies, I said, (whom Mr WelshRev. Walter Welsh, JWC’s cousin, who lived at Auchtertool Manse. knows) got charge of the Books:—franked as far as Menzies; who was to despatch them by rail “next day.” If they have not arrived when this comes to hand, please let me know, that I may push him again.

My Wife got a great benefit on the High-grounds of Auchtertool; and is much stronger hitherto than her wont has been of late. That will be good news to you: long may it last! The coming frost gives new emphasis to that later aspiration.

We send many compliments and grateful regards to the good Ladies;Liddell’s sisters, Eliza and Isobel, who lived with him at Kirkton farm nearby; see 35:106TC to JAC, 7 June. both of whom I vividly remember, and will, in a very pleasant form.

closer.salute: Wishing health and welfare heartily to you and yours, I remain always

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG [AGIL], [10 Nov.]. MS: Duke. Pbd: Gilchrist 79. Gilchrist places it in 1860–61; dated by annotation attached to MS.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: Dear Mrs Gilchrist— Here is a letter I have had today from that dear little Mrs Hawkes,Emilie Hawkes, who was wintering in Florence; see JWC to Lady ALAI, [28 Nov. or 5 Dec.].—so amusing that it seems a shame to keep it all to myself when there is another intelligent reader otherside the wallThe Gilchrists lived next door at 6 Cheyne Row.— Let me have it back tomorrow—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 11 Nov. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: In regard to the Two Berlin Proof Prints, which I have had in hand these five days, and have been considering with best attention, my report is this:

1°. As to the First Print, the Younger Friedrich, I pronounce it at once to be of first-rate excellence, almost as good as Wille’s original; and think we have nothing to do but accept that, as in all respects the thing wanted. If the Berlin friends could add (from indubitable authority, Herr Dr Preuss, for example) in what year Wille engraved (at Paris, I suppose) and Pesne painted,—so that we might put “aetatis 30,” “1742” or whatever the year is,—it wd be a useful adjunct.Portrait of Frederick by Antoine Pesne (1683–1757), originally engraved by Johann Georg Wille (1715–1808). TC’s engraving was by Stanislaus Lukomsky (1835–67), overseen by Johann August Eduard Mandel (1810–82); see 35:31TC to JN, 11 Feb. It was used as the frontispiece to vol. 3 of the 1st edn. of Frederick (1862), where “Berlin, Jany. 1742” was added under Pesne’s name and “Berlin 1861, after Wille” under Lukomsky’s; see Works 15:frontispiece.

2° With regard to the Second Print (after Francke’s Picture),Portrait of Frederick by Heinrich Francke (1738–92).—tho’ this too is beautifully worked, and the figure, attitude, &c are perfect,—I am sorry to say that the face is entirely a failure, an inconceivable mistake, from beginning to end; and will not do at all! What it is that Herr Mandel has been copying, or where he got that face, I cannot understand. Francke’s Picture in the Schickler Banking House is still vividly present to me,TC had seen the painting, thought at the time to be by Anton Graff, on his visit to the Schickler Bros. bank in Berlin, Oct. 1852; see 27:325TC to LOA, 7 Oct. 1852, and 30:145TC to JN, 23 Dec. 1855. and I have a Photograph of it, sent me by Herr MagnusEduard Magnus (1800–1872), German portrait painter; see 35:8TC to JN, 14 Jan. long ago; there is also, beside me here for two years past, an English Francke (done for an English Lord,Sir John Borlase-Warren (1753–1822), whose grandson W. W. Vernon lent TC the “brother” portrait of Frederick by Francke (see 33:210TC to WWV, 22 April 1858), now hanging in the Athenaeum Club, London; see 33:209–12TC to WWV, 22 April 1858; see also TC to WWV, 4 Feb. 1860, and TC to WWV, 10 Feb. 1860. passing thro’ Potsdam, I think in 1773), which perfectly corresponds to the Schickler Picture at Berlin, and to this Engraving if we except the face:—but the face given in this Engraving has, alas, no resemblance almost, scarcely a relationship, to either of these; and both in feature, & above all in expression, totally differs from the Schickler Original! How it has come I know not; but here is the Schickler Photograph (the face wanted and bargained for); there is the face sent:—irreparably unlike; another face, another character; whh will not do at all! The expression in the Photograph is of aggressive inspection, polite yet Kinglike vigilance & command; that of the Engraving is of peaceable passive amenity; polite, but almost weak; nothing of the King in it, more like a polite Professor of Belles-Lettres: it is passive, timid; not aggressive, royal, lion-like. What is to be done! I have shown the thing to some Artist friends:Possibly Robert Tait and the Pre-Raphaelite painter and designer Ford Madox Brown (1821–93; ODNB; see 35:88–89TC to FMB, 5 May); otherwise unidentified. they find almost every feature altered: the scalp (which looks more like a wig, as it shd not do) is set on the brow at a wrong angle (droops to right); brow itself is visibly of different slope; eyebrows, eye, &c &c,—and what strikes myself much or most, is the nature of the mouth; shaped here like a mild Apollo’s-bow, and carefully shut (lest it bite something), instead of carelessly half-open (as in the original), and protruding rather, with a fine unconscious defiance in it.— In brief, the expression given to the face in the Engraving is fatally different from that in the original at Schickler’s whh I want;—and as it is, more especially, pretty much the reverse of what readers are likely to gather from the Book I am writing, it will never do for Frontispiece there.TC used a portrait of Frederick’s sister, Friederike Sophie Wilhelmine (1709–58; see 30:47TC to JAC, 28 Aug. 1855), margravine of Baireuth, from a picture in Count von Usedom’s collection, for the frontispiece of vol. 4 (1864); see Works 16:frontispiece.

My opinion, and that of all my Artist Advisers is, This face must be abolished (erased from the metal altogether), and the Francke one then put in. Put in the Francke one (of Schickler’s-Bank) must be; or else I can get no good of it. Here is the Photograph; forward it to Berlin; the Proof Print they, of course, have there: bid them look on this picture then on that! And finally contrive to get the real face for me;—which must be little of a problem (if tried on clear terms) to such Artists as I see these are.For “look at this picture,” cf. Hamlet 3.4. Mandel was asked to do the engraving again, and it was then reluctantly accepted by TC; see TC to FC, 29 Aug. [July] 1860. The Francke portrait, dated Potsdam ca. 1770, engraved by Mandel, dated Berlin 1860, was used as the frontispiece of vol. 5 (1865); see Works 17:frontispiece.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 13 Nov. MS: NLS 516.98. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Since there are no orthodox List ShoesIndoor shoes made of strips of list, or selvage, sewn together; see 35:246TC to LOA, 30 Oct. to be had, we will not mind that part of the affair at all. The proper substitute wd be the sort of thing women have by way of “Snow-boots” (omitting the leather soles from them in this case); I have had two pairs of such by way of slippers (with the leather soles); but both of them were such scandalous misfits and ugly botherations, we will not meddle on that side again till there is better chance for us. Do you knit me (as you will right well) a pair, or even two pairs, of right sock boots (proper length of foot not erring on the short side, and with some strength in them as well as spring): these will perfectly equip me agt the dry cold for this current winter. I ride daily with the old tattered flimsy pair, thin leather pumps and excellent thick stockings inside; and, so capital and substantial are the outer overalls, I suffer nothing from the cold,—the rather as “Fritz,” the Horse, is quite up to speed, this winter!— Sufficient now of that business.

We are still holding out here, Jane too, tho’ the d[r]earyLetter omitted. weather (rimy of late, and always on the edge of frost, with perhaps two hours of struggling sun in all) is very unfavourable to her. I hang on, like a spavined gin-horse, to my uncomfortable harness; and have more and more a kind of defiant intention that, better or worse, this villain of a load shall be at last kicked about its business,—in the Devil’s name, if not a better. My progress is small; my botherations (from without even) are many, and my strength cannot be on the growing hand at this hour of the day!— “Pleag ma’ car’; A carriet my reeg!” as
Joe Rule said, in the ancient time.Joe Rule, one of the Dumfries-to-Craigenputtoch carriers; see 7:47TC to BN, 26 Nov. 1833; possibly “Damn [plague on] my cart; I carried my rig [load].” Jack is here, as you know, for a ten days past; busy with his WattsTheir brother John Aitken Carlyle and his stepsons. chiefly, I think. He has now actually an Offer in for “The Langshaw” (near Kirtlebridge) whh is on sale:Langshaw House, 2 mi. SE of Ecclefechan, was advertised for sale “by Public Roup … if not previously disposed of by private bargain.” The house had “Dining, Drawing and Ante-rooms, six bedrooms, Water closet, two good Kitchens, with other conveniences, and is suitable for the accommodation of a genteel family” (Dumfries and Galloway Courier, 25 Oct.). I do heartily wish he may get it, poor fellow: An old man wandering houseless is not a pleasant object to those interested in him. He is still strong and hearty,—tho’ clearly growing old, like some others of us. I am glad Margt of The Gill is so wedded.TC’s niece Margaret Austin m. Thomas Stewart 1 Nov. TC sent “£25 (to Mary, for Magt Austin. Wedding day)” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Send us some news again soon. My blessings of you all, dear Jean. Yours T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [14 Nov.]. Addr: Montague Square. PM: London, 14 Nov. 1859. MS: NLS 1797.21. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: It was “a tempting of Providence” to make an appointment in such weather! and you too not even got over your horrid fright!Eliza Forster’s accident; TC has written “(what” in blue pencil after the word “fright”; no details are known.

It might be such a savage day as this tomorrow here, in Chelsea, and not foggy at all with you—and so, like the “wee wifie who lived in a shoe,” I shouldnt know “what to do”Nursery rhyme; see also 30:249JWC’s Journal, 1 May 1856, and 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March 1858.!—
Best to give it up today, in time to warn you not to expect me to lunch—
I will come the first feasable day, for a call—on the purely “voluntary principle”Coterie speech; see 32:48JWC to IC, 10 Dec. 1856. the only safe one at this season—
But Mr C is not too weak either in mind or body for making appointments and he says he will be happy to go up to Montague Square any evening this week Mr Forster likes to name—after dinner of course
Oh I am afraid this accident will have shattered you to pieces and made you ill for a long time
I will soon come to ask—only not to luncheon
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO], [14 Nov.]. Addr: Montague Square. PM: London, 14 Nov. 1859. MS: NLS 1797.18. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: Just the minute after my note was sent to the Post office came yours— Thanks I am glad to see you are not ill— I send no 2 to say Mr Forster must not fix Thursday—for Mr C coming over for a Greek is coming with his new wifeStavros Dilberoglue and Sarah Anderton had m. on 6 Sept. to tea here—

Suppose he Mr Forster came too with the Browning letters?Forster and Robert Browning were frequently at odds, but were currently on good terms; apparently Robert Browning’s letters to Forster were often shared with friends. If you were to do such a thing would it kill you—or bore you—which were still worse?
docBody.name: J W C

div3.sourceNote: TC- JM [JMA], 14 Nov. MS: British Lib. 3032.27. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES MARSHALL

docBody.p: You can, with my profound respects, assure H. R. H. The Grand Duke that I am fully sensible to the honour he does me;Karl Alexander, grand duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, had offered TC the Order of the White Falcon (see 23JWC to MR, 9 Dec.). He wrote, 9 Nov.: “I have long admired your genius, long taken a lively interest in those of your writings especially, which, while they clearly reflect the intellectual life of Germany to the minds of your countrymen, prove at the same time a profound source of instruction to our own. It is natural therefore that the approaching festivities in honor of the most national and popular of our Poets should remind me of your peculiar merit as one of the earliest of Schiller’s biographers,—and no less natural that, on such an occasion, I should request your acceptance of the accompanying token of my sincere acknowledgement of that merit, as well as of other important literary performances, by which you have deserved the lasting gratitude of two Nations.” The letter was written in Marshall’s hand. For TC’s biography of Schiller (1825), see Works 25. The centenary of Schiller’s birth was 10 Nov., and the certificate that accompanied the Order was also dated 10 Nov.; see 14above. and that there is no law or custom in England to prevent a man from deciding as he himself pleases in regard to such matters.
As to my own particular case, there are only two facts which I now submit to you: then well considered, and taken as candidly true, the decision shall be yours, not mine. The two facts are:

1°. That the fixed intention of such a favour, from such a Quarter, is itself a
real possession to me, and will always privately be a proud little item in my memory henceforth. This you will have no difficulty in believing.

2°. That the wearing, or publicly using, of any Title, foreign or domestic, great or small, would not now appear suitable or be a satisfaction to me, as things go and have gone. This also you may take to be very certain.

So that, strictly speaking, it is the Princely Intention alone that can be really precious to me;—and this being already indisputable, and even officially on record, the question of completing it or not completing I will leave to your own tact, insight, and polite management, on those data.See TC to JMJMA, 28 Nov.

With many homages to His Royal Highness and to the High LadyTC had apparently not heard of the death, 23 June, of Maria Paulowna, Marshall’s employer and Karl Alexander’s mother. TC had met her in Weimar in 1853; see 27:301–2TC to JWC, 25 Sept. 1852. Marshall replied, 21 Nov.: “Perhaps you may think of writing H. R. H. soon … ; it may be as well to remind you that the Grand-Duchess-Mother, your old Belvedere friend, died in June last, and that Their Royal Highnesses lost their second daughter, a sweet little girl of about nine years old, only a month before.” whom you have the honour to serve, I remain
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: The Herr Hofrath Marshall &c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 28 Nov. MS photocopy: British Lib. RP6421; handwritten copy: UCLA. Pbd: Joseph Viscomi, “Blake after Blake: A Nation Discovers Genius,” Blake, Nation and Empire, ed. Steve Clark and David Worrall (Basingstoke, 2006) 214.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: My Neighbour, Mr Gilchrist, has finished, or is on the point of finishing, a Book (to be in one Volume) on the Life of the Painter Blake,Alexander Gilchrist’s Life of Blake was completed by Anne Gilchrist after her husband’s death from scarlet fever, 30 Nov. 1861, and pbd. by Macmillan, 1863.—Painter, or Engraver rather;William Blake (1757–1827), engraver, painter, and poet. a remarkable man, not unworthy such a service. Mr Gilchrist wd prefer you as a Publisher, if it suited; if &c &c;—and to you therefore I first of all despatch him for survey & scrutiny.

I have not myself seen the Book, or any part of it; but from conversation I gather that Mr G’s idea of the man is what I should call accurate and good; the Book moreover is about the right size for such a subject;—and lastly I can predict with Confidence that it is faithfully done, and will be found an honest piece of delineation and examination. My own private guess wd be that such a
Volume might sell, to a fair extent;—at all events I am justified in requesting you to examine a little, till you are satisfied about itEnd of MS.
[Which is all at present from
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: E. Chapman Esq. 193 Piccadilly

by A. Gilchrist Esq.]Material in square brackets is taken from the copy, presumably made by Gilchrist before he delivered the original to Chapman. Gilchrist wrote in his journal, 28 Dec.: “Carlyle again asked me about the Blake; what was I doing with it. I stated that I had delivered his letter to Chapman, but was giving my MS a last revisal before sending it in” (Gilchrist 74).

div3.sourceNote: TC-KRHM, 28 Nov.. Addr: 35 Bernard Street / Russell Square. PM: London, 28 Nov. 1859. MS: Houghton 42M=488. Hitherto unpbd. Kenneth Robert Henderson Mackenzie (1833–86), ed. and trans., brought up in Vienna; an accomplished linguist and antiquarian, he was elected a Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries in Jan. 1854, nine months before his 21st birthday. He trans. Karl Richard Lepsius, Briefe aus Aegypten, Aethiopen … 1842–1845 (Berlin, 1852) as Discoveries in Egypt, Ethiopia, and the Peninsula of Sinai, in the years 1842–1845, during the Mission sent out by His Majesty Frederick William IV. of Prussia (1852). He pbd., at his own expense, four issues of The Biological Review: A Monthly Repertory of the Science of Life (Oct. 1858–Jan. 1859), which was particularly concerned with mesmerism’s medical applications, homoeopathy, a novelty called “electro-dentistry,” and what Mackenzie described as “the finer Physics generally.” He later became a Freemason and was associated with occultism and Rosicrucianism. For his life and influence on the Freemason movement, see Ellic Howe SJ, “Fringe Masonry in England, 1870–75,” Ars Quatuor Coronatorum 2076 (14 Sept. 1972): 242–95. TC mistakenly addresses the envelope to W. Kth Mackenzie Esq.
div3.head: TC TO K. R. H. MACKENZIE

docBody.p:
I have received Tyll Eulenspiegel,The Marvellous Adventures and Rare Conceits of Master Tyll Owlglass, coll. and trans. K. R. H. Mackenzie (1859 [1860]). a beautiful volume, which seems to be learnedly and ingeniously worked out, in all respects;—and for the present I can only say that I am very much obliged by this proof of your polite regard;Mackenzie paid tribute to TC as “one of the most thoughtful and philosophic writers of our day”; he quoted (xvi—xvii) from TC’s enthusiastic critique of the Tyll stories in “Early German Literature,” where TC described the tales as “abound[ing] in inventive humour, in rough merriment and broad drollery” and “in many points instructive” (Works 27:305–6). TC had included Tyll’s prank on a parson, which Mackenzie omitted from his collection because “there is a smack of profanity about it” and therefore “not quite consonant with the ideas of the nineteenth [century]” (xviii).
and that I wish the Book all manner of success, and your faithful labour remunerated according to its worth.
In these times Mr Forster is well justified to describe me as kept in perpetual hurry; but I hope there is a season of more leisure coming, for behoof of self and friends.

closer.salute: I remain, with many good wishes,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 28 Nov. MS: NLS 516.99. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: It is ‘almost a shame to say so,’Cf. coterie speech, “I’s ashamed to say, I’s no better”; see 21:151JWC to JCA, 2 Feb. 1847, and 34:36TC to JWC, 12 July 1858. but this is really the first moment I have had in which to write a line, & thank you for the excellent Foot-apparatusSee TC to JCA, 13 Nov. you have sent me, so punctually according to request. I did get JamesJean’s son James Aitken, who lived in London. to send you word immediately that all was come safe to hand; and that was the essential part.

I have had-on the greys, which you consider the weaker pair, three or four times, while the frost lasted; they kept me about completely warm, altogether so when I chose to ride fast: so that, with the stouter brown pair, I consider myself safe against any kind of weather. Many thanks;—and may so useful a hand not lose its cunning,Cf. Ps. 137:5. in the knitting or any other department! I will not employ you further upon socks at present, my actual stock being so abundant,—alas, alas, you know whence that came to me!TC’s mother had often sent him socks; see 26:227TC to MAC, 12 Nov. 1851.— But if ever I do fall into want again, I shall know where to apply, and will not fail, on the first symptom.

Our weather has grown muddy again, raw and damp, occasionally heavy with rains: the mud and comparative absence of cold set the rider into mackintosh overalls for the present, whh return home all in a splash, but are cleaned at oneThus in MS. by being swashed thro’ a pail of water.

Poor Jane fell bankrapt to the frost, after the third or fourth day; and is still a close prisoner, very ill off for sleep, for strength in any kind; but does now begin to talk of venturing out again when we have a good day.John Ruskin had written to JWC, 23 Nov.: “I have had to go down into the north [to Winnington] since I came from abroad, and have been sharply unwell since and am still confined to the house, but unless I hear from you to the contrary I shall come the first evening in next week that I am well enough.— I have been nearly crushed by the badness of German painting, & all that it signifies of worse evil. … I think I shall have to give up painting—writing—talking—everything but reading—and I read little now but Mr Carlyle.— Fiction sickens me, because it is fiction— I am weary of it—. Truth depresses me—because it is true. Not that one can find much very plainly written. And it depresses me also never to have had a line from you—though I heard you were both on the whole well, in Scotland.” Ruskin had been traveling on the Continent from May to Oct.— I, for my
own part, am not below average order, rather above; busy at all hours with my sad operation, and hoping to work thro’ it by dour degrees in something like the next twelvemonth if I be enabled to hold out. Courage, for this last tussel!

James & his UncleJohn A. Carlyle. came last night for a little while; brisk and hearty both of them: James left me a new-fashioned tobacco-pouch, poor fellow, whh will be useful in any pocket in good proportion to the small room it occupies there. Jane charges me to say that the Tongue now come to hand, and getting itself deliberately consumed by degrees, is of excellent quality;—whh is satisfactory after all mistakes. Adieu, dear Sister,—with ma[ny]MS torn. regards to James & all of you. Your affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JM [JMA], 28 Nov. MS: British Lib. 3032.29. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES MARSHALL

docBody.p:
I have got, all in perfect safety, the Missive you sent me by Post;Marshall wrote, 21 Nov.: “I sent the Grand-Duke a copy of your letter [TC to JMJMA, 14 Nov.], without adding a single word by way of commentary. I felt that it needed none, and H. R. H. seems to have been as much struck with the manly and dignified tone of it, as I was,—for, without consulting anybody on the matter, he at once decided on sending you the ‘Comthur’;—so that you are now (in spite of your teeth, as it were,) a Knight-Commander of the Order of the White Falcon, otherwise called ‘the Order of Vigilance’;—a mere toy in itself, if you will,—but, as the symbol of the recognition of your worth in Germany, I trust it will give you some satisfaction. I do not congratulate you on the honor done or meant to be done to you,—because I think ‘the White Falcon’ as much to be congratulated as you, on the occasion;—but I sincerely wish that honors and blessings in every shape may crown your past, and attend your future, labors.” “Comthur” is an anglicized form of the old German “Komturkreuz.” For the certificate (MS: NLS Ch. 882), see 14above. and next day, equally in safety the White Falcon symbol itself,See 23JWC to MR, 9 Dec.—which is a very pretty thing; much admired by the female judgement here (female judgt almost threatening to wear it on occasn, and astonish the world!)—I will now request
you to deliver the inclosed little Note;To Karl Alexander, grand duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach; untraced. and so complete a business,—whh surely has not been disagreeable to me, hurried as I am! Nobody knows here (except my Brother & Neuberg), nor shall know; but we ourselves shall always be, privately, very well aware of it!—

figure.p: Certificate for the Order of the White Falcon

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: I am driven as I never was by that unutterable horror of a Prussian Book; which has quite broken my heart, and indeed has often seemed as if it would kill me outright before I had done with it. We are to begin printing (taliter qualiter [for what it’s worth] for all is still chaos!) in about a month; and if I can hold out, unchoked by the tumble of this Brandenburg shot-rubbish and immeasurable Sand-Walz [wallowing in sand] over sky and earth, for about one year at the top of my speed, then, O Heavens, then—! —! In quiet truth, there never came athwart me any job comparable to this, since life began (whh has had a good many ugly ones); and I doubt if any writing creature, not himself of quite chaotic nature, in this age or the last, ever got such a dainty dish (with so many pecks of dirt in it) to regale himself upon before.

I ride daily at a vigorous rate; speak to no creature; am as a ghost among my fellows,—only that I sometimes smoke a little on horseback, in the raw smoky dusk and fragrant fogs of these parts: ghosts, I believe, do not take tobacco at all.

HorseTC’s horse, Fritz. is at the door even now; and I must go. We were in Scotland, a four whole months almost, last Summer & Autumn;TC and JWC had spent from late June to late Sept. in Fife, first at Humbie Farm, nr. Aberdour, and then at Auchtertool House, Auchtertool; see vol. 35. my Wife extremely in need of some strengthening did improve on the beautiful shores of Fife,—tho’ the London frosts are again sore upon her.
Adieu; all good be with you, dear Marshall.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LAI] , [28 Nov. or 5 Dec.]. MS: NLS 20767.33. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the birth of Lady Airlie’s da., 16 Nov., at Cortachy Castle.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / Monday [28 November or 5 December 1859]
docBody.p:
Heaven bless you my Lady! and bless It! Maude Josepha Ogilvy.—the new “little Bundle of flannel,”—little “armful of joy,”—Baby that I divined by my own sharpness, while yet in a most incipient state! What do you think? this is the third Baby
deduced by me,—who have no personal experience in Babies,—and rightly deduced, from a—Yawn! Gracious! I hope no young Lady, that is to say no unmarried Lady will ever have the idea to yawn in my presence, for I should hardly now be able to pass over such fact without inferences!

Anyhow I am glad they (the Ashburtons) have given up their projected visit
to the Francis Barings and the “pauvres Enfants,”The two sons of Lord Ashburton’s brother Francis Baring, who was currently his heir; see 35:208 TC to JWC, 19 Sept.
till the important Child is fairly confectioned and “in arms.” That “Heir” looks to me up to most things that Heirs do in French novels; and it would have been so easy to give the young Lady a fall or a fright when one had her under one’s own roof!

figure.p: Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire
Jones’ Views of the Seats of … Noblemen and Gentlemen in England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland [1829]

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
When are you coming to London, I wonder? I am confined to the house as usual with a bad cold, and the dear little woman who nursed me angelically in my last illness is away in Florence.Probably Emilie Hawkes, a favored visitor during JWC’s illness, summer 1858; see 34:22 JWC to TC, 9 July 1858
; she was in Italy Sept. 1859–May 1860. She wrote to JWC from Florence, 9 March 1860: “I was overjoyed yesterday to get a letter from my sister Mrs Ashurst, telling me that she had seen you, and that all the mischief was in the accursed post … . [A]ll the letters I have directed either to Chelsea or Fulham have been lost. … I had grown afraid to write—your silence had in it something to me quite mysterious and sinister. I feared you were ill, wretched, or at least forgetful of poor me— For all this folly my excuse is that I have written three times since yours which I received & answered immediately from Vallombrosa, having no answers and being continually ill—exceptionally so even and very worried and low spirited, I got into an obstinate fit of determining to see none but the gloomiest possible explanation. … [S]o I wrote Bessie a request that she would find out the truth for me. She never noticed my request in her next letter … I chose for a short time to consider you had either received her coldly or not at all—then softening again to the memory of all your kindness and sympathy I repeated it—and found that the first letter to her had miscarried, and that you were all I wished, and ought to have trusted and known you to be for me still. Dear you must forgive me, now I have confessed all my wickedness, for you know only too much how physical gloom brings with it mental distress & discomfort. I made an entire mistake in coming to Florence, and then had not funds enough to go away: the climate is abominable, I see no difference between this and one of the worst London winters, except in as much as that in London we have carpets, fires, curtains, etc., in abundance, and here everything is cheap except comfort, which is quite beyond the reach of any but the really rich— So I have been in constant trouble and sickness—first and foremost the old trouble, and then and now with neuralgia— I have however a clever Dr now, who has driven me by force away from the city, and though I cannot yet—owing to the bitter winds—live in the open air as he wished—I feel—even from my constant seat by the troublesome unsatisfactory wood fire some of the benefit of the purer air, and am better again at last. My worst trouble by far though, because a small, constant, everyday worry, has been my young frivolous companion in perpetual need of an excitement and variety I could not give her, and fretting herself into semi-illness and whole hippishness.” Bessie Ashurst was her sister-in-law, wife of William Henry Ashurst (1819–79), solicitor. I am asked to go to the Grange “to be made strong”!! One must go some time—if we all live;—so, “as well soon as syne.”Proverbial; cf. 22:159 JWC to JF, 16 Nov. 1847
. But I shudder at the idea of a first visit there, under such changed circumstances. The very fact, that the new Lady seems to wish to be as kind to me as the other was, constantly reminds me of the other, and that this is not she! Lord Ashburton’s first wife, Lady Harriet Ashburton. My dear Lady!—You!—Don’t go and die! and get replaced! I should
hate your successor and be horribly ungrateful for any attentions she might show me!
