My poor little dogNero.—my substitute for a little bundle of flannel,—being in a musing and trustful state of mind on his return from Fife, got run over by a Butchers Cart— Ach! Yes! the wheel passed over his poor little neck! and he was brought home to me in the arms of the sobbing Charlotte,Charlotte Southam, the Carlyles’ maid. all huddled up like a crushed spider, and the eyes all but started out of his head! For a week he was despaired of; but my loving cares prevailed to restore him to what an old Lady of my acquaintance would call his “frail usual”Coterie speech, usually “frail ordinar”; JWC’s cousin Jackie Welsh is usually listed as the source; see JWC to MCA, [late Feb. 1860], and A. Carlyle NLM 2:344. Possibly one of the Miss Donaldsons also used it in this form. (she is always writing to me—I am THANKFUL to say I am in my frail usual!). Since then however his incipient Asthma has developed itself at a fearful rate— The dog doctorPossibly George Gillingham, 64 Church St., Chelsea. has now ordered him to keep the house all winter if he wouldn’t die—so the choice is to die of Asthma or Indigestion. Meanwhile I have made him a little warm coat, which gives him the looking of an inchanted human being! and I devote myself to soothing his sufferings! Poor little dog after all!Coterie speech; see 13:55 JWC to JOST, 9 March 1841
.
I end as I began with God bless you my Lady—
To see your handwriting warms my blood always—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p:
no feathered thingsPheasants or grouse from Cortachy Castle, Lady Airlie’s home in Angus. Lady Airlie had sent a box of grouse in 1852; see 27:242 JWC to LAI, 22 Aug. 1852
. The grouse season was 12 Aug.–10 Dec. and the pheasant season, 1 Oct.–1 Feb. please! to us they are not worth the carriage which is heavy from [so] long a distance.Cortachy Castle (see 16 above ) was in NE Scotland, about 15 mi. inland and N of Dundee.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EF, 30 Nov. MS: Trinity. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:370.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD FITZGERALD

docBody.p:
I have not for many a day had a welcomer bit of writing handed in to me than your friendly honest Note the other morning. My Letters here,—“impacts from the owls of the Parish on the poor old Horn-lantern with a
candle-end lighted in it,”TC appears to mean dull people drawn to anything with a spark of light in it; cf. 35:17TC to LOA, 30 Jan.—are not oftenest of an exhilarating character!--I am shocked to discover tonight that I have not yet answered: I imagined I had, the same day; and so omitted you on “Letter-Answering Day“: but my Wife by her question brings me accurately to book; so before going to bed, I do it,—and close the day in a pleasant way.

We staid a long time in Scotland, chiefly in Fife, almost 3 months there, sea-bathing &c, then 3 or 4 weeks in Annandale; did not get home till deep in October:TC arrived home 1 Oct. 1859; see 35:223TC to JAC, 3 Oct. JWC returned home 23 Sept.; see 35:215JWC to TC, 24 Sept. it is long since I had such a spell of idleness and rustication; and both Wife and I had had need of enough of “trying something” for a little improvement if possible. My belief is, we both got considerable good of the adventure: she was evidently a good deal stronger on setting out homeward, and has never yet quite given in, tho’ not now on the improving hand at all, as winter with his fogs and frosts advances. I on the other hand traced my chief improvement after getting home, and resuming my unutterable “literary enterprise” after a long cessation. In fine here we are, in the old equipment, fronting the winter rather on better omens than last year, nor on worse.

I ride diligently and with vigour every day (Horse immensely improved by Scotch rye-grass and other solacements of country life): I sit all day to the chin in Brandenburg rubbish; groom comes at half past 3, “Oss, Sir!“—and I go scouring about till deep in the dusk, a most spectral object on four legs. Very spectral, alas, both inwardly and [out]wardly! I live in nearly perfect loneliness here. [S]peakLetters obscured. to no person (Wife does all the society there is); and stand with my whole remaining strength to the task of getting this intolerable millstone cut away from my poor neck! That is pretty much all the hope I have left now in the world. In perhaps another Twelvemonth, if I can hold out so long, there may be deliverance,The next vol. (3) of Frederick was pbd. in 1862, and the final vol. (6) in 1865. or clearer hope of such;—God send it! I really never in my Life was so held to the grindstone by anything laid on me; were I once out of this, on any tolerable terms whatever, it is my fixed purpose to rest for the remainder of my life,—and after that, we may look with some confidence to rest of a good eternal sort; welcome to the wearied who can go no farther!—

Thackeray fell lately in a dark fog and lamed a leg, I am told, whh still keeps him prisoner: no doubt he is busy exceedingly with his Magazine,The Cornhill Magazine, of which Thackeray was the editor; the first vol. was to be pbd. Jan. 1860; see 35:237TC to WMT, 20 Oct. with his &c &c. I cannot get to see him yet. Spedding is gone to Cumberld:James Spedding (18011808–81; ODNB; see 8:196JWC to JCA, Aug. 1835, and 19:205TC to TSS, 20 Sept. 1845), literary editor and biographer; old friend of FitzGerald’s; lived at 60 Lincoln’s Inn Fields; presumably going north to visit his brother, Thomas Story Spedding (1800–1870; see 35:26435:biographical note), and family in Cumberland. FitzGerald had seen James in London in Oct.: “as immutably calm, wise, and kind, as ever” (Terhune, LEF 2:338).—You when
you are tired of Lowestoff,FitzGerald had been staying at Lowestoft, fishing village in Suffolk, on and off since the death of William K. Browne (1818–59; see 19:82TC to AC, 17 June 1845) in Goldington, Bedford, 30 March; FitzGerald had loved him for many years. He wrote to TC, 20 June: “my poor W. Browne (who got you a Horse some fifteen years ago) had been fallen on and crushed all through the middle Body by one of his own” (Terhune, LEF 2:335). Browne’s wife, Elizabeth, m. 1844, was five months pregnant when he died. Browne had found TC a horse in 1845; see 19:82TC to AC, 17 June 1845, and 19:86–87TC to EF, 27 June 1845. come to us, and smoke a pipe again in peace! Good be with you, dear F.— Yours ever truly T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD [WDO], [30 Nov.]. MS: NLS 1797.203. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by TC’s note on last page of letter: “Chelsea, 30 Novr, 1859–.“
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p:
Dear William Dods, how are you? How is your nice Wife?Jane Dods. When were you at “Babbie’s Butts”?Haddington footpath; see 24:163JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 18496. Do you read Haddingtonshire Courier?The Haddingtonshire Courier began 28 Oct. Samuel Smiles wrote to JWC 13 Dec.: “I have got several of the copies of the Haddingtonshire Courier, and was as much surprised at it as you could be. Yet the thing is a success, commercially speaking. Wonders will never cease”; for Smiles, see TC to JCA, 10 [11] Dec.— Can you believe it? it is apropos of that spirited publication that I am writing to you this night!— Not to reproach you for having left me in ignorance of such literary outbreak in the poor dear old Place! still less to congratulate you thereon! For, between you and me, the two numbers of the said Courier which I have seen, by favour of Hamilton Vetch,Col. Hamilton Veitch (1804–65), school friend and admirer of JWC; see 32:210JWC to TC, 30 July 1857. made my hair stand slightly on end, and penetrated me with a mild horror and despair! My own dear Haddingtonshire! which I had loved for its sincere stupidity, and contented dullness,—for its dignity of silence when it had nothing to say,—for its practical industry when it had nothing to think! It too burst out into gabble-gabbling, as of infinite geese!— Puffing, Lecturing, Speechifying rising up in every corner of it! even GarvaldVillage 6 mi. E of Haddington; among the advertisements on the front page of the Haddingtonshire Courier, 11 Nov., was one for John Anderson’s general store in Garvald. calling the attention of the Universe to its “large assortment of goods”! “The Schoolmaster”Untraced. not only “abroad” and be hanged to him, but
dancing a hornpipe on the crown of his head over all East Lothian!!— The horrid young men that will grow up under this reign of the Schoolmaster dancing on his head!— Upon my word, I felt after looking over these newspapers very like to cry. All that ambitious mediocrity, shouting out to be heard and looked at, seemed to separate me from the home of my youth more than the four hundred miles that lie between it and me!
But it wasn’t to say all this either,—not a single sentence of it,—that I began to write!

To come to the point then, In one of those Haddingtonshire Couriers I read a notice of the death of John RennieJohn Rennie (ca. 1770–1859), farmer of Oxwell Mains. rather long and complimentary. When George Rennie (his nephew)JWC’s old friend and admirer; John Rennie was the brother of Marion (b. 1761), George’s mother. was here the other day, I told him of it, and found him, to my astonishment, in profound ignorance of his uncle’s death! He remembered that he had once had such an uncle; but didn’t seem to have heard of him, or turned him in his head for the last thirty years!! Whereupon I could no longer suppress many things I had had in my mind to say to George this long while—about his estrangement from his relations and early friends—all except myself—and not thanks to him for that exception, I told him; “for he held to me, only as Sinbad the Sailor held to the old-man-of-the-mountain whom he couldn’t for the life of him get shaken of!“— Now, if he made new friends, I shouldn’t have thought him worth railing at so much; but the poor fellow has only acquaintances! And besides I know he has a good heart—but “Lucifer Son of the morning!”Isa. 14:12. got into it in the beginning, and barred all ingress to it, and put a dreary ‘to Let’ in its windows! So he is more to be pitied than blamed.— Stop!— I am quite away from the business in hand again!
I have had next to no sleep for many nights, and in that case I get always dreadfully discursive and metaphorical!— Pardon!

The result of our dispute, was, that he owned to being “proud and shy, and not hardhearted” and owned even to a sudden affectionate interest (better later than never!) in the old Uncle John, and a real desire to read what had been said about him in the Haddington paper.The obituary noted that John Rennie “belong[ed] to a family long well known and highly respected in East Lothian. … Rennie during a lengthened life maintained the reputation of an excellent man and an intelligent agriculturalist. … [He] delighted, as a young man, in athletic exercises, and many anecdotes are told of his strength and courage” (Haddingtonshire Courier, 18 Nov.).

You see now what I want? Colonel Vetch took back those papers to send them to some one else. And unless you can get a copy of that far back number
for me, I shan’t be able to gratify poor George’s little impulse of family feeling. which I am naturally interested in; feeling as if I had if not planted it, at least developed it myself!

Are you cross? Is it a trouble?— I don’t know why I am so unscrupulous in troubling you; remembrance I suppose of your goodnature to me about the—ProblemsPresumably referring to Dods helping JWC with her algebra at school; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 43–44.—and—the white cotton stockings.He had once lent JWC his white cotton stockings; see 33:88JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857.

I ask nothing about the Old ChurchVisiting Haddington at the end of June 1859, JWC had been horrified at the state of the parish church where her father was buried; see 35:189–90JWC to WDO, 3 Sept. The Haddingtonshire Courier reported, 28 Oct., the “Dangerous State of the Parish Church. … [T]he south wall was bulging out nearly eight or nine inches beyond the perpendicular. The pillars at the same time were falling out in an opposite direction. In fact, the building was just breaking its back on the rafters which supported the galleries.”— I know you cannot put my heart at ease about that yet—or you would have done it, without waiting to be questioned. My love to your Wife. I have been very ill again, and my dog has been run over by a Butcher’s cart. Ever affectionately Yours Jane Welsh Carlyle

The paper spoke of great family affliction that had befallen John RennieThe obituary noted that John Rennie’s life was “somewhat chequered, and darkened with not a few painful domestic bereavements” (Haddingtonshire Courier, 18 Nov.). Can you tell me any thing of his life? He once carried me from a dancing school Ball on the palm of his hand! He was big and I was small

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [9 Dec.]. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:220–22 inc; Bliss, JWC 281 inc. Quot: Ashton 413. Text: A. Carlyle, where dated “Autumn, 1859.” Dated after newspaper report, 6 Dec.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Dearest Mary— … Did you see in your newspaper that Mr. Carlyle was made a “Knight of the White Falcon”?The Dumfries and Galloway Courier reported, 6 Dec.: “The reigning Duke of Saxe-Weimar has conferred the ‘Order of the Falcon’ … on Herr Tom Carlyle, of Craigen-puttoch, ‘historian of Frederick the Great.’ All hail to the new knight of Weimar, and long may he live to confer lustre on the court of Goethe and Schiller.” Consequently I am a Lady of the White Falcon! Charlotte told our charwoman,Unidentified. with great glee, that the Master might call himself “Sir Thomas, if he liked.” “My!” said the charwoman, “then the Mistress is Lady, now!” “Yes,” said Charlotte, “but she says she won’t go in for it! Such a shame!“—The Order, however, which Mr. C. immediately made
over to me, is beautiful! A solid enamelled White Falcon, on a green star, attached to a broad red ribbon.See above. The Order is in private ownership, on loan to Carlyle House, Chelsea. If I live ever to visit you again, I shall wear it, when you have Mrs. Kennedy and Robert M’Turk!Probably Isabella Kennedy (ca. 1801–90) of Burnside farm, neighbor of Mary Russell, unless a misreading for Dunwoodie, Robert McTurk’s sister Isabella’s married name; Robert McTurk lived at Hastings Hall, Moniaive, Dumfriesshire, about 7 mi. SW of Holmhill.

figure.p: Order of the White Falcon

p.hi: Courtesy of the private owner and The National Trust

docBody.p: My poor little Dog is become a source of great sorrow; his tendency to asthma having been dreadfully developed since the Butcher’s cart went over his throat. I have made him a little red cloak, and he keeps the house with me.The photograph of Nero on 25 was probably taken by Robert Tait ca. 1855. For another of Tait’s photographs of Nero, see 61JWC to RST, [ca. 6 Feb. 1860].

figure.p: Nero asleep, by Robert Tait, ca. 1855

p.hi: Courtesy of Edinburgh University Library

docBody.p: Love to the Doctor; remember me kindly to all my Thornhill friends. …
docBody.note: Ruskin wrote to JWC, ca. 9 Dec.: “Poor little Nero. But he will love you just as much, even when he is blind—& move his little paws just as prettily.” Alexander Gilchrist wrote in his journal, 28 Dec., after visiting the Carlyles: “Talk fell on the dog Nero, now very ailing. Mrs. Carlyle has had it ten and a half years; six months old when Nero was brought to her. Carlyle said, ‘Never dog had given trouble more disproportionate to its use and worth than Nero had to him.’ (Mrs. Carlyle) ‘It had been worth it all.’ He denied it, and reiterated the absurdity of its existence. It would be a kindness to kill it. / (Mrs. Carlyle) ‘If he is to be believed, he shouldn’t make affectionate speeches to Nero in the garden when he thought no one heard’” (Gilchrist 75).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 10 [11] Dec. MS: NLS 516.100. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated as he was writing on Sun., 11 Dec.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: This is one of the blackest Fogs ever seen,The Times reported, 13 Dec.: “The metropolis on Sunday afternoon was enveloped in the most dense fog we have been visited with since October 1851; from half-past 12 at noon until 2 o’clock the darkness was so intense that it was dangerous to attempt crossing the carriage-road.” which we have today; scarcely with light to read; and as silent up here as if I were in Craigenputtoch in my old backshop among the everlasting moors again. At any rate I have no right to try much labour today; and am now for sallying out (streets to be all mapped in one’s head, and attention kept) for a little vigorous walking;—but will first send you a couple of words, as one small act of propriety in one’s day of rest.2. Sunday.

I quite forgot to mention the Hareskin Breastplate last time! But I have by no means forgotten to put it about me nightly before going to bed (by day it was superfluous, and took some trouble); and an excellent thing I find it, all tight, cosy, and fur next the skin: fairly the best medicine I have yet found for that new ailment of mine.Bronchitis; see 35:240TC to JAC, 23 Oct. I am much obliged to you for all your assiduous continual kindness; and ought to say, nothing has been more successful than this particular item.

We are a little better here; i.e. Jane is and stealthily gets out again on a mild day; as to myself I have never been making complaint, but am always able to go plodding on at the sad prescribed step: one of the gloomiest quiet lives, if I did not hope it wd mend in the course of certain months. My progress is sorrowfully slow, but it seldom or never entirely stops. Please Heaven we shall get this intolerable slave-chain filed thro’ at last; and then there will be improved times, let us hope!—

Jack is again in negociation abt Langshaw; BarkerE. J. Barker was handling the sale of Langshaw House (Dumfries and Galloway Courier, 25 Oct.); see TC to JCA, 13 Nov. repentant— But say not a word of it, now I bethink me! Indeed it is very uncertain whether the matter be not out again, and reduced to flat nothing within the next day or two. To
have a House of his own, any House rather than none, wd certainly be advantageous to him: that is the one charm of Langshaw. And I hold my peace upon it (so far as possible), leaving things to their own course. He comes tonight to me,-and perhaps your James, if luckily he bethink himself. The said James, you may take it for certified, is doing well; a modest rational young soul, much commendable as things go. Adieu, dear Jean: God bless you all. T. CarlyleSamuel Smiles (1812–1904; ODNB), b. Haddington, biographer and author of Self-Help (1859), wrote to JWC from Blackheath 10 Dec. He had met Mrs. Keith Falconer, “an East Lothian woman, & Dr Welsh attended her family—Grants of Congleton. … Mrs Falconer is an exceedingly sensible person, with ‘no nonsense’ about her.” He apparently knew JWC, as he ended the letter: “I trust you are now fairly convalescent, & I hope to have the pleasure of seeing you some day soon.” JWC replied (letter untraced), as Smiles then wrote, 13 Dec.: “My Dear Mrs Carlyle / I am glad to find that my note has brought up in your mind so many associations of delightful girlhood. Curiously enough, Mrs Falconer spoke of those early days in very much the same tone; expressing an anxious desire to see you. I must tell you that she married Capt Keith—afterwards Keith-Falconer,—one of the sons of the Earl of Kintore. Capt Keith built the new house at Monkrigg,—but long after you left Haddington; and after his death several years ago, she sold the place. She has been living at the Earl of Kintore’s seat in Aberdeenshire since then, for the most part, in charge of the young earl as guardian; and her home is now at 3 Eaton Square. As she signs herself ‘L,’ I have no doubt she is the ‘Louisa’ of your memory, though her brown hair is grey now. But she is as youthful & cheerful in mind as ever. I found she had, as her ladys maid, a niece of Mrs. Brook, who stole into the room (while I was alone in it) to see a Haddington face! She gave me a most glowing account of her mistress’s character. It was the first time I had been in the house; and positively the first time in which I was ever regarded in the light of a small lion. But a Haddington animal of this sort, even of the very smallest, is such a rarity, that I feel it is possible to be a curiosity, & at the same time a very ordinary creature after all.” Smiles’s Self-Help: With Illustrations of Character and Conduct was published late Nov.; 20,000 copies were sold in its first year. Louisa Keith-Falconer, b. Grant (d. 1862), m., 1830, Capt. William Keith-Falconer (1799–1846). Monkrigg, on the outskirts of Haddington, was “an elegant modern mansion, finely situated, and encompassed by some highly-enriched scenery” (Topographical Dictionary of Scotland [1846] 1:528).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, [15 Dec.] MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Date on MS by unknown hand confirmed by TC’s illness and the freezing weather.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: I have caught cold; I have got toothache, and an ugly fixed pain in the brow (both of whh latter phenomena are new to me); in fact I am quite on my beam-ends, and no prospect of righting, but the contrary, before Saturday! We must give it up, my friend, or do worse,—till these bad elements (not to speak of the glassy frost unfriendly to human nature and to equine) pass away, as they will do.
I am sorry to disappoint myself,—far sorrier than you will believe;—but there is no alternative. Esperons [let us hope].
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CR [CRO], [15 Dec.?]. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee and date taken from annotation on reverse of the letter in an unknown hand; the letter is badly faded and partly indecipherable. The letter has probably been misdated. Latter-Day Pamphlets was repbd. as vol. 13 of the cheap edn. of TC’s Works April 1858 (see Chapman & Hall’s Advertisements and JWC to AHO, 24 Oct. 1857). TC could well have written about it to the printer Charles Robson Dec. 1857, as it was going to press Nov. 1857 (see TC to JN, 5 Nov. 1857); his 1857 would then be read in error as 1859.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES ROBSON

docBody.p:
Yesterday, in my haste, I neglected [illegible] and such like (of Latter Dy Pts), [illegible] set of those Two sheets. I recollect [illegible] that I felt dimly disappointed, [illegible] at that ([illegible] with [illegible]), that I expected [illegible] at the present time and then the date (in brackets) and at Haddington
itself.-- The [illegible] of all [illegible], That you [illegible] nothing to Prevent [illegible] it agt [illegible]
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 19 Dec. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 21 Dec. 1859. MS: NLS 553.206. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—The Schulz-DeckerWilhelm Schulz was an employee of Decker’s, the Berlin publishing firm managed by Rudolf Ludwig Decker (1804–77); see 27:375TC to RLDAKD, 27 Dec. 1852. communication went into pipe-spills that same night; and there is no part of it recoverable. It is certain I did not trace in it the slightest intention of a Gift to me, tho’ I read every word:—nevertheless it now strikes me there may be something in yr surmise; the Decker people, from my refusal of the Fredc long ago,Decker had offered TC a free copy of their publication of J. D. E. Preuss, Oeuvres de Frédéric, 31 vols. (Berlin, 1846–57); see 32:136TC to JN, 29 April 1857. may have got a notion that I won’t accept Books freely &c &c;—whh was by no means the fact in this case, had they known it!—
In any case you must keep the Book,Unidentified. and make due thanks for it and explanations.

Almost beyond doubt that thing you have found in vol VOf Helden-, Staats-, und Lebens-Geschichte. is the real MentzelFriedrich Wilhelm Menzel (ca. 1724–96), a govt. clerk in Dresden; see Works 16:402–4 and 17:3–9. Business, and Preuss’s reference must be wrong.In Aug. TC had wrongly given the source as vol. 7 of Helden-, Staats-, und Lebens-Geschichte (see 35:166JWC to MR, 12 Aug.), apparently from a reference in one of Preuss’s books, possibly Friedrich der Grosse, eine Lebensgeschichte, 5 vols. (Berlin, 1832–34), the Preuss book most often cited in the vols. of Frederick on which TC was working at this time. At all events, pick that up (abstract, abridge); that, with what you already sent, will suffice for one poor knave.
I have not yet altogether surrendered riding,—tho’ today I have not been out.
There was something else, surely; but I have forgotten it?

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: C. Desrivières (apparently a French political refugee, a “veteran of the press” who had been in London for eight years; not further identified) wrote to JWC from Fulham, 17 Dec. Taking advantage of an amnesty and reluctantly returning to France, despite his dislike of the government, his letter was to say goodbye and ask for a small sum of money toward travel costs. He concluded: “I do not say adieu to your illustrious spouse, for his name is everywhere, despite the Daily Telegraph! One day his statue will be in the heart of London, and if I live and cannot revisit the places that I love, I will tell my children: go and kneel down before the statue of Thomas Carlyle and pray for his noble Lady!” (trans.).

div3.sourceNote: TC-HE [SHE], 24 Dec. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Sir Henry Ellis (1777–1869; ODNB), principal librarian of the British Museum, 1828–56.
div3.head: TC TO SIR HENRY ELLIS

docBody.p: I am glad to hear of you again;—unfortunately for me your Excerpts about FontenoyFor the battle of Fontenoy, see Works 16:93–104; Ellis’s contribution is untraced. are still likely to be in very good time! I shall be glad of them when they are ready.

The Cromwell-Luke Letter,Oliver Cromwell’s letter to Sir Samuel Luke (ca. 1603–70), M.P. and col. in the parliamentary army, 8 March 1643; TC acknowledged Sir Henry Ellis, Original Letters, Illustrative of English History (1846) 4:225–226, as the source; see Works 9:224. first in your series, is worth something;—comes in at p.146 vol.i (of the stereotype Letters and speeches);TC refers to the place the letter should have appeared in vol. 1 of Cromwell in the cheap edn. of his Works (1857) (Works 6:181). It was later pbd. as one of the appendices to Cromwell in the Library edn. (1869–71). and will deserve a little inquiry and elucidatn, if I ever again have time: “Where was Luke (Hudibras)Sir Samuel Luke was thought by Ellis to be the original of Sir Hudibras, the knighterrant in the satirical poem Hudibras, 3 vols. (1663–78), by Samuel Butler (1612–80); see Sir Henry Ellis, Original Letters, Illustrative of English History, (1846) 4:217–18. at that date (8 March 1643–4), and what was he doing?” &c &cTC did not subsequently provide any elucidation.

Of Raguenet or his BookFrançois Raguenet (1660?–1722), Histoire d’Olivier Cromwell (Paris, 1691). I never knew anything. You might examine, some day, whether that “English Pampht”Probably Cromwell, Lion of the Tribe of Judah, mentioned by Raguenet (292); not further identified. is in the Library, and what it says. That is evidently all the poor Frenchman knows of the “Asiatic Messiah” speculation;Raguenet seems to be the only source for the ” ‘Asiatic Messiah’ speculation” (290). There was a movement in England in the mid-1650s to re-admit Jews into the country that was supported by Cromwell, and a corresponding movement among European Jews to press for re-admission into England; see Works 8:241–42. Rumors were rife among Jews, including one that Cromwell was perhaps sent by God to facilitate the coming of the Messiah. See David S. Katz, The Jews in The History of England 1485–1850 (Oxford, 1994) 107–34. and that is probably mere quizzing, and banter from the Opposition side.——

Enclosed is a rag of Catalogue with one Book marked. Please give it to Mr WattsThomas Watts (1811–69; ODNB), the British Museum’s director of acquisitions of foreign-language books. (with my Compts) if the Book is not in the Library. I individually want nothing with it farther.
Pray accept this small Xmas gift inclosed.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-George A. Dodds [GD], 26 Dec. MS: sold at auction. George A. Dodds may be the same as the verse-writing George Dodds, to whom TC wrote in 1852; see TC to GD, 12 July 1852; otherwise unidentified.
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE A. DODDS

docBody.p: [Contents unknown]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WHB, 27 Dec. Pbd: Brookfield, Circle 2:491–92, where dated 27 Dec. 1860. Dated 1859 by Brookfield’s letter to JWC, 24 Dec., by the mention of the Brookfields’ visit to Elba three years previously, and by the reference to the “quadruped on the hearthrug” (Nero d. 1 Feb. 1860).
div3.head: JWC TO W. H. BROOKFIELD

docBody.p:
Bless me! Dear Mr. Brookfield! Wonders will never cease! Again a letterBrookfield wrote from The Grange (the Ashburtons’ country house in Hampshire) 24 Dec., remembering previous visits and wishing the Carlyles were there now. As well as the “small assembly” of Baring relatives, the Brookfields, their three children, and “Lord & Ly A & an embryo possibility” were there. “all out of your own head,”Coterie speech; see 33:87JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857. three years after the one from Elba!Brookfield wrote: “In so brisk a correspondence as ours it is difficult to recall when I last addressed you; but I think it was the Isle of Elba.” The Brookfields spent the winter of 1856–57 in the Mediterranean with Lord Ashburton and the first Lady Ashburton (see 32:18JWC to MR, 24 Oct. 1856); in Jan. 1857, they were “rolling and tossing off Elba” (Brookfield, Circle 2:450). I am struck—not dumb (as you see), but struck any other word you like—say foolish! And that will explain anything and everything that may follow; what will follow I have no more notion than you have, than that quadruped on the hearthrugNero. has! I know I have got a pen in hand to write you a letter; a civil letter deserves a civil answer all the world over. But what about? “God
knows,” which means that nobody else does! The fact is, you see, you are outside my natural correspondence. A man who fires off a letter at one from the island of Elba, without rhyme or reason, and three years after fires off another from the same principle from the Grange, can’t be called a natural correspondent, can he? Then for unnatural correspondence, Mrs. Ellis, my chosen guide,Sarah Stickney Ellis (1799–1872; ODNB), author of The Women of England, Their Social Duties and Domestic Habits (1839) and other books which advocated women’s subservience to men while maintaining a moral supremacy; much disliked by JWC; see 21:18JWC to HW, 19 Aug. 1846, and 24:259JWC to JRS, 19 Aug. 1846. as you know, has given no rules. Perhaps her simple rules for making conversation might be applied with advantage to unnatural correspondence, “Be careful always to announce a fact, or inculcate a moral sentiment.”The third rule of conversation: “the establishment of a fact, or the deduction of a moral” (Ellis, Women of England 145). But, oh, Mr. Brookfield! between man and man, if there be anything I detest more than an announced fact it is just an inculcated moral sentiment! So that line is no go! Suppose then I address you as “a man and a brother,” “open my heart” to you (the woman idea of making friendship). That were touching! and future biographers might make their own of it. But there is one insuperable objection the opening-one’s-heart style of writing, that whatever you and I may be, neither of us are born spoonies!

What would you think now of just enquiring after your health, expressing a hope that you are not only well, but “quite well” (one might emphasise the quite, like the Bishop of Oxford)?Samuel Wilberforce (1805–73; ODNB), bishop of Oxford 1845–69, friend of the Ashburtons, and known to the Carlyles since the 1840s; see 18:103TC to JWC, 4 July 1844, 28:339TC to JMA, 11 Dec. 1853, and 30:243JWC’s Journal, 16 April 1856. That I see from your letter that you are flourishing there—like the green bay treeSee Ps. 37:35.—need be no impediment to expressing the deepest interest in the actual state of your health. It is an understood thing that one doesn’t feel the interest one expresses about another’s health, so there’s no humbug in saying “How are you, dear Mr. Brookfield? Are you well? Quite well?” and just see how much paper all that covers! and think what variations might be played on it! and what a harmless topic it is. There, I’ve written a long enough letter without having decided what to write. Is that very stupid or very clever? I hope the Miss BaringsLouisa and Lydia Emily Baring, sisters of Lord Ashburton, were also at The Grange, along with their brother Frederick and his wife, Frederica. are to stay till we come; tell them. You can’t think how good they were to me when I went to them with the strength of half a sparrow.JWC had stayed with them for three weeks in Bay House, Hampshire, Aug. 1858; see 34:134JWC to DD, 17 Aug. 1858. I shall always think if Miss Baring had not taken me away then I should have died
the death of Jenkins’ henA hen that d. from weariness of living; see 1:385TC to TM, 2 Oct. 1821, and 9:323JWC to JOST, Sept. 1837. alone here at Cheyne Row, England. I love them, and Miss Baring should have a Royal Humane Society’s medalThe Royal Humane Society, founded in London, 1774, by two doctors, William Hawes (1736–1808) and Thomas Cogan (1736–1818), with the original aim of saving people from drowning and encouraging the use of resuscitation techniques. The original financial rewards were soon replaced by medals for bravery in saving human life. if she had her due.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, [29 Dec.?]. MS: NLS 607.572. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:24–25, where dated “Jan. 1860? or March?” Dated here conjecturally by reference to the coming dinner with Forster (see TC to JAC, 29 Dec.) and the forthcoming visit to The Grange.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: All right, dear Mr Forster!
Nothing but “Yes“es out of that man’s mouth, when your proposal was stated to him— Willing, pleased Yeses!— I am afraid something must be going to happen to him!—
‘Yes’; he would go on Sunday;The invitation was for Sat., 31 Dec. 1859.—“Yes”; he would be there a quarter before six; “Yes”; he would walk there, and let you send him home.
Exactly as you predicted, he did not come in till half-past six by the clock.

It is a pity for poor me; I daren’t do anything pleasant ever. Tho’ like the Pigs I get “used to it,”Coterie speech; see 20:153JWC to MAC, 28 March 1846. and am thankful if I can but keep on foot indoors.

I am bent on seeing Her and Katie,Most probably Forster’s wife, Eliza, and possibly Catherine Macready, with whose family Forster was close. TC later wrote above “Her and Katie” in blue pencil: “Mrs Macready & child.” William Macready’s first wife, Catherine, d. 1852. however, before we go to the Grange.In TC’s later hand in blue pencil: “Examine (for date).” The Carlyles went to The Grange on Thurs., 5 Jan. 1860.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: [In TC’s hand] Yes, Saturday;—for the Brougham to fetch me, No with thanksIn TC’s later hand in ink: “(written then!— T. C.).”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Dec. MS: NLS 525.60. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I sent you the ThackerayPresumably an advance copy of the first number of the Cornhill Magazine (Jan. 1860), which went to press 15 Dec. Richard Monckton Milnes wrote to Thackeray praising it, 27 Dec. (Ray 4:169). according to order: along with it I intended, that day and also this, to send a single line of writing with it;—but actually have not had one moment of time, so obdurately sluggish was the step I went at thro’ the working element! It will be as bad tomorrow;—therefore I write at the stroke of midnight now, just before going to bed. I am upon the Battle of Zorndorf,Village 6 mi. N of Cüstrin, in Brandenburg, Prussia, where Frederick defeated the Russians, 25 Aug. 1758; TC called the battle “the bloodiest … of the Seven-Years War” (Works 17:373–97).—woe’s me that ever the like fell to my poor lot! But I must get it done; there is no other remedy known.

We are to go to The Grange on Thursday nextThe next Thurs. was 5 Jan. 1860. (this day week); time of stay is not fixed, but will hardly exceed the number of days you have given yourself. Printing ought to commence directly on our return.They returned 13 Jan. 1860. There is to be nobody there, or nobody I in the least care for, except Richd Milnes.— You will see us in time, whether you come on Saturday or on Monday. This Note, I compute, will find you on Saty before starting, if you do start that day
Saturday evg I have to go to Forster, and dine after all.TC had canceled a planned visit to Forster, 17 Dec.; see TC to JF, [15 Dec.].— These are all my news.

We have got no meal yet; and are rather longing to see it for some reasons. Dr RussellProbably Dr. John Rutherfurd Russell (1816–66), who moved to 3 Harley St., London, in 1859; see 33:246–47TC to JRR, 21 June 1858. called here one day; inquired yr address, and I rather think left a card in Brompton RoadWhere John lodged when in London; see 34:163TC to JN, 28 Aug. 1858. before returning. The weather is tepid and muddy to a degree; Jane complains of it as almost worse than the frost for certain invalids
By the bye will you take those rides on my Horse while I am away? He will do you nothing but benefit and kindness, poor fellow. Till you refuse, I will speak to no other.
Adieu, dear Brother

ps.p: Friday morng [30 December 1859].— Jenny writes from Scotsbrig that the meal package was despatched on Tuesday, and may be expected here today.
I have slept too long; and have again a hurried, puffy, too probably ineffectual day ahead: mean to be thro’ Zorndorf any way if I can!—

Oration (rede [lecture]) abt Schiller, in some Sitzung [meeting] at Berlin or somewhere, by Jacob Grimm, is sent by Plattnauer;Richard Plattnauer (1813–92; see 34:280TC to CBU, 9 June 1858) had sent Jacob Grimm, Rede auf Schiller (Berlin, 1859).—looking into it over my coffee, I find the said Jacob suspect of being a very melancholy old owl!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD], [31 Dec.]. MS: NLS 1797.168. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea Last day of the year [31 December 1859]
docBody.p: I don’t often get out of all patience with the contradictions of one’s daily life; having convinced myself long ago, that it is more profit to follow Paddy’s rule; “keep never minding”!Coterie speech; see 22:161TC to JF, 18 Nov. 1847; see also A. Carlyle, NLM 2:110. But today I am—furious!!—there is no other word for it!

Last night I had just sat down to write some letters for newyears day: a good long one to you, and another good long one to Mrs DavidsonDavid Davidson’s aunt Janet Davidson. among others; when two GentlemenUnidentified. “dropt in” to tea and staid till twelve o’clock. Well! I should have time before the General post hour today,Letters could be posted at pillar boxes until 5 p.m., at the General Post Office, St. Martin’s le Grand, until 6 p.m., or until 7 p.m. upon payment (in stamps) of an extra 1d. I thought; and went to bed without wishing any serious mischief to these Gentlemen. But today!, Oh my Gracious!— I had hardly got my book-parcels &c made up, and one little hasty letter scribbled to Mrs Skirving;Margaret Lindsay Skirving (1789–1868), an old Haddington acquaintance; see 33:126JWC to AHO, 23 Nov. 1857. when I was broken in upon by such a rush of improvised botherations, continuing till long after post-time; that I find myself now, at night, as tired, and dissatisfied, and enraged as if I had been kept all day thrashing—chaff!

In case tomorrow should prove as unfavourable to expansions of the heart—on paper; I write this notekin before going to bed, just that you may know it is from no want of good will that no “nice long new year letter” accompanies the Book-parcel— Tho’—! to be sure!—there is perhaps no
great amount of good-will due from me, to people, who, when I see them after a year can never bestow on me more time than “twenty minutes.”

But I believe you good and kind in a general way— So I make a request to you: to go this minute to Mrs David Davidson’sJanet Davidson; her husband had also been named David. and see if she have received, the only gift I could think of for her; dear suffering soul! likely to be any good—an indian rubber bottle for holding warm water— It is the most pliant comfortable thing in a bed! and fits in to any part of the body where there is an ache that heat can relieve or mitigate. Show her how to unscrew the top, and if she have not a small funnel for filling it; will you buy her one—you will get a tin one for two or three pence. And explain to her that her new-years day letter is not forgotten nor omitted—only delayed by stress of circumstances—

God bless you and all your belongings—my love to your eldest Sister.Marion Wilkie (1803–78) lived with their other sister, Mary Ann Wilkie (1806–82), at Tyne House, Haddington. She seemed to me more pleased to see me last autumn than you ever are— I can’t get over the “twenty minutes”
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 2 Jan. MS: NLS 517.1. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Here has another year come, to us unworthy,—another of our years is gone with its account!

Along with my many wishes, let me send you this little New years Gift;TC sent his sisters Jean Aitken and Mary Austin a check each for £10, and £2 2s. to his niece Jenny (Janet) Carlyle (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). may it do you good a hundred times beyond the value of it; otherwise it will not be much!—

I am holding on here, on the old terms; rather better, both of us, if there be any difference. Before actually yoking to the Printers,Robson, Levey & Franklyn. we are to be off, Thursday next,The next Thurs. was 5 Jan. for a week to The Grange: I had much rather not; but there is no avoiding handsomely, and perhaps it may be useful too.— JackTheir brother John A. Carlyle. has just returned from a similar week of Country; and your JamesJean’s son. I believe must be reporting himself all right.
Never was such a hurry as I am kept in! My blessings on you all, young and old.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS], 2 Jan. MS: NLS 19.3.52.8. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I intend to be faithful to my promise tomorrow; and to appear at yr door on horseback nearly exactly at 4 p. m. If one of yr grooms will take my horse for half an hour,—the grand operation (analogous to “projection[“]TC omits closing quotation marks. “Projection“: the chemical process of casting the powdered philosopher’s stone upon the base metal in order to turn it into gold. in Alchemy) will then take effect, and, if not gold, respec[t]able porridgeLetter omitted. “Porridge“: presumably representing something more ordinary than gold, rather than porridge itself. be the issue.
If my “wishes” could make your New Year good, dear Lady, it should be the best in London or England!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ED [EDO], 2 [Jan.]. MS: NLS 8992.208. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the Carlyles’ departure for The Grange on Thurs., 5 Jan.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA DONALDSON

docBody.p:
Oh my dear Eliza how provoking!— The luck that attends your visits here is quite awful!— Tho’ I did not expect you would come without warning me, (according to programme) I meant to write this very day to save you the trouble of writing even; in telling you that we were just going off to The Grange (Lord Ashburton’s Place in Hampshire) and that you were not to think about coming till I announced my return; And there you have gone and come “quite promiscuously”Coterie speech; see 35:38JWC to GEL, 20 Feb. 1859. bringing your sisterCatherine Rawlins. too all that way for no good! To be sure you came early, Charlotte said; but a woman who has not been in company for two years—doing colds all the winter, and retirement all the summer, can’t have been giving much heed to her wardrobe you may think! And so, when about to be launched again among people wearing
“purple and fine linen” and “dining sumptuously every day,”Cf. Luke 16:19. the quantity of elegant details wanted is enough to turn my brain! To day I was out after some of these; so soon as I had done my breakfast! result: a Belivedera-likeLike a belvedere, a raised turret on top of a house. head dress, black, with golden stars! the spiciest most ruffianly little FouardePresumably foulard, a lightweight silk often decorated with a printed pattern. jacket, black velvet overlaid with gold lace—sleeves collars &c &c!— No wonder I had to go out early and take a good deal of money with me! N. B. if you want to know where the prettiest, most stylish most expensive things are to be got in London—go to Madame Elise—successor to Jane Clark!Mme. Elise Delepine, b. Elizabeth Marie Louise Jäger, milliner and dressmaker, at 170 Regent St.; she m., 1857, Frederick Wooton Isaacson (1836–98), silk merchant. She had been left the business by her aunt, Jane Clarke (d. 1859), milliner (see also 33:141JWC to DD, 29 Dec. 1857).
I am really sorry to have missed your Sister “Kate” the only name I know her by—
I had a letter from Aunt JessJess Donaldson. on Saturday, and from the writing and look of it altogether I had hoped her better than she was— Charlotte reports you said she was worse—
Love to your MotherBetty Donaldson. and you all—a kiss to yourself
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 4 Jan. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 4 Jan. 1860. MS: NLS 553.207. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—Here is Tauchnitz,Presumably a letter from Christian Bernhard Tauchnitz. with some other tagrags that solicit your attention. The Prince de Ligne,Charles Joseph Emmanuel, prince de Ligne (1735–1814), Belgian-born soldier and writer, who distinguished himself in the Seven Years’ War; his collected works were Mélanges militaires, littéraires et sentimentaires, 34 vols. (Vienna, 1795–1811). TC cited de Ligne’s Mémoires et mélanges historiques et littéraires, 5 vols. (Paris, 1827–29) in Frederick; see Works 19:92. He also cited de Ligne’s diary, pbd. in Joseph Kutzen, Vor hundert Jahren. Zwei Gedenktage deutscher Geschichte (Breslau, 1857); see Works 17:318–19. TC’s copy of Kutzen: HCC. I doubt, is not in the London Library (nothing but De Staël’s SelectionsMme. la baronne de Staël-Holstein published Lettres et pensées du maréchal prince de Ligne; BL has three different edns.: 2 vols., 2d edn. (London, 1809), 3d edn. (Paris and Geneva, 1809), and 3d edn. (Paris or Leipzig, 1810). No copy of de Staël’s collection is listed in the London Lib. 1865 catalog. from him), this you may ask; in the Museum
they are safe to have both these Books; and any good thing of them (that is not in De Staël n.b.) ought to be tried for.

I meant to give you “Book I”Bk. 1 of vol. 3 of Frederick. for survey &c before it go to the Printer. It must wait till I come back,—an 8 days hence, I hope, at farthest.— We go tomorrow at noon noon;TC repeated “noon” because of the turn of the page.—hope to see you on the 2d SundayThe second Sun. was 15 Jan. following. Interim Address, if anything turn up, is “The Grange, Alresford, Hants.”
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea, 4 jany, 1860–

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 Jan. MS: NLS 525.62. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written on The Grange headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This morning your little Note came to me in bed,—a “first foot”For TC’s note on the Scottish custom at New Year of first footing, see 17:231JWC to JW, 2 Jan. 1844. of an agreeable kind. I would of myself have written today;—yesterday even but I reflected there was no London Post.

We got down hither without the least mischance, or anything disagreeable to encounter: had there been No 5 and our old habits to walk into, the journey wd have done both of us good. From the new habits, no dinner till 8, much talk, and many petty points soliciting attention, we, or chief I, suffered somewhat, and still suffer; but are getting well broken in. Jane in particular seems rather to profit.

We are not a large party, nor a brilliant, Lowe, Milnes, Venables the chief figures;Robert Lowe (1811–92; see 33:275–7633:biographical note), Richard Monckton Milnes, and George Stovin Venables. and a queer little Silesian or Polish Count Streletzki (or some such name)Paul Edmund de Strzelecki (1797–1873; ODNB), Polish exile, explorer, and philanthropist; he was probably not a count. He came to England 1843, was naturalized as a British subject 1848, and was awarded many honors, including Fellow of the Royal Society and Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, both in 1853; he was knighted 1869. whom I have known a long time, who has been everywhere, and who saves me the expense of talking; whh is his important quality. A very good little soul; with a physiognomy that reminds one of the late Ld Jeffrey,Francis, Lord Jeffrey (1773–1850), an old friend of the Carlyles; see 25:13–14TC to JWC, 29 Jan. 1850, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 349–84. and a
clear ringing voice whh also much resembles his tho’ set on a higher key.— Two rides I have had; of whh the first only was pleasant or useful: yesterday I had a horse Uneasy in Company; we went at a walk (for no good reason), and I was right glad (in the horrible state of interior) to get upon my own feet again, and be at peace.— I have broken my watch-glass; shall have to apply at AlresfordAlresford, the nearest town to The Grange; see 27:345TC to JHLH, 27 Oct. 1852. for a new one: this is happily the one misfortune that has befallen.—— HorroxProbably A. B. Whatton, Memoir of the Life and Labors of the Rev. Jeremiah Horrox (1859); Jeremiah Horrox (1618–41), early English astronomer whom TC had once studied; see 1:146TC to RM, 6 Nov. 1818. I IWord repeated in MS. shall like to look at; I know the man sadly from very young years: it will be a certain Weimar Horrox that has done this Life?For Charles, James, and John Horrocks, brothers “who usually reside at Weimar,” see 31:19TC to JWP, 31 Jan. 1856; they wrote poetry and romantic fiction but no memoir of Horrox. On Thursday I expect to be home. The kind MiladiLady Louisa Ashburton. wishes Jane to stay a while longer; but that I think will hardly be. My Compts to the Horse Fritz. Ever yours dear Brother,—T. Carlyle

ps.p: Pray ask tomorrow at No 5, If the Examiner is off? And if no, send it on to JeanJean Aitken.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 7 Jan. MS: NLS 553.208. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written on The Grange headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I am nearly certain there is no Anhang [Appendix] to my 8th Vol. of Adelung, and altogether certain there is no Index.See TC to JN, [1 Nov. 1859]. Perhaps the surest way will be for you to take a look at the thing (up in the Garret Apartt, left-hand Book-case; easily discoverable): you will then at once see how the matter is, and know how to instruct Tauchnitz. An Index, fail not to enforce that upon him, as the first of requisites! Vol 7 and all the prior volumes have each, singly or by pairs, their excellt Index; whh constitutes the main utility of the Book to me.

Thanks for your De Ligne Industries. I have read what is in the London Library, ofter than once; and indeed remember all de Staël’s Selection tolerably
well; but could never see the Complete Farrago of the loose Books he wrote. From the Journal I have got at second hand an Excerpt about LeuthenFor the extract about the battle of Leuthen from de Ligne’s diary, see Works 17:318–19. whh is well worth having.

Poor Wilhelm Grimm seems to have been a respectable man; but by all the lights given must have been a rather commonplace one: one is sorry for the poor old Brother, left alone after so long a joint warfare.Jacob Grimm (1785–1863) and Wilhelm Grimm (1786–1859), folklorists and philologists; see 12:16TC to RWE, 17 Jan. 1840, and 26:79TC to JAC, 6 May 1851. Wilhelm had d. 16 Dec. 1859; his obituary in the Examiner, 31 Dec. 1859, noted that he was “the younger of two eminent brothers who by their united efforts have so vastly contributed to the knowledge of German antiquity, German folk-lore, and the history of the German language.” Jacob gave a memorial address on Wilhelm to the Berlin Academy 5 July.

We have pretty winter weather here; a pleasant enough little party within doors; and absolute silence and purity when one steps out for a little whiff of tobacco or of fresh air. The late hours, the &c &c suit me badly:—on the whole I shall be glad to find myself at home again, and to see you this night week.TC writes on Sat.; he had previously mentioned Sun., 15 Jan., for their meeting; see TC to JN, 4 Jan. Yours always T. CarlyleThomas Babington Macaulay (1800–1859; ODNB; see 26:273TC to JCA, 20 Dec. 1851, and 274TC to JAC, 20 Dec. 1851), historian, essayist, poet, and an earlier member of Lord and Lady Harriet Ashburton’s circle, d. 28 Dec. 1859 from heart failure; his obituary was next to Grimm’s in the Examiner (31 Dec. 1859).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO], [10 Jan.]. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written on The Grange headed notepaper.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: You asked for my address that you might write to me— You got it and you have not written—

I will tell you a wise saying that you should write down in your pocket-book, and if possible in your heart—it is this: “Hell is paved with good intentions”JWC wrote “Good” after the colon and before the proverb and then apparently deleted it by smudging the ink.
I caught no cold on the journey and have been rather better than worse since I came— The same can’t be said of Mr C— He sleeps badly—and looks very wild—
On ThursdayThey returned Fri., 13 Jan. you may confidently expect us according to the original plan—
We were meant to stay till the end of the month—but nothing can keep Mr C from his work more than the “one week“—

Oh that poor little dog!JWC’s dog, Nero, had been run over by a butcher’s cart at the beginning of Oct. 1859; see 35:223TC to JAC, 3 Oct. 1859, 238–39JWC to SS, 21 Oct. 1859, and 243–44JWC to MR, 26 Oct. 1859. He has been a wet-blanket on all the glories of this place— Comes in my head whenever the talk as at the brightest—
You should have written to tell me about him—but perhaps you thought the less I was reminded of him the better—
I would give all the diamonds on Lady Ashburtons head and neck—and I think the Grange itself to have that poor wee beast well and young again—
Put good fires on Thursday morning—in the drawing-room and both bedrooms
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [11 Jan.]. MS: NLS 525.63. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written on The Grange headed notepaper.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: The Grange / Alresford Wednesday Evg [11 January 1860]
docBody.p: The daylight is just going, the Candles not lighted; and I have one word to write you before creeping into my own Corner to go in for a little prae-prandial sleep.

We are not coming home tomorrow; we have been persuaded to “another day,” and are (for certain, if no accident befal) to come on Friday. This is really all I had to say; you will find us on Friday; and I expect to get upon my own horse on friday again. This day and the foregoing days I have had enormous gallopings on turf; which indeed are the salutary element of life to me here: but quietude and a slower pace will again be welcome to me

Jane takes well with her new atmosphere, and is decidedly better within these two or three days: I for my part am well enough too,—i.e. pretty near the common average again; tho for the first few days I was decidedly hurt by my changes.
Your Saturday Review arrived duly: thanks.
The light is quite doneThe bottom of the page has been cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 14 Jan. MS: NLS 517.2. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: We got home yesternight, and are in our old posture again: so much I may tell you, tho there is hardly opportunity for more.

Jane seemed to suit the business better than I; and indeed she has returned, to appearance, with a small decided improvement for the time being: she slept better; enjoyed the much talk that was going; profited by the heated air (House all warmed by pipes)Presumably the first Lord Ashburton (1773–1848) had introduced the central heating system into The Grange; TC’s first visit there was in 1844, when he commented that the house had “modern improvements” on Inigo Jones’s original interior and “every convenience”; see 18:208TC to JWC, 14 Sept. 1844. &c &c. As for myself I was decidedly wretched, for the first three days (a dirty feverish cold spread all over me); a heart very sad, and a body very sore, in my sudden new element: but afterwards, chiefly by galloping over the fine grassy downs, I got quieter, and did tolerably well. Nothing could be kinder than our Hosts were old and new; nice people too, of a shining enough quality, went & came: but alas—! In short I am glad to be at home again; and to get at last into the one consolation that does not fail one in this world, that of getting grappled with the task laid out for us, and trying at least to do something upon that.

Jack has ridden my horse in my absence,—to keep him going. I called at Brompton RowJohn A. Carlyle’s lodgings were with Mrs. Thirza Kingham, 48 Brompton Row; see 34:163TC to JN, 28 Aug. 1858. last night; found all right,—the Inmate sunk in a litter of Old Books & New; smoking; not discontented that a “Manchester man” had bought Langshaw.Langshaw House had been bought by William Dunbar (ca. 1819–94). My poor old patient Brother Jack. Your YouthJean’s son James. had been with him a night ago: well, and doing well.—
Here are the Cootikins come, dear Jean, the leg-sloughs;Both are Scots words for gaiters. sign that the Horse is getting under way.

closer.salute: Adieu, with blessings to you all.

docBody.name: T.C.

ps.p: Jack was bidden send you the Examiner:On 7 Jan.; see TC to JCA, 7 Jan.TC to JAC, 7 Jan. but here it still lay last night;—goes only now, speed to it. Enough!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 14 Jan. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Getting home last night (in a more or less broken condition, wife not so ill, and in fact nothing to complain vocally about), I find that Note from Duffy,Charles Gavan Duffy (1816–1903; ODNB), Irish nationalist and politician, who emigrated to Australia in 1855; see 32:46TC to MACA, 7 Dec. 1856, and 34:54 and 56JWC to TC, [19 July 1858].—whh you will not grudge to read, and then to dispose of as is fittest. If you see good to send the whole or any portion of it to Macready,William Charles Macready. or if you judge better to suppress all notice of it or allusion to it in that quarter, follow your own decision;—only let the bargain be that poor M. (whose sorrows I am truly sorry for on this occasion) shall not make me the least answer on this painful matter. Unless indeed he might wish (whh I doubt) something farther to be tried by means of Duffy, who is evidently of willing mind in the affair.On Forster’s advice, Macready wrote to TC 13 April 1859. He asked TC to write to Duffy and ask for his help in finding employment for Macready’s son, Edward, which TC did; see 35:70TC to CGD, 13 April 1859. Duffy did his best, but Edward wanted to become an actor; see Duffy 202–10.

We have had a most bewildering week,—in whh to me there was little or nothing of wholesome except some swift galloping I had over the Hampshire downs, sub dio [in the open air] and in silence;—and now here is the old smithy again, with considerable lumber accumulated; and the poor old Smith in such a condition, of mind and of back, as you can fancy for a Hammerman of that description!

Adieu dear F.; let us always be unwilling to let the lumber have victory: one is bound to hammer on those terms till the sun do set, and the bell ring, “To bed!“— You need not return that Letter, unless it be altogether handy.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [14 Jan.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:22–23. Quot: Blunt, CR 151; Wilson 5:375. Dated by their return from The Grange, Sat., 13 Jan.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. BARNES

docBody.p:
I send you a Pheasant, which is a Trophy as well as a dead Bird! For I brought it home with me last night, from one of the most stupendous massacres
of feathered Innocents that ever took place “here down”Coterie speech. (as Mazzini expresses himself) From seven hundred to a thousand pheasants shot in one day! The firing made me perfectly sick! Think of the bodily and mental state of the surviving Birds when the days sport was ended! Decidedly men can be very great Brutes when they like!
We have been away for ten days at the Grange—(Lord Ashburtons place in Hampshire) where I always thrive better than anywhere else—and where as you see there are many Pheasants!

I went to take leave of you before we went, but saw all the blinds down and grew sick with fright!— I went into Mr Gigner’s shopJohn Gigner, chemist, 131 King’s Rd., Chelsea. and inquired was anything the matter—and he told me of your new loss.Presumably the death of a close relative; not further identified.— At least, it was an immense relief to me to hear that your FatherDr. Alfred Brooke Barnes. and yourself were not ill or worse—

After that I thought a note about my insignificant movements would only bother your Father—so I left him to learn my whereabouts from the—Morning Post!Presumably from a list of guests at The Grange pbd. in the Morning Post certain he would be too much preoccupied for looking after me at all—
Do come soon—if I dont go to you— Do you care to have this card?Untraced.— It will do for an autograph if you dont want to use it
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], 16 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 246–47 inc. Quot: Surtees, JWC 242.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: The worst of that Arabian-Nights-Entertainment sort of thing is that, coming back to one’s ordinary Life, one finds it has gained immeasurably in dinginess and dulness!

Our ordinary Life recommenced at Waterloo Station; where I had to leave off thinking about The Grange, and its goings on, and about you and your adorable kindness; that I might seek and identify our various luggage; which Mr C insisted was “hopelessly engulphed in the Belly of Chaos”!—where it might have remained, for any step that he would stir in the matter!—
Then followed the drive in a rickety bad-smelling street-cab, thro’ fog and mud; justifying Mr C’s exclamation: “Ough! my Dear! This is a terribly clarty City we are come back to!”

When we stopt at our own door; my heart was going “like-like-like-anything!”Coterie speech; source untraced; cf. 7:109TC to JAC, 25 Feb. 1834, and 18:130JWC to JW, 12 July 1844. about the wee sick Dog. Would he be still among “the Living and Loving”Possibly coterie speech; cf. “land of the living and the loving,” 15:155JWC to JW, 31 Oct. 1842.—Dogs? Would he be able to raise one bark of welcome?
The door was opened;—no bark! My eyes plunged into the lobby; no Dog!— “Is he dead”? I asked at the Servant; and, simultaneously with the question, came the answer: “Oh Mam! He is a little better!“—
Was it a sin and a shame to say—“Thank God?“—whether or not; I said it!

Poor little Creature! he had hurried to the bottom of the stairs, to receive us ‘avec explosion’Coterie speech; a phrase from French drama, according to JWC; see 23:124JWC to JW, 28 Sept. 1848. She also used the phrase in her 1845 notebook; see 30:169JWC to NB, 13 April 1854. (no doubt), and there, had been seized with a paroxysm of coughing! and the more he tried to express his joy, the more he couldn’t do it!— Apart from violent emotions however, he really seems less suffering; certainly not requiring to be poisoned—just yet!
I tell you about my Dog, knowing that you also had a dog, and believing that one’s dog makes all dogs touching for one!

For the rest; having come back to a “clarty City” is nothing like so bad as having come back to Frederick the Great! You can’t imagine what it is to have to pass one’s days in the Valley of the ShadowCoterie speech; cf. Ps. 23:4. of that dead man! I am sure he is taking many years of life out of me, as well as out of his Historian! Better be an “owl in Desert”Coterie speech; cf. Ps. 102:6. at once and cry to-hoo! to-hoo! than have an articulate speaking tongue in ones head and next to no opportunities of using it!TC wrote later: “My darling must have suffered much in all this; how much! I sometimes thought how cruel it was on her, to whom ‘Frederick’ was literally nothing except through me, so cruel, alas, alas, and yet inevitable! Never once in her deepest misery did she hint, by word or sign, what she too was suffering under that score; me only did she ever seem to pity in it, the heroic, the thrice noble, and wholly loving soul!” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:18).

Just now especially—since my return from the Grange—I am tempted to fall back on what Mr C calls “the one happiness of Life—the great Charm of Home—unbounded freedom to be as ugly and stupid and disagreeable as ever one likes”!Coterie speech; cf. 13:196JWC to JF, 24 July 1841.— But I doubt if Woman can ever appreciate that freedom as man does; besides,—“Don’t she wish she may get it?”Coterie speech; cockney phrase; see 29:30711 May 1855.
Now, I am not expressing myself like a reasonable woman for I have not had to leave all the good of the Grange behind
“For some one else to find”!From a popular song of the time; see 28:221JWC to TC, 25 July 1853.—

I have brought back with me the picture of it and of the life carried on in it, retouched and brightened up in my head; and have brought back with me loving and trusting feelings towards you, my Lady, which are a pleasant wonder to myself! so set had I been on never caring for you the least bit!According to Anne Gilchrist, 17 Feb., JWC had said, “[I had] resolved not to like her, but had been obliged to; ‘stood out five days’ … but when on ‘the fifth day she came up into my room, and spoke like an unaffected Highland girl, that Lady Ashburton won my heart; she spoke so freely and unguardedly about persons and things; most people in that station so guarded and careful’” (Gilchrist 82–83). having got it in my head that it would be a sort of infidelity, a sort of disloyalty to ever care for another Lady Ashburton than HerLady Harriet Ashburton. who had shown me so much kindness and exercised so much influence over me, during some fourteen years!

It was a narrow ungenerous idea; as if one’s human heart were like the stone house one lived in, laid out in a certain number of rooms of certain dimensions! I have overcome it or rather you have overcome it—to my great relief!
This is a delicate topic to engage in with you; but you encouraged me by saying the first word; with a noble frankness which touched me more than I can express!—
— And so—at parting— I made you that proposal,Unidentified. meaning every syllable of it; and hoping that, by its audacity if nothing else, you might be surprised into bearing it practically in mind.

Lord Ashburton did not say good by to me!— When I saw him going off before our departure, I took one step to run after him, and tell him I had been very happy—then suddenly I “thought shame”Coterie speech.—and slunk back to my seat—

Mr C was again, at breakfast this morning, lyrically recognising your “recklessness,” and wondering how you were!— If he were your monthly NurseTraditionally the nurse who looks after a mother and child for a month after birth. he couldn’t be more interested than he is in your “getting successfully thro’ the thing”!!Her pregnancy; see JWC to Lady AirlieLAI, [28 Nov. or 5 Dec. 1859].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 16 Jan. Addr: 25 Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 16 Jan. 1860. MS: NLS 553.209. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I am sorry to interrupt the deliberate composure of your survey of “Book I“:See TC to JN, 4 Jan. but here has the Printer made his appearance; and he is eager to be at work!

I can see nothing for it but that after reading carefully some 10 or 12 of the first leaves (and making your jottings about them) you give them up to Robson; taking the rest more at leisure,—for he will not be in a very great hurry of speed; and is certain to waste a few days at the very first, in making adjustments, and settling preliminaries.

I shall not correct anything till I see the whole Book in slips;—if you could get yr leaves back from Robson for me, in a printed state; and let me have the whole (with yr remarks) on Sunday night next, that wd be the utmost I could expect, and indeed wd do well enough.

I have promised that you will call on Robson (1. New Street, Fetter Lane,—any time before 4 p.m.) either tomorrow (Tuesday) or next day (“next day,No closing quotation marks in MS. most likely); and give him a few leaves if you can. Make the best bargain for me you can, on the above conditions. If you find that it will decidedly be better that I have the whole Book once more in Ms. before me, settle it so; and let the enterprise of beginning be put off for a week more.—— You may fancy what a flurry all this is for the dejected weary mind! I shudder to contemplate what lies ahead for the next 12 months. But there is deliverance too, if we can hold out so long!—
Sunday Evg next; and you need not write to me abt Robson &c unless necessary.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [16 Jan.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:221–23 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 482–83; Wilson, Carlyle 5:377.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: The Box is come. I have just unpacked it “with my own hands.”Coterie speech; Edward Irving’s phrase; see 1:301TC to AC, 2 Oct. 1821. and much admire the contents! Especially the big beautiful eggs, which look little short of a miracle (the number of them) to people who have all the winter been ferretting out an egg here and there, at twopence halpenny a-piece, with as much difficulty of search as if they had been, every one, a gold nugget!

The breakage this time has been trifling compared with the lastProbably early 1859; see 35:9–10JWC to MCA, 15 Jan. 1859, and 21–22JWC to MCA, 7 Feb. 1859.—only the three or four loose eggs on the top of the fowls were absolutely squelched. A good many in the basket were craked, or bruised, but the damage went no further. The Gill fowls are always welcomed “in our choicest mood.”Coterie speech; another of Edward Irving’s phrases; see 4:424JWC to JCA, Dec. 1828>. and the great currant loaf has already received the compliment of having a good half slice of it swallowed down Mr C’s throat; to my immense surprise! for not only does he avoid all such “dainties” as a general rule; but today in particular his “Interior” had been entirely “ruined” by a piece of Pheasant he ate yesterday! and more than usual discretion was to have been expected of him! The fact is; he ate it, I am sure, entirely out of affection for you, and as an expression of grateful feeling; not out of any real liking for currant loaf, nor yet “as a melancholy distraction,” (the motive he usually assigns for committing any extravagance in eating, breaking into green-pears and such like!)—
Thank you much! you are the same dear kind Mary always!

We are only subsiding still, from the glories of the Grange! and from the indegestions!—not that my individual degestion has been disturbed by the visit. I frankly confess that “french cookery”Lord Ashburton’s household had a French cook, Louis Gabriel Sedille (ca. 1814–72), from at least 1857; see 32:147JWC to MR, 18 May 1857. agrees with me remarkably well! and that I can drink champagne to dinner every day, not only without hurt, but with benefit to my health and spirits.

Then; it is cheering to get out of ‘the valley of the shadow’ of Frederick the Great for even eight days!— And it is wonderfully pleasant to live in a house, where by means of hot-water pipes, there is the temperature of summer in the dead of winter!— Not to speak of the brilliant talk, and brilliant diamonds, and brilliant ever-so-many things! which tho’ “the flames o’ Hell”
may certainly “come and burn it aa up”!Coterie speech; see 13:92–93TC to MAC, 11 April 1841. is very pretty and pleasant “in the mean-while”!

All the prettier and pleasanter for me, that I have lived more like “Owl in Desert” of late years, than like an unfeathered articulate speaking woman! Haunted ‘every day and all’Refrain of “A Lyke-Wake Dirge.” by the Ghost of Frederick the Great!

And so; I was unusually well at the Grange; and came home in better case than I left it! And much pleased with the new Lady who was kindness’s self! a really amiable loveable woman she seems to be; much more intent on making her visitors at their ease and happy, than on showing off her self, and attracting admiration.

It was in sickening apprehension that I arrived at my own door however. I had left my poor wee Dog so ill—of Old Age, complicated with asthma; that I doubted if I should find him alive! It was the first time for eleven years that his welcoming bark had failed me!— Was he really dead then? No! strange to say he was actually a little better—and had run up the kitchen stairs to welcome me as usual; but there he had been arrested by a paroxyism of coughing! and the more he tried to show his joy, the more he couldn’t do it!—

Mr C keeps insisting on the propriety of “a little prussic acid” for him! At the same time, he was overheard saying to him in the Garden one day. “Poor little Fellow! I declare I am heartily sorry for you! If I could make you young again upon my soul I would!”See also JWC to MR, [9 Dec.] 1859.—
And now goodby dear Mary. It is time I were in bed. This letter cant go tonight—but it will be ready, safe against all contingencies, tomorrow
My kind regards to your HusbandJames Austin.—and best wishes for you all
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AB [ABB], [17 Jan.]. Pbd: Blunt, CR 151–52; Blunt, Forum 66 (1921): 398. Dated by TC’s check to Dr. Barnes for £5 7s. 6d., 17 Jan. (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).
div3.head: TC TO ALFRED BARNES

docBody.p:
I have very much pleasure in paying,Presumably concerning his care of JWC in 1859; see 35:81TC to JCA, 20 April 1859, and 93–94JWC to MR, 12 May 1859. with a great many thanks over and above. No man of the many who present themselves at this season has done us so essential a service during the past year; and none of them all could do his poor ‘work’ more like a workman than you did your high and important
one! We wish you many good years, useful to your fellow creatures and yourself. I am, always,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 23 Jan. Addr: 25 Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 23 Jan. 1860. MS: NLS 553.210. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: What you give will do for Hubertsburg,For the sack of Hubertsburg Castle, Jan. 1761, see Works 18:345–47; for the peace treaty signed at the castle, Feb. 1763, see Works 18:487–89.—must do!

I now inclose you certain snips of writing, done at various times within the last 48 hours: labour for you is in all of them; for you of the willing mind labour; for me of the heavy ladenCf. Matt. 11:28. do help.—— Nothing is in immediate hurry. The “Preuss XIV (14°)”Presumably vol. 14 of J. D. E. Preuss, Oeuvres de Frédéric, 31 vols. (Berlin, 1846–57). TC describes it as “agreeably exceptional; being, for the first time, correctly printed, and the editor himself having mostly understood it,—though the reader still cannot, on the terms there allowed” (Works 14:323). can be left any day if to me or to Larkin. His Address is
Henry Larkin Esq / Elm Cottage / Old-Brompton Road / S.W.

He is appointed to be here, day after tomorrow; & I will tell him of the Preuss 14° affair. He goes Officially into the City every day, and can carry anything by his Steamers.Larkin worked for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.

The Tauchnitz Sendung [consignment],See TC to JN, 7 Jan. I find on examining, is worth as nearly as possible nothing in its present state. “Erste Abtheilung [first part]” only, and no Index! Cannot Ttz find a bibliographer of that magnitude in Leipzig;—practically he should ask some Librarian or the like, and be sure of his affair. I am loath to quit the hope of Adelung complete, and an Index to it (Look in Leipzig Libraries, University Liby for instance whether there is not an Index)!— On the whole, I have given you memoranda for another Letter to him on that mournful subject,—Heaven help us all!—

Robson has got his Proofs back and more copy. That first bit abt George IIPossibly J. F. von Bielfeld’s description of George II in Lettres de familières et autres, 2d edn., 2 vols. (Leiden, 1767) (TC’s copy: HCC); see Works 14:320–21. will very evidently not do where it is; and I have clipt it out: where to go in again, or how in the world,—with the general web flying thro’ the Robson Mill, and invisible to me except in snatches!
Courage, I must not lose my wits altogether, nor will;—I had better keep silent, for one thing.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: P.S. (most important).— I have never yet got a sheet of Note-paper; delays on delays have occurred with people here whom I tried on the matter! Send me a Packet of the kind you now write upon (kind that came this morng); Larkin when he delivers “Prs 14°” will bring it,—if that is of the least convenience. Perhaps Gotto’s manEmployee of Parkins & Gotto, stationers, 57 Rathbone Place, London. wd bring it sooner? Only be sure you have the right kind. Ohe, Adieu.
mema for Letter to Tauchnitz.The “memoranda” are on a separate sheet enclosed with the letter.
vol. came other day;—thanks

Half of the vol is what I already had; other half is not “Vol 9,” but “Erste Abtheilung” of Vol 9 (with certain Beylagen [additions], attainable (or avoidable!) everywhere)! There will be a 2te Abtheilg (a dritte [third] for what I know); the History goes ‘to the Peace of Hubertsburg,’ i.e. to March 1763;The Peace of Hubertsburg was signed 15 Feb. 1763; see Works 18:489. and the Tauchtz Volume ends with 1758 (only some Beilagen, wrong-placed, belong to 1759).

2After writing this sentence and the following one, TC marked them “2” and “1” to show the points in their correct order. Beilagen are totally witht value one and &Thus in MS. all of them,—I do not care if they were all wanting.
1 Let Ttz make another effort for the 2te & andThus in MS. other Parts (if there be other), and on the whole get us the Narrative till (Pce of Hubg) March 1763
Beylagen————wanting.
Finally, an Index to voll. 8 and 9 must certainly be in existence, if well looked for;—it is ⅞ of all the value of the Book to me: Oh infinitely desirable!—

Do make this into some kind of Letter to Tauchnitz;—perhaps you might write to HeberleJ. M. Héberlé in Cologne; see TC to JN, [1 Nov.] 1859. too, revoking yr late revocatn: Was there ever such bother, from the immethodic ways of certain persons? But I shd much like to have the Book (and Index), after such unspeakable fishing for it. Basta [Enough]. T.C.

Frh’s Letter to ValoriThese notes are on a scrap of paper, written the previous day and enclosed with the letter. Guy Louis Henri, marquis de Valori (1692–1774), French ambassador at the Prussian court.
