(t.o)The “t.o” referred to the final sentence about the “Buch für Jedern“ (see below), written on the reverse of the paper.

If you cd get me (from Stenzel,16. Gustav Adolf Harald Stenzel (1792–1854), Geschichte des preussischen Staats (Hamburg, 1830–54). or other indubitable source), in 3 lines the statistic cipher of Populn, revenue (Schatz [wealth]TC cited both Preuss and Stenzel: “The exact statistic cipher is, at Friedrich’s Accession: Prussian Territories, 2,275 square miles German (56,875 English); Population, 2,240,000; Annual Revenue, 7,371,707 thalers 7 groschen (1,105,756l. without the pence)” (Works 14:307). of Frh Wm,Friedrich Wilhelm I (1688–1740), Frederick’s father. whh I have often known but lost again!), and the like particrs, I shd be much obliged—you have the Buch fur JedernPreuss, Die Lebensgeschichte des grossen Königs Friedrich von Preussen: Ein Buch für Jedermann (Berlin, 1837); TC’s copy: HCC. (and Valori’s LetterUntraced. in it): if it is short and good, we might squeeze it in!— Accordg to your judgt, send me copy, or not.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 24 Jan. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: I got precisely the same Letter about old Miss LowePresumably about the death of Anne Elizabeth Lowe (1778–1860), d. 15 Jan., 5 Minerva Pl., Hatcham, “eldest daughter of the late Mauritius Lowe, Esq. … and god-daughter of the late Samuel Johnson, LL.D., aged 82” (Times, 18 Jan.). from that Ecclesiastic;Unidentified. Presumably neither H. H. Milman (1791–1868; ODNB), dean of St. Paul’s, nor Samuel Wilberforce, bishop of Oxford, both signatories of the original appeal letter to the Times about the Lowe sisters; see 30:99TCAO to EOT, 31 Oct. 1855. and made no ansr whatever (busy almost to delirium!)—if you wrote him a civil word to say that you yourself, Dickens & I are obliged by the trouble he took; that we none of us ever heard a whisper from the Old Lady after she got her money tho’ she was so diligent before it;Forster, Charles Dickens, and TC had organized a public subscription for the Lowe sisters, Anne Elizabeth and Frances Meliora Lucia (ca. 1783–1866) in 1855; see 29:346–47TC to EOT, 30 June 1855, and 30:97–100TCAO to EOT, 31 Oct. 1855. and that we &c &c— No doubt that wd be the polite thing, and I shd be relieved from a peccadillo on cheap terms.
Macready (poor man, what an ugly wound to a good old man, that same!) had done what was right. There it must rest,—or rather drift along at the discretion of that unstable Youth.Edward Macready.

A week ago I began printing,—Consented to “begin slowly”;—with my ms a
mere scrawl, and in an utterly chaotic state (where ms. there is), I never was so “like an old dog thrown into the fire,” as even now! Adieu, dear F. Oh what a twelvemonth lies ahead for me, if I live at all!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [28 Jan.]. Addr: Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: 28 Jan. 1860. MS: NLS 607.539A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:19–22 inc; Bliss, JWC 282–83 inc; Fielding and Sorensen 247–48 inc. Quot: Wilson 5:375; Hansons, NE 482–83; Rebecca Stott, Oyster (2004) 125.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: A letter from me would have crossed yours (with the BookMary Russell had sent JWC Pre-Adamite Man; Or, The Story of Our Old Planet and Its In-habitants, told by Scripture & Science (1860), published anon. by Isabelle (Belle) Wight Duncan, b. Clark (1812–78; ODNB); da.-in-law of Dr. Henry Duncan (1774–1846; ODNB), minister of Ruthwell, Dumfriesshire, who discovered the first quadruped fossil footprint in Britain and had been an old friend of TC; see 1:223TC to AC, 26 Jan. 1820, and 17:78–79TC to JWC, 23 Aug. 1843.) on the road, if it hadn’t been for—a jacket!— Things are so oddily hooked together in this world! The connection in this case is simple enough! I needed a little jacket for home-wear, and possessing a superfluous black-silk scarf, I resolved, in a moment of economical enthusiasm, to make, with my own hands a jacket out of it! For in spite of the “thirty thousand distressed needlewomen”For JWC’s views on “distressed needlewomen,” see 31:80TC to JRU, 2 May 1856. one hears so much of; the fact remains that nobody can get a decent article of dress made here unless at enormous cost. And besides, the dressmakers who can fit one, wont condescend to make anything but with their own materials! So I fell to cutting out that jacket last Monday, and only finished it today (Friday)!! and was so much excited over the unusual nature of the enterprise—(For I detest sewing, and dont sew any for weeks together) that I could not leave off for anything that could be postponed till the jacket was out of hands. But Lord preserve me, what a bother! Better to have bought one ready made at the dearest rate! I wont take a needle in my hands except to sew on Mr C’s buttons for the next six months! By the way would you like the shape of my jacket which is of the newest. I have it in paper and could send it to you quite handy!
Oh my Dear! I am very much afraid, the reading of that Book will be an even more uncongenial job of work for me than the jacket! and won’t have as much to show for itself when done!

If there be one thing I dislike more than Theology it is Geology! And here we have both! beaten up in the same mortar, and incapable, by any amount of
beating to coalesce!Duncan followed the theory that interpreted the Creation days of Gen. 1 as geological epochs. She then argued that the first humans appeared long before Adam and Eve, during the first era of Creation, which came to an end with the Ice Age. The second era began with Gen. 2:19 and Adam. She explained the absence of fossil evidence by suggesting that the “pre-Adamites” were transformed into either angels or demons. What could induce any live woman to fall a-writing that sort of Book? And a decidedly clever woman!— I can see that much from the bits I have already read of it, here and there. She expresses her meaning very clearly and elegantly, too.

If it were only on any subject I could get up an interest in, I should read her writing with pleasure. But even when Darwin, in a BookCharles Darwin (1809–82; ODNB), naturalist and geologist; his On the Origin of Species was pbd. 24 Nov. 1859. TC’s copy is in NLS (with no marginalia). that all the scientific world is in ecstasy over, proved the other day, that we are all come from shell-fish! it didn’t move me to the slightest curiosity whether we are or not! I did not feel that the slightest light would be thrown on my practical life for me by having it ever so logically made out, that my first ancestor millions of millions of ages back had been or even had not been an oyster!Edward Twisleton wrote to TC, 1 Jan., that he thought On the Origin of Species “the most remarkable and original work in its line”; his wife had been ordered by her doctor “to lead the life of her hundredth million million, million, million Cousin, the Oyster” so as not to injure her health “by an intemperate use of [her] brains.” Although the phrase “hundredth million million, million, million Cousin” comes from On the Origin of Species (cf. 420–21), Darwin does not refer to oysters specifically; no mention of oysters has been traced in the small number of reviews pbd. before Twisleton’s letter, 1 Jan. The idea of people being descended from oysters is used by reviewers later in 1860. The oyster, as a primitive organism that fossil evidence showed had existed since the earliest times, was used on both sides of the evolutionary argument. It was seen both as something virtually unchanged for millennia, “knowing its place” in the animal hierarchy, and as a creature constantly able to adapt to differing environments, evolve, and survive. It was also “that most familiar of nineteenth century urban street objects” (Stott, Oysters 117), cheap, and eaten in huge quantities by all classes of society, especially the poor (cf. CL 34:181). Ellen Twisleton was being treated at Malvern by Dr. James Manby Gully (1808–83; ODNB), whom Darwin had also consulted several times since 1849. For TC and JWC’s trip to take the waters at Malvern, see 26:109TC to JAC, 24 July 1851, 143JWC to HW, 27 Aug. 1851, and 154JWC to TC, 5 Sept. 1851. It remained a plain fact that i was no oyster! nor had no grandfather oyster within my knowledge and for the rest, there was nothing to be gained for this world or the next by going into the oyster-question till all more pressing questions were exhausted! So—if I cant read Darwin—! it may be feared I shall break down in Mrs Duncan!Isabelle Duncan’s book was pbd. anon. until the 5th edn. (1866). According to the ODNB, her “decision to reveal her authorship stemmed partly from her irritation that most reviewers assumed she was male.” Her husband, George John Craig Duncan (1807–68), like his father, joined the Free Church of Scotland at the Disruption, 1843; he was minister in Greenwich, 1851–61, and lecturer on pastoral theology at Theological Coll. of the English Presbyterian Church, becoming the church’s general sec., 1861. They lived in Blackheath.— Thanks to you however for the Book. which will be welcome
to several of my acquaintan[ces]Letters missing.— There is quite a mania for Geology at present in the female mind! My next-door neighbourAnne Gilchrist. would prefer a Book like Mrs Duncan’s to Homer’s Iliad or Milton’s Paradise Lost— “There is no accounting for Tastes”!Proverbial.

I have done my visit to the Grange, and got no hurt by it, and it was quite pleasant while it lasted. The weather was mild—and besides, the House is so completely warmed with warm-water pipes that it is like summer there in the coldest weather. The House was choke-full of visitors—four and twenty of us most of the time!!TC had noted: “We are not a large party, nor a brilliant”; see TC to JAC, 7 Jan. and the toilets!—nothing could exceed their magnificence! for there were four young new-married Ladies among the rest, all viing with each other who to be finest. The blaze of diamonds every day at dinner quite took the shine out of the chandeliers!— As for myself; I got thro’ the dressing part of the business by a sort of continuous miracle! and after the first day, had no bother with myself of any sort.

The LadyLady Louisa Ashburton. was Kindness’s self—and gave general satisfaction. Even I who had set my mind against liking her, could not resist the pains she took to make me.— By the way— I don’t wonder you thought Lord A not too happy when you took that sentimental letter I sent you for his! The letter was from Lady A—and he merely broke into it near the end, and then signed his name!— Oh no! He shows no signs of regret! His devotion to the new Lady is perfect— And really he never was so ‘made of’ before! I cant wonder that he likes it!

I had heard from Countess Pepoli of Mrs MacVeaghs sad state—Mary McVeagh (1784–1860; see 34:278TC to CBU, 9 June 1858) d. 7 Feb. Madame Pepoli herself has been seriously ill, but is recovering— Poor Mrs MacVeagh will be much missed—she was a dear kind soul—
Love to your husband
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC [JACA], 30 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE THE YOUNGER

docBody.p: I have been to Mr BatesProbably Joshua Bates (1788–1864; ODNB), an American banker living in London, partner in the merchant bank Baring Brothers & Co. since 1828. this afternoon, by appointment, and have talked your matter over;—and am very sorry to say there is not the least outlook in that direction.

The Baring House in Liverpool, it seems, deals mainly or only in Cotton;Baring Brothers had opened an office in Liverpool in 1832, under the aegis of Joshua Bates, specifically to deal with the cotton trade with the U.S. the Clerks are young men who want to learn that, or other kindred sorts of trade; and they serve without salary at all; and then go forth on their own score, when sufficiently up to it.

In London, the Junior Clerks have “small salaries,” Mr Bates says; but they learn nothing whatever: there are Twelve Upper Managers (I know not whether Clerks altogether, or at the same time Partners in some degree, but suppose the latter): these “have large salaries, and manage all the business”; the juniors sitting under them in a mainly mechanical capacity, copying Letters and the like, and “are forbidden to speak” in the Office. Vacancies which occur in the Twelve are filled up, I guess, mainly by relatives of the House; who, if they ever work in the junr department, do it with that view. In short, it is extremely difficult to get in; and, unless you have farther interest, not worth being in when you are. “All trade is altered, in London,” according to Bates, “cut into departments, whh know nothing of each other;—a bad system, growing ever worse; and London a bad place for learning it”; &c &c I need not trouble you with more of this. Mr Bates, I considered it likely, had some real desire to oblige me (perhaps not very much either); and he seemed to like well the Portraiture I made of my Nephew: but the Negative to my inquiry was visible in every part of his answer. He considered, “Such a youth might do a great deal better in Australian life, than in any kind of Mercantile, whh was open here; such competition, such“— I took my hat; thanked politely, and came away.

You may believe how sorry I am, dear James; how gladly I wd have helped you, for your own and your brave Father’s sake; but I cannot in this way;—I would, and will, with very great readiness, in any other that is feasible to you and me. Courage; I guess you will find something to do in the world,—or I am much mistaken in the figure of you and of the world. My best brotherly regards to your Father, my love to every one. Yours affectionately T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AB [ABB], [2 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:23–24. Quot: Ireland 259–60; Wilson 5:377–78; Hansons, NE 483. Froude put “[Nero died]” after his date of 1 Feb.; Thurs. was 2 Feb.
div3.head: JWC TO ALFRED BARNES

docBody.p: I cannot put into words how much I feel your kindness. It was such a kind thing to do! and so kindly done!
My gratitude to you will be as long as my Life; for shall I not, as long as I live, remember that poor little Dog?

Oh dont think me absurd—you—for caring so much about a Dog! Nobody but myself can have any idea what that little creature has been in my Life! My inseparable Companion during eleven years, ever doing his little best to keep me from feeling sad and lonely! Docile, affectionate, loyal up to his last hour—when weak and full of pain he offered himself to go out with me, seeing my bonnet on; and came panting to welcome me on my return! and the reward I gave him—the only reward I could or ought to give him—to such a pass had things come—was, ten minutes after, to give him up to be poisoned!

I thought it not unlikely you would call today—because your coming today would be of a piece with the rest of your goodness to me— Nevertheless I went out for a long drive— I couldn’t bear myself in the house, where every thing I looked at reminded me of yesterday. And I wouldn’t be at home for visitors, to criticise my swollen eyes and smile at grief “about a dog”! and besides, suppose you came, I wished to not treat you to more tears—of which you had had too much—and today I couldn’t for my life have seen you without crying dreadfully. Tell your little jewel of a Daughter,Isabella Barnes. I have not forgotten her wish,Possibly for a photograph of JWC or of Nero; see JWC to IEB, [10 Feb.]. for which I thank her— I wish all her wishes were as easy to fulfil!
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [3 Feb.]. MS: NLS 553.211. Quot: Wilson 5:382.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I expect you on Sunday Evg Pray look at the Prussn statistic (of square miles &c) again;—that of the square miles (if they are English, and almost still more if they are not English, namely to be multiplied by 25) astonishes me! Pray examine (by other lights if needful) till you are sure.For the statistics, see TC to JN, 23 Jan.

2°. IV, 506 The page in MailathTC cited Count Janos Mailéth, Geschichte des östreichischen Kaiserstaates bis auf die neueste Zeit, 5 vols. (Hamburg, 1834–50) in Frederick (Works 14:393). where he speaks of Karl VI as “serious even in laughing”TC described Karl VI without giving a source: “He looks, in his Portraits, intensely serious. … ‘[S]omething solemn in him, even when he laughs,’ the people used to say” (Works 14:392). It was not from Mailéth 4:506. &c—— The Buch für Niemand (i.e. the illegible Paper
upon it) you have probably finished?“Book for Nobody,” TC’s ironic title for J. D. E. Preuss’s Die Lebensgeschichte des grossen Königs Friedrich von Preussen; its subtitle is Ein Buch für Jedermann [A Book for Everybody]; see TC to JN, 23 Jan.—— The poor little Dog has got his quietus; do not mention or allude to him!

I have had to stop the Printing; hardly ever was in such disgust with myself, such—!“This first attempt of October–February, 1859–1860 (after dreadful tugging at the straps), was given up by her serious advices, which I could not but admit to be true as well as painful and humiliating! November 1860 had arrived before there was any further printing: nothing thenceforth but silent pulling at a dead lift, which lasted four or five years more” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:18). Stand by me, if you can help, this once!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WWV, 4 Feb. Addr: Wolseley Hall / Rugeley / Staffordshire. PM: Rugeley, 6 Feb. 1860. MS: Athenaeum Club, London. Pbd: Vernon 157.
div3.head: TC TO W. W. VERNON

docBody.p: I am much satisfied to hear of the beneficent Proprietor of my Picture again;Vernon lent TC his portrait of Frederick by Heinrich Francke, April 1858; see 33:208–9TC to WWV, 21 April 1858, and TC to EC, 11 Nov. 1859. For the portrait, see 33:210TC to WWV, 22 April 1858. often lately, in the sad Prussian “whirlwind of paper-clippings” here (whh is only half subdued yet, very far from done!), I have said to myself, This Picture at least ought to be returned to its place!Vernon was apparently anxious to have the portrait returned, as Lord Ashburton wrote to him, 2 Feb.: “I have sent [Carlyle] your letter. A thousand excuses for not having watched over the return of what you so goodnaturedly lent at my request” (MS: Athenaeum Club). They are now engraving for me at Berlin the best FranckeSee TC to EC, 11 Nov. 1859. they there have (almost a facsimile of yours, only perhaps in better keeping), whh will go into my Fourth or last volume,It became the frontispiece of vol. 5 of the 1st edn. of Frederick (1865). shd I ever survive to finish that,—as I am trying hard to do! This of yours is plainly superfluous here this long while; fronting me in a kind of reproachful way, for so many months past, saying only, “Get on; won’t you get on!” & the like sad things.

If you will have the goodness to tell me, by what conveyance, and to what specific address,—I will at once have the fierce King screwed into his Packing case again, and put upon the road.Presumably to Wolseley Hall, Staffordshire, 2½ mi. NW of Rugeley, and 20 mi. N of Birmingham.— The Railway did him no ill last time,
except shattering his crown,See 33:208–9TC to WWV, 21 April 1858. which is now glued well together again: railway will do; but some slower and quieter conveyance, if there is such, might be safer still. Lord Ashburton gave me, long ago, from some Catalogue now in yr House, some Note referring to this Picture,—its date, first owner,Vernon had inherited the picture from his grandfather, Sir John Borlase-Warren; he later presented it to the Athenaeum Club (Vernon 159); see 33:209TC to WWV, 22 April 1858. &c:—I have lost the Note; and could beg another copy if you wd permit.
With the sense of your very great civility to me in this matter, I remain always
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Wm. Wrn Vernon Esqr &c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A [LOA], 4 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have written to Vernon; shall be extremely glad to despatch his Francke Picture again, whh has done me all the good that was in it, a long while ago. I have again and again had the firm purpose to ask you what the Address was; but always forgot, when we met, and had so many other things to speak of. The Picture has not got, nor shall get if precautions will hinder, any injury; and this unknown young Gentn’s civility to me will always be a pleasant recollection.

I am delighted to hear of you in the woods; or even following the hounds, tho’ that latter is in a less degree. The hot rooms, the dinings, the assemblages, they are right well away, and no harm done! We expect you “the end of this month”;At Bath House, Piccadilly, the Ashburtons’ London home.—and one of us expects there may be a ride or two in store, in the bright spring weather.

We cannot brag much here, we for our part; but must not complain. The Wife keeps on foot, stronger than in usual winters lately; I myself am rather below par,—and very greatly bothered and hunted by this sad Book of mine; which, like the Siege of Sebastopol to Sir Jn Burgoyne, seems always the more impossible the longer one gazes on it!Sir John Fox Burgoyne (1782–1871; ODNB), military engineer; in 1854 he proposed an alternative course of action to the direct assault on the Russian fortress of Sebastopol being planned by Lord Raglan. The failure of Burgoyne’s strategy led to his being recalled, 24 Feb. 1855, by Lord Panmure (1801–74; ODNB), sec. of state for war; see 29:317–18TC to JRU, 23 May 1855. Burgoyne’s remark is untraced. I attempted lately to do it by
coup de main (or continuous storm, to last for 12 months!)—that is to say, I set the Printers to work to chace me thro’ it at a slow rate;—but have been obliged to call Halt in that, and go back to my trenches with heavy loss! Some way or other this intolerable state of things must be brot to end. I feel that all my days and moments are due to it; and that there can be no good in store, till this be swept fairly to its place. I have seen nobody; heard of nothing,—I rather shrink from seeing and hearing, in my poor shivering humour. “You don’t want any Reform Bill?” some one said.Pressure on the Palmerston govt. to legislate for parliamentary reform had increased as the result of a campaign led by John Bright, demanding limits on the power of the House of Lords, a redistribution of seats, and greater working-class representation. The Times commented, 4 Feb.: “when it is asked why we are to have a Reform Bill, the answer is that we must, and there is no help for it.”— “No; and I don’t care how many there may be!”

We are weekly reminded of My Lady; my coffee was whiter this very morning by her bounty!Cream was included in the hamper of provisions that Lady Ashburton had arranged to be sent weekly from Addiscombe Farm. Pray take (really) care of her;—and may all good be with you both. Faithfully yours T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC: Testimonial Letter for Mr. Miller, 6 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC’s TESTIMONIAL LETTER FOR MR. MILLER

docBody.p: Mr. Miller, who is now about removing to a better post, has served, these last Eight years, in the London Library, as one of the Clerks there; and, I have reason to believe, has proved himself uniformly an amiable, punctual, polite, diligent and intelligent young man; giving great satisfaction to his Employers. Whatever I, for my part, have happened to know of him is to his advantage.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-RST, [ca. 6 Feb.]. MS: NLS 1808.104. Quot: Beryl Gray, “‘Nero c’est moi’: Jane Welsh Carlyle and Her Little Dog,” Carlyle Studies Annual 22 (2006): 184. Dated a few days after Nero’s death, 1 Feb., and before JWC to IEB, [10 Feb.].
div3.head: JWC TO ROBERT S. TAIT

docBody.p: I have been to Caldesi,Leonida Caldesi (d. 1900), Florentine photographer; his firm, Caldesi, Blandford & Co., 13 Pall Mall E., specialized in “Portraiture, Reproduction of Pictures, instantaneous Photographs of Groups, of Animals, and the celebrated ‘Cartes de Visites’” (Illustrated London News, 7 Jan. 1860). and learnt to spell his name, and found him charmingly polite, and bespoken half a dozen ‘Interiors.’Reproductions of photographs of Tait’s painting A Chelsea Interior (1858); see 33:196–97JWC to MR, 29 March 1858. Tait often used photographs while painting it, 1857–58. Gray points out (190) that Tait’s photograph of Nero (ca. 1855; sent to Ellen Twisleton by JWC; see 30:128N to ETW, 30 Nov. 1855) is identical to Nero as painted in A Chelsea Interior (see 33:235JWC to TWO, 3 June 1858). For further discussion of reproductions of Nero, see Gray 181–213. So—There! You think, with a sigh of relief, that you are safe from more bother from me about Interiors—whatever else! Not so Mr Tait!— I now write to ask if you have, by happy chance, in that old heap of photographs of yours, one or even two copies from the little negative of the Interior you did yourself—and, if so, to give me them (or it) “for love,” or in exchange for two of Caldesi’s large ones! This proposal sounding somewhat like the offer of “New Lamps for Old ones” in the Arabian Nights: I will explain its motive that you may not dread any such awful results to the bargain as befell Aladdin’s Wife!“Aladdin and His Lamp,” Arabian Nights’ Entertainments, where Aladdin’s wife is tricked into exchanging their old (magic) lamp for a new one.

figure.p: Nero, ca. 1855, by Robert Tait

p.hi: Courtesy of The National Trust

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle, ca. 1857, by Robert Tait

p.hi: Courtesy of The National Trust

docBody.p:
My little Nero is dead Mr Tait. You know how fond I was of the creature, but my sorrow over him is my own affair—incomprehensible, of course, to anyone besides myself—and perhaps good little Charlotte who has gone about with red eyes ever since. Charlotte has all along been extremely good to the dog grudging no trouble with him and I want to make her a little gift, to remember him by: and it has occurred to me that a little portrait of him mounted in a brooch would be a keepsake that she would dearly value. Now the dog in even the smallest of Caldesis negatives is too large for my purpose— There were some of yours which made me think at the time “what a nice brooch that would make!”Tait had also photographed Nero sitting on JWC’s lap (1854); see 31:161JWC to TC, 8 Aug. 1856. The brooch with Nero and the framed small photograph of JWC (which was also used as a carte de visite), both handtinted, are in Carlyle House; see oppabove.— He was alive and well then, and it was only a passing fancy—now he is dead—and I want it carried into effect—and the Interiors of your own doing which you gave me are all parted with— One for
Charlotte—but I have said two?— Well Mr Tait—to confess the truth I want the second—to be put in a brooch for myself! If you choose to laugh at me you may— It is no laughing matter to me however—but the very most crying matter that has come across me for many a day!—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: will you be so good as send me the address of the ManPossibly William and Philip Evans, carvers and gilders, 18 Silver St., Golden Sq.; see TC to WWV, 9 Feb. who made my last two frames

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [7 Feb.]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 7 Feb. 1860. MS: NLS 553.212. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: No need of haste abt those “Buch-für-Niemand”TC’s name for Preuss’s book; see TC to JN, [3 Feb.]. Notes; the point is, to make them accessible and intelligible. Exercise yr own good judgt upon them; whh I have often enough found helpful.

For one thing, date everything (or say that there is no date); time always and place always, if it be possible to sift them out. And plenty of paper
(as you proposed), that I may be able to clip out, and reposit elsewhere to my convenience.

There is one story, Of a parsonUntraced. from some Consistorium [assembly], on some vestry case hugely interesting to him, who came to have the Consistorium vote ratified by Frh who was then campaigning, and very anxious abt some military event from the distance. Frh, a bad sleeper, had ordered that any estafette [mounted courier] coming shd be immediately introduced;—Parson was introduced under the idea of his being the Estafette: Frh’s “Well then?” on starting out of sleep has often been in my head for the last 12 years!— I shd guess the thing is in “Niemand” (in Preuss it somewhere certainly is): he does not date it (I think), but I want his authority.

If you go to the Museum, glance if there is anything abt the Berlin Rejoicings (for Peace of Xmas 1745; 2d Silesian War done); how they first called him “Great” by acclamatn hereThe Peace of Dresden, at the end of the Second Silesian War, was signed 25 Dec. 1745 (Works 16:192). Frederick returned to Berlin, 28 Dec. 1745, to huge public acclaim, with the crowds crying, “Vivat Friedrich der Grosse!” and singing, “Vivat, vivat Fridericus Rex; / vivat Augustus, Magnus, Felix, Patri-æ——!” (Works 16:193). (d’ArgensTC probably means D’Arget, secretary to Valori, the French ambassador, a favorite of Frederick, and shortly after taken into Frederick’s service (see Works 16:186–90), rather than Jean Baptiste de Boyer, marquis d’Argens (1704–71), French political satirist, close friend and adviser of Frederick, who lived at the Prussian court for over 25 years (see Works 16:318–19) but was not in Dresden at this time. &c very busy); also how he made a Feast (Supper to all Comers) for the Berlin People,TC does not mention a feast but does write that “[i]lluminated Berlin shone like noon, all that night” (Works 16:193). and was disgusted a good deal by their sottish greedy ways? Some old Germn Magazine, Englh Newspapers &c &c?“The K. of Prussia made magnificent presents to the Austrian and Saxon ministers who signed the treaty. … This done he set out for Berlin on the 27th past, and arrived there amidst the acclamations of his subjects, who strewed his way with laurel, and saluted him with the title of Frederick the Great” (Gentleman’s Magazine [Jan. 1746] 47).
Be sure to get the Preuss, and straightway; it will be well worth our having.

Book II is not quite so bad as I had expected. Courage, we shall perhaps get our poor Grt Eastern launched,Comparing Frederick to the launching of the Great Eastern steamship; the first two attempts failed and it was finally launched 31 Jan. 1858; see 33:128–29TC to JAC, 7 Dec. 1857. if we push steadily, in spite of the iron ways and the much rubbish! Without pushing, and of the steady kind, I see too well, it will never be done!

closer.salute: Yours always (just going out to ride in the rain,—uh-uh!)

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WWV, 9 Feb. MS: Athenaeum Club, London. Pbd: Vernon 158.
div3.head: TC TO W. W. VERNON

docBody.p: The Francke King is packed in his case (crown royal secured by all the art our man had);The crown royal at the top of the frame of the picture had been slightly damaged in transit from Vernon to TC; see 33:209TC to WWV, 22 April 1858. and will now set out on his journey, so soon as you are kind enough to give us the word.

Our man, a kind of Frame-maker &c,William and Philip Evans, carvers and gilders, 18 Silver St., Golden Sq. and used to the trade of sending Pictures, thinks clearly the railway after all is the best conveyance.

We will still wait, four days, for some hint from you on that point: on the fifth day (that is abt Tuesday or Wedny next week), if nothing come, we shall take for granted that “Wolseley Hall” is the intended home of the Picture, and write for the railway van to come and take charge of this valuable cargo.
I am sorry to give you all this trouble; whh is a sorry return for your great kindness and politeness.

closer.salute: I remain always Your much obliged

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: W. W. Vernon, Esq., &c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-WWV, 10 Feb. MS: Athenaeum Club, London. Pbd: Vernon 158–59.
div3.head: TC TO W. W. VERNON

docBody.p: Thanks for the trouble you take. The Francke has got its new Address put upon it; and shall be (safely, we may hope) in Evans’s hands tomorrow. If you hear nothing farther from me, please to consider that such is the case.— I understand our man took the crown-royal off altogether (glue not being strong enough, in his opinion); and packed the fragments (all he had of them) in paper,—nailing the same to the Box itself, lest they shd get loose in the railway jinglings, and perhaps scratch the Picture. Some more solid finish to that part of the Frame (or indeed mere removal of the crown altogether) wd evidently be advantageous.

There is no doubt but the Picture is an original:—and to enhance and secure whatever worth it may have, I think you shd introduce (fixed, say, on
the back of the Canvas) that Note by the Original Proprietor, whh is in your Catalogue, and gives the date &c in an authentic form,—needing only your signature (and the new date) to make it valid to the present and to future time.— That Note was to me an essential part of the interest this Picture excited; and it ought not to be lost.

Francke was not a Painter of eminence, and I think is now pretty much forgotten; but from this Note in yr Catalogue, added to what had turned up for me at Berlin, I considered it pretty evident that Francke was, then and there (viz: at Potsdam, 1773),TC’s ”?” above the date; the picture was painted about 1770, when Frederick was 58; see Works 17:frontispiece. considered by persons on the spot to have hit off Friedrich well, and to be the man whom an English Nobleman wanting a Portrait of King Frh, ought to apply to. That is valuable testimony. And it completely coincides with the fact, so far as I could guess it from this distance of place and time. No likeness in Berlin, except that of Francke’s, whh they are now engraving, had the least credibility for me; and I saw the chance of leaving Berlin more uncertain abt what the Physiognomy of Frh had been than I ever was.— Friedrich never sat to any Painter after his accession (1740, in his 29th year); each had to watch for himself, and pick him up by memory or how he could. The Berlin Artists have now an Orthodox likeness of F, whh they have tacitly agreed upon, and will produce at once for any comer;—and many comers do believe in it; but to me the feat was impossible, and even contemptibly so
My own notion is, Francke comes nearer the real Likeness than anybody yet heard of: and accordingly I am having him engraved for my own use. This is all I know.— Believe me, dear Sir,
docBody.name: [T.] Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [10 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Blunt, CR 152–53.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. BARNES

docBody.p:
My dear “little Nun” (minus vocation)! What bad luck to miss both your Father and you in one day! or rather; what bad management! (For I believe there is no difference between Luck and management but in the spelling!)—Certainly “I, “as one solitary Individual,”Coterie speech; see 33:4JWC to TC, 3 Aug. 1857; quotation marks: thus in MS. (my Husband’s favorite phrase) have been managing shockingly in the last ten days! throwing over everything for locomotion; and locomotion towards no point or object—merely for the
distraction of the thing! But without Rule and Routine to keep me within bounds (like a moral strait-waistcoat) I should soon be in Bedlam—Moi!—So I seriously purpose, by strength of Heaven, to recommence living the regular-ticking existence of an eight day clock so soon as—as I can!
Meanwhile recollect you are to be ready to take a drive with me at 2 on Monday next.

To day I am in hope of realizing the photograph for you,See JWC to RST, [ca. 6 Feb.]. in the course of my circulation thro’ space! and if so, shall leave it with this note in passing— If it still is not finished we will go for it together on Monday
My best love to your Father—
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 11 Feb. MS: NLS 517.3. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: If I had you not to write to, what a remorse it wd be that I am so remiss in writing to one that loves me so truly! I have you always to think of, as of one still left me, faithful while life lasts; and many times that is a consolatn to me when I sadly count to myself how many are not now here, and how solitary the Scene of Life is fast growing.— I have been very slack in writing of late; but truly it is not my blame, it is my sorrow & misfortune rather; and I know too you never blame me, but pity me, and hope for a day when I shall be clearer of the burdens that are at present so heavy on me. The truth, however, is, you have not heard from me since before we went to The Grange:The Carlyles left for The Grange on 5 Jan. JohnJohn A. Carlyle, their brother. I do suppose keeps you on a level with my poor history such as it is; your Notes he duly talks of to me:—but I ought to write now & then a word for myself; and one might do so, were one at all hours thoroughly alive to seize the passing five minutes, and make use of it,—as now. “Ye must just excuse us,”Coterie speech; see 7:199TC to MAC, 30 May 1834. as the Coach-guard once said, after the day had been rainy all the way from Edinr: “Another day we will do better!”Coterie speech; see 6:232JWC to MAC, 25 Sept. 1832.—

The truth is, I am pretty much at the bottom of the deep well, these 5 or 6 weeks back; and have seldom, or hardly ever in my life, been in such a pucker,—so very near the end of all resources that were visible to me. We
began printing, you probably heard; and we were obliged to stop it again. This includes a whole world of miseries and confusions, whh have tumbled me about at such a rate ever since,—rendering the very daylight a burden to me sometimes! Nor can I yet be said to be out of the well; very far from it: but I hope I am now down at the “bottom”;—and there is something generous and encouraging in the thot that one is scrambling upwards. If it please Heaven’s Goodness, I shall yet work my way out of this ruin of ruins; and reappear on the green Earth, to a calmer Evening than my Day has been. If it be Heaven’s will!—

Jane is still on foot; clearly better than last winter: may that continue, for that is clearly a great blessing.“She seemed generally a little stronger this year, and only a little; her strength, though blind I never saw it, and kept hoping, hoping, was never to come back, but the reverse, the reverse more and more!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:18). Yesterday I brot my Horse down in the frost: I got but little harm of it, and might have got a great deal. Let us be thankful! our good motherMargaret Aitken Carlyle. wd have said. “Let us call on Patience!”Coterie speech; see 28:130TC to MAC, 6 May 1853. was another of her sayings.— Yr James was here this night week. Adieu dear Jean; God bless you all.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [12 Feb.]. Pbd: Wilson 5:378–81. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 248–49.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Have you ever noticed how long—preternaturally long—the time looks, when one had been thinking and feeling more than usual in it, even without changing of place or interrupting of one’s outward routine?
I have just been making an experience of this. … It wasn’t much “to speak of.” A small tragedy—very small—and yet, more heart-rending than some grander ones.

My little dog had become rapidly worse, till “common humanity required that he should be made away with,” I was told. “My Dear” (urged Mr. C.) “it is an Act of Roman Virtue that is demanded of you; and so (!) you surely will not shrink from it!“—as if Acts of Roman Virtue were among the simplest ordinary obligations on a nineteenth Century Scotchwoman!—and I who have no taste at all for Roman Virtue—oh, any other sort of virtue rather than that! Indeed I have never been able to understand what these old Romans
could be made of, or to altogether believe in them.For JWC’s story about her childhood admiration for Roman stoicism, see 30:191–92JWC’s Simple Story. The appeal to any latent Roman Virtue in me found nothing to act upon. But the intervention of my Doctor,Dr. Alfred Brooke Barnes. who happened to call, was more effective. He told me the little creature was suffering dreadfully, and would suffer still worse if he lived;—that keeping him going on so was “a bit of selfishness” he wouldn’t have given me credit for. And then he asked, suppose he himself should come some day when I was out—in a week or so—and give the poor dog something to put him out of pain in one moment, “without hurting him the least;” would I be very angry? Of course I burst out crying which meant consent. He had said “in a week or so,” but that, I knew, was merely to put off apprehension, and accordingly, the very next day, the Dr. in driving past our house, seeing the Drawing room windows open, supposed me gone out; and was half way up stairs, when we met each other face to face. He was for retreating, good kind man; but I felt, “the sooner the better,” the sight of my little dog following one about, trying to discharge his bits of duties the same as ever, in spite of his agony of breathlessness; with my knowledge that he was about to die—to be poisoned; that the reward about to be given him, for his lifelong devotion—the only reward that could and ought to be given him, was—prussic acid! Oh it was too horrible, could not be ended too soon. So I called him (the Dr.) back, and said now was no worse than any other time would be, and bade Charlotte take my little dog away. I could not lift him to put him into her arms, but I kissed his poor little head. And He licked my cheek.
Then I ran and shut myself into my bedroom, and flung myself down and cried—as I hadn’t cried since I was a girl.

My Dr. kept his promise, the little creature died in one moment (Charlotte said) without a struggle. Fortunately Mr. Carlyle was himself entirely upset by little Nero’s death; so that he could not lecture me on my “excessive grief,” his “own heart being” (as he expressed it) “quite unexpectedly and distractedly torn to pieces by the misery of the thing.“— His lyrical recognition of “the poor little creature’s docility, and loyalty, and sense of duty, and manifold undeniable merits,” interrupted more than once by downright human tears, might have seemed to some people a fall from his (Mr. C.’s) philosophic heights. But for me, I liked him for it more than for all the philosophy that ever came out of his head.

Now, however, already, he speaks of “poor Nero” very composedly. And Charlotte, who went about, the first two days, with her face swollen and red with weeping, on the third day recovered her prettiness and cheeriness. Only myself whom the little creature belonged to, and whom he loved before
everybody and everything else, only I am still horribly sad and perplexed.Lady Ashburton replied, 15 Feb.: “There is no comfort to be given—no words of mine can make up to you for that little beastie’s faithfulness, & love—nor its touching loyalty & trust—you have lost a little life, to whom you were the Bright Star—poor Beastie! … I know all you are feeling—I have gone through it all & people may laugh as they like, but it is a real Grief—a real Loss—& you will every day miss his caresses, & his loving little ways— I am so glad Mr Carlyle shed good human tears—but he is made up of tenderness—that is what I felt most in his Nature—tho’ we scarcely exchanged 20 words— I hope some day he will let me know him—for I am a good deal in Love!” Emilie Hawkes wrote, 9 March: “Bessie told me of poor dear little Nero’s death, and I was truly and deeply grieved for you because I know by experience that few humans leave behind them such a blank as a dog that has really loved us with all its little limited loving unselfish soul.” For, what is become of that beautiful, engaging little life, with its “manifold undeniable virtues” (as Mr. C. said)? Could these be extinguished, abolished, annihilated by some drops of Prussic Acid? Is that credible? Is Prussic Acid more powerful than qualities which, found in a Human Being, the self same qualities—we call divine, immortal? “I cannot make myself believe that,” I said the other day to Lady William Russell;Lady Elizabeth Anne Russell, always called Lady William. and she whom people call “so Worldly,” (I could never see why), answered—“But why should you make yourself believe it, my good Lady? Who does believe it? I don’t.” And then she gave me her ideas about the Future of dogs, which, if not particularly well founded, were so poetical and so sympathetic to me, that I was tempted to jump up and kiss her. Luckily I didn’t; for it would have given her a dreadful fright.

All my other visitors have spoken odiously on what they call my “little bereavement.” They don’t conceive what pain they give me. Three several men,Possibly Rev. John Barlow, John George Cooke, and John Forster. the only men I am intimate with here, offered one after another to “give me another little dog.” And two women,Unidentified. of the sort called “full of sensibility,” inquired if I had “had him stuffed?” “I wonder you didn’t” said one of them plaintively, “he would have looked so pretty in a glass case in your room, and still been quite a companion to you.” Merciful Heavens! If one lived in what Mr. Carlyle calls “a sincere age of the world,” wouldn’t one take such a Comforter as that by the neck and pitch her out at the window?
The frank indifference of one’s fellow-creatures, that is a common complaint. But it is not that one suffers most from; their so called sympathy is often far worse to bear.

But why, you think, in the name of wonder, do I write always to you, my Lady? I know well enough why. It is because the Heavenly kindness in your eyes and voice, when we talked about my little dog at the Grange, has come back to me many times since, and magnetises me into these strange confidences.
But understand, I have no expectation that you should answer such a letter as this. If you read it to an end without protest it is as much as could be asked. Someday however when you have much leisure perhaps you will write me two or three lines, just to say how you feel, and when you come to Town, and how the dear wee Baby is.Mary Florence Baring was b. 26 June.

I heard from “St. Thomas” a few days since. His letter was mostly about you—all the better for that.Thomas Erskine of Linlathen was known for his piety: “his personal character was most attractive, even saintly” (Henry F. H. Henderson, Erskine of Linlathen: Selections and Biography [Edinburgh, 1899] 87–88); for earlier use of the nickname, see 24:187TC to JWC, 10 Aug. 1849, and 30:243JWC’s Journal, 17 April 1856. Erskine wrote, 6 Feb.: “Your account of the lady is excellent & most satisfactory, I am happy to believe that she fills her rather difficult place well. From what I saw here, it was quite evident to me, that the two parties stood very well with each other—having thorough confidence in each other—so that I should hope that their home will be a happy one, whether it be the centre of an applauding circle or not.”

I have so many things to thank you for, my Lady, that I really don’t know where to begin—or end. All that game, that unfailing Addiscombe hamper.Farm produce sent weekly from Addiscombe. “My Heavens!” (as Lord Ashburton used to say, as often as Mr. Carlyle says “Ah me!”) what am I to do with it all?
docBody.name: J. W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD [WDO] & JD, 15 Feb. MS: NLS 1797.24. Quot: Hansons, NE 484.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS AND JANE DODS

docBody.p:
I am so glad! so obliged to you! I don’t know when I was so pleased at anything; or so surprised at anything; or so grateful for anything!— No Valentine delivered in Chelsea yesterday, and there were many—to judge from the lateness of our Postman—Caused more enthusiasm, “I’ll be bound to say, than just this Valentine of mine! (of course you meant it for a Valentine?)—The enthusiasm commenced at the Street-door, and in the bosom of my young Maid, who took in the big letter, and whose craving after all sorts of “Compliments of the Season” for herself is hardly greater than her craving after them for me!— On the 13th of Feby gone a year, this Damsel asked me quite seriously: “do you expect many Valentines tomorrow morning Mam?“—And on my astonished negative, she merely gave her head a pretty toss, and said; “Oh!—You’ll see!“— But the next morning, after the Postman had gone
by, she came to me, exclaiming with the ruefulest look; “Not one Valentine Mam!— Neither for you nor for me!—what a shame!”

Yesterday, it was quite another story! Closely following on the Postman’s ring, the strange creature burst into my room, her eyes dancing in her head, her cheeks like roses (very pretty my maid is!) and holding out in one hand the big letter, and in the other an opened envelope with some fluttery paper thing hanging to it, she cried; “Here they are! A Valentine for both of us! and mine is such a pretty one! I hope yours will be as pretty!“— “My dear Child, I said, what nonsense!— A Valentine—for me!— Come let me see yours; mine, I can tell before opening it, is nothing but the Photograph I ordered from Caldesis”See JWC to RST, [ca. 6 Feb.]. And thereupon I took the big letter, and rather sadly tossed it on the sofa, and fell to lyrical recognition of the love knots, and doves, and orange blossoms, and other captivating details of the girl’s Valentine, which was really a most elaborate one! had cost half-a-crown at the least!— “Now if we only knew who it is from!” said the girl; “I thought at first of the young man in the City who wrote me the stupid letter; but it cant be from him, for he knows my name, and this, see; is addressed to Miss Charlotte Whoever sent it hasn’t known to put Southam—Miss Charlotte at Mrs Carlyle’s“— And she turned to me the direction on the envelope. I smiled—for the handwriting was a revealation. “Oh it is from you!” cried the girl quick to read my looks. “No not from me—but I think I know who sent it.” “Do, do tell me then.“— “Well I think the handwriting is Mr BarlowsRev. John Barlow. a little disguised.” Whereupon my young Lady commenced dancing something like a hornpipe in the room, and singing a song of triumph to it! (an odd servant to have; don’t you think? but she just suits me!) And really a Valentine from the “Chaplain to Prince Albert,” and “Secretary to the Royal Institution,” and one of the best gentlemen in London was something to turn the head of a little Maidservant; altho’, the discovery of the Authorship took away all significance from the orange blossoms (at least) Mr Barlow being an elderly married man.

You may think that elderly married men here, especially such as clap Revd on their cards and are F R SFellow of the Royal Society. besides, might be more fitly employed than in paying “delicate attentions”Coterie speech; see 34:50JWC to TC, 16 July 1858. to a servant girl—however pretty!— But it may be said, I think, of this as of most other questionabilities in the world; c’est selon [that depends]!Coterie speech; see 13:179JWC to TC, 10 July 1841. In this case, the delicate attention was meant as much for me as for her (if that make the thing any more seemly!) and then,—my goodness!—there was an amount of good nature,—of real human kindliness in it, enough to cover a multitude of such infringements of the Ceremonial
Law—” the three thousand punctualities”Coterie speech; see 33:104JWC to AHO, 24 Oct. 1857. (as the Chinese call it).— Mr Barlow had chanced to call here on that Valentine’s day a year ago, when Charlotte had been so disappointed, and I had repeated to him her naïve little words. He had remembered them till another valentine’s day came round, and determined that this time she should have her hearts desire, and I for her.

Now all the while my big letter lay on the sofa unheeded. “Just look at yours Mam,” said Charlotte at last, “I am by no means sure it isn’t a Valentine after all!” So to please her I took it up and was proceeding to break the seals when I saw the postmark Haddington! “Good gracious“—I exclaimed—“There! I told you—”! said Charlotte— Very quickly, now, I extricated the photograph—and found it as far as possible from being come “from Caldesis”! If I could still have danced a hornpipe it was now my turn to have done it; my enthusiasm having risen as high as the girls!—

And god knows it was very good for me, to have a little bit of gladness thus unexpectedly provided me—if it had been only to give a change to the train of thought I had been living and having my being in, since the death of the loyalest most devoted little companion and friend that ever woman had and lost—my dear little dog!— If you never had a dog, either of you, your friend thro all his life (eleven years) you cannot have any sympathy or even perhaps any patience, with the sorrow I feel over mine—so just pass over the cause of the sorrow—whether it be what is called “a legitimate sorrow” or not—and think; that you have come and comforted me a bit, when I was sorrowful!

As for the portraits per se, they are very like—but very far from flattering. My Recollection can touch them up a little however—so as to make them “all right”Coterie speech; see 32:63JWC to KS, 27 Dec. 1856. to my own heart at least. God bless you both

ps.p: I do wonder often and sadly how my poor old friends at SunnybankThe old name for Tenterfield, Haddington home of the Donaldson sisters; see 33:89JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857. are standing this cruel weather!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [ca. 16 Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after the receipt of the Valentine cards and the photograph of the Dodses; see JWC to WDJD, 15 Feb.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
Hurrah! My dear little woman! I call that first rate packing!— It was a pleasure taking out the beautiful large white eggs this time; independent of the
prospect of eating them. No smearing of ones fingers, as if one had been with them to the Land of Canaan of which the Child said, “Oh Mama! how sticky”! (on being told it “flowed with milk and honey”)Exod. 3:8.— Actually out of all these dozens of eggs there was not one wasted! Two were broken but not spilt—and are already down my individual throat in form of a refection called Zambaio.Zabaglione; see 35:95–96TC to LS, 17 May 1859, and 35:95–96TC to JC, 20 May 1859. Two others were slightly chipped, and behold all the damage! Clearly that is the right way to pack eggs! plenty of hay, and all by themselves. Much thanks dear Mary, from us both.

For the rest; we are “thankful to say that we are in our frail ordinar” (as my illegitimate cousinJohn Amelia (“Jackie”) Welsh. at Haddington expresses herself). And in truth even that gets to be something to feel very thankful for; after having come thro so many dreary crisises of illness as I have done of late years. Except for three weeks in November I have not been confined to the house thro all this severe winter. I never go out after dusk; but on days when there is no fall—of “old wives” or anything, I usually go out in “a Fly” or an Omnibus, or on foot even, for a couple of hours in the middle of the day, which is a great improvement on the four preceding winters and helps to keep up my heart in this weary passage thro’ The Valley of the Shadow of Frederick the Great!— Whom I am as sick of as I ever was of any thing in this world.
And his unlucky Biographer, would, I dare say, tell the same story.

Have you heard that my little Nero is dead? You saw the little creature once at Scotsbrig; but you, with your family of handsome daughters,Mary and James Austin had eight das. can have no idea, the least [in the]Inserted by TC later; TC also added: “[1860, Nero/ah dear!].” world, how fond we had become of that bit Dog. Not I only, who dont set up for having any “sound sense” to speak of; but Mr C too! He was such an affectionate, loyal, dutiful little creature! “No den[y]ing his manifold virtues”! (as Mr C said of him after his death) and he had been inseparable from me for eleven years!—and during his long illness, the patience and gentleness he showed; and the struggles he made to show his poor little love, and do all his bits of duties up to the last hour were not the less touching but I should say the more touching because he was not human, “only a dog” (as people say). I assure you Mr C cried on the day of his death!—the particulars of which I would rather not dwell on—so no wonder at my being upset. Charlotte too went about for three days with her face swollen and red with weeping. It was a luck for me that others were so affected; for it was the means of sparing me a great deal of unendurable good advice and remonstrance on the “irrationality” of my grief. Mr C naively remarked—“My Dear! I cannot rebuke you; for my own heart is most unexpectedly and
distractedly torn to pieces with the misery of the thing”!— That is it you see! What people dont happen to feel themselves, they disapprove of and “rebuke” others for feeling. When they feel the same themselves it is all right.

Imagine! Mr C got a Valentine on the 14th! the first Valentine he ever got in his life, he says!— He is beginning!—and the nature of the Valentine was as extraordinary as the idea of sending one to him. It was a handsomely “got up” little English Prayer Book!! with some verses of Scripture in a sprawling female handUnidentified. on the Fly leaf—and on the cover”

p.hi: A Valentine for dear Carlyle

docBody.p: “On whom may God’s great glories smile”

Such an absurd mixing up of things! A German friend of mine once said to me, “Ah! it is the mixing up of things that is The Great Bad”!Count Oskar von Reichenbach (b. 1815; see 32:25532:biographical note); see TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:332.— I quite agree with him!—

I too had a Valentine tho’ not calling itself one—a photograph of my first Boy-lover—with his—second wife at his side!William and Jane Dods.—so like and nice!— Charlotte had two regular magnificent Valentines—from two different GentlemenOne from John Barlow; the other sender unidentified. who visit here to whom I had told her speech to me last year; bursting into my room after the Postman had passed: “Not one Valentine! Neither for you nor for me Mam! What a shame!“— These goodnatured men had recollected this for a year! I liked Scotsbrig JamesJames Carlyle, Mary Austin’s and TC’s nephew. so much! so intelligent looking and so modest, and so kindly
kindest regards to your husband and the “world like” bairns” a kiss to yourself ever affectionately yours
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ED [EDO], [18 Feb.?]. MS: NLS 8992.204. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after Countess Pepoli’s recovery from illness (see JWC to MR, [28 Jan.]) and before George Rennie’s death, 22 March.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA DONALDSON

docBody.p:
I do think the Devil has taken your visits here under his especial charge! To think of your again coming in vain—so early too!— There is one practical inference to be drawn that I should never represent myself as findable at
certain hours; the fact being that, at this season of the year, I am what old Thomas Erskine called one of the Lady Oglvies,JWC is probably referring to the four das. of David Ogilvy (1785–1849), 6th earl of Airlie, and Clementina Drummond Ogilvy (d. 1835): Jean Graham Drummond (1818–1902), Clementina Drummond (1819–48), Maria Anne (1827–93), and Helen Susanna Catherine Gertrude (1831–63).—“an extremely accidental sort of young woman“—

When I came home the other day Charlotte received me with “Oh Dear! Countess Pepoli ‘has been here and was in such a passion’!“— “Passion! at what?” “Why she said you had told her you always dined at 3! and then Mr Barlow came and showed me his watch and made it repeat 4 (such a curious watch!) and said; “there! you see it is half past 4, and Mrs Carlyle told me she never staid out later than 4!”

But how can I help it—living in a conditional world?— I wish to be regular, and I aim at keeping times—but alas! one’s “wishes are “not” presentiments of one’s powers!”One of JWC’s phrases; cf. 16:82TC to UC, 13 March 1843, and 29:36JWC to WA, 1 March 1854. tho’ it is so pretended by conceited moralists!

Yesterday I was gone to early dinner (in my sense to luncheon in the Lady’s) with a friend at Rutland GatePresumably Ellen Twisleton, who lived at 3 Rutland Gate.—and was to call first at a house in Prince’s GateLouisa and Lydia Emily Baring lived at 23 Prince’s Gate.—so I needed to be off betimes— And I am afraid you did not get even a rest much [less]Word omitted. a warm—for Charlotte when I questioned her, said, she could not ask you up to the Drawing room where there was a good fire, because there was a gentlemanUnidentified. there waiting for Mr Carlyle on business— I dare say he (the gentleman) would have been comforted rather than otherwise by a pretty female face to relieve his ennui I am quite regretful—and would be remorseful as well,—if I did not consider remorse at all times a wasteful sentiment.

Instead of writing I would have gone to Craven HillEliza’s mother, Betty Donaldson, lived at 21 Craven Hill, Bayswater. on Monday had I not been engaged to the Rennies at York TerraceGeorge and Jane Rennie lived at 32 York Ter., Regent’s Park.—but I will try to find you soon— The news Charlotte gave me of Miss Donaldson seemed to good to be true— Oh my Goodness! If you and I should sit together beside her again after all!Eliza’s aunt Jean Donaldson d. 30 March. It makes me so glad even to think of this as a bare possibility Love to you all
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [20 Feb.]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 20 Feb. 1860. MS: NLS 553.214. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I am in the bottom of the Slough of Despond,Cf. John Bunyan, Pilgrim’s Progress. weltering and labouring what I can for life,—beyond speech!

Of this Note I have only read the first line & the signature (unknown to me);TC wrote on the reverse of a letter written in German from Angelika von Lagerström (1812–79); a German political exile in London since 1852, she supported herself by teaching and writing; she was a colleague of Baroness Malwida von Meysenbug (1816–1903; ODNB), who initially described her as “alone and friendless, eating the bread of exiles” (trans.; von Meysenbug, Ein Leben für die Anderen. Aus den “Memoiren einer Idealisten“ [Berlin, 1953] 295). Von Lagerström wrote that it was refreshing to read that TC, as Schiller’s biographer, was so loved and admired in Germany that he had been honored during the centenary celebrations of Schiller’s birth; for the award of the Order of the White Falcon on 10 Nov. 1859, see TC to JMJMA, 14 Nov. 1859. of the sublime “Rede [Address]”Von Lagerström wrote that she was enclosing a “splendid piece” (untraced). not even a line.— Throw the two into the fire,Von Lagerström asked TC “to return this well-traveled piece.” if you don’t care to read them first. And pray for me!—
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 24 Feb. MS: NLS 607.539B. Pbd: Carlyle, NLM 2:223–25 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 483; Wilson 5:381–82 (where he identifies the letter wrongly as to her paternal aunt Grace Welsh).
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: If you are going to make a jacket, the sooner you have the pattern the betterJWC had offered to send a pattern of the jacket she had made; see JWC to MR, [28 Jan.].—for the sooner you begin, as I know, you will be the sooner ended. So I won’t put off more time, waiting for a day of leisure enough to write you a good long letter; but take my chances of interruption, which are rather many just now—

I wish I was beside you, to help you with the jacket; in the way of delivering a lecture on the paper illustration, you will need some directions and I must
give them as well as I can at this distance In the first place, a reflective woman like you must have noticed without telling that the effect of these jackets, so popular of late years, depends mostly on the trimming. If your jacket is to be of black material it should either be trimmed with a colour or with jet or something to make a marked contrast to the body of the thing. The one I made of black silk is corded all round with scarlet silk and then, about half an inch from the edge, a tartan velvet ribbon is run on plain— That sounds intelligible enough? But you must further observe that the seam which joins the front part to the side should be left open for about two inches at the bottom (you will see where I have put crosses on the paper) and then your ribbon, or whatever trimming you use, must be conducted neatly round the opening: The sleeves should have the seam turned more to the front, about an inch, than is usual in the sleeves of a gown, and left open to within some three inches of the top—having a row of small buttons on one side and loops on the other to close it up if required The same process of cording and trimming is “carried out” of course on the sleeve—but the trimming must be taken up the sleeve on both sides of the seam as well as round the sleeve. Decidedly my talent does not lie in the way of drawing for The Magazine of Fashion!For JWC’s diagrams that illustrate her meaning, see oppabove.; JWC’s first diagram is below, her second above. That my Dear is meant for the side of the sleeve turned to the public— And now God be with you and good speed to you!

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle to Mary Russell, 24 February [1860] (detail 1)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle to Mary Russell, 24 February [1860] (detail 2)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
For the rest; I am still not laid up, but going out for a drive twice a week and sometimes for a short walk But if I am less ill than usual this winter, I am more than usually sorrowful. For I have lost my dear little companion of eleven years standing. My little Nero is dead. And the grief his death has caused me has been wonderful even to myself. His Patience, and gentleness, and loving struggle to do all his bits of duties under his painful illness, up to the last hour of his life, was very strange and touching to see, and had so endeared him to every body in the House, that I was happily spared all reproaches for “wasting so much feeling on a dog.” Mr C couldnt reproach me; for he himself was in tears at the poor little things end! and his own heart (as he phrased it) was “most unexpectedly and distractedly torn to pieces with it“— As for Charlotte she went about for three days after with her face all swollen and red with weeping. But on the fourth day she got back her good looks and gay spirits—and much sooner Mr C had got to speak of “poor Nero” composedly enough! Only to me, whom he belonged to, and whom he preferred to all living, does my dear wee dog remain a constantly recurring blank, and a thought of strange sadness! What is become of that little beautiful graceful Life, so full of love and loyalty and sense of duty, up to the last moment that it animated the body of that little dog? Is it to be extinguished,
abolished, annihilated in an instant; while the brutalized, two legged, socalled human creature who dies in a ditch, after having outraged all duties, and caused nothing but pain and disgust to all concerned with him, is to live forever? It is impossible for me to believe that!— I couldn’t help saying so in writing to my Aunt GraceGrace Welsh. and expected a terrible lecture for it— But not so! Grace, who had been fond of my little dog, couldn’t find in her heart to speak unkindly on his subject—nay actually gave me a reference to certain verses in Romans which “seemed” to warrant my belief in the immortality of animal life as well as humanPossibly Rom. 8:21–39.—

The thing is sure anyhow; my little dog is buried at the top of our garden—and I grieve for him as if he had been my little human child.Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 10 March: “Poor Mrs Carlyle has lost Nero wh is a great sorrow.” Edward Sterling “took her the most charming little dog to console her & she refused it” (MS: Mantell 85:322:2).
Love to the DrDr. James Russell.—and a kiss to yourself. Affectionately yours / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 26 Feb. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Vernon Lushington (1832–1912; ODNB), lawyer, friend of TC; see 32:biographical note.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p:
I could and would, with a great deal of pleasure, be of your Dinner Party;Lushington and his twin brother, Godfrey (1832–1907; ODNB) were holding a dinner party to celebrate their birthday on 8 March. but alas, we are fallen even lower since you saw us:Lushington wrote to Joanna Richardson, [26 Feb.]: “I had such a long evening with [TC] a little while back, with talk about many things, ‘sudden death,’ ‘modern unbelief or doghood,’ Valentine’s day, & the whole story of Valentine & Orson,—some part of which I duly got down on paper afterwards for my satisfaction in aftertimes. He spoke so kindly of your father; ‘innocent-hearted,’ he called him, and said if he ‘were not so chained up to his Prussian matters’ he wd pay you all a visit at Kirklands, & hoped some day really to do so. Mrs. C. is better this winter than for several years back. But she gave me an account of her daily life, which struck me as very sad,—so lonely it seemed to be—breakfast in silence, dinner separate, & he absorbed in his work; out of reach of fireside talk” (MS: NLS 3990; pbd: K. J. Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 17). Isabella Helen Richardson (b. 1821) and Joanna Baillie Richardson (1831–1900), and their father, John Richardson (1780–1864; ODNB; see 21:137TC to JAC, 17 Jan. 1847), were also asked to the dinner. Richardson, an old friend of the Carlyles, parliamentary solicitor who retired 1860 to the family home of Kirklands, Roxburghshire. For a dinner with him that the Carlyles and Lushington attendedin 1856, see 30:256JWC’s Journal, 19 June 1856. my Wife has at last caught
a cold; and as to self, the Prussian Rubbish so breaks my heart, I have been obliged, at any rate, to deny myself all such Recreations in the sad months that run.
Perhaps I shall one day get out of this bad pass, and be more at liberty to enjoy my friends.
With many kind regards, and wishes for happy years to your good Brother and yourself.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: This by accident was not written yesterday;Lushington told Joanna Richardson that answers to his invitation were “to come tomorrow morning,” i.e., Mon., 27 Feb. (MS: NLS 3990). whh I much regret.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CB [CBU], 28 Feb. MS: EUL. Pbd: Southern 271–72 inc. “No. 13.” has been written at the top of the letter, possibly by Butler.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES BUTLER

docBody.p: Last night the Postman duly delivered me your Letter of the 10th ult., with its valuable inclosures;Writing from New York, 10 Feb., Butler sent TC a check for £42 12s. 6d., together with a certificate of purchase for $5,000 worth of bonds of the Chicago & North Western Railway Co., bought for TC, 1 Aug. 1859. Butler had explained, 17 Aug. 1859: “Hereafter your interest will accrue on 1 Feby & 1 Augt 7% on $7000 … $245 each semi annual remittance” (Kimball 288). all perfectly exact and as they should be. You are a model of punctuality; and certainly have been and are the kindest and wisest of Managers in these matters for me. It is also, to my imagination if not otherwise, a considerable solace that you now send a visible and tangible Paper Document with a red star on it: this I can lock henceforth in a safe drawer; and leave the matter to sleep, with entire composure upon it, as a thing fixed like the old rocks. Again permit me to thank you very much;—and to say that when I get more money, you shall again be asked to lay it by for me.

We probably got some benefit out of our long Scotch rustication last year:TC wrote in his Journal, 3 Oct. 1859: “Returned Saturday night [1 Oct.] … from a long miscellaneous sojourn in Scotland … whh has lasted very idly, and not too comfortably since the last days of June. … Bathing, solitary riding, walking. … Perhaps both of us are a little better; one cannot hope, much” (Froude, Carlyle 4:236). See also 35:223–24TC to JAC, 3 Oct. 1859. at least my Wife has been perceptibly better all thro’ Winter; and has never (till just now, I hope only slightly) had one fit of cold, which used to be so unkind to her. I myself am not above par, indeed, rather below; but that has its special causes,—or rather one great cause: my baleful Prussian Enterprise;
whh, as it approaches completion,Butler wrote: “the last two volumes of Frederick have been read in my family circle with absorbing interest and gratification and we shall look for the forthcoming third volume with quickened desire” (Kimball 289). Frederick was not finished until Feb. 1865. presses harder and harder; and declares itself, sometimes quite aloud, to be altogether an impossible problem!— There is no use in complaining about it; one remedy there is, and only one, Stand to it, and either die or compel it to be doable! I dare not set any time; but it seems to me always, if I could hold out about another twelvemonth, I might see myself freed from the most intolerable millstone that was ever hung round a poor creature’s neck,—and shd thenceforth swim with a great deal more of buoyancy and levity till I got to port. “Hope springs eternal in the human breast,”See Alexander Pope, “An Essay on Man” 1:95.—this is indeed the “Place of Hope.”See Tarr, Sartor 121. All people are greatly agog about Gladstone’s Budget;Butler wrote, 10 Feb.: “it seems to me as if the Emperor … would give … a mighty impulse to commercial and industrial activities throughout Europe—that his programme of reform, in abolishing or modifying the restrictive & prohibitory system which has so fettered France and establishing such free interchange with England will earn for him greater fame than all his great battles” (Kimball 289–90). Gladstone’s budget speech, 10 Feb., dealt with a commercial treaty with France, to be in force for ten years, in which France engaged “to reduce the duty on English coal and coke … pig-iron and steel … on tools and machinery … and on yarn and goods in flax and hemp” (Hansard 832). In exchange England engaged “to reduce the duty on brandy … [and] on foreign wine” (Hansard 834). Defending the treaty, Gladstone argued, “What we have done is good—nay, doubly good,—good for ourselves if France had done nothing at all, doubly good because France has done a great deal” (Hansard 843).—interested too, as I frequently notice, that you have at last got “a Speaker” (may he speak to the purpose!) after so long waiting.William Pennington (1796–1862), Republican congressman from New Jersey, was elected Speaker of the House of Representatives, 1 Feb., after two months of bitter debate and 44 ballots. The Times commented, 17 Feb.: “The Congress of the United States has for the last two months presented a spectacle by no means edifying to those who are determined to see nothing but what is excellent on the other side of the Atlantic.” Although the Republicans were the largest single party in the House, they did not hold an overall majority, and the delay was caused by the conflicting positions of the political parties over the constitutional implications of slavery (although none of the parties wanted to split the union). In 1855–56 the election of a Speaker had taken two months and 133 ballots.— I send many compliments from wife & self; and am ever, Yours sincerely T. Carlyle

ps.p: HereFrom “Here” is written on a separate piece of paper. is my “Autograph,” with best wishes, in very great haste.
ps.name: T. Carlyle
ps.p: Chelsea, 28 feby, 1860–

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 5 March. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 5 March 1860. MS: NLS 553.215. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—It is tragical and also shameful to say, I write to you again abt that beggarly affair of the Reference to PertzGeorg Heinrich Pertz (1795–1876), German historian, chief librarian in the Royal Lib., Berlin, from 1842. about Wilha’s Book.Mémoires de Frédérique Sophie Wilhelmine de Prusse, margrave de Bareith, soeur de Frédéric-le-Grand, escrits de sa main, 2 vols. (Paris, 1811); see Works 12:320. I have lost yr little slip of writing (as I have done the Book itself); laid it by so well that I cannot find it again!— But at any rate, it was not quite what I wanted. Berlin Academy Transactns (vol, place, year, then Title of Pertz),Pertz had discovered “a few insignificant pages” of a continuation of Mémoires de Frédérique Sophie Wilhelmine and discussed them in Über die Denkwürdigkeiten der Markgräfin von Bayreuth (Transactions, Academy of Sciences, Berlin, 1850); see Works 14:385. that was the thing. Oh let us be patient,—patt!

In an old more importt note of yours (abt the Populatn &c at Frh’s Accession)See TC to JN, 23 Jan. you cite Preuss, “Frh’s Jugend-Geschichte“:Neuberg conflated two titles, J. D. E. Preuss, Friedrichs des Grossen Jugend und Thronbesteigung: Eine Jubelschrift (Berlin, 1840), described as “a minor Book of Preuss’s” in Works 14:286, and Die Lebensgeschichte des grossen Königs Friedrich von Preussen: Ein Buch für Jedermann (Berlin, 1837), the book Neuberg meant; see Works 14:307.—I have never seen that Book; nor definitely heard of it: Do you mean Thronbesteigung [accession to the throne]? If so your paging is wrong. “Place, date, page” (pray fix that beggarly affair too, so that we may have done with it for the Eternity to come!)—
I have unluckily picked up a baddish cold; tho’ I hope (since sunrise), it is slightly getting better, it of itself wd lay a veto on Wedy Evg.

I do, at a snail’s pace, make some half-visible kind of way in the Awful Rubbish mound ahead. Courage! To extract a respectable Brother Mortal out of the like of that, and set him visibly on his feet,—there too is an Enterprise (little short of the 7-years War, on present terms!),—had one been young enough for it.
Enough, send these two unutterably important particles of reference,—and let us preserve our sanity.
I hope you will bring a right horse or Cob,—pony will not quite do.Presumably Neuberg intended riding with TC.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 15 March. MS: John Rylands Univ. Lib., Univ. of Manchester. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin” 216; Cate 84–85.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: The door had no sooner closed on you than the maid brought in her Cigar Box,—the Third I have had from that cornucopia of a House: a shame to think of! This is what may be called cigarring a man for his difficult adventure, as they talk of “Coaling” a Steamer to go thro’ high seas. Fact is, I am not yet half way thro’ the First Box; tho’ I carry something of it daily in my pocket; and the Horse of himself pauses at the fit places, inviting me to smoke and be thankful. I can only say, and think, you are very good.

The new Dürer is hung up in fine light, and I study to make acquaintance with it before it return home. The invincible grave simple Ritter, industriously riding on his way,Ruskin had lent TC a copy of an engraving by Albrecht Dürer, German painter and engraver, “Ritter, Tod, und Teufel [Knight, Death, and Devil]” (1513).
