Ruskin described the knight: “He rides quietly, his bridle firm in his hand, and his lips set close in a slight sorrowful smile, for he hears what Death is saying; and hears it as the word of a messenger who brings pleasant tidings, thinking to bring evil ones” (Modern Painters [1857–60] 5:243). Geraldine Jewsbury presumably saw the print, as she wrote to Walter Mantell, 18 Jan.: “Carlyle is grim as Albert Dürers Knight riding thro’ the forest & dogged by Devils—he is ill to live with just now Frederick does so disagree with him” (MS: Mantell 85:322:3). with such a load of sorrow whh he makes not the least complaint of, pleases me more and more;—less and less am I pleased with his two detestable companions;“Beside him, but a little in advance, rides Death on a pale horse. … Behind him follows Sin; but Sin is powerless; he has been conquered and passed by, but follows yet” (Ruskin, Modern Painters 5:243). who, I incline to think, lie beyond and below the real domain of Art, tho’ they are very true to Nature too, and attend every man, tragically visible to him, if not to others. The Picture I guess to have no other meaning than that universal symbolical one.— Of the other Dürers which you shewed us,Ruskin wrote to JWC, [3 Dec. 1859]: “I have been looking over my Durer’s and find an impression of the melancholia … [and] can only hope Mr. Carlyle may think it worth placing in a house where so much noble work has been done. … The next time I come, I will bring a number of Durers with me, to look over—I am so selfish as to want to hear what Mr. Carlyle says of them.” Dürer was one of the first artists to portray melancholy as philosophical and artistic suffering rather than just miserable laziness. JWC evidently appreciated the engraving, as a few days later Ruskin wrote: “I am so very glad you liked the things … for indeed the Melancholy is not exactly likeable. What it means—no one knows. ‘Cavernous meaning’ is just the word for it. / In the main, it evidently means the full sense of the terror-mystery—turmoil—responsibility of the world, ending in great awe & sadness—and perpetual labour. … Strong bodied. Having the Keys of all knowledge” (early Dec. 1859). Dürer, “Melancholia” (1514). the Scarlet
Woman,“The Whore of Babylon” from The Apocalypse (1498). with the flames bursting out, and the universe all going to live rubbish (like a cheese to mites) under her guidance,—is the most vivid in my memory; but by far the most pleasant there, is St. Hubert“St. Eustace,” commonly misidentified as “St. Hubert” (ca. 1501). in the primeval woods of Liège; so beautifully sculptured out, he and they, and what they contain for a devout simple heart. Excellent pious Dürer; who made himself an ornament to this world, in his day and generation!Popular phrase; see 35:6TC to JCHA, 7 Jan. 1859.—

I wish you were not going off in May to paint pine needles!Ruskin, exhausted after finishing Modern Painters, left the final publishing details to his father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), and went to Chamouni (Chamonix) in the French Alps to walk and to draw; see E. T. Cook, Life of Ruskin (1911) 2:2–3. Are there not plenty of unpainted needle-woods and beautiful umbrageous creations nearer home? ‘The finest trees that grow in the Temperate Zone’ stand all about, not far from Denmark-Hill, I am told! Cor inquietum est [The heart is restless].
I expect to ride out again, in the interim, some day soon.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: Emilie Hawkes wrote to JWC, 9 March, from Italy: “on the top of the highest hill in the neighbourhood of Florence, and if the constant cruel wind would allow, [I] should be in daily enjoyment of the most uninterrupted and lovely panorama imaginable, the city at our feet and the Appenines around of a lovely fertile plain bounded on one side by the Maritime Alps—but the North wind, snow and neuralgia combine to prevent me from profiting thereby as I ought. … Dear Jane do write me an egotistical letter! I want to know everything about yourself, and how you are physically and morally. I do nothing, think nothing, paint nothing, and even read nothing. … But I want a letter so much—and it has to be all about yourself and trifles mind—the small trifles that alas! Make the sum of human things. … Tell me above all things of your health—tell me do you see Mr Ruskin? and have flowers from him still? When will his 5th Vol appear. I think I should revive if I could have it to read and not be quite so stupid again. Does Charlotte continue satisfactory? if so give her my kindest remembrances— Does Mr Carlyle know who I am? if so, I would fain be remembered to him. … I hope in the spring my intellect will thaw— Even in the cold though I am still your loving friend / Emilie.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-[RH], 17 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee presumably Robert Harrison, librarian of the London Lib.
div3.head: TC TO [ROBERT HARRISON]

docBody.p:
I will, as I am bound to do on demand of any subscriber, return the Three Voll. of LloydGen. Henry Humphry Evans Lloyd (1718?–83), army officer and military writer. The 2d edn. (1781) of History of the Late War in Germany, between the King of Prussia, and the Empress of Germany and Her Allies (1766) included Reflections on the Principles and Art of War (also known as Political and Military Memoirs); a 2d vol. was compiled from Lloyd’s papers after his death (1784). The London Lib. had a three vol. edn., as its catalog (1847) listed it as History of the Seven Years’ War in Germany, 3 vols. (1781–90). tomorrow; on whh you will have command over them for the
time given in the Rules.The London Lib. specified in its regulations: “If application is made for any book which has been taken out two months before, the Librarian shall give notice to the subscriber who has borrowed the book to return it; and the subscriber shall return the same within one week from the issuing of notice, if he is resident within ten miles, and within a fort-night, if more than ten miles” (Catalogue of the London Library, ed. John George Cochrane, 2d edn. [1847] xii).— I never heard of “Lloyd’s Life of Friedh”; and suspect it does not exist.Untraced.

The best part of yr news is, that certain British Officers are now expected to read and study Lloyd. It is a shame, and has long been, that any British Officer, or any one who has more intellect than his Horse, shd not have read Lloyd, and earnestly considered and laid to heart what he will find there!

closer.salute: In very great haste / Yrs sincerely /

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 18 March. Addr: Elm Cottage / Old-Brompton Road. PM: London, 1860. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—You may put thisUnidentified. into plain writing (guess on the French sentence), and leave it here any day soon,—in case it shd come to me when the Proofs arrive.
docBody.name: T. C. (18 March

ps.p: Get me a Copy of that Day-of-the-week IndicatorTC either meant a perpetual calendar for his historical dating or a current calendar such as “De la Rue’s Red Letter Diaries and Calendars for 1860. To be had at all Booksellers and Stationers,” advertised in Illustrated London News, 4 Feb. as soon as you like!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF [EFO] , [20 March]. Addr: 46 Montague Square. PM: London, 21 March, 1860. MS: NLS 1797.28. Quot: Hansons 484–85. Dated the same day as Jane Rennie’s letter to JWC, Tues., 20 March; see JWC to GDI, 23 March .
div3.head:
JWC
TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p: I was going to you tomorrow with all gladness— But I have just received a note which will take me in another direction—and leaves me no spirits for any pleasure—

My oldest friend is at the point of deathGeorge Rennie d. 22 March. TC wrote in blue pencil above “death”: “George Rennie (Sculptor, M. P., Govr of Falkld Islds &c).” Rennie’s obituary in the Illustrated London News, 14 April , noted: “The country has lost in him a truly efficient and faithful public servant” (356). ILN also published his picture, 14 April; see 86 above .— I shall go immediately after breakfast tomorrow and stay to help his wife if she will let me Jane Rennie and JWC had been cool toward each other in the past; see 7:253 JWC to EA, Aug. 1843
, and 30:247–48 JWC’s Journal, 26 April 1856
. —
If I do not get staid, and find any betterness, I will come round by you after, for a look of dear Mr MacreadyWilliam Macready was a close friend of the Forsters.— But don’t expect me for Luncheon—
I am so stirred I don’t know what I am writing

figure.p: George Rennie
Illustrated London News, 14 April 1860

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GD [GDI], 23 March. Addr: The Terrace, Belford, Northumberland. PM: 24 March 1860. Copy: EUL. Pbd: Ireland, JWC 260–62; Fielding and Sorensen 249–50 inc. Quot: Hansons NE 485; Surtees, JWC 243. The copy was made by William Maddam, Sandgate, Berwick-on-Tweed, and sent to D. G. Ritchie, 26 Aug. 1889: “The original is in the hands of Grace Rennie’s daughter & it was temporarily in my hands for perusal & the enclosed is a careful copy” (MS: EUL). Ireland’s text is probably from the original letter (transcribed “with reverence”), shown her by Grace Rennie’s grand-da., Mrs. Anthony F. Nichol, Bradford House, Belford, Northumberland (Ireland, JWC 260 and v—vi). Text: copy in EUL; PM and address: Ireland, JWC.
div3.head: JWC TO GRACE DINNING

docBody.p:
My dear “Grace Rennie” of long ago— It must be something like 40 years since I saw your sweet face or had any exchange of words with you! Still I recollect you well and kindly— I wonder if you have any recollection of me? Of the little Jeanie Welsh you were all so kind to, and your nephew George so much in love with?— At least you will recollect my name, and the fact of my
existence when recalled to you by this letter and you will recollect my beautiful Mother, who was so fond of you!

Well-after all this lifetime I am writing to you! Not to recall myself to your mind, but to tell you what you ought to be told—not merely officially, but with some words of sympathy and detail. George—your George Rennie and my George Rennie is dead! died yesterday morning at six o’clock,—having been insensible from the previous sunday. By a strange fatality it was I who watched by him thro’ his last night on Earth! I, his first love, who received his last breath and closed his eyes! Was it not a strange sad thing! After so many
separations—so many tossings up and down this weary wearyWord repeated on turn of page. earth! His wife wrote to me on Tuesday that he was at the point of death and I “as his oldest friend should know it.” God bless her for that thought—death abolishes all forms and ceremonies; so I went to her at once, and begged to be let stay—She granted my petition; indeed, she was quite worn out with sleeplessness and anxiety, and was needing the help of one [who]Apparently omitted by JWC, because omitted on copy and bracketed in Ireland, JWC. could give it with such fellow feeling as I could— After that I never left him till all was over— He never was conscious for an instant,—but still it was a satisfaction to have been with him at the last. Mrs Rennie begged me to stay with her; she was so desolate! tho’ she bears up bravely—and I was willing for his sake to be of any earthly use to her, so long as my husband will spare me from my own house.

If I saw you I could tell you much about George, that you would like to hear—but just now I am so sorrowful and tired, that I must content myself with saying, tho’ he kept up no intercourse with his relations it was not from a cold or changed heart—a few weeks before his death I spoke to him about that part of his conduct which displeased me, and found that pride, reserve, his soured temper about the world was at the bottom of it allSee JWC to WDWDO, [30 Nov. 1859].—he spoke affectionately of his Aunt Grace and said he would take takeWord repeated on turn of page. the first opportunity of going to see her—“would do many things too long neglected could he only get rid of these depressing headaches that made his life miserable“—

I think you will like to know this was his intention tho’ never to be fulfilled! and I offered to RichardRichard Temple Rennie. to write the letter he would else have written himself to tell you of his Father’s death—that along with the news you might receive the comfort to your good heart—(It cannot have changed from the heart I knew it) which the assurance of his Kind feeling towards you is calculated to give and which I only, perhaps, had heard from him. Never was there a man, as I told him then, who did himself more injustice— I believe he had the warmest, truest heart, but it was incased in pride & distrust of others affection for him making it of no use to them or himself.JWC apparently also wrote to Thomas Erskine about George Rennie’s death, as Erskine wrote to her, 4 July: “It is the most tender & touching romance I ever heard—I wish he had had five minutes consciousness—he might have thought that all the intermediated history was a dream, & that he had been all along living a quite different life. … What strange things these lives of ours are! … that you should be the sole human witness of the ebbing out of that breath! … one asks why was this so arranged by the great arranger?—There is something most intensely sweet & sad in it.”
God bless you.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

ps.p: If you would write me a line some day wouldnt I like to hear of you from yourself— I never passed thro’ Darlington in coming or going to Scotland without thinking “wasnt it in this neighbourhood that Grace Rennie went to live” I dare say you will hardly be able to read this scrawl—I am so tired!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-RG & Co. [RGAC], 26 March. MS: BL. Hitherto unpbd. Richard Griffin & Co., publishers, booksellers, stationers, chemists, and dealers in philosophical apparatus, 39–41 West Nile St., Glasgow, was run by Charles Griffin (1819–62) from 1852. Its London address was 10 Stationers’ Hall Court, London. Although apparently addressed to the firm generally, TC’s letter was presumably in reply to Griffin’s letter; see n. 1.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD GRIFFIN & CO.

docBody.p: Thanks for your civility, for your wish to be exact. I am sorry to say I have quite lost that Piece you sent me;The preface (dated Nov. 1860) to A Dictionary of Contemporary Biography: A Handbook of the Peerage of Rank, Worth, and Intellect. Containing Memoirs of Nearly One Thousand Eminent Living Individuals, ed. Charles Griffin (Glasgow: Richard Griffin, 1861) noted that the editor “took the liberty of addressing a communication to every individual whose name is introduced in the volume. … We stated that we wished to produce a trustworthy work, endeavouring to avoid, as far as possible, matters of opinion … and that we therefore respectfully requested replies regarding points of fact. Our communications have been generally responded to.”—being then, and indeed still, extremely occupied with other pressing things.The conclusion to the entry on TC noted: “His latest work, ‘The Life of Frederick the Great,’ partakes at once of his failings and his genius, but is still as interesting as, and more instructive than, a romance. Few authors have been better abused, and more admiringly upheld, than Carlyle, but his influence over contemporary literature continues powerful” (87). Please to proceed as if I had read it, and had put imprimatur upon whatever you found right.The entry was inaccurate about TC’s marriage: “In 1825 Mr. Carlyle married Miss Veitch, a lady of cultivated tastes and much literary ability, and he shortly afterwards proceeded to Craigenputtock, a small farm in the moors of Dumfriesshire” (86). JWC had presumably been confused with her friend Agnes Veitch (or Vetch) (b. 1801; see 33:36JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1857) or one of her three sisters. The Carlyles m. 1826.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 27 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
I should need no “tempting,” I should need only permitting; were it not, alas, that I am in the House of Bondage, and tied hand and foot. The Printer
is upon me,Unexplained, as TC had claimed to have stopped printing in Feb.; see TC to JN, [3 Feb.].—worse than any Pharoah;—and daily there is the tale of bricks to do, not so much as stubble procurable,See Exod. 5; see also 35:7TC to JN, 7 Jan 1859. for most part!— My life is dark, and a burden, these many years, with an unprofitable, hideously undoable Task; and the rule has to be, “Either die or get it done.” Inch by inch, it surely will one day be got shoved away;—then, like Sicily from EnceladusEnceladus, wounded giant of Greek mythology, buried under Mt. Etna in Sicily; his struggles to break out were thought to cause volcanic eruptions. with the one Eye, there will such a load lift itself; and one will be free, and belong to friends, and to repose, for the remainder of life! This seems poetic description; but it is more sadly prosaic and allied to fact than you are aware of.

For above a week, the accompany-volumeUnidentified. (whh I picked from a stall not long since) has lain wrapt up for you,—in hopes your Highland heart might leap up into some interest over it here and there, if you would consent to read it. There wanted only the three words of Note to write along with it;—and there it has lain till now. Judge of the hurry I am kept in;—and how this black element has demoralised me, almost into total worthlessness; unable to write three simple words!— Read the old Book at yr leisure, I advise,—or his Lordship and you together;—there is a strange meaning for one, in those poor old indubitabilities of domestic fact, scattered like live sparks in the void Night of Time past.

Please tell his Lordship I have been longing for some Note from him,—something of Historical, of Prospective:—we looked to the “end of February”;TC had expected Lord Ashburton to be in London late Feb.; see TC to Lord A.LOA, 4 Feb. but, tho’ disappointed, were obliged to confess that it was probably most wise. Say farther that there has been no want of diligence about the Prints (Candover, The GrangeThe manor of Chilton Candover in Hampshire belonged to Lord Ashburton, as did The Grange. &c); on the contrary much hunting by my neighbour here;Probably Alexander Gilchrist. Walter White (1811–93; ODNB) recalled a visit to Cheyne Row, 16 March: “To Chelsea to tea with Alexander Gilchrist at 8 p.m. Went next door to call on Thomas Carlyle. Found him in his long dressing-gown, and his wife in the drawing-room represented by Tait in his ‘Chelsea interior.’ Tea on table, opposite the fire the large picture, a gift of Lord Ashburton’s, showing the infant king of Prussia in the garden, as engraved in a frontispiece to the ‘Life of Frederick.’ … I was struck by Thomas’ youthful and fresh-coloured appearance, remarkable in a man of sixty-three. Talk having arisen about an abortive search for engravings of Lord Ashburton’s seats, he took down a volume of ‘Beauties of England and Wales,’ and read part of the description of Highclere, which becomes so rapturous over the charming scenery that we all laughed. … His face was a good study while he read, wearing no spectacles, shadows thrown on one cheek, bushy eyebrows, moustache and beard masking the massive underlip. A cheerful tone of voice, the more reason by its occasional manifestations of native Scottish” (Walter White, The Journals of Walter White [1898] 130–31). E. W. Brayley and J. Britton, The Beauties of England and Wales, 18 vols. (1801–15); Highclere, which belonged to Lord Carnarvon, is described in vol. 6, which covers Hampshire and Herefordshire (237–41). For TC in his dressing gown, see 33:174TC to JAC, 28 Jan. 1858; for Tait’s A Chelsea Interior, see 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March 1858. who has an excellt nose in such matters; but seems now
nearly reduced to his last shift,—and “after trying in Soane’s Museum,”Sir John Soane (1753–1837), architect and collector, presented his house, museum, and lib., 12–14 Lincoln’s Inn Fields, to the nation in 1833. fears he will have to give it up as desperate.— — Take care of yourself, if you wd be kind to all yr friends.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GD [GDI], [31 March]. Addr: The Terrace, Belford, Northumberland. PM: 31 March, 1860. Copy: EUL. Pbd: Ireland, JWC 262–64 inc. William Maddam sent D. G. Ritchie the copy 27 Sept. 1891; it is not in his handwriting, although he had corrected it and inserted a few missing words. Ireland had seen the original; see JWC to GDI, 23 March.
div3.head: JWC TO GRACE DINNING

docBody.p: I should like to put my arms round your neck and give you a hearty kiss! It is such a pleasure to meet with anyone in this changeful world whom one can recognise for the same after forty years! and you look out of that letter on me the same Grace Rennie that was such a favorite in my old home! Not that if we should see one another face to face, we should not, I daresay, be mutually struck with a certain sorrowful wonder at the alteration in our appearance, for “Eh siree”! as the old Airshire Lady said, on meeting after a life time the companion of her youth, “Eh siree”! Forty years maks a great odds on a girl!Coterie speech; see 28:86TC tp MAC, 25 March 1835. In outward appearance yes; none of us can carry off an additional forty years without a “great odds” being perceptible to “the naked eye.” But, thank God! there are people—not many—but a few who do continue to keep their inner selves the same—who wont let years get into their hearts and minds, to carry on any hardening, deteriorating process there! and you are such a one, dear Grace, I could swear from your letter to me! and also from my recollection of your Eyes! it wasn’t what is called “the Devils beauty”Cf. “la beauté du diable,” Honoré de Balzac, La Vieille Fille (Paris, 1836) 311. (youth) that your eyes were so beautiful with! but the beauty that comes of a loving honest heart!—

I have not seen your “Henry” nor heard of him.Grace Dinning’s son, Henry. Please to give him my address yourself (it is written at the top of this sheet) I daresay they would
not give themselves much trouble about it at York Terrace.The Rennies’ house.— Tell him moreover that after four is the surest time for finding me and that a Chelsea Omnibus will bring him to within a few yards of my door— I shall like so much to see him!

I would have stayed with Mrs Rennie till after the funeral, if I had not felt myself falling ill, But I was warned by a beginning of sore throat, on Saturday, to get home before worse befell me and the apprehensions which the mere mention of “sorethroat” inspired her with, made Mrs Rennie more than willing to let me go. So I returned home on Saturday afternoon, and having devoted the two following days to a sick headache, which the sorethroat had turned to. I went back to York Terrace on Tuesday to see if I were still needed; No! Not at all! Mrs Rennie’s mood had veered round in the interval from soft to hard; her wants were no longer such as I could supply nor her topics such as I could sympathise in, So having merely helped her to put on her weeds (a strange service from me to her! as strange as all the rest of this sad business!) I left, with the feeling that having now exhausted the mutual excitement which had drawn us together; brought two such antipathetic natures as hers and mine into a quasi-sympathy: we might drop away into the old distance from one another—with advantage to both! Dear Grace, the things that are in my heart & memory about poor George, would find more response from you, I am sure, than from her: and some day we shall surely meet, to have a long talk about him. I dont know whether I shall be going to Scotland this year: I was not minded to go, having spent all last summer there; and my Husband being too busy with his Book for taking any holyday at all this coming summer. But a new motive for going has arisen which may perhaps overcome the motives for staying at home. You remember Sunny-Bank and the Miss Donaldson’s? My Mother’s ever kind, most trusted friends. They and I have never lost sight of one another: their love for me has been like the love of a Mother; of late years since they were reduced to twoCatherine Donaldson had d. 1852. (the two Eldest) and very suffering & sad; I have gone to visit them every two years or oftener, besides writing to them once a week. They cared so much for seeing me and hearing from me! and it was such a pleasure to me to be of any comfort to them in their dreary, lonely suffering lives! Now—Miss Donaldson—(the Eldest) who has been blind, deaf and dying for the last two years but with a warm heart and as clear a mind as she had in her prime, is dead;Jean Donaldson d. 30 March. and none of us can be other than thankful at her release, But poor Miss Jess; the last of them all!—and since ever I remember the most ailing of them all—to think of her, alone at Sunny-Bank to struggle with ever increasing infirmities:
that makes me very sorrowful! and if she would like me to come to her, when the London neice,Eliza Donaldson. and other relations who have gathered about her, but will soon “tire of the dullness” leave her to her solitary fate—why, I should just have to provision my husband for two or three weeks: give my servant as minute instructions about him as if he were a three years old Baby (Baby just old enough to get into the fire!) and take the North British! Then as sure as you live, I would get out at Belford,Grace Dinning’s home in Northumberland, 48 mi. N of Newcastle-upon-Tyne and 15 mi. S of Berwick-upon-Tweed. The Great Northern Railway ran from London to York; the North Eastern Railway, from York to Berwick, via Belford; and the North British Railway, from Berwick to Edinburgh, with a connection at Longniddry for Haddington. and have a few hours talk with you face to face and soul to soul”Original source untraced; used by Oliver Wendell Holmes in his 1859 poem “For the Burns Centennial Celebration” line 15.—(as ones poetry book had it long ago! why should one cease to be poetical because one is getting near to sixty? I see no reason). But if I go at all it will not be for two or three months yet and very likely I may not go north this year. Let us hope in that case that we may meet another year—
Meanwhile after having been kindly remembered by you for forty years, I need not fear being forgotten by you in one.

closer.salute: And so good by, Dear—with best wishes for all your Belongings

docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

ps.p: H. Dinning!!!Presumably JWC enclosed his card and wrote her postscript on it.;

Look there! Just as I wrote my name his card was brought up— He has been here a long time and I like him dearly, so earnest and unaffected and affectionate looking! and doesnt he love his Mother! His eyes shine whenever he speaks of her—
Oh what a different sort of man from the cousins at York Terrace!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ED [EDO], [7 April]. MS: NLS 8992.206. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the recent death of Jean Donaldson on 30 March.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA DONALDSON

docBody.p: Do, pray, my dear Eliza write me two or three lines! I dont want to plague you with writing a letter; but just a few words to tell me how you think Miss Jess really is—
and do give her a kind kiss for me! Oh I am so sorry for Her!
You won’t leave her soon Dear! Oh don’t!— Your LoverUnidentified. can wait, surely? Poor Jess’s need of sympathy and cheering-up cannot wait!

I have much less pain in thinking of my beloved “god-mother”Jean Donaldson. now, than I have had any time this eighteen months back!— But Miss Jess—! It is as if all the anxiety I used to feel about them both had concentrated itself on her alone—

It is such a heavy, dismal lot, when you think of it—all her life an invalid, and to have survived all the others,She had survived nine sisters and six brothers. Tell me about the servants—does Ellens sisterPossibly Helen Dickinson (b. ca. 1823); sister unidentified. please? and who will come in place of Ellen?— Will Mrs Campbell leaveJean Donaldson’s nurse, who stayed on to nurse Jess Donaldson; see JWC to JDJAD, [2 or9 May]; unidentified further.— I am sure Miss Jess should have some one besides the servants— Oh I have fifty things to ask—and you, poor child, have not time or spirits, I am sure, to answer me fifty things!
Tell Miss Jess I do not write to herself, because the words lie frozen in me in presence of her great sorrow and dreariness.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle—
docBody.note: Mary Smith (1822–89; ODNB; see 29:20JWC to MS, 16 Jan. 1854) wrote to JWC, 3 April: “No, there is no danger of my forgetting you since every communication I receive from you strengthens my reasons for preserving your perpetual remembrance. / In truth Dear Madam I was very much gratified by your receiving the poor compliments I wished to honour you with so kindly and still feel as I did when I wrote them that the fashion of my expressions was too formal to convey in any but a very insufficient and restricted way my real thoughts and feelings relative to my experience of your amiability of character and singular readiness to do the offices of gentleness when there were no claims but such as are generally evaded or ignored. It was indeed no common kindness you did me when you advised me so amply and showed me in such a pure womanly way the difficulties of your own past path that I might take courage to walk patiently and hopefully on mine. Nor did it fall fruitlessly into forgetfulness.” Smith possibly referred to the dedication to JWC of Poems by M. S. (1860); see 34:70–71JWC to MS, [late Nov. 1860]. JWC wrote to Mary Smith in 1857 about her early difficulties in Craigenputtoch; see 32:70–73JWC to MS, 11 Jan. 1857. JWC then wrote summer 1858 (see 34:148–49JWC to MS, 19 Aug. 1858) and may also have written summer 1859, as Smith described her last letter coming “like a summer sunbeam.” Smith concluded: “I am still going on with my school here which prospers very well. It is a laborious life and one not very congenial to the cultivation of literary gifts but I get through it an independent livelihood. … As to my poetry though I can never write as I wish I cannot give it up. I first began to rhyme when I was a governess. … But I am writing too much. My object was simply to thank you for your last kind communication which as heartily as I can I do, and most sincerely do I hope that you and Mr Carlyle are well. For both I cherish a deep and reverential esteem.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WHH, 13 April. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM HOLMAN HUNT

docBody.p: Will you oblige me by letting Mr WatsonPossibly John Dawson Watson (1832–92; ODNB), painter, illustrator, friend of Ford Madox Brown. He moved from Manchester to London, 1860, and was commissioned by Routledge to illustrate an edition of The Pilgrim’s Progress, completed in 1861. see the Picture?Presumably TC and JWC had a private viewing of Holman Hunt’s painting The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple (see 99TC to LS, 19 April), about to go on public exhibition at the German Gallery, New Bond St. Having raised his curiosity about it to a pitch! I feel myself responsible for the gratification thereof!

Mr Carlyle says, “it is a really grand Picture! The greatest Picture that he has seen painted by any modern man!”For TC’s more detailed description of the painting, see TC to Lady SLS, 19 April; the Athenaeum, 21 April, declared the painting “almost unequalled, in our time, for power of design or splendour of execution” (549). And Mr Carlyle being notorious for never praising except in negatives,—(“not a bad Picture;“—“a picture not wholly without a certain merit;“—&c &c) the present outburst of positive praise evinces an appreciation of your Picture, not to be exceeded by “any modern man”!
Please recollect that you settled with him to come here some evening soon.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 13 April. MS: MUL. Pbd: Marrs 735–37; A. Carlyle, NL 2:205–7 inc.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p:
The other night John read to me a Letter of yours to Jean, which had been sent hither from Dumfries for our use; and was very welcome after the long silence. You give us there a fine lively account of your dear Household over the Sea; the whole matter came home to me, and I thought of you my Brother ever true to me, and far away, struggling handsomely on, tho’ growing old, like others of us: in short it brought up such a vivid picture of the present, and the past, and was so wholesome and agreeable in its simplicity of truth, I privately determined to go and do at once a thing I had long intended, but had put off for want of time,—namely to send you the Bit of Paper whh is now
here inclosed,TC enclosed £50 (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). as a small memorial of my regard for you whh will live as it ought so long as I live. Dear Brother, you may believe me, it is years since I had such a pleasure as in sending you this little gift. It will ditt up some little hole in your establishment perhaps, and keep the wind out, as if by my command, Brother Tom’s command; and no man can be more welcome to a thing than Brother Alick is to this.—— I am not now so scarce of money as I used to be, nor indeed scarce at all, within the last few years; we have, on the contrary, an increasing stock,TC had just received £521 12s. from Chapman & Hall, “being the amount due to me for the royalty and use of the stereotype plates for my works printed from Jany 1 to Decr 31 1859” (TC’s receipt, signed and dated “5 Cheyne Row Chelsea, 3 April 1860“: Maggs Bros. online catalog, 15 May 2008). with the diminishing time left to use it in: pray remember this always; and never scruple to apply to me in any pinch,—you know that I literally mean what I say it, and that I would not say it if it were not the the truth. It has been in my head for a long time to write to you about Tom my namesake;Alick’s eldest son, Thomas. TC repeated “the” in the previous sentence. of whom, on all that I could gather and guess, I have a good opinion; and who seems to be struggling towards some settlement for his own behoof, as is natural at his age, but not successfully hitherto. If you can see any way for him that could be opened by a £200 or so, and that promised to be for his real good and yours, I wished you to tell me about it. I am so held to the grindstone, and almost slaved to wreck with this sad Book of mine, I have seldom a moment of my own for any purpose: but I wish you would consider this thing, now that I have got it stated, and if you come to any conclusion, let me know instantly. It is very possible you may not wish Tom himself to know of this at all; if so, be only silent; the secret lies between you and me, and shall so lie till you permit otherwise. Again I say we are not now scarce of money, nor like to be: my late Books have sold beyond common; the British Public, after having tried in vain to starve me into compliance or death, now renounces the attempt, and says, “Live!“—now when one has so near done with it at any rate! I cannot say I care for any Public, or men or body of men that are so loose from me. That is a kind of kingship I have attained to by their treatment of me,—and by stern Time’s treatment withal, who spares no mortal. Pray understand all this, dear Brother; and act accordingly when there is reason you should—namely good to be done to you or yours by so doing. And so enough on that subject.

We are all as well as usual; my poor Jane, whom you wd hardly know again, so changed and weakly is she, is decidedly better this winter, than for the last two. Jack is here this good while; doing little or nothing; buying old Books, reading, rambling about; very healthy still, and feeling less of age (I fancy)
than you or I do. From Annandale we hear similar accounts. Jamie at Scotsbrig has his eldest sonJames Carlyle the younger. now at home (a very reasonable nice young fellow) out of a situation; who talks of going to Australia &c,—to Jamie’s sorrow in his lonely state.James’s wife, Isabella, d. 1 June 1859. As for me, I ride diligently and count on a fine continuance of idleness to the end, if I can live to get this sad Task off my hands, whh is by far the hardest I ever had, when there was much more birr in me. Adieu dear Brother. God’s blessing on you all.— T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 13 April. MS: FC. Quot: Davies, John Forster 238.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
Your Book is a capital setting forth of that memorable Parliamentary Adventure.John Forster, The Arrest of the Five Members by Charles the First: A Chapter of English History Rewritten (1860); it was reviewed in the Athenaeum, 31 March. It abounds with information, collected from far and near;—and set forth with a lucidity, and perfection of indexing whh is without example, and indeed a great merit. Would to Heaven my Germans had imitated you in that respect, as in several others! The whole thing is solidly hammered out, rivetted like iron; and rolls along like a strong waggon full of goods, but at the trot, and on the crown of the causeway,—warning those that meet it in lighter vehicles to hold wide! I think you are too severe upon the poor Charles-First Party;Forster apparently told Dickens about TC’s letter, as Dickens wrote to Forster, 2 May: “I can understand any man, and particularly Carlyle’s, having a lingering respect that does not like to be disturbed, for those … loyal gentlemen of the country, who went with the King. … But I don’t think Carlyle sufficiently considers that the great mass of those gentlemen didn’t know the truth—that it was a part of their loyalty to believe what they were told on the King’s behalf” (DL 9:244–45). and am sorry for their poor heads, going like eggs under your wheels. That is now the side to take; has it all its own way, after two centuries of suffering: but there is another side too, whh will again claim to have the meaning of its views brought home to us, and justly interpreted on the new terms now possible.In the same letters to Forster, Dickens wrote: “It did not occur to me in reading your most excellent, interesting, and remarkable book, that it could with any reason be called one-sided” (DL 9:244). Take that Strafford Affair up,Thomas Wentworth (1593–1641), 1st earl of Strafford, one of Charles I’s most able and most ruthless ministers, lord president of the Council of the North from 1628, and lord deputy of Ireland from 1632. He believed in maintaining strict centralized royal and clerical power against what he saw as the excesses of parliamentary democracy, and he often used harsh and arbitrary methods to achieve his ends. He was impeached for “high misdemeanours” Nov. 1640, and executed May 1641. Forster had written a biography of Strafford in 1836 as part of the series Lives of Eminent British Statesmen, 7 vols. ([1831–39] 2:178–421), which TC had praised highly; see 13:323TC to JF, 18 Dec. 1841. In autumn 1860 Forster pbd. The Debates in the Grand Remonstrance, in which, while admitting that Strafford was “a man of courage and genius,” he continued to maintain his strong disapproval of Strafford’s principles and methods. In 1861 he pbd. an article, “Strafford’s Youth,” in The Victoria Regia, ed. Adelaide A. Proctor (227–53), which was meant to be the first part of an extended biography of Strafford, though the biography was never completed (see Davies, John Forster 236; see also 13:15TC to JOST, 12 Jan. 1841, and 33:229–30TC to JF, 28 May, 1858). whh you were speaking
of; get fairly into the inside of Strafford, and make the eyes of him shine again! That too wd be an admirable thing! Dare you?—

I am sorry to say I shall not for a month or six weeks have the least need of that manuscriptUnidentified. back, at this rate of going. Never was such a pace heard of, after all one’s spurring. Pity a poor old roadster, up to the withers in quagmire, vainly sprawling, plunging, and vainly calling on the Heavens or the Earth to help it!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS] , 19 April. MS: NLS 19.3.52.9. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:383.
div3.head:
TC
TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p:
Your little Note was a great pleasure to us; perhaps greater than you think;—like a little wax-lucifer kindled in a bad night, and cheering one with its clear flame, while it burns, and in memory afterwards. I hope you will send us another, if you don’t keep your prophecy of being homePresumably to Lady Sandwich’s London home. this week. As for me, I have been in such a toss ever since you last saw me,—what with the state of Fritz (the two-footed Fritz), Frederick. state of my own liver, state of the weather; what with one thing, what with another,—I felt it (and feel it) a duty to keep strictly under a bushel;Cf. Matt. :15. and say nothing at all, till the ugly cloud got away in some measure. Our weather has been bad to a degree; and today is at the worst,—except that this is now the crisis (hail, sleet &c), and I foresee summer sun behind it. This is a last tussel of Winter with Summer; such as is due (according to the Scotch weather-proverb) in the entrance of April. Six bad days, they say, horribly bad; just when March is ending and April beginning:—here they are, a little behind date, and more than six of them; I
have noticed they generally do come. Here is the Proverb, if any of your grandchildrenLady Sandwich had five surviving grandchildren; her third grandson, Sydney Montagu, d. 4 April. will learn it, for the sake of weather wisdom in future years:

lg.l: Three days, and they were ill:
The first was sleet, the second was snow,
The third was waur than they were a’.
Three days of wind and rain;—

docBody.p: Six days, whh they call the “borrowing days”Generally cited as three not six days; cf. John Brand, Observations on Popular Antiquities (1813) 1:460–62. in that wise Country, and mark not in chalk.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle to Lady Sandwich, 19 April 1860 (detail)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
I went one day, somebody dragging me, to see a new Picture (Christ disputing in the Temple, Father & Mother finding him there) by HuntSee above. the Preraphaelite; upon whh he has been working for 3 years (7 in all, for he spent 4 in Palestine as preliminary):Hunt spent two years, 1854–56, traveling through the Middle East, including a stay in Jerusalem. a worse job for him than even Fritz, I think! But the Picture, and the Painter, did seem to me to have extraordinary
merits. The Christ is an exquisite mixture of a god and a peasant lad. His mother too is very fine; but I thot she shd have been a little angry withal (at having got such a fright from her careless son) instead of merely rapturous over him as she might be over a baby saved from the wolf. There were other criticisms:-but I have not seen such a Picture, for fidelity of execution, for exquisite finish, and limner and other talent, by any modern man.— It had turned out worth my while to go?

figure.p: The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple by Holman Hunt, 1860

p.hi: Courtesy of Birmingham Museums & Art Gallery

div3.sourceNote: TC-[P&G] [PAG], 21 April. MS: Strouse. Addressee identified as TC’s usual paper supplier, Parkins & Gotto, 24–25 Oxford St. and 57–58 Rathbone Pl.; see TC to JN, 20 Nov. 1856. Henry Gotto lived at 24 Oakley Villas, next door to Joseph Neuberg and Rosetta Frankau.
div3.head: TC TO [PARKINS & GOTTO]

docBody.p: So far as I can see, this Paper is about identical with the old favourite kind,—at any rate, is nearer it than we have a chance to come other wise;—and I am very glad and thankful that you have found it.

You may with very great confidence order me 9/ worth of it; to begin with, and complete my experimenting upon. If a roller will improve it, let it be rolled. Should it turn out altogether as expected, there will be (I hope) a great deal more of it needed,—shaped into Note-paper, Letter-paper &c (as well),—by myself and others. In the mean time I am greatly obliged by your successful industry; and solicit despatch with the 500 sheets first in question.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: (This is the paper itself)

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS], 23 April. MS: NLS 19.3.52.10. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I have a great mind to accept that kind offer of Lord Sandwich’s and yours,An invitation to Hinchinbrook House. and wd say, “Yes at once,—Thursday nextThurs., 26 April. by some train or other, and home again on Saturday or Sunday!” But the fact is, I am in a crisis at present (a cold on me, under medical bombardment, and with likelihood of giving way): please leave me loose till tomorrow, and then I will give positive response, Can or Cannot.
A thousand thanks to Lord Sandwich and you. The Wife is urgent I should say Yes just now; but it will be safer left as above.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS], 24 April. MS: NLS 19.3.52.11. Quot: Hansons NE 486. TC’s signature has been cut away, causing words in first para. to be lost.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: My cold is considerably gone tod[ay] [I will arran]ge for Thursday next; and pro[pose to stay] a couple of days at Hinchinbrook, if nothing unexpected intervene!

Twelve o’clock King’s Cross, they tell me, is the proper train; goes in 1½ hours; and, unless I misremember, Hinchinbrook is but a little way off the statn.Hinchinbrook House was ½ mi. W of Huntingdon and about 59 mi. NE of London.
Rain & wind, very ugly weather;—wife has caught a little cold, but will not hear of my staying; and indeed has specially invited a BoreUnidentified. on Saturday to keep me away!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 27 April. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Huntingdon, 27 April 1860. MS: NLS 615.523. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p: My dear little Jeannie,— Be patient with me; I am the unhappy animal, but don’t mean ill! Listen to my history since parting—

I had the mildest and most satisfactory drive with “Jarvis,”“Jarvis”: a name given to drivers of hackney coaches, although by this time “jarvey” was more usual. who set me down 10 minutes before my time, and departed with blessings: the railway journey, too, carriage all to myself for the first 45 miles, and not the least uproar anywhere, was altogether solitary and pleasant:—the good people “had been twice down at the station seeking me” (I was told); in short I got landed in the lobby here under good auspices; and had I gone away immediately to a sofa, and wrapt myself in my rug & Cape, and lain down far from affairs, I had done altogether well.

figure.p: “The Volunteer Review in Hyde Park”
Illustrated London News, 7 July 1860

docBody.p:
But I was taken up to Lady Sandwich’s Room (everybody else being out drilling riflemen &c);Volunteer rifle corps were being trained all over the country because of fears of a possible invasion by the French. The Times reported that “the movement of last year has created a great national institution. Some 70,000 young men belonging for the most part to the more affluent classes of society have found that they can spare time from their various avocations to fit themselves for the defence of their country” (8 March). Grand reviews of volunteer rifle corps in the presence of the queen were held 23 June in London (see above) and 7 Aug. in Edinburgh. and by
her, good Lady, after some refection, I was carried over all the House,Hinchinbrook House, built by Sir Henry Cromwell (1536–1604), grandfather of Oliver Cromwell (1599–1658), on monastic lands acquired by his father and inherited by his elder son, Sir Oliver Cromwell (1563–1655), who sold it, 1627, to Sidney Montagu (1571–1644), brother of the 1st earl of Manchester and father of the 1st earl of Sandwich. It had been substantially rebuilt after a fire in 1830. looking at Pictures, looking at,-in a word I was quite done up, and she too I dare say for my sake. I am, with my modesties, a stupid sumph, I often reflect! Lord Sandh John William Montagu, 7th earl, Lady Sandwich’s son. came, by the time I had well got quit, and taken to tobacco; I was in the act of kindling my short pipe out of doors, when his Lordship, beaming with real hospitable pleasure, fell into my arms! Half an hour with him; and we were then an hour off dinner; and I fit to leap out of my skin!—

ps.p: Lord Sh has run up to London (home for dinner again); so I am solus till Lunchn time;—and mean to clear off three or four Notes after this.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCH [JCHA], 30 April. MS: Houghton. Pbd: Copeland 223–25 inc. Text: Copeland.
div3.head: TC TO JANET CARLYLE HANNING

docBody.p:
Dear Sister Jenny,—I have twice had a Newspaper from you lately, the last otime only two days ago; and I am always glad to see such a mark of your remembrance,“Newspapers direct from the British Colonies by packet are delivered free of postage at any place within the British dominions” (Post Office Directory [1860] 2192); the Carlyles often used the free delivery of newspapers as a way of sending messages to each other; cf. 34:151TC to JWC, 20 Aug. 1858. and understand by it that things are going tolerably well with you, or at least not going far out of course. I would write oftener, and I hope to do so by and by; but at present I am kept at such a press as you have not the least idea of; and, for months and indeed years past, I have had almost to cease corresponding with everybody; and have not, except upon compulsion, written the smallest Note,—every moment of my time being so taken up with another dismal kind of “writing” which I cannot shirk. It is of no use afflicting you with complaints of what you cannot help, or with pity for me which could
do no good, but the truth is I never had in all my life such a frightfully undoable disgusting piece of work as this which has been reserved for the end of my strength, and it has made and makes me now and for years back miserable till I see it done. I stick to it like death and it shall not beat me if I can help it. No more of it here,—nothing of it, except to explain my silence; within a couple of years, if I live so long, I hope to be much more in case for correspondence with those whom I merely think of with affection, as times are.

To-day I have done a little thing which has been among my purposes for some time, namely, got a small memorial ready for you—which so soon as you have read this note you can go and ask for and so conclude. For the paper of the Messrs. Coutts, Bankers,Coutts & Co., 58 and 59 Strand. I conclude, will go in the same steamer as this Note and all will be ripe by the time you have done reading. You are to go to the “Bank of Upper Canada,” Hamilton, to say you are “Mrs. Janet Hanning” and that there is £10 for you from “Mr. Thomas Carlyle, London”The money was paid via John A. Carlyle: “2 May 1860 / To John (for Jenny / in Canada / £10..0..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).—upon which they will hand it out and so end. It is a great pleasure to me, dear little Jenny, to think of your getting this poor fairing from me, and stitching up for yourself here and there a loose tack with it—as I know you well understand how to do. Do not trouble yourself writing; address me a newspaper in your own hand and put one stroke on it, that will abundantly tell me whatever is to be said.

Your kindred here and in Scotland are all in their usual course. Nothing wrong with any of them, or nothing to speak of. My own poor Jane has by accident hurt her side a little the other day, which annoys her for the present, but we are promised a “perfect cure in less than four weeks.”The end of the letter and the signature are missing.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 30 April. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Slater, CEC 530–32. Quot: Correspondence of Carlyle and Emerson, ed. C. E. Norton, 2 vols. (London, 1883) 2:272–74.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p:
It is a special favour of Heaven to me that I hear of you again by this accident;Emerson wrote, 16 April, with questions about the American edns. of TC’s works. and am made to answer a word de Profundis [out of the depths]. It is constantly among the fairest of the few hopes that remain for me on the other side of this Stygian Abyss of a Friedrich (shd I ever get thro’ it alive) that I shall then begin writing to you again, who knows if not see you in the body before quite taking wing! For I feel always, what I have sometimes written,
that there is (in a sense) but one completely human voice to me in this world, and that you are it, and have been,—thanks to you, whether you speak or not!Emerson wrote: “Continue to be good to your old friends. Tis no matter whether they write to you, or not. If not, they save your time.” Let me say also while I am at it, that the few words you sent me about those first Two Volumes are present with me in the far more frightful darknesses of these last Two; and indeed are often almost my one encouragement.In the fourth lecture in his series, “Art and Criticism,” delivered 13 April 1859 at the Music Hall, Boston, Emerson welcomed the American publication of Frederick the Great: “Here has come into the country, three months ago … infinitely the wittiest book that ever was written; a book that, one would think, the English people would rise up in a mass to thank him for … a book holding so many memorable and heroic facts … with a range, too, of thought and wisdom, so large, so colloquially elastic, that we not so much read a stereotype page as we see the eyes of the writer looking into ours, whilst he is humming and chuckling, with undertones, and trumpet-tones, and shrugs, and long commanding glances, stereoscoping every figure that passes, and every hill, river, wood, hummock and pebble in the long perspective, with its wonderful mnemonics, whereby great and insignificant men are ineffaceably marked and medalled in the memory by what they were, had and did” (“Art and Criticism,” Complete Works, ed. Edward Waldo Emerson, Centenary Edn. [Boston and New York, 1904] 12:298–99). In a notebook entry of 1867, TC placed a clipping from The Critic, 3 March 1860, quoting Emerson’s eulogistic praise of Frederick. TC attached to it a scrap of paper, on one side of which he wrote “sent by a Mr Langley,” and, on the other side: “Chelsea, March 1860. This already exists quoted in a letter I had from Emerson many months ago. It is very exaggerated criticism, but contains a genuine human recognition of the Book; and is the only sentence of writing or print, in praise or blame, that I have read on it without more or less of disgust,—when the reading at all happened to be forced on me by some cause. This has silently given me a great deal of pleasure, and been a source of pious thots and encouragets.— T.C.” He later wrote: “found, & reposited here, March 1867” (TC’s notebook; private owner). That is a fact, and not exaggerated, tho’ you think it is. I read some Criticisms of my wretched Book, and hundreds of others I in the gross refused to read; they were in praise, they were in blame; but not one of them looked into the eyes of the object, and in genuine human fashion responded to its human stirrings, and recognised it,—completely right, tho’ with generous exaggeratn! That was well done, I can tell you: a human voice, far out in the waste deeps, among the inarticulate sea-krakens and obscene monsters, loud-roaring, inexpressibly ugly, dooming you as if to eternal solitude by way of wages,—“hath exceeding much refreshment in it,” as my friend Oliver used to say.Oliver Cromwell; see Works 6:101.

Having not one spare moment at present, I will ansr to you only the whole contents of that Letter; you in your charity will convey to Mr WightOrlando Williams Wight (1824–88), American physician and author. His publishers, Brown & Taggard of Boston, had written to Emerson, enclosing Wight’s suggestion that TC be given part of the profits from a forthcoming stereotyped edn., Critical and Miscellaneous Essays: Collected and Republished, by Thomas Carlyle, ed. Wight, 4 vols. (Boston, 1860). For TC and JWC on Wight’s novel Quinland, see 33:39TC to JWC, 19 Aug. 1857, and 66TC to JWC, 3 Sept. 1857. and to
Mr CabotJames Elliot Cabot (1821–1903), longtime friend of Emerson; see 33:117TC to LOA, 15 Nov. 1857. what portions respectively belong to them. Wight, if you have a chance of him, is worth knowing: a genuine bit of metal, too thin and ringing for my tastes (hammered, in fact, upon the Yankee anvils), but recognisably of steel and with a keen fire-edge.— Pray signify to him that he has done a thing agreeable to me, and that it will be pleasant if I find it will not hurt him. Profit to me out of it, except to keep his own soul clear and sound (to his own sense, as it always will be to mine) is perfectly indifft:—and on the whole I thank him heartily for shewing me a chivalrous human brother, instead of the usual vulturous malodorous and much avoidable phenomenon, in Transatlantic Bibliopoly! This is accurately true;—and so far as his Publisher & he can extract encouragement from this, in the face of vested interests whh I cannot judge of,—it is theirs without reserve.

To Mr Cabot be so good as say That Harper of New-York is to me Harpy, odious, rapacious, not lovely or beneficent at all; that he has not, nor shall ever have if I can help it, the least vestige of a “bargain” with me in regard to these Two-expected Volumes of Friedrich;—and that in fact I will rather give them frankly away for Zero to any honest Bookseller whom you or Cabot may recommend, than consign them to Harpydom on the terms their predecessors had.Emerson wrote, 16 April: “No bookseller here now appears able to fight the Harpers.” Harper & Bros., New York publishing firm, run by four brothers, James (1795–1869), John (1797–1875), Joseph Wesley (1801–70), and Fletcher (1806–77). Harper & Bros. had pbd. the first two vols. of Frederick the Great and had apparently claimed to Cabot that they expected rights to the remaining vols. (Slater, CEC 529). The wretched mortal wrote to me again and again, while the question with me was not of lucre but of life or death; and in every letter you saw the mingled physiognomy of owl, raven and unclean birds,The owl and the raven are among the unclean birds listed in Lev. 11:15–16.—creating a certain horror! To be rid of him I said “£100 per volume, and no farther talk!” He held back, corresponded with Chapman, made me sensible of his evil presence in secondary ways; at length offered while I was in the agonies, “£50 per volume.” I bid Chapman, “Close with him, for God’s sake, and let him disappear!”Edward Chapman, TC’s publisher; for earlier correspondence about the U.S. edn., see 33:115TC to EC, 13 Nov. 1857.—— That is the exact state of it;—and my wish then strongly was, and still is, that I could in some way signify to him, “Avaunt, unclean bird, come not between the wind and me again!— Be so extremely obliging as to steal any property of mine you can find not guarded by the gallows, and to hold your tongue about it, and not trouble me with any dialogue at all!“—

I am very glad I have got this written down for Mr Cabot; and pray tell him I do not wish that he should take any action farther on the subject,—except it were to point me out a man to whom, as above described, I could send the Sheets gratis; if that were the way of shutting Harpy’s beak, whh perhaps it
isn’t? In short, that latter is the one result I am ambitious of. And by simply doing nothing, I suppose it will be pretty much secured. The £100 from all America is nearly the same as what TauchnitzChristian Bernhard Tauchnitz, Leipzig printer and publisher. yields in the name of all Germany: sums not vital to me ‘at all at all,’—and worse than zero if there has to be speech of unclean birds about them first!—— You will need to translate all that into rational deliberate speech; and deliver it mildly, with my gratitude, and other good human feelings (whh are not wanting, had I time to state them) to Mr Cabot. Nay the poor devil Harper, he too ought to have justice; and I am not the least angry at him, while he keeps wide of me! Besides I remember, it was not he at all that wrote; but some hungry feathered being (probably in moult at the time) whom he keeps here in London.Sampson Low, Son & Co., publishers, 47 Ludgate Hill, acted as London agents for Harper & Bros., 1847–86; see also 34:144JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1858; Sampson Low (1797–1886; ODNB) and his son, also Sampson (1822–71). God give us patience with all creatures feathered and unfeathered,—at least till we can get a chance, to suppress (and extinguish by good methods) the intolerable kinds of them!—

Adieu my friend; I have not written so much in the Letter way, not, I think, since you last heard of me. In my despair it often seems as if I shd never write more; but be sunk here, and perish miserably in the most undoable, least worthy, most disgusting and heartbreaking of all the labours I ever had. But perhaps also not, not quite. In whh case-- Yours ever truly at any rate T. Carlyle

ps.p: (No time to re-read; I suppose you can decipher)Emerson also wrote: “I saw, in Toronto, in the winter, two stalwart Carlyles, nephews of yours, sons of John Carlyle of Mohawk, Canada West. … They do credit to the name.” In his journal entry describing the encounter, Emerson added: “The young men did not know that their uncle Dr J. A. Carlyle of London, was named John like their father, but called Dr John ‘Uncle Aikin’” (The Journals and Miscellaneous Notebooks of Ralph Waldo Emerson, ed. Susan Sutton Smith and Harrison Hayford [Cambridge, Mass., 1978] 14:342–43).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 7 May. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 7 May 1860. MS: NLS 553.217. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Your “George-Second campaignings”George II’s plan to besiege Dunkirk, as the prelude to a broader invasion of France, July 1742; see Works 15:372–75. are very good, and will help me considerably. I wish I had not troubled you with LangleySamuel Langley, impoverished writer who occasionally worked for TC; TC’s most recent payment was recorded as “8 April 1860 / … (half / charity) £2..0..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). at all;—pray, at least
do not cut any more of him out. I had remembered some early points abt ‘the Scots Greys’Scottish cavalry regiment; see Works 15:373. &c, a line or two of whh might have had an enlivening effect, if introducible: I suppose they are still standing in their place? Besides these there was a Letter from Ghent Octr 16 (n.s. or O.S.?)New style (“n.s.”) and old style (“O.S.”) refer to the new Gregorian calendar and the old Julian calendar respectively. The Gregorian calendar had been adopted in most of Europe in 1582, but was not officially adopted in Britain until 1752; see also 30:83TC to JN, 18 Oct. 1855. This caused much confusion of dates, especially in English-language histories of European events. from a puddingheaded John-Bull Captn,TC referred to officers’ letters from Ghent but did not quote any; see Works 15:400. whh I had thots of, to make the winterquarters palpable. The greater part of that is here (indeed almost the whole of it, but wants words &c). I return you the pasted Pieces; perhaps you can restore them to their old places:—unless it be easier to go direct upon the Letter itself in the Old Newsprs, some day; and see whether an extractible affair (with date &c) cd be made of that?—— Try a little; it is not worth much trial!—

Here is some of the genuine old white straw-paper recovered again. Actually attainable (by miracle) once more! I have ordered 3 9/ worths of it.See TC to [P&G][PAG], 21 April. The chief mercy it is whh has been extended to me in this Abyss of degrading slavery where our doom is for the prest.
No hurry with that Ghent Letter; nor with the rest of the War things. You can bring the old Adelungs & take a new vol. on sunday night—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-TB, 9 May. MS: NLS 3112.261. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS BALLANTYNE

docBody.p:
I have looked into the Nos of the Manchr Review1. Manchester Review of Politics and Literature began publication 7 Jan. 1860 and ended 28 Dec. 1861. whh you successively sent; and am happy to see that you are under way again. If you will send me a stamped Copy, and the account punctually every quarter, I shall be glad to become a subscriber: but as to writing a “Letter” of any kind,—the CriticPerhaps Ballantyne’s pseudonym in the paper. is under an enormous mistake if it fancy I have the least minute of leisure time, or the least prospect of any. Very far other is the case if the Critic knew it! And, to say truth, if I even were at leisure, I shd find it a questionable step, and savouring of the impertinent, to write such a Letter as you want,—upon
topics almost totally witht interest to me; being, as I defined myself the other day, one who “does not want any reform-bill; no, and does not care how many there may be!”Thomas Hare (1806–91; ODNB), political reformer, wrote to TC, 26 April: “I perfectly concur with you in thinking that nothing can be expected from those who confine themselves to talking instead of doing”; he then asked TC to reply with a note that he could present to the House of Lords committee that was inquiring into constituency reform and into the reasons why so many people did not vote.— That is really pretty near the sad fact with me.

Bright,John Bright, involved with many radical causes since the mid-1830s. He and Ballantyne with others founded the Manchester Examiner; see 20:181TC to TB, 28 April 1846. TC and Bright had met in Manchester, 1847; see 22:58TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1847. except that he is an entirely ignorant commonplace mortal who has acquired the sad art of uttering his follies as if they had some wisdom in them, is totally without importance to me. Nobody believes that this dirty little Bill will come to any result except death in the Commons,Lord John Russell’s Reform Bill to extend suffrage, supported by Bright, had its second reading in early May but was widely felt to be too extreme. It was withdrawn 11 June; the next Reform Act was not passed until 1867. whh I am glad of for the present; but my fixed notion is, in this universe of vile palaver where the foolish have got command over the wise, and are more and more in condition to reduce them to silence,—some form of universal Suffrage is inevitable for us; and I have said to it, “very well, then! Come along at your own rate,—perhaps the faster the better!”

This is not to discourage you or other persons of insight to keep saying their say, and getting what audience they can; but it represents my profound indifference to the matter, and that I am disgusted with it to the heart; and have not the least hope left in the Parliamentary Affair at all, in the pass it has now come to.
Adieu: go on and prosperCf. 1 Kings 22:12. nevertheless.

closer.salute: Yours (in very great haste) sincerely always

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD] [9 May]. MS: NLS 1797.164. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after TC to JCHA, 30 April, when TC wrote that JWC “hurt her side a little the other day” and had been “promised a ‘perfect cure in less than four weeks,’” and by this letter, where JWC mentions she had hurt her side “ten days back,” i.e., around the end of April.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p: You very nice woman! In no ordinary circumstances could your first letter to me have remained so many days unanswered. But my circumstances have been “anything but” (as my Cockney maidCharlotte Southam. says)—in fact quite exceptional—for am I not, at this writing, and have I not been for ten days back, plastered and bandaged up after the manner of an Egytian Mummy? and forbidden, under penalties to use my right hand? But human patience has limits—and today I take the liberty of clearing them at a flying leap! I have just written to Miss JessJess Donaldson.—and now I write to you before putting my arm into its sling again.
My excuse for making this great crash among my Dr’sDr. Barnes. commandments is just, that I have something to say. and I will be brief with it.

Since I had your letter, I have received one from Mrs Campbell,Jess Donaldson’s nurse; see JWC to EDEDO, [7 April]. also written at Miss Jesss desire. In this last I am told that Eliza Donaldson leaves this day week; and in the same sentence the writer goes on to say that Miss Jess is very “sorry about my accident which disappoints her glad expectance.” Now look here! Dear!—I want to understand clearly—if possible—(and it is only possible thro’ your intervention) what Miss Jess’s real wish and feeling is about seeing me; and if you think it would be worth while for me to go to her for two or three weeks—I mean worth while in the sense of being of any use or comfort to her—enough to counterbalance the bother of me.

Even I, who know Miss Jess so well, cannot always gather her real meaning out of her words, unless I have her looks to help them out; she is so beset with delicacies and apprehensions in her intercourse with even her most intimate friends. She is quite up to saying she desires a thing that would be disagreeable or at best indifferent to her; in mere apprehension of seeming “unkind,” “ungrateful,“—of “hurting some one’s feelings” by not expressing desire for it. Or again, she is up to expressing no desire for what would in reality be very agreeable to her; out of excessive delicacy about putting anybody to “trouble” for her. Such being her manner of being from of old I am quite at a loss, how to interpret, practically, her present talk about my coming.

When I heard that Miss DonaldsonJean Donaldson. was at the point of death, and before I knew whether any of “the nieces”There were six Donaldson nieces. would go to poor Miss Jess,—at the sacrifice of all these marriage gaities!,Helen Kay Donaldson m. Edward Griffith, 11 April.—I wrote offering to go at a days notice; and begged of Jane HowdenOne of the das. of Dr. Thomas Howden, partner of JWC’s father. whom Miss Jess had employed to inform me about her sister, that she would find out if Miss Jess would like me there. Jane Howden’s answer was, that “Certainly I ought not to come”; and that “Miss Jess wanted nothing but to be let alone.“— Short and not sweet—but conclusive as to the purpose. When I heard from Craven HillLondon home of Stuart Donaldson’s widow, Betty, and family. that Eliza had gone at once, and was not to leave again immediately; I felt as well as Jane Howden could tell me, that there was no need of me there. In a family bereavement, one of the family is always the most natural & acceptable companion—however it may be at other times.

Now having made this offer, and Miss Jess being so made; it is quite possible she might express herself eager for my coming—without feeling at all eager—just to show what she would call “a due sense of my kindness“— On the other hand she might be really wishing for me, and not like to say how much,—for fear of putting me to inconvenience.
In trying to ascertain for me her actual, exact wish in the matter; you will be helping me to decide whether to come or not—

For the case as regards myself is this. Independently of Miss Jess, I have no wish or intention of going to Scotland this year. I saw all my people there so lately; my Husband is not likely to leave home this year; the journey is a very fatiguing one; and expensive, as I am not strong enough for cheap travelling. All this considered, there would be no sense in my streaming off by myself to Scotland; unless for some special good reason. If I could feel sure that my presence would be any comfort or pleasure to that dear suffering Soul, even for the time being, I would deem that special good reason enough—and decide to go—with what heart I have! Not only because I would do harder things than that to please her; but because, should I outlive her, it would be a cruel thought for me hereafter, that I had it in my power to please her and let the opportunity slip. I dont think I need say any more to make my meaning plain.

If you recommend my coming tell me when would be most agreeable to her. My broken rib will be all right three weeks hence my Dr thinks. Love to your HusbandWilliam Dods. a kiss to yourself affectionately yours
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Please go up to Miss Jess at once—for she will be wanting my letter answered, and that would be a good opportunity for seeing into her mind

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 11 May. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 11 May 1860. MS: NLS 553.218. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: The exact date of Frh’s first Treaty with FranceThe treaty with France was signed 5 Jun. 1741; see Works 15:217–218. wd be worth putting beyond doubt: 3 dates are assigned to it in difft Books of Authority at prest: 1° (Valori i. 108) “5 june 1741” (that page and often): Valori was at the making of the Treaty, and shd have known; but he is certainly in error.Guy Louis Henri, marquis de Valori, Mémoires des négociations du marquis de Valori, 2 vols. (Paris, 1820); TC described it as “[a] valuable Book, which we shall often have to quote: edited in a lamentably ignorant manner” (Works 14:305); see TC to JN, 23 Jan.

2° (Schöll ii. 296),Christophe Guillaume de Koch and Maximilian Samson Frédéric Schoell, Histoire abrégée des traités de paix entre les puissances de l’Europe, 15 vols. (Paris, 1817–18); the reference is 2:297; the book is listed under “Koch” in catalogs, with Schoell as the secondary author, although TC used “Schoell” to identify it; see 35:166JWC to MR, 12 Aug. 1859. “5 july 1741” (whh I guess to be the real date, but shd like to know beyond question or cavil).—3° (Adelung ii. 442, with hesitatn) “17 Augt“:—it wd illustrate one point considerably, had this any title to be considered the date of signing, of finishing, much more of beginning!—

The Treaty itself does not seem to exist in print: but they all refer to Flassan (Hist. du la Diplomatique Française V. 142)Gaëtan de Raxis, comte de Flassan, Histoire générale et raisonnée de la diplomatie française, depuis la fondation de la monarchie, jusqu’à la fin du règne de Louis XVI, 6 vols. (Paris, 1809); see Works 15:218. as having something decisive to say. Wd you look strictly in Flassan (examine how he comes to know): Preuss’s opinn also wd be worth having. No more at present,—or till Sunday night.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p:
item (still more importt). RaumerFriedrich Ludwig Georg von Raumer, Beiträge zur neueren Geschichte aus dem britischen Museum und Reichsarchive, 5 vols. (Leipzig, 1836–39); TC used the English trans. of vol. 2, King Frederick II and His Times (1837); see Works 15:9. i.104: Austrian ministers in Council at Vienna “fell back into their chairs like dead men” when they heard for certain of the “Treaty between France, Prussia & Bayern.”TC had also asked for this information June 1859; see 35:108TC to JN, 10 June 1859. He used it in Works 15:231. This is from a Despatch
of Robinson,Sir Thomas Robinson (1695–1770), 1st Baron Grantham, diplomat; ambassador at Vienna 1730–48.—and the ass has quite omitted Robinson’s or any other date to this! Get it if you can.

Raumer takes ‘5 june’ for French-Prn Treaty, and is otherwise ignorant as a mule; but perhaps you may have Robinson’s dateFrom the context in Raumer, the date must be 28, 29, or 30 June 1741. Neuberg wrote various notes on the reverse of TC’s letter, including “Raumer (1.103) Existence of a treaty known in London 24 July [June] (ns): Letter from Ld Harrington, 24 June, in Austn State Papers vol. 136.” in your State-Paper notes?— Try!

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 16 May. Addr: Elm Cottage Old-Brompton Road / Old Brompton. PM: London, 16 May 1860. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Will you be so good as leave here that List of Frh’s Battles whh is in Reimann (in a slip, at the beginning;—I don’t want the Rn itself, and am in no hurry for it).Daniel Gottlob Reymann, General-Karte von einem Theil des Russischen Reiches in Gouvernements und Kreise eingetheilet (Berlin, 1802); Larkin had TC’s copy; see 35:234TC to HL, 19 Oct. 1859. Item, Orlich’s Book:Leopold von Orlich, Geschichte der schlesischen Kriege nach Original-Quellen (Berlin, 1841); TC’s copy: HCC. I need that, at once, for a day or two; you shall then have it back.—— By the same cargo, I wish you wd also bring back in toto (making a clean sweep of them) all the Magazines, Memoirs &c whh you have about you. They are sometimes wanted here; and part of them are not even my own, or the London Library’s,—so that they (in sick times) afflict my imaginn, were there nothing more!

I mostly forget what it was now that I wanted you to do with them; and it never was of much consequence;—and is now of none, now when you are at your right trade, that of the Maps whh are so important to me. Pull steadily by that rope; and do your very best upon it! No haste either, for I am still deep overhead here in this sad welter of clippings.

The rain beats perfectly harmless on your invincible window,Larkin had organized the repair of a window in TC’s attic study, summer 1859; see 35:159TC to HL, 28 July 1859.—thanks to your BrotherJohn Richard Larkin; employed by Edward Chapman to etch the maps for Frederick; see 33:203TC to HL, 8 April 1858. and you.

Wd you also call, before Saty at the Newsvender’s;Possibly Richard Kirby, newsvendor, stationer, and tobacconist, 37A Lambeth Walk. and tell him I can stand
the Examiner no longer; and that he must try me with the Observer,The Observer, founded 1791, the oldest Sunday newspaper in the world, known for its serious coverage of politics and literature, apparently available Sat. evenings. stamped copy, on Saty Evg next.

Item ask at the Watchmaker’s near therePossibly Samuel Ephraim, watchmaker, 9 Lambeth Walk. (where you and I once were); and ask if he has sent my Watch back, or what is becoming of it. Poor watch got into trouble again (by my own blame mainly); and you not being at hand, nor near your old Artist8. Unidentified. at any rate, I shoved it off my hands into that shop. Yours ever truly
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 16 May. MS: NLS 553.219. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I have a bit of partly simple, partly very abstruse Copying for you here,—or we may call it Copying and Editing;—in whh if you can succeed, as you have sometimes done, there will be a bit of real service rendered.
If this get you in time, you might be here tomorrow on horseback at the hour;—tomorrow or any day will do: I will go on with the sequel in the interim.

The Elliot Berlin letters (1776–1782)Hugh Elliot, minister at Berlin 1777–82. TC is presumably referring to the letters found at Eden Lodge from Elliot to his brother-in-law, William Eden; see TC to Lady SLS, 19 April. TC cited one letter; see Works 19:179. promise to turn perhaps to something, not to very much: they will be ready in a week or so;—and we are to take the “utmost precaution” not to dirty or in any way injure or harm them during our short period of possession.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD], [17 May]. MS: NLS 1797.156. Hitherto unpbd. This letter is in answer to Jane Dods’s reply to JWC to JAD, [9 May].
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p:
Oh my Dear! I don’t think a more sensible thought has come into my head these seven years, than just that of writing to you as I did, the other day!
