How completely the letter received from Jess herself, some three hours after receipt of yours, would have misled me! What a foolish game at cross-purposes we (she and I) should have played, if I had not had your Answer, helping me to a right interpretation of her words!

Poor Miss Jess! I should be very angry with her sometimes for her want of directness; if it weren’t that when one has known and cared for a person as long as I have known and cared for her, one gets to accept that person all of a piece,—not mapped out for one into such and such qualities and dispositions, like a phrenological plaster head! And so I make no more objection to any feature of Miss Jess’s mind than I make to the nose on her face! It is a part of her—I see it there plain enough—I love her as a whole—and what signifies going into details? You understand?— Besides her state is so sad and forlorn now, that one may well grant her any little individuality that gives her the least comfort!

But what a stupid mistake she would have led me into if I had trusted to her words alone!— I should certainly have gone to Sunny Bank—so soon as my broken rib had mended, and I had escaped from my condition of Mummy! And it would have been very inconvenient for me to go, and very painful for me to be there! how inconvenient and how painful I would not let myself think; so long as the fulfilment of an old promise, and present sympathy and kindness might demand it.

Here is what she says about my coming—in spite of my most earnest entreaties to her that she would be “frank.“—letting no nonsensical delicacies modify the expression of her real mind!— She says—“you are the only friend that thoroughly understands what my feelings are, and whose words sooth and comfort me, and would have come to me, the poor lonely one, and would still do so! Oh what happiness to me, were such a thing right! But I feel that I would be selfish to write what my heart would dictate; For surely there is no one I so desire to see!“— Then again she says, “I will much long to hear again! I know you could not venture just at present. You must suffer from your sad accident for some time. And I would grieve were you to run any risk. I can only say, that if you can venture at all any time, any day would be hailed by me!”

Now, my Dear, would not any one interpreting the above, by the light of unassisted nature, read out of it, that the only drawback in Miss Jess’s wish for me was the fear of putting me to risk or inconvenience?—a consideration which (if she had thought of it) was sure to excite a contest of generosity, in which I should have insisted on having the best—and both of us would have gained a loss!

Interpreted by my knowledge of the dear woman’s ways, and by the clear indications, contained in your letter, the meaning however reads differently.
And I have already written to her that I have quite given up the idea of seeing her this year I did not say a word of your last letter—but as I cannot ‘pretend’ (as we used to say at school) I told her my reason for changing my mind was, that I could see she would rather be let alone. I told her this in the kindest words I could find. still I dare say she would rather I hadnt seen so far—tho’ she will be relieved from the idea of my visit. It is a great relief to myself also—for several reasons, which I feel the whole force of now; tho’ I would not let them speak out in me above their breath, so long as going seemed to me (in Miss Jess’s words) “the right thing to do.”
If you would kindly tell me now and then, how she is in health and spirits, I should feel it very kind. “Mrs Campbell can write at anytime” Miss Jess says—but—I would rather here from you.

I do hope I shall be in London when you come in August. Be sure to send your address so soon as you arrive, that we may make some appointment. Chelsea is rather too far from the center of things, for coming there on chance, tho’ it is very accessible. I shall be heartily glad to see you both again

ps.p: Love to your husband

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [21 May]. Addr: Cadogan Pier. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Once more a sight of you,—and the watchSee TC to HL, 16 May. if it is now ready.
docBody.name: T. C.
docBody.p: Monday
The watch is not all, not quite. Soon as you can.
Monday morng

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[IEB?], [22 May]. MS: Peter Stern, bookseller, Boston, MA. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee tentatively identified as Isabella Barnes, because she was someone who both lived nearby and with whom JWC was affectionate at this time. Dated during JWC’s recovery from her injured side (see TC to JCH, 30 April) and after Eliza Donaldson’s return to London (she left Haddington 16 May; see JWC to JAD, [9 May]).
div3.head: JWC TO [ISABELLA E. BARNES?]

docBody.note: Phrase from the Book of Common Order and much used by Church of Scotland ministers. In Sir Walter Scott’s Old Mortality, English soldiers use it in mockery of the Covenanters; see chap. 4.
docBody.p: not tomorrow! Tomorrow I have to render myself at Craven HillEliza Donaldson lived at 21 Craven Hill, Bayswater, with her mother and sisters. as early as one oclock. Next day I have a wild notion of going to Richmond.Possibly to visit Margaret Welsh, who still lived in Richmond. On Saturday perhaps I may go to—Heaven—or elsewhere! So we must leave it (what?) hanging in the wind.
My side continues to hinder me—nothing more by day; but by night it pains me considerably—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 23 May 1860. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I am often, very often thinking of you here, tho’ I say nothing; and indeed I have seldom the least minute of time to spend on anything but my dreary most dreigh and intolerable Task which has consumed painfully so many of my latter days and years. Except upon compulsion I can seldom or never be got to write a Note to anybody, even those most valuable to me. If I live ever to get done—! And that I do hope in general; tho’, at times, I am in considerable gloom about it. Since last Newyearsday,—finding all wrong when I actually got to the Printer with my ware,—I have had a bad time, hardly ever a worse (so far as mere work went); but I am now getting, or seeming to get, my head a little above water;—and think I could manage to make a tolerable Book out of this abstruse waste thing, if my health will only stand out; whh I must try to husband the best I can. It is one of the pleasantest hopes whh
remain to me, that of coming to Scotsbrig (victorious, or at least having broken prison), and then going idle for a long long time together!

I send inclosed as Bank-Draught the exact sum (including sixpences you will have to pay, penny stamps &c &c) whh is now due for the operatn completed at Ecclefechan:TC wrote a check: “23 May 1860 / Brr Jamie (for railing / &c in Ecclefn) / 8..7..6” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). John, whom I saw last night, does not wish to alter what he sent.John A. Carlyle wrote to James, 11 May: “When you next write tell me the cost of the railing &c in the Ecclefn Churchyard” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). He intends soon sending some farther thing, abt the rent of his Book-Room at Ecclefn:John wrote to James, 22 May: “I also sent off £3 to D. Easton, abiding by your advice in regard to the room. If he wants a larger rent, let him ask for it” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).—I shd think he now more than ever requires such a Room; for he is buying very great quantities of Books, & seems to have that chiefly on hand at present. Poor good Jack: he too is growing old! He makes no complaint about anything, and is in good bodily health; but I think is not nearly so merry as heretofore. I hope James junr takes care of himself;—I trust to find you all well again some day: God grant it!Signature cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[Sir GS] [SGS], 24 May. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. Conjecturally identified as Sir George Sinclair because of his publicly expressed hostility toward Napoleon III.
div3.head: TC TO [SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR]

docBody.p:
You are very kind to think of me again, and remember me after so long a silence.If this letter is to Sinclair, then the letters of 2 and 8 Oct. 1859 (see 35:224TC to SGSOUC, 18 Oct. 1859, and 230TC to SGSOUC, 8 Oct. 1859) were almost certainly not to him but to an unidentified correspondent, as eight months would hardly constitute “so long a silence.” For TC’s last known letter (in 1855) to Sinclair, see 30:8–10TC to SGS, 24 July 1855. I agree heartily in your indignations and abhorrences about that conspicuous Devil’s-Servant who for the present is called “Emperor of the French,”Sinclair was known to regard “with an intensity of dislike I have never known to be surpassed, the conduct of Louis Napoleon ever since the coup d’état of 1852. [Sinclair] looked upon that deed … as the most enormous crime which has been committed in our day” (Grant, Sir George Sinclair 326).—and finds hitherto no Servant of The Other Party, sufficiently fixed in mind and circumstances, to take him by the beard, and fling him, and his sulphurous rubbish after him, home to the Place they will full surely reach by one route or another!—— But on such points I keep myself studiously
remote, studying not to think of them at all; tho’ well pleased to see honest men doing it, as they have opportunity.Sinclair repeatedly attacked Napoleon III in the Northern Ensign. Lord Derby, having read his letters there, wrote to him, 17 March, about the treachery of Napoleon and Victor Emmanuel (1820–78), king of Sardinia and Italy, in the annexation of Savoy: “Events are very critical at this moment, even more so than when you wrote: for the last forty-eight hours have completely stripped off the mask from both Emperor and King, and have shown themselves and their motives in the clearest, if not the cleanest point of view. What Europe will do remains to be seen; but I fear the various Powers are too much at variance with each other to hope that they will take the one safe course, and unite against the general disturbers of the peace of Europe” (Grant, Sir George Sinclair 333). Napoleon III had annexed Savoy ca. 12 March; the treaty of annexation was signed 24 March.

I am at a very low pitch at present; having had, and being still like to have for unlimited months, a most undoable problem in this poor Book of mine, whh I have got chained to, for my sins. Never in my life did there turn up for me so intolerable a burden as this, whh I look upon as the finale. Certainly either it must finish, or else I! The outlooks are sometimes very bad; then again not quite so bad. If I had any health left, I seem as if I cd still do it: but that is the ticklish point,—especially at the years I have reached. Silence, and the frugal employment of every available hour and resource, is clearly my only method. Not once in the month do I write even such a Note as this. If I live to get thro’, you shall hear more of me.

My Wife has been a good deal better last winter than for the preceding two, whh is surely to be counted a great alleviation in the bad times. She sends you many regards and wishes;—as do I; and am always,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[WPG] [SWPG], 24 May. MS: Mr. R. Hamilton. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified by references to Chequers and Lower Belgrave St. and by TC’s reference to “Sir William” in TC to [EAPG], 5 June. Sir William Payne-Gallwey (1807–81), M.P. for Thirsk, m., 1847, Emily Anne Frankland (d. 1913), third da. of Sir Robert Frankland Russell (1784–1849), 7th bart., and Louisa Anne, b. Murray (1790–1871), current owner of Chequers.
div3.head: TC TO [SIR WILLIAM PAYNE-GALLWEY]

docBody.p:
You are abundantly obliging:—and if you go on Saturday Afternoon, and dare undertake a Valetudinarian Companion (decidedly below par at this time, and longing for Country quietude, and silence more than anything), I shall be glad to attend you, and make some acquaintance with ChecquersChequers, Tudor mansion nr. Ellesborough, Buckinghamshire, 40 mi. NW of London. In 1715 it came into the possession of John Russell (1670–1735), son of Oliver Cromwell’s da. Frances (1638–1720), through his second wife, Joanne Thurbane Cutts Rivett (ca. 1684–1764). In 1837 the estate passed to Sir Robert Frankland Russell, a descendant of John Russell’s sister Elizabeth (1664–1733). His widow, Louisa Anne lived there until her death. The house contained a large number of pictures and relics of the Cromwell family. It is now the country residence of the British prime minister. &
the last KinswomanTC is possibly referring to the portrait of Frances Cromwell Russell painted by Heroman van der Mijn (1684–1741); she was Cromwell’s youngest child, and the last to die; see TC to [EAPG], 5 June. of a Hero with whom I have had a great deal to do in past years.

If Saturday be your day, perhaps I could catch you in Lower Belgrave StreetSir William’s London home was at 7 Lower Belgrave St. most conveniently of all? If you go on Friday,TC writes on Thurs. please let me know the name of the StationPrinces Risborough, about 2½ mi. SW of Chequers, on the Great Western line from Paddington. for Checquers, that I may try to follow next day. On Monday, the earlier in the day the better, I must be here again. Hampden,Great Hampden, 2½ mi. S of Chequers, birthplace of John Hampden (1595–1643), Puritan politician. He is buried in the church, and a stone cross in the grounds of Hampden House supposedly marks the spot where he first refused to pay ship money, levied by Charles I without consent of Parliament; see Works 6:93–94 and 97–98. I hope, is not too far from Checquers, for a sunday ride or walk?—

closer.salute: I am, with many thanks / Yours sincerely

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WMT, 24 May. Pbd: Anne Ritchie, “Chapters from Some Unwritten Memoirs,” Macmillan’s Magazine 66 (1892):348; Ray 4:187. Text: Anne Ritchie.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM MAKEPEACE THACKERAY

docBody.p: Alas, dear Thackeray, I durst as soon undertake to dance a hornpipe on the top of Bond Steeple,Presumably a misprint for “Bow”; Christopher Wren (1589–1658), had rebuilt St. Mary-le-Bow Church, 1671–80, after the Great Fire of London, with an elaborate steeple; it was 224 ft. high, surmounted by a red dragon weather vane, and was one of the landmarks of the London skyline. as to eat a white-bait dinner in my present low and lost state! Never in my life was I at such a pass. You are a good brother man; and I am grateful. Pray for me, and still hope for me if you can. / Yours ever,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[SL] [SLA], 25 May. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Correspondent conjecturally identified as Samuel Langley, who occasionally did research for TC; see TC to JN, 7 May. TC always addressed his other assistants, Larkin and Neuberg, by name.
div3.head: TC TO [SAMUEL LANGLEY]

docBody.p: mem. 1st.

The Battle of MollwitzThe battle of Mollwitz (10 April n.s.) was Frederick’s first battle as king and cemented his authority over the newly conquered territory of Silesia; see Works 15:114–40. was, 10 April 1741 (n.s. as always).— King George came down to his Parlt, 8th April (19th?), demanding a subsidy for Maria Theresa; and got it: £300,000,See Works 15:174–75. ‘April 11’ (I think). Upon whh I have these two queries:

First, Is the ‘8 April’ mentioned here, O.S. or N.S.?The date TC queries was 8 April o.s., 19 April n.s. (I suppose in some Parly History, Chandlers Debates,Richard Chandler, The History and Proceedings of the House of Commons from the Restoration to the Present Time, 14 vols. (1742–44). or the like, you will ascertain witht doubt; (Commons Journals, best of all; it is O.S. there always till 2 / 13 Septr 1752)—as also whether ‘April 11’ (22d?) is the real day when the Subsidy was granted.The subsidy was granted 14 April o.s./25 April n.s.: “That a Sum, not exceeding Three hundred thousand Pounds, be granted to his Majesty, for the further enabling his Majesty, in the most effectual manner, to support the Queen of Hungary, for preventing the Subversion of the House of Austria; and for the maintaining the Pragmatick Sanction, and supporting the Liberties and Balance of Power in Europe” (Journals of the House of Commons 23:705).

Second Query is, Had the news of Mollwitz reached England on 8 (19) April?As the London Gazette of April 11–14 o.s. recorded the news as coming in a dispatch from Berlin dated 15 April n.s. (4 April o.s.), it was heard in London between those dates.— That wd be rather curious to me. You can see what day in the old Newsprs the first mentn of it occurs,—at any rate. And indeed that is all you need do. (N.b. The same in regard to all the other Battles, if you easily can).

Mem. 2d.— The Library People (precisely at the wrong time!) have carried off my old Gentn’s Magazine;—and I indispensably want a few lines; whh you will find, readily by the annexed indicationPlease copy that Paragraph for me (with the date &c, as you usually do).TC quoted various passages from the Gentleman’s Magazine; see Works 15:185, 186, 195, and other vols.
Dear Sir,—If you cd have me the response to the above lying here on Monday before 2 p.m. it wd be a real furtherance.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-WMT, 26 May. Pbd: Anne Ritchie, “Chapters from Some Unwritten Memoirs” Macmillan’s Magazine 66 (1892):348 ; Works of William Makepeace Thackeray with biographical introductions by his daughter, Anne Ritchie (1899) 11:xxi; Ray 4:188. Text: Anne Ritchie (1892).
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM MAKEPEACE THACKERAY

docBody.p: Dear Thackeray,— The thing I contemplated just now (or the nucleus of the thing) was a letter concerning that anecdote about Fontenoy, “Faites feu, Messieurs,” on the part of the English, with answer from the Gardes Françaises, “Begin you, gentlemen; wouldn’t do such a thing for the world!”See Works 16:98–99. My letter is from Lord Charles Hay,Lord Charles Hay (ca. 1700–1760), maj.-gen., M.P. for Haddingtonshire, 1741–47, who distinguished himself at the battle of Fontenoy, 11 May 1745. For the battle of Fontenoy, see Works 16:93–103. Captain of the Scots Fusiliers, main actor in the business; it was sent me last year by Lord Gifford;George Hay (1822–62), earl of Gifford, eldest son of George Hay (1787–1876), 8th marquis of Tweeddale. and I could have made a little story out of it which would have been worth publishing.In the Cornhill Magazine.

But on applying to Lord Gifford, he (what he is himself, I believe, truly sorry for) cannot at present give me permission.Charles Hay’s letter, written to his eldest brother, John (d. 1762), 4th marquis, was in the family papers at Yester House, East Lothian; see Works 16:99. Presumably the marquis of Tweeddale did not want a family letter to appear in a monthly magazine, but he later agreed the use of it in Frederick (1864) 4:119. So the poor little enterprise falls to nothing again; and I may be said to be in a state of ill-luck just now!
If I ever in the end of this book have life left, you shall have plenty of things. But for the time being I can only answer de profundis [from the depths] to the above effect.

Fair wind and full sea to you in this hitherto so successful voyage, for which the omens certainly are on all sides good. Your people do not send me a copy (since No. I.);The first issue of the Cornhill was pbd. Jan. 1860; TC had been sent an advance copy; see TC to JAC, 29 Dec. 1859. but we always draw our purse upon it to the small extent requisite.— Yours ever truly,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[ET] [ETW], [29 May?]. MS: Houghton bMS Am 1498 (58–60). Ellen Twisleton identified as addressee by MS being with other letters to Twisleton. Dated on MS as ”?29 May 1860.“
div3.head: JWC TO [ELLEN TWISLETON]

docBody.p: Bless your dear little kind heart! No!— I did not “really mean anything”!
It was nonsense—a fashion of speech—a dodge to scare those, whom I did not wish to go to, from ever asking me!
I shall take no hurt from so short a drive in a close cab at this season of the year, even after dark. I felt quite sure of this when I said yes, with all my heart.—
I am just going off on an expedition of more danger—to lunch at Lady Airlie’sThe Airlies’ town house was at 27 Berkeley Sq. and go with her afterwards in an open carriage to the Hampstead road.
Put up a slight prayer for me!
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle
docBody.note: Lady William Russell wrote from Abergavenny, Monmouthshire, 27 May: “Dearest Mrs Carlyle / I have been 3 weeks ‘over the Hills & far away’———But notwithstanding the Distance am overcome & almost annihilated by the mild reproof in the Book Line!————I thought———(I dreamt?) that I had carried all the Books myself to your Door——?—& that you were out?—I return next week & will Call & bring them & throw myself at your Feet & hope for forgiveness?————I had the grippe since I Saw you & it was inter-minable & unconquerable & LEVELLING—I grieve much & more at your worse accident!! My Son (Arthur) urged me to accompany a charming little Lady to her Country House in Wales———whither She was returning alone———a 6 Hours rail———I did so———& am of Course recover’d———Arthur is here too profiting of his House of Commons Holidays——It is Pentecost———for the purpose of taking me back to Town————The Country is really Arcadian————& we lead an Idyllic Life FISHING included in our Pastoral occupations———But I shall soon resume “the Town Eclogue.” Arthur Russell was M.P. for Tavistock; the “charming little Lady” is not further identified.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 30 May. MS: NLS 517.4. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:207 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I am very greatly pleased that you have applied to me for poor old Mary Tait again:“Mrs. Grierson, née Mary Tait: the widow of an uncle of Carlyle’s (by marriage), Grierson of the Grove” (A. Carlyle’s note in NL). Mary Tait (ca. 1775–1861) m., 1811, John Grierson (ca. 1770–1828); his first wife (m. 1793) was TC’s maternal aunt Jean Aitken (d. 1810); see 4:3TC to MAC, 6 Jan. 1826, and 423TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1828. For TC’s previous finanacial contribution to members of this family, see 17:216TC to JCA, 26 Dec. 1843. I have many times thot she must surely be in need of some help I
could afford her; but was always till now denied the opportunity. Inclosed is £5,“31 May 1860 / Sister Jean (for / old Mary Tait) / £5..0..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). whh you are to dispose of for her,—in your most judicious but also most liberal manner. Let her have tobacco what she can set her face to; also tea &c, anything you can observe her to be in want of: she shall have more money whenever you inform me that this is done.—— I have long wished to ask you also about the poor Maffle Johnnie Grier: is not he quite broken down; thot to be dying; and in great poverty, with an ill wife &c?Johnnie Grier (ca. 1796–1860), general laborer, son of John Grierson and Jean Aitken, d. 16 Jan.; his wife was Mary, b. Bell (1811–79); they had two das., Janet (b. 1839) and Agnes (b. ca. 1849), and a son, James (b. 1840). I suppose it is because you do not think money could be advantageously laid out on him that you have either not spoken, or not spoken favourably of my projects in that kind. Consider it; and answer me more distinctly

It is a long time since I heard from you; but I impute it chiefly to your charitable notion of leaving alone to try if I can get my Devil fought down. I have had an awful time of it since about the beginning of February last: things do begin to look a little better with me; but the prospect is still sufficiently bad. I must do my wisest as well as my best. If I had health I could now do the Book; but I have not enough; and am not permitted to drive myself at the rate I used once.— It was quite a romantic meeting that of JimJean’s son James. & me in the crowded tumult of Piccadilly for a little moment! He was looking perfect; and, I do understand, is getting on in every respect well.— Jane keeps up wonderfully. I must end here; I have not yet got breakfast!— My Blessings on you, dear Sister. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HG, 30 May. MS: Grote Papers, A 3.5, Univ. Coll. London. Harriet Grote, b. Lewin (1792–1878; ODNB), writer, feminist, philosophical radical, and wife of George Grote (1794–1871; ODNB), historian and radical politician.
div3.head: TC TO HARRIET GROTE

docBody.p: I have your VoltairianaShe had previously lent him various books by and about Voltaire; see 29:246TC to HG, 8 Feb. 1855, and 30:7TC to HG, 10 July 1855. complete to the last item, and always discoverable, and returnable if you actually require, in a moment: but, alas, I have a great deal of hard work ahead before I can expect to have quite done with that miserable affair!

Of several of yr Books I have procured Duplicates; some of them are worthless to me; the only one I recollect (in this hurried moment) that promises to be essentially useful is Collini:Côme Alexandre Collini (1727–1806), natural historian; Voltaire’s secretary 1752–59; author of Mon Séjour auprès de Voltaire, et lettres inédites que m’écrivit cet homme célèbre, jusqu’à la dernière année de sa vie (Paris,1807); see Works 16:261 and 265. if you could let me keep that for another 6 months or 12? If you do wish it, pray tell me, and I will surrender it loyally at once. I have often thot of your kindness to me, of your great patience with me; and hoped I might find some opportunity of signifying that all was right on the Book side.

Your Note did not get to me till Monday Evg when I returned from the country; yesterday I expected you wd call,—& save me the expense of writing a Note, whh is a thing I always avoid if I can in these busy times.— I got hold of Ary SchefferHarriet Grote, Memoir of the Life of Ary Scheffer (1860); Ary Scheffer (1795–1858), Dutch painter; see 30:211JWC’s Journal, 4 Nov. 1855. Harriet Grote’s Memoir was reviewed in the Athenaeum, 14 April, by Henry Fothergill Chorley. the other day; & read the great part of it at one sitting, with much approval and entertainment.— — Please tell me at once if I must send the Collini, and do not fear to do it: the others I can send witht sacrifice to speak of.

closer.salute: Yours, dear Mrs Grote, / with many thanks & regards

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JDO], [2 June]. MS: NLS 1797.59. Hitherto unpbd. Dated with reference to JWC to JD, [4 June], where JWC quoted this letter and wrote about her sadness at learning that Jess Donaldson was already dead (she d. 1 June) when this letter was written.
div3.head: JWC TO JESS DONALDSON

docBody.p:
I think I should have cried, in receiving Mrs Campbell’sJess’s nurse; see JWC to EDEDO, [7 April]. letter; at the idea of your “wearing“—of your having been allowed the time to weary—“to hear from me“—if it hadn’t been for the knowledge that my letter would be in your hands almost as soon as Mrs Campbell’s was posted!— I did not forget on Wednesday. I am not apt to forget where my affections are concerned,—tho’ I never in my life could recollect some things—for example the multiplication table—historical dates,—or people I meet in society who havn’t interested me! But whoever or whatever might slip thro my head; it would never be you, Dear, or any known wish of yours—never, never as long as I live! And so, I would have made time for writing on Wednesday if I had not been unavoidably hindered till Thursday the week before, so that the
week was not absolutely out till Thursday— Tho’ I see now that was a stupid way of computing.

Oh my dear dear Friend! how unhappy it makes me to hear of your having caught fresh cold, and having bad nights, and being altogether so suffering!—And you must feel all your bodily ailments more severely now, feel them in all their natural painfulness now that the nervous strain is removed—the continual anxious thought and care of my beloved Godmother,Jean Donaldson, who d. 30 March. which was so long a sort of artificial strength for you, has found sad rest for evermore! Your own weakness of body, and shattered nerves was a terrible enough burden to bear; and in addition to that, there is now to be born the reaction of all your long anxieties and over exertions! Can I wonder that you are so suffering my poor Dear?— Alas! that there can be no wonder, does not make the fact less sorrowful to me!—

Actually I am terrified now to hear the Postman’s rap, and to open a letter! so much bad news has been the result of late! I don’t recollect if I told you that my other cousin John Welsh (my Uncle in Liverpool’s youngest and favorite son)John Welsh, son of JWC’s maternal uncle, John Welsh. died in America of a stroke of apoplexy a few weeks ago. He was the pet of the whole family, and his Brothers and SistersHe had two brothers, Alexander and Walter, and three surviving sisters, Jeannie, Margaret, and Mary. are in sore distress—not only at having lost him but that none of them should have been beside him at his death—and that his being so far away from them all had led to it; the climate and society of MobileMobile, Alabama, one of the wealthiest and busiest ports in the United States at the time because of the cotton boom. having a bad repute for betraying young men to a reckless course of Life.

Yesterday I had an intimation of the death of Robert MacTurkHe d. 30 May of apoplexy. (a very old Dumfrieshire friend, endeared to me by many associations, as well as by a lifelong affection for myself).

He too must have been cut off quite suddenly. For in two letters from different people, received within the last fortnight, he was mentioned to me as being “in the most flourishing condition, both as to health and fortune, of any man in Dumfrieshire.“— The Three black bordered lines, coming so soon after, to tell me he was dead, made me all but drop from my chair.— He has left a sweet little invalid Wife, who has been nursed and cherished like an infant by him for twenty years! One fancies she will just die of his death!Janet McTurk lived until 1871. He told me, when I saw him in Dumfrieshire two years ago, that he had “put all his affairs on the simplest footing, and so arranged his establishment that he might leave home and go anywhere &c—stay anywhere, just as his Wife’s
health required—at a days notice”! He has left home at short notice—but not with her—for her!“For,” i.e., the Scots “afore“: before.— Poor little sore-tried woman. She was an only child, a little Heiress,She inherited Hastings Hall, near Moniaive, Dumfriesshire, from her father, James Hastings, surgeon. and made so much of in her youth like some others of us.For JWC on herself as an only child, see 13:109JWC to TC, 22 April 1841, and 32:71JWC to MS, 11 Jan. 1857. Then came economic troubles, losses— But she had comfort thro all in her own only ChildJames Hastings McTurk. a son who was a wonderful bright and loving creature!— He lived to the age of twelve the joy of his house—and then died!— Since then her Husband has been Son and Father as well as Husband to her—and now—she is alone!—like you!
I will not write any more today for as you see there is not a cheerful word to be got out of me!
God be with you dearest Miss Jess
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC [JACA], 4 June 1860. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE THE YOUNGER

docBody.p: Dear James,— There are Two things at The Gill for whh I owe Jas Austin money:When TC paid for them in Sept., he still identified them as “two things“: “26 Septr 1860 / Jas Austin (for / the two things!) / £2..19..7” (TC’s checkbook; MS:NLS 20753). will you bid yr Father inquire for me there (by the first opportunity) what they are, and what the Cost was; that I may pay it, so soon as I know.

We are all in our usual state of health here (none of the strongest, some of us); and are sprawling along, thro’ the bad roads, at the old rate. Sorry that John has not got his Farm.James’s brother John had been interested in renting the farm Rosehill, approx. 3 mi. N of Dumfries, on the estate of the duke of Buccleuch. John A. Carlyle wrote a letter of recommendation to the duke, “in half a dozen pithy lines, for his time is always much occupied.” He then wrote to his nephew John, 23 May, quoting the duke’s reply and pointing out the advertisement for the farm had stated that the duke would “not be bound to let it to the highest offerer”; he hoped that John’s offer “was not too high.” Walter Francis Montagu-Douglas-Scott, 5th duke of Buccleuch (1806–84; ODNB). John A. Carlyle had traveled with Buccleuch and his family as their physician, 1838–39 (see 10:218TC to RWE, 15 Nov. 1838, and 221TC to MAC, 27 Nov. 1838).— With loving salutation to you all,—in great haste / T. C.An article in the Saturday Review (2 Jun. 1860), “Mental Stature,” praised TC: “Mr. Carlyle has perhaps done more than any other single individual to introduce the plan of looking … at the essence of men’s characters. … All his characters are drawn upon the supposition that every individual forms a whole, of which we can predicate all kinds of qualities which do not attach to any part of him in particular, but to the man himself, considered as an indivisible unit. … / There is a great deal to be said in favour of the mode of proceeding, when it is carried on by a man of genius. It is incomparably lively and interesting. … There is no one subject which Mr. Carlyle so much delights to draw as the hero or great man” (705–6).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD], [4 June]. MS: NLS 1797.170. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p: Oh my Dear, my Dear!— I could not have believed that Miss Jess’s deathJess Donaldson d. Fri., 1 June. would shock me as it has done! Since she was left alone there, so desolate, so suffering, I have not felt to expect or wish her life prolonged;—have said again and again, that it was to be hoped that she would not long survive her sister.Jean d. 30 March. But to say, even to think that was one thing; to feel it come true is another!— Then, I thought only of her, with her ailments and her sorrows, from which no deliverance was possible, while life endured; now I think of myself—who have lost, in these two dear old Sisters, not only the most loving, most faithful Friends that woman ever had; but the last living link between me and my happy childhood.

When I think of Sunny Bank all silent and empty—for me—for evermore!— I can’t cry—I dont grieve—it was so miserable to think of them alive as I saw them last! but—that strange, new silence and emptiness strikes to my heart like positive physical pain.
And it was so dreadful the way in which the news came to me!—
On Saturday morning I received a letter from Mrs Campbell.

Miss Jess had told her “last night” she said (that was on the Thursday night) to write to me, and “tell me how she was,” and that she was, “wearying to hear from me“— It was only six days since I had written her a long letter!, another letter from me would reach her on Friday morning a few hours after Mrs Campbells letter was written— The date of that being “11 minutes after 4—morning—Friday—in haste“— The account of Miss Jess, tho’ mentioning “increased weakness” and a“fresh cold caught,” had nothing immediately alarming in it—except for that strange minuteness of the date, which one might make much or little of according to the quality of one’s Imagination. I was inclined to take alarm at it. But Mr C, when I pointed it out to him, said he “saw nothing in it but a wish to be minute“—so I wrote another letter to Miss Jess,See JWC to JDJDO, [2 June]. and then one to Mrs Campbell asking about the perplexing line of
her note, and whether Miss Jess would like me to write her a short letter every day, instead of the accustomed long one, once a week. I got Mr C to take my letters to the post office in a Thunder shower; so anxious I was to not miss a post! Then I flung myself on the sofa to compose my mind; and I had not lain there many minutes when a note was brought me—it was from George Donaldson,George Hay Donaldson, Jess’s nephew. forwarding the telegraph message! My God! the kind heart which had just been “wearying to hear from me,” and which I had just been trying to comfort with the most loving, sympathizing words, had already ceased to beat—my written words would travel on at Railway speed, to a house of Death!—

I knew I should get a letter from you this morning waited for it as confidently as if it had been promised; For I have faith in your kindness and thoughtfulness have had, ever since that first night I spoke to you in the Drawingroom at Sunny Bank!They met Sept. 1857; see 33:89JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857.— YourThus in MS. remember?
And I have faith in your Husband,William Dods. of much longer standing!— I don’t believe he has the least idea how well I have kept him in mind all thro’ my womans life!
See what comes of helping a little girl with her problems and lending her white cotton stockings!See JWC to WDWDO, [30 Nov.].
I dont gather from your letter whether Mrs StarkUnidentified further. actually went, or was still there at the last.
Mrs Campbell never mentioned her.

George Donaldson’s note to me was very kind; with a touch of more earnestness in it than I ever saw in any of them.There was a large family of Donaldson nieces and nephews, whom JWC felt did not care for their aunts as they should; see 35:24JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1859.
And he calls the old place “Sunny Bank” not “Tenterfield”JWC also preferred to use the old name, Sunny Bank, for the Donaldson sisters’ house in Haddington; see 33:89JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857.—
God bless you both— I am horribly sad tonight but always affectionately yours / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[EAPG], 5 June. MS: NLS 2883.234. Hitherto unpbd. The addressee is identified by the references to her mother, Lady Frankland Russell, and to her husband, Sir William Payne-Gallwey.
div3.head: TC TO [EMILY ANNE PAYNE-GALLWEY]

docBody.p: Many thanks for your kind gift of the Cromwell Photographs:There were several portraits of Cromwell at Chequers, the most famous being that of Cromwell in armor, with a page tying his sash, painted by Robert Walker (ca. 1600–1658). According to Augustus Hare, who visited Chequers April 1860: “in its grand old gallery hung portraits of the Protector, his mother, brother, his four daughters, two sons-in-law, secretary, &c. Here, also, enclosed in a cabinet, was a very awful mask taken from Cromwell’s face after death, which Lady Frankland used to uncover with great solemnity” (Augustus J. C. Hare, The Story of My Life [1896–1900] 2:240). I have put them up in my Dressing room, that I may have them daily in my eye henceforth;—it seems these things have a tendency to fade in course of time, as we ourselves and all other things have! The little OliverPossibly the portrait of a two-year-old child said to be Oliver Cromwell, although of doubtful authenticity; see John Gilbert Jenkins, Chequers (Oxford, 1967) 124. is charming; so like the “mask” he ultimately left, too (not yr Chequers one),The “death mask” at Chequers is probably a cast from a bust of Cromwell by the sculptor Edward Pierce (ca. 1635–95). The bust is possibly based on the head of the funeral effigy modeled in wax by the official engraver, Thomas Simon (1623?–65) (Jenkins 123). TC had been given a cast of the original effigy by John Sterling; see 31:40TC to TWO, 2 March 1856, and 32:33TC to RST, 21 Nov. 1856. and all the good Portraits we have. Mary Cromwell (Lady Fauconberg) looks as if she had a red nose; which is not in the Painting, that I remember? Pray do not forget me when you attack the others: Richard Crl, Elizabeth (Claypole), and my “little Fanny” (your Ancestress, whom I had always figured as a young nimble girl of 18, and was astonished to find as a solid old gentlewoman turned 60, much resembling her Father, and of a good size among her fellow creatures)!The portraits of these four of Cromwell’s children were possibly the following: Mary Belasyse (ca. 1637–1713), Countess Fauconberg, painted by Cornelius Johnson (or Janssens) (1593–1661); Richard Cromwell (1626–1712), painted by Robert Walker; Elizabeth Claypole (ca. 1629–58), painted by Jacob Huysmans (ca. 1630–96); and Frances (Fanny) Russell, described by Mark Noble, Memoirs of the Protectoral-House of Cromwell (Birmingham, 1784) 2:401, as “a large sized woman,” painted by Heroman van der Mijn (Myn) ND100,0(Catalogue of the Principal Works of Art at Chequers [1923] 66 and 86). You will find somewhere in that BookTC had presumably given her a copy of Oliver Cromwell’s Letters and Speeches. a couple of invaluable young Letters from her Sister, on Fanny and her delicate affairs.There are two letters in the book from Mary Cromwell, both to her brother Henry (1628–74) and mentioning Fanny, one merely saying she had been ill, the other discussing Fanny’s proposed marriage to Robert Rich (d. 1658); see Works 8:243 and 256–59.

Thanks also for not mounting that alarming old fellow, with the eyes turned
up and wide-awake laid off,A photograph of TC himself; for TC in his “wide-awake,” see 33:frontispiece [available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 33]. who seems to expect very little good from the time coming, in a contradictory and evil world!

I retain a lively remembrance of Chequers, as is very natural; and of the good hospitable inmates there, who would have made a far less interesting place agreeable and memorable. May prosperity remain within its walls;Cf. Ps. 122:6–7. that is the least I can say and feel.
With many kind regards & thanks to Mamma and Sir William,Lady Louisa Anne Frankland Russell and Sir William Payne-Gallwey. I remain
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [6 June]. Addr: Thornhill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 6 Jun. 1860. MS: NLS 607.540. Quot: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:225–26.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I am really terrified just now to hear the Postman’s rap and to open a letter! one death after another, in which I have an interest more or less deep, has followed, till it is born in on me that every letter I receive, especially in an unknown handwriting, must be either “an intimation,” or news of deadly illness!

Two, within the last week, of my oldest friends! gone! the one so unexpectedly; for I had heard quite recently of Robert McTurkA. Carlyle noted that Robert McTurk was an “early lover of Miss Welsh, when she was ‘an extremely absurd little girl’” (A. Carlyle, NLM 2:225), quoting what JWC had said of herself in relation to McTurk; see 34:257JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1858. For an early reference to meeting McTurk, see 1:280JBW to EA, 14 Oct. 1820, and for his inclusion in JWC’s list of unacceptable suitors (which also included George Rennie), see 2:17JBW to EA, Jan. 1822. both from you, and from Mrs Pringle (Pott)Janet, previously Mrs. Pringle, now Mrs. Pott.—and both reported him so well! Mrs P said, I remember, that he was “the one flourishing man in that quarter“—

Too flourishing!— I take it for granted that he died of apoplexy!See JWC to JDJDO, [2 June].— My dear old Miss Jess Donaldson’s death was not unexpected for me; Since the elder Sister went, hardly two months ago, I felt sure the other would soon follow; the one interest and occupation and companionship in life that had kept her from sinking under a complication of ailments (the worst of them old age) being withdrawn; what indeed remained for that poor old solitary life-long invalid but to die?!— Those who loved her best could not wish her life
prolonged in such suffering and desolation! But it was so sudden a death at the last! almost without any increase of illness—a slight cold, that would not have killed a baby, killed her, worn to a shred as she was! And there were circumstances which made the suddenness a great shock to me, tho’ both expecting and wishing she might not live long!

On Saturday I received a letter from her Nurse to the effect that Miss Jess had desired her the night before to write to me, to tell me how she was, and that she was “wearying to hear” from me—(she had had a long letter from me just six days before! and another would reach her an hour or two after the nurse’s was posted! I had written to her once a week for years back—) The Nurses account told of “increased weakness” and “a slight cold” but did not suggest immediate danger. Only the date “4 in the morning in haste” perplexed my imagination— I was just going to write to you, to ask about Mrs MacTurk; but I wrote instead to the nurse, to ask how she came to be writing to me at that hour of the morning? “Was Miss Jess so ill that she had to sit up with her?” “What was the “haste” about?” And “would Miss Jess like me to write her a short note every day instead of the accustomed long one, once a week?”
This done, I wrote another long letter to Miss Jess herself. The dear old soul shouldnt be let “weary to hear from me” again!

The rain falling in torrents, I had a difficulty in getting my letters to the post office—at last they were posted and I laid myself on the sofa to rest, and think it all over— Before many minutes the Postman rapped and a note was brought me— I didnt know the handwriting and opened it with impatience, not to say indifference—for I guessed it was some bothering invitation that would require me to get up and write a polite refusal—

An invitation?— Good God! it was a note from George Donaldson (their eldest nephew, in London) telling me he had just received a telegraph message from the Haddington Banker(!)Probably William Dods, bank agent and a friend of the Donaldsons. to say Miss Jess was dead!

On Monday morning came a whole handful of black-bordered letters to me—all on the same subject—one from the nurse explained that, Miss Jess had told her on the Thursday night to write a letter to me in time for the eight oclock morning post— She was sitting up with her; but would not write while a candle was needed for fear of the light disturbing her. at four in the morning of Friday she said to the Nurse—“it is daylight now; couldnt you see to write to Mrs Carlyle” When the letter was written she (Miss Jess) got out of bed to read it!—but couldnt and bade the Nurse read it to her— “That will do” she said, “I am sure Mrs Carlyle will be sorry to hear I am so poorly and she hasn’t seen me”! The Nurse said “will I tell her to come; I had better—” “No! said the other not yet!—we will wait till we see her letter.” Nobody thought her so near
her end—she died at eight the same evening! The letter from me which reached her in the forenoon of her last day. She opened, but laid aside unread—saying “I cant be troubled to read it just now—I will read it after!”
Which the Nurse thought very strange “after having so wearied for it“—not seeing their was a worse weariness on her—the weariness of death!

Will you write and tell me any thing you know about Robert MacTurks death. and how that poor little sweet invalid womanJanet McTurk. is bearing it?— Surely it will be her death too! for he seemed to carry her thro life in his arms! I would like to write to her—just to say how sorry I am! But I am afraid of her being too ill to find a line from me anything but intrusive, There are some griefs too cruel for being touched even with a word of sympathy, and it seems to me this of hers must be such! Love to your Husband—
docBody.name: JWC

ps.p: My Husband is working himself to death—has no thought of going north this year!“Except a week or two at the Grange (January 1860), which did not hurt either of us, I think we had intended to make no visits this year, or as good as none. We did, however, and for good reasons, make two—hers, a most unlucky or provoking one, provokingly curtailed and frustrated, as will be seen. This was in August, to Alderley, and she could have gone further but for blind ill luck. Beginning of July she had tried a week or thereby of lodging at Brighton, and invited me, who tried for three days but could get no sleep for noises, and had to hurry home by myself; where also I could not sleep nor stay to any purpose, and was chiefly by brother John, who accompanied, led by sea to Thurso, for a ‘long sail’ first of all” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:18–19). TC went to stay with Sir George Sinclair at Thurso Castle 4 Aug. to 7 Sept.—and I shall not dare to leave him in his present way. I cannot make him take care of himself—but I can put all sorts of hindrance in the way of his absolutely killing himself.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 7 June. Addr: Elm Cottage, Old-Brompton Road / Old Brompton. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p:
Dear Larkin,—We were much shocked to learn contrary to our hope the great grief you had had.Unidentified. What a thing for your poor Sister,Ann Larkin. —alas!— You of course are extremely occupied; do not mind my small affairs, nothing presses there for weeks to come.— — I need at prest Orlich’s Book;See TC to HL, 16 May. and a Complete Map of Böhmen [Bohemia] & Mähren [Moravia], for a week or two. If
you can spare me yours, do; if not, please call at Wms & Norgate’s,Williams & Norgate, foreign booksellers, 14 Henrietta St., Covent Garden. aThus in MS. buy me new Nos of StielerAdolf Stieler, Karte von Deutschland (Gotha, ca. 1829–36), “excellent Map in 25 Pieces” (Works 14:352). for these Provinces. This only 2 or 3 shillings, never hesitate the least.

I begin to feel there will be Two big Maps needed (one for each vol.): Vol I’s Map ought to give up a good deal of the North, and something considerable of the West, and if possible take in the Donau [Danube] to Vienna.Vols. 3 and 4 of the first edn. of Frederick contain fold-out maps “For The First and Second Silesian Wars” (end of Works 15: end) and “For The Second and Third Silesian Wars” (end of Works 17: end). Can that be done? You may be considering till we meet
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 7 June. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 7 Jun. 1860. MS: NLS 553.220. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I know not whether you have yet been to look at the Museum Hyndford.John Carmichael (1701–67), 3d earl of Hyndford, diplomat, envoy to Prussia 1741–42. Following Frederick II’s invasion of Silesia in 1741, Hyndford was sent by George II to mediate between the Prussian king and the Austrian empress Maria Theresa. Most of his papers were in the State Paper Office, but there were also some in the British Museum; see Works 15:215. Neuberg replied, 9 June: “I have not been at Hyndford yet, but will look next week.” These two Leaves,Untraced. whh are mostly from yr Abstract are to go in (poor Book iii will require all to be re-written, alas!):—I want you to read the Piece over; noting any queries put &c; in short, doing for it what you can.Neuberg replied: “My ‘Notes’ from the State paper Office have nothing but what is in your ‘Abstracts’— / The last time I went to the State Paper Office (abt a year ago I think,) I made some researches for you about Ma Tha’s whereabouts at that period. You must have the notes somewhere.” That for first thing, please.—— I have [been]Word omitted. quite useless till today, all week,—owing to an accidental dog that barked, one night! There is a man to struggle with the German Dryt [Dryasdust], and extricate a Frh from the dust and ashes!— However, it must be done, or worse will come.

I have got a 10 little voll. (rather amusing, if one had time) Campagnes de
Broglio, de MailleboisPierre François Du Moulin, Campagne de monsieur le maréchal de Maillebois en Westphalie: L’an M.DCC.XLI. & II; Campagne de messieurs les maréchaux de Broglie et de BelleIsle, en Bohème et en Bavière: L’an M.DCC.XLI. [M.DCC.XLIII]; and Tables de ces campagnes pour les XIV volumes, vols. 8–26; pbd. as vols. 8–16 and vol. 27 of Recueil des campagnes de divers maréchaux de France, 27 vols. (Amsterdam, 1760–73); see Works 15:251. TC wrote about them: “Campagnes des Trois Maréchaux (Maillebois, Broglio, Belleisle; Amsterdam, 1773) … in nine handy little volumes … and … Index … which are elucidative beyond bargain, and would even be amusing to read,—were the topic itself worth one’s time” (Works 15:251). Jean-Baptiste François Desmarets (1682–1762), marquis de Maillebois; Victor François (1719–1804), 2d duc de Broglio or Broglie. &c (perfect indexes of every kind); out of whh I think you might pick me a good many useful things. I will put them down in queries, as I go on, and give you the Books first time you are here.
I like summer rain in London; but here is rather a superfluity of the good thing!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG [AGIL], 13 June. Pbd: Gilchrist 79.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: My Dear! Behold a cap! Fresh from India—a delicate attentionCoterie speech; see 24:161JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849; otherwise untraced. to Mr. Carlyle on the part of a Lady! But the cap fits Mr. C.’s large head like an inverted tumbler! so I laid it aside to give you when you came as a delicate attention to PercyHer eldest son, Percy Carlyle Gilchrist, nine years old. on the part of me!

Now you have come so seldom lately and staid so short a time, that I have never got subsided into recollection of the cap—so I transmit it by Charlotte—who is much obliged to you for sending her tea all in a heap instead of in quarters, as it insures her better weight measured out by me!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [16 June]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:418–19 inc; Hansons, NE 485–86 inc. Dated by the imminent birth of the Ashburtons’ child.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Oh thank you, Lady dear! I am so glad, and obliged! I wasn’t expecting any sign of remembrance; had, indeed, no claim to; but—I was wishing for one
all the same; my Thought of you was feeling to need one, just as Alum in solution (it may be said, in highly figurative speech) feels to need a thread for crystallizing on!!

You think; why couldn’t your last letter have sufficed for that purpose?— It was a dear lovely letter, and, truly, it might have given the encouragement I required for writing, any time betwixt then and now—if, betwixt then and now, things had been going on with me in a natural human way;—but they haven’t, that is the fact! The way they have been going on has been quite the contrary of natural and human! That unlaid and apparently unlayable Ghost of “Frederick” has broken all bounds latterly; reminding me rather poignantly of old Dr Ritchie, the Edinr Professor of Divinity,’sWilliam Ritchie (ca. 1748–1830), prof. of divinity, Univ. of Edinburgh, 1809–28; see 1:97TC to RM, 31 March 1817. description of a certain Personage; “with the trumpet of Discord in his mouth, and the Torch of Dissension in his hand (Pray picture him to yourself!) he goeth about as a roaring Lion seeking whom to devour! and, when he hath set son against Father and husband against wife, he returns to his Den, with a horrible grin on his countenance, rejoicing in the mischief he hath wrought”!!TC was also to quote Ritchie’s description of the devil who “after succeeding in his vile machinations retires to his infernal den and grins with horrid satisfaction!” (Allingham 232). For the roaring lion, see 1 Pet. 5:8; for raising family dissension, see Luke 12:53.

Whereby I merely mean to say,—in plain English,—Mr C has been getting on dreadfully ill with that unlucky book—and his health and spirits, and especially his temper, have suffered in consequence, to a degree that has been making me not only very sorrowful but very anxious. Indeed I never before in all my life have seen him so—what shall I say?—“put out”! (that is the strongest Cockney term for mental upset, from whatever cause! A woman here, who had just seen a poor little Boy’s head split into two by a wheel of Pickford’s Vans,National firm of carriers. and waited till the mother was brought, answered my question; “Oh what did become of her?” with, “Oh, well Mam; as you may think; she was sadly put out!!“—)— Now, besides the worry of seeing him and feeling him in this state, I have been “suffering Martyrs” (as a French friendEtienne Paulet (d. 1850; see 25:34025:biographical note); coterie speech; see 31:201JWC to TC, 29 Aug. 1856. of mine used to express it) from rheumatic pains in my own head; and all this together has produced a solution of continuity in my small Life,—torn up, as it were, a furrow thro it, which alters nothing of what was a few weeks since but alters my own firm hold of it all—so that I need to take a new grasp, over the interruption. Do you understand what I mean? I should think not! When one lives much alone, one feels so many things one never puts into thoughts, not to say, words! No wonder if one gets to express oneself obscurely and fancifully!

When will that Baby take a notion of coming to light?Mary Florence Baring was b. 26 June. I declare I never cared so much for any prospective Baby in all my life before! I actually dreamt about it the other night! dreamt that I was at the Grange, and heard it crying, and felt it my duty to go and feed it (!!) and went wandering about in the dark and could never find it! And still the crying became more and more plaintive till—it awoke me! Awoke me to the vexatious discovery that our poor cat had been shut out from her week-old-kittens, and was mewing, like to break her heart, to get at them!For the cat’s previous litter, see 35:249JWC to JACA, 31 Oct. 1859. a consumation only brought about thro’ my getting out of bed, and putting some clothes on, and going down stairs.

Just think of poor Miss Wynn!Charlotte Williams Wynn.— She was on the point of returning to London after six weeks—of Yorkshire, when a letter came to her from her Cook, that she (the cook) “wished to leave in three days“— “By all means” wrote Miss Wynn; “tho’ I think such conduct very extraordinary“— But before her answer could have reached Green Street, a Telegram arrived from the Housemaid to say the cook had got a Baby in Miss Wynn’s house, and what was she, the virtuous housemaid, to do?— “To go for a married woman was the only thing she had been able to think of in the meantime.” She wrote by first post— So Miss Wynn had to stay another ten days in Yorkshire till mother and child were fit to be removed.

I saw Lady Sandwich on Monday, just returned from Hinchenbrook— She looked dreadfully ill, but professed to be better than when she left London in a snow storm! I think her grandchildren are becoming a great comfort to her.

Here is something for you to tell to Lord Ashburton. A Lord Somebody (I forget the name) was talking to one of his farmers on the news of the day—“Pray, said the Farmer what is your own opinion of this Pope, they talk so much of?“— “Well! replied the Lord,—I don’t know what to say—I did think when he began his career that he wished to govern on liberal principles”Giovanni Maria Mastai-Ferretti (1792–1878), elected Pope Pius IX 1846, began as a liberal and reforming pope, but was not prepared for the radicalism of those who wished to unify Italy under temporal power.—“Oh said the other interrupting, I don’t mean that—I dont know anything about governing and politics and all that, what I want to know is; what sort of Man is the Pope? does he make a good Husband and a good Father”?

Oh my Lady,! there is something I want you to give me! I have not seen it; but I have heard of a photograph of you lying on the hearthrug, as I once saw you, and shan’t ever forget having seen you— Miss Emily Baring has got it, and one of Lord Ashburton that is thought excessively like— They were gone to be framed when I was there, but ever since I heard of them I have been wondering if you had any more copies and would give us them! Perhaps I
should have made a question of conscience of asking for them, and gone on wishing for them, without ever mustering courage to ask; if it hadnt been for the case of conscience propounded in the Saturday Review, “should or should not the young Lady ask for a little more cream to her tea”!Possibly referring to the article “Economy,” Saturday Review 9 (2 June): 704–5, in which the author disputes the assumption that thrifty wives are necessarily superior to spendthrift ones: “It is not obvious that a bad manager who had partaken of the humble milk in her tea … would not have had something to say for herself” (705); otherwise untraced. which Mr VenablesGeorge Stovin Venables. was making me laugh with last night— If you dont like to give me the photographs it is so easy to refuse— So there cant be much harm in asking—as it is not in a novel by a woman—where as the Saturday Reviewer said every thing was made a case of conscience of—
Oh there is a carriage! God bless you—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GC and MC [GCMC], 18 June. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGIANA CRAIK AND MARY CRAIK

docBody.p: I laid the address carefully in my pocketbook, in the idea of going to find it this day in person— But it has just struck me that people dont come from Belfast to London for the purpose of sitting inside 2 Little Smith Street Westminster and that I havn’t the least earthly chance of finding yourselves when there!—
Better to write then and beg you to fix an evening for coming to tea—

We never go to parties so—any evening will suit us—only tell me the evening in time to get an answer—in case of its falling out at the same time as a two days investigation of the south coast I am about to enter onSee JWC to JN, [22 June].—

I shall be so glad to see you all again— You will find me better than last time,Presumably when JWC traveled to Scotland with the Craiks, July 1857; see 32:173–74JWC to TC, July 1857. tho’ I have just been going thro the process of a broken rib! Mr C is overworked and haggard—and poor wee Nero you will not find at all!— He died on the first of February this year—and a sore business that was for me! Nobody but one who has been “the first” object in the heart of a loving little dog for eleven years can understand how sore it was!

p.name: Jane W Carlyle
p.note: Georgiana Craik’s most recent work, My First Journal: A Book for the Young (1860), was reviewed by Geraldine Jewsbury, 2 June: “This ‘First Journal’ is by no means ‘a book for the young,’ such as we should wish any young people of our own to take in hand. It is rather a book such as a grown-up silly young lady might indite by way of a make-believe journal. This story is not even amusing; and the chief speaker, the writer of the journal, is a very unpleasant, self-conscious, disagreeable little girl. Miss Craik has not the fairy gift of writing stories for children” (Athenaeum 755).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JN, [22 June]. MS: NLS 554.59. Pbd: Scudder 27–28. Dated by surrounding letters.
div3.head: JWC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Mr C has as good as engaged to go to SouthendSeaside resort town in Essex, 40 mi. E of London. tomorrow; provided you came along with us; and I was on the point of writing to that effect. Now he has “reconsidered the matter“—(A most distressing turn for reconsidering that man has!)—and the result is an obstinate determination not to stir—“with the light he at present has.“— Clearly the only chance to get him out of this bad train of awaking at unseasonable hours“Early in the summer of [1860], I was visited by sleeplessness; and first began to have an apprehension that I should never get my sad book on Friedrich finished, that it would finish me instead. I still remember well enough the dark, cold, vague, yet authentic-looking feeling of terror that shot athwart me as I sat smoking ‘up the chimney,’ huddled in rugs, dressing-gown and cape, with candle on the hob, my one remedy in sleepless cases; the first real assault of fear, pointing, as it were, to undeniable fact; and how it saddened me the whole of next day. The second day, I compared it to Luther’s temptings by the devil; and thought to myself in Luther’s dialect, ‘Well, well, Herr Teufel, we will just go on as long as we are alive; and keep working, all the same, till thou do get us killed!’ This put away the terror, but would by no means bring the sleep back. I recollect lying whole nights awake, still as a stone; getting up at six, and riding to Clapham Common, to Hammersmith region, by way of surrogate for sleep” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:25–26). is that I should go myself to Southend, in the first instance, and qualify myself for reporting about “quiet beds” &c from my own experience.
So are you prepared to go with only me tomorrow, by the 2.22 train?—to stay till Monday—if possible? If not, could you send me by the first post tomorrow precise directions about your “quiet Inn“—
I am very bothered and miserable—shall be glad to have a calm hour or two at the seaside on my own basis
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Tell me precisely where I am to meet you—unless you will come for me here—
That is if I am to meet you at all

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 24 June. Addr: Elm Cottage, Old-Brompton Road / Brompton. PM: London, 25 Jun. 1860. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Wd you bring me back that Piece of Book II;TC probably means the second book in vol. 3 of Frederick (Works 15:1–198), which he was working on at this time. I considerably want it here; and I dare say you have quite done with it (“picked all the names out of it”)Presumably Larkin was indexing. long ago.—— I have got a couple of old Letters (very short, and more like Notes) for your Copying. Getting on very slow, as usual!
docBody.name: T. C.
docBody.note: John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle the younger, 25 June: “Your uncle and aunt I saw last night, & found them as well as usual—which is not very well. He still comes to me, every night almost, when out walking” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [29 June]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 252. Dated by the Carlyles’ forthcoming trip to Brighton.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh my Lady! I should so like to see Her! Your wee Bairn!Mary Florence Baring, b. 26 June. The Inverness Courier announced, 5 July: “Brahan.— The news of the birth of a daughter to Lady Ashburton was celebrated with much enthusiasm on all parts of the Seaforth estates. Bonfires were erected on no less than twenty conspicuous places, and at every one there was a band of ‘Caberfeigh men,’ who pledged a hearty bumper to the little stranger.” “Caberfeidh” is Gaelic for deer antler, the badge of the Clan Mackenzie. Lord Ashburtons own wee Bairn!— I am going on Monday to Brighton for a week, and that would be long to wait. Will you give orders that, if She be awake when I call tomorrow, they will show her to me for a minute?

Of course she will be quite red still! But I am as sure as you are, that she will grow up very beautiful and very good; and be the light of her Father’s eyes and the joy of his heart. And no little Brother who may come will ever be able to displace her from the first place in your hearts.

Will you care to read a letter from dear ‘St Thomas’?Thomas Erskine. His voice is always soothing to me— I think his memory is failing; he asks; “how do I like Lady
Ashburton?”Erskine wrote, 25 June: “How do you like Lady Ashburton? I like her & believe her to be cordial & upright.” In a letter of 4 July, he mentioned that his sister Christian Stirling ” reminds me (for I woefully need reminding now).” and on my return from the Grange I wrote the dear man a long letter all about how I liked Lady Ashburton and no other topic!— And his answer was full of compliments on my right reading of you!—

When I got Lord A’s announcement I ran with it to Mr C, and what do you think were his next words after the; “Well! Thank God it is all safely over”! his next words were, “Is your note from the Lady herself?—!!“— “My gracious! I cried, how can you be so absurd as to imagine her up to writing notes the instant after her confinement?“— “Well my Dear! said he, I dont pretend to know what people are up to in these cases. The Lady seems to have all along been up to more than most women who have nothing of the sort the matter with them—and how could I know that she would break down at the last?”!!! What a wonderful thing a Man of Genius is to be sure!
Oh my Lady you wont forget to tell me when I may come and sit with you.
We shall not be away more than a week.

closer.salute: Yours with the heartiest and truest good wishes

docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JN, [3 July]. MS: NLS 554.56. Pbd: Scudder 28–29.
div3.head: JWC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.dateline: Mrs Nicholsons 46 Waterloo Street / Brighton Tuesday [3 July 1860]
docBody.p: Oh Mr Neuberg what a goose I am! I left the address you gave meProbably Neuberg’s address in London as he had apparently not yet arrived in Brighton. behind at Chelsea and couldn’t communicate with you till Mr C came.

I found the Lodgings all that could be wished and more— The price being more—two guineas and a half per week— But then the rooms are lovely, and the Landlady “a Mother to me” (as Miss Barnes promised—and what is more to the purpose a first rate cook! And there isn’t a bug in the house—nor a flea—nor a speck of dust!
if Mr C can only sleep! He is hardly giving himself a fair chance for the night having had one sleep before dinner and being now preparing for another after dinner—

He came by the 12 oclock train. There is a Parrot in the kitchen calling itself Jacko, but Mr C dont know of him! There is also “one pet hen” in
an adjoining garden; but that as the Landlady shrewdly remarked “doesn’t crow”! There is a crowing cock-a devil of a cock—to the front however—who kept me awake two hours this morning—but Mr C cant hear him in his back room—

The only rock ahead that I see is a noise of carts in the early morning, bringing coals from a yard beyond the gardens behind— I know all about everything already, having spent the night in trying the several rooms!! If he goes to sleep undisturbed he wont hear them—and catch me telling him!

It is quite delightful here! such beautiful—food!—since my scotch experiences last summer I have come to think a good Butchers shop round the corner much more important than picturesque scenery— So make haste or you wont have the pleasure of our company—we shan’t stay more than a week
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Tait called on Sunday Night and had a photograph of his Baby and one of the MotherRobert and Harriet Tait’s da. Mildred was born 21 May. after her confinement in his pocket and showed them to Mr Carlyle!!!!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 4 July. MS: NLS 525.64. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,— I got well enough on to Brighton yesterday; indeed had nothing to complain of, except that at Wandsworth London suburb S of the Thames, approx. 2 mi. from Chelsea. while we never dreamt of such a thing our door opened,TC’s traveling companion is unidentified. and a whole cartload of children with two parents (fat grocer-looking people) were tumbled in upon us, and we had to ride on those terms, 12 or 13 souls I shd think & no steady supply of air except thro’ my poor window! Happily it ended in 2 hours; and I got to our lodgings, a very nice cool place, and was soon after joined by Jane, who seemed no worse for her change to the sea side. I expected to do very well all yesterday; and still hope I shall, tho’ not so emphatically,—the diligence of cocks &c having (in spite of all assurances) been busy upon me, so that my sleep was broken, tho’ in sum I had a good deal of it, and feel a little better. I must try to do my best tonight and endure the annoyance with the minimum of flurry. The Town is quite beautiful, so cool, clean, airy, wholesome; I have been twice in the sea, & find it profitable and delightful: in short, if I could find a quiet sleeping place to the other qualities our lodging has I shd be quite right and certain to improve much in a day or two. We were at Rotting-DeanA small town 4 mi. E of Brighton where JWC had previously considered renting a cottage; see 30:30 JWC to TC, 14 Aug. 1855
, and 33:256 JWC to TC, 27 June 1858
. today, pleasant wholesome drive; tomorrow we must go somewhere else, and keep upon the move. We have seen nobody; not even Neuburg, who is probably here somewhere since some hours. In the morning indeed we did call on poor Mrs Ross (Kate Sterling that was),Kate Ross, to whom JWC had been close before Kate’s marriage in 1856. and her Husband walked with me over the “Brn Teapot”The Royal Pavilion; built, 1786–1822, for the Prince of Wales (later George IV) in a mixture of oriental styles, it had been purchased from the crown in 1849 by the Brighton Commissioners; see 143 above . It was used for many kinds of public and private entertainments. TC also used this name for it in 1828; see 4:434 TC to TD, 11 Dec. 1828
. while Jane spoke a little to her.—

figure.p: “The Grand Entrance to the Brighton Pavilion”
John George Bishop, The Brighton Pavilion (Brighton, 1875)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
Any light reading rubbish might have a chance here better than it has at Chelsea commonly!— Adieu, dear Brother: Yours ever
T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO], [5 July]. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the trip to Brighton.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: The Addiscombe Hamper may be expected tomorrow as usual. Unpack it yourself and try to scald the cream as I did stirring it one way over the fire till it begins to boil— Perhaps it will keep till Monday
Mr C may be home sooner— Tomorrow if he does not have a better night— I have had much difficulty in keepingMS ends here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 July. MS: NLS 525.65. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am going on pretty well, and really rather improving, in spite of my extreme bad luck in regard to sleep,—1½ hour, 3 hours, 6 do, my respective allowances since the time you last heard. I have, for the last 2 nights, changed with Neuberg, who has a much quieter place, and who can sleep in any place, indifferent like a stone: one way and other, I will manage the remaining 2 nights; and on Monday we come away.TC wrote on Sat. This Town is the best bathing-quarters I ever saw; many excellt lodgings in it too, and I have no doubt one might be got of feasibly quiet character. This present, except for noise, is first-rate. Poor Jane, tho’ much disturbed too in her own premises, and still more by anxieties abt mine, is evidently getting good, the element is otherwise so perfect, the sea so beautiful and pure, the air so fresh, all things so good. One might have a very nice House here; I believe, by making proper examinations;—away on the Hilltop, I shd think, the lodgings must be quieter than here. The last two Nights I have sat serene, twice over, in Neuberg’s balcony in Bedford Sqre, and smoked under the moon and over the slowly swinging sea. Beautiful if one were well!—

Mrs Ross (“Kate Sterling” that was) is here with her Husband, in a very sickly way,—we think nervous rather than yet pulmonary. The Husband is an eloquently talking man; really very kind of nature; but much wanting backbone. Robertson’s marriage, it seems, is off; former wife still living!John Robertson (1811–75; see 9:337TC tp JSM, 30 Oct. 1837), journalist, known to the Carlyles since 1837; he had first introduced Alexander J. Ross to JWC, ca. 1851; see 30:234JWC’s Journal, 25 March 1856. For some of Robertson’s previous amorous adventures, see 19:49JWC to JW, 5 April 1845. His intended and his “former wife” are unidentified. I have
not seen him, nor will: Ross thinks him as good as mad; tumbling on, I suppose, with Vanity and tinctured Sensuality for guides, as of old.—— The beggarly works of Hanbury WillmsSir Charles Hanbury Williams (1708–59), satirical writer and diplomat; envoy at Dresden and Berlin, 1747–54; for The Works of the Right Honourable Sir Chas. Hanbury Williams, 3 vols. (1822), see Works 16:245. are on my Bookshelves; may lie there till I return on Monday. I want to take a Note or two from them first: good, except in that way, they can do to no man. Monday some time I hope to see you again. Adieu dear Brother. T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HF [HFE], [ca. 10 July]. Pbd: Hansons, NE 488–89 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO HELENA FERME

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! how provoked I was to find your and your husband’sJohn Ferme. names on my return from Brighton! I hadn’t been a day out of London since New Year time and I was gone only a week! … But I can trust to its not being out of sight out of mind with you and him. In spite of all the cross things you say of yourself, I have always thought you had a warmer heart than many sweeter-spoken people!—so I expect you to keep me in kind remembrance tho’ you failed to see me here, and tho’ I have no definite prospect of ever seeing you at Haddington again! Now that dear old Sunny Bank is fallen empty and silent—forevermore empty and silent for me at least—I shudder at the idea of ever setting eyes on Haddington again! While even one of them lived, I had still a feeling of homeness there! But nowPbd. extract ends here.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [11 July]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
But I did see Her, my dear Lady! did see your “little brown Beauty”Lady Ashburton wrote, 9 July: “I sent 3 orders that day that you were to be shown up to see my wee Brown Beauty—not one was given! & I was so grieved to hear you had been, & gone! I long to show my wee Bairn to you—all my heart is centred in her—& she is such aGood Pet—such a sweet thing—does Everything a Baby ought to do—& nothing it ought not—& her father is so fond of her—so proud of her—as who would not be?” before I went to Brighton; and carried away the most bewitching impression
of Her!— Every facility was given me; the men seemed to have constituted themselves nurses for the time! the Porter, Groom was each as proud of Her as ever nurse was of her charge, and vied with each other in zeal to show her to me!——“only I was to walk softly; and not let my voice be heard by her Ladyship in the next room; It was the Dr’sUnidentified. Dr. James Rouse had been the Ashburtons’ doctor in the country (see 31:22JWC to DD, 2 Feb. 1856); he was listed as a surgeon, 62 Coleshill, Eaton Sq. Charles Locock (1799–1875; ODNB), obstetrician, was Lady Harriet’s doctor in town (see 23:119–20TC to JAC, 25 Sept. 1848) but had retired in 1857. orders when he left, that her Ladyship was to be kept very quiet.“—

And it was charming to meet the enquiring, pleased looks of these men on my return from the nursery! bearing out their words “she is an uncommon fine Child Mam?“— The Porter added “did you ever see such a head of hair? why it is as long as that! (measuring two inches on his own finger)!”

Oh yes! I saw her all over, lying like a pearl in an oyster shell in her pink and white basket! and not only saw her but touched her—with the tip of my finger! and I drew a finger thro her long dark soft hair—and finally, my enthusiasm having reached a pitch, I went on my knees and kissed her cheek, lightly as if it had been a butterfly’s wing that might have the colours rubbed off with a touch!— The dear wee Bairn!— It puckered all its bit face together into the queerest, funniest yawn! as much as to say; “Please don’t! now—do go away”! and I went away vowing inwardly a life-long interest in Her and a loyal affection to Her,—the first human child that had ever, so to speak, come home to my business and my bosom!Cf. Francis Bacon, The Essayes or Counsels, Civill and Morall, of Francis Lo.
