Verulam, Viscount St. Alban (1625), dedication; see also 35:38JWC to GEL, 20 Feb. 1859.—and awakened what is called the maternal instinct in me—me whose lines have always been cast in Babyless Places!

I dont understand about St Thomas! He gave you the highest praise that could be put into words “cordial and upright”Lady Ashburton asked: “is St Thomas’s opinion who I love so much, so small of me?” For Thomas Erskine’s letter, 25 June, see JWC to Lady ALLA, [29 June].—what more could be desired in Woman? and that from a man who always means what he says and expresses his true meaning in the very briefest, simplest terms he can find for it!
How many women do you yourself know in the world whom you could stake your life on the cordiality and uprightness of? I know so few who combine these qualities!

But of this when I come on Friday—as of course I mean to.Lady Ashburton wrote: “Will you come & see me the end of the week? Let me know what day & hour? Friday would suit me—before then, I am scarcely able.” I will come
between 12 and 1—as being the time of day when you are likely to feel freshest— If it should happen that you would rather not be troubled with me then,—would prefer another time,—I trust you will feel no reluctance to sending down a message to that effect.
I have enough to tell about Brighton! how cocks crew! and it all ended in “immortal smash”!Coterie speech; see 14:210TC to TSS, 26 June 1842. Oh dear oh dear!
I am like poor Martha in the Scriptures “troubled about many things”Luke 10:41.—but ever
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [13 July]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 13 July 1860. MS: NLS 553.222. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—We hope you are got back, safe, and the better for yr week of sea air. We look for you on Sunday Evg to report progress.

There is a paltry little Book, Works of Sir C. Hanbury Williams, 3 voll. 12 mo,See TC to JAC, 7 July. for whh they have been clamouring at the Library since before I returned from Brighton: I think you got it, in regard to some Russian matters: pray let them have it again,—with blessings, wretched rag that it is!

If you find any marginal marks, save them. There are some scandalous details abt the Court of Dresden (Kurfürst King of Poland,Friedrich August II (1696–1763), elector of Saxony and king of Poland. and Daughter-in-law who was Frh’s correspondent, and a very clever creature):The da.-in-law was Maria Antonia (1724–80), princess of Bavaria, who m., 1747, his eldest son, Frederick Christian (1722–63). Hanbury Williams says of her: “Before she came here, she was reckoned to meddle much in politics, and to be in the French interest. She denies all this herself, and declares against women’s meddling in state affairs; but I will venture to prophesy, that if ever the Prince Electoral should outlive his father, she will govern this country most absolutely” (Hanbury Williams, Works 2:218). I shd like to have the reference (page &c) to that, in case of need,—tho’ it is not credible to me, except in a sense.Hanbury Williams alleged that the king was having an affair with his own da., Maria Anna Sophia (1728–97), who m., also 1747, Maximilian III (1727–77), elector of Bavaria. “He [the king] has had a great loss in the Electress of Bavaria being married, for she often came to him in the afternoon, and they have been surprised together in very indecent postures. The Queen knew this, and was furious about it. She complained of it to her confessor, but the good jesuit told her, that, since things were so, it was much better that the King’s affections should remain in his own family, than be fixed upon a stranger, who might be a Lutheran and do prejudice to their holy religion; and thus the holy casuist appeased her angry Majesty. / The whole court is now gaping to see who will succeed the Electress; for his Majesty’s Constitution requires somebody beside the Queen. … When [Maria Antonia, his da.-in-law] first came, she had flattered herself with hopes of succeeding the Electress, and attacked the King the first night, but without success” (Hanbury Williams, Works 2:213–17). TC dismissed “the rumoured mysteries” as “mere poisoned wind”; see Works 16:246.
Please bring back the War-summaryUntraced. (if indeed I gave it you!) so soon as you can conveniently.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GS [SGS], 16 July. MS: Houghton Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR

docBody.p: The sight of your handwriting is again welcome to me; thanks for all the friendlinessess it has been the sign of to me, first and last. I will look into the Piozzi,Hester Lynch Piozzi (1741–1821), writer; Observations and Reflections made in the course of a Journey through France, Italy, and Germany, 2 vols. (1789). what babble she may have gathered from the Berlin circles when Frh had just left them.Piozzi was in Germany the winter of 1786–87, a few months after Frederick’s death, 17 Aug. 1786; she visited his tomb, his town house in Potsdam, and his summer palace, Sans Souci (Piozzi 2:357–61). “As he expired he said, I give you a vast deal of trouble. We saw the spot he sate in at the moment … his servants wept as they repeated the particulars, caressing while they spoke his favourite dogs, one of which, a terrier, could hardly be prevailed upon to quit the body” (Piozzi 2:360). For TC’s description of Frederick’s death, see Works 19:296–98.

By this post I send you a couple of German volumes; whh are not good for much anywhere, and are good for nothing here or like to be, but whh may amuse a leisure hour to you who have such. You must at any rate read the Murder of Major Sinclair the Swedish EnvoyMalcolm Sinclair (1690–1739); a major in the Swedish army, he came from a Scottish family that had been in service in Sweden since the Thirty Years’ War (1618–48); for his murder, see Works 15:80–81. (who I think must have been a remote Kinsman withal);No direct kinship traced. it is a very black story, and I never saw it clearly set forth, vouchers in hand, before. The small red volume is for any grand child you may have who is learning German;Unidentified. your own uses with it a few minutes will satisfy.

I am getting on very ill here;—chiefly for want of sleep, if you know what that sore evil is. I feel as if I were a little getting above my Book, as if I could now write it, wd my health hold out; but the latter element proves capricious upon me, as above. We tried Brighton, and it wd have been extremely salutary; but to get a sleeping room with silence and purity of air was not possible: so Brighton had to be given up: nor does home yet completely prosper, in spite of my precautions.

Your Note awoke in me a brilliant idea; that of gathering certain confused Mss together, along with a few Books that might be made sufficient, and making off by sea for Thurso Castle, there to finish off vol iTC means the first of his next two vols. of Frederick to be pbd.; i.e., vol. 3. while the hot weather lasts!— Alas, alas, one looks only at the goal whh is very pretty, 500 miles off, and one forgets all the lions by the way. I communicate this small spiritual phenomenon to you; for it will probably have vanished again, sunk in impossibilities, before I could hear from you again. My Wife is tolerably well, “for her”; and sends you along with me many kind regards. Yours sincerely T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GS [SGS], 24 July. Pbd: Grant, Sir George Sinclair 423–24; Edwin P. Hood, Thomas Carlyle: Philosophic Thinker, Theologian, Historian, and Poet (1875) 470–72; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:171–73.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR

docBody.p:
There is something so truly hospitable in the tone of your letter, something so human-looking and salutary in the adventure proposed me, that I decide on attempting it;“Autumn 1860, I made a visit of four or five weeks to Sir George Sinclair at Thurso. … My head had an unpleasant cloudy feeling; I was certainly far from well, far below my average of illness even. Brother John, who lived in his Brompton lodgings then, recommended strongly a sea-voyage; voyage to Thurso, for example, whither the hospitable Sir George Sinclair had been again, perhaps for the third or fourth time, eagerly inviting me. Nothing else being so feasible, and something being clearly indispensable, we both set off, John volunteering to escort me to Wick; and generously and effectively performing that fraternal service” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:25–26). and mean actually to embark in the Aberdeen steamer, on Wednesday, August 1The Aberdeen Steam Navigation Company advertised in the Times, 20 July: “fast, powerful, and commodious steamships City of London or Earl of Aberdeen leave london for aberdeen … weather, &c. permitting.” TC traveled on the Earl of Aberdeen, 1 Aug. at 1 p.m. (that is to-morrow week), sea voyaging being much
more supportable at all times than the horrors of railwaying, vainly attempting sleep in inns, &c., &c.; and shall hope to be at Wick,Port and town in Caithness, NE Scotland, 21 mi. SE of Thurso Castle. and thence under your roof, at some time on the Saturday following, if all prosper. There!

Most likely I shall write again before sailing; in the meantime I have only to bid you thank the beneficent LadyLady Catherine Camilla Sinclair. in my name, and say that I have good hope her angelic intentions will succeed upon me in some measure, and thus it will be a welcome help indeed. That, for the rest, my domestic habits are all for simplicity and composure (simplex munditiis [plain neatness] the motto in all things), that I live, with clear preference where possible, on rustic farm-produce,—“milk and meal,” eggs, chickens, moor-mutton; white fish (salmon, veal, lamb, three things tabooed to me); reckon an innocent bread-pudding the very acme of culinary art; am accustomed to say, “Can all the UdesLouis Eustache Ude (d. 1846), chef to Louis XVI. He fled to England during the revolution and became chef to William Philip Molyneux (1772–1838), 2d earl of Sefton; he supposedly resigned when a guest added pepper to his soup; later chef to Frederick, duke of York (1763–1827), before finally cooking for Crockford’s Club. in Nature, with all the kings’ treasuries to back them, make anything so good as good cream?“—and likewise that “the Cow is the friend of man, and the French cook his enemy,”Cf. 26:101TC to JCHI, 5 July 1851, and 32:94TC to LA, 23 Feb. 1857.—and not one day in ten drink beyond a single glass of wine. Sufficient on that head. For company I want none but yours and hers:—The great song of the everlasting sea, and the silences of earth and sky, will be better “conversation” to me than the kind I have long had!

On the whole I am quite gay with the hope of becoming a “König in Thule”Goethe’s poem “Der König in Thule” [” The King of Thule“] (1774); the king drinks deep and often from a golden goblet given to him by his dying wife, and, ever faithful, at his life’s end leaves everything to his heir except for the goblet, which he throws into the sea. (though without the misfortunes and bibacities of that old gentleman). There, in my Schloss am Meer [castle by the sea]Castle described in “Der König in Thule” st. 4. for a while, I promise to become a much more human animal, were sleep restored to me, in that grand lullaby, and the rough hair smoothed down again a little. Adieu, in the hope of soon meeting,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [25 July]. MS: NLS 553.223. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—wd you look carefully into this whether you see anything wrong.TC is probably referring to events at the end of the First Silesian War, Aug.–Sept. 1741; see Works 15:244–57. Give me the reference (Mss in Museum, p. &c);Probably extracts from the Hyndford Papers in the British Museum; see TC to JN, 7 June, and Works 15:253–57. Neuberg had also sent TC, 9 June, abstracts from the Carteret Papers in the British Museum; see Works 15:441. John Carteret (1690–1763), 2d Earl Granville, politician and diplomat.—and choose one short note from Ng.Possibly in error for “Adelung”; otherwise unidentified.—if inclosing a PresburgSeat of the Hungarian diet (see Works 15:261), where Maria Theresa was based at the time, and from where Robinson was writing to Hyndford. one whh cd also be given, so much the better. Steady! Exact!

I go for Thurso (actually!) this day week: a Schloss am meer [castle by the sea], comparable to the King of Thule’s;—may it prosper better! Friday afternoon for a drive? (I will try to make some appointt more precise). Yrs T. C.

ps.p: (Chelsea, Wedny)Thomas Woolner reported to Emily Tennyson, 25 July: “I am sorry to tell you that Carlyle is sadly knocked up with this hateful weather and hard work. … [He] is going next week to the most northerly point of Scotland to stay with Sir Something Sinclair, and thinks 2 months of doing nothing may set him up again. He was wonderfully kind and tender in his manner. Mrs. Carlyle is much better than I have seen her for a long time” (Woolner 197).—

div3.sourceNote: TC-RF, 27 July. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Robert Farie (1813–82; see TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1846), longtime friend of the Carlyles, who had chosen TC’s horse, Fritz, for him; see TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856.
div3.head: TC TO ROBERT FARIE

docBody.p: I am just going out of Town. On Saturday I shall probably ride at 5 p.m.; at all events I expect to be here at that hour,—and, if you make appearance, will attend you on horseback, if I can.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 29 Aug. [July]. MS: NLS Acc. 9826. Hitherto unpbd. Reference to TC’s departure 1 Aug. confirms TC’s misdating.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: I believe we shall have to be content with this,—tho’ the eyes and mouth disappoint me.The picture of Frederick used as the frontispiece to vol. 5 of the first edn. (Works 17:frontispiece.); see TC to EC, 11 Nov. Please return me the Engraving when you have done looking at it;—and answer MandellJohann August Eduard Mandel; see TC to EC, 11 Nov. (asking him to tell you, if he can, the exact or approximate year of Franke’s Painting):The date given is “circa 1770”; see also TC to WWV, 10 Feb. his payment, if you are satisfied, will be the grand thing he expects.See 35:31TC to JN, 11 Feb. 1859. — — Wedny forenoon (Augt 1), I am off for Scotland and the Sea-side;—quite low in health these many weeks, tho’ still struggling to make some progress. If I saw you before going, I shd like. Any evg abt 7½ p. m (not later than 9).
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GS [SGS], 31 July. Pbd: Grant, Sir George Sinclair 424–25; Shepherd 2:173–75. Quot: Wylie 268. Text: Grant.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR

docBody.p:
Your note has come this morning; thanks once more. I write a line, as at any rate I intended, merely to say that the purpose holds; that I am booked for the Aberdeen steamer, Wednesday 1 p.m.; thence to Wick by the old program;See TC to JWC, 3 Aug. and that I hope to cut across, if all prosper, and find you at Thurso Castle some time on Saturday,—and there to lie down and sleep for I know not how long! If sleep do not come, you will have to shove me on to Inverness, into the current of railways;In 1860 there were no railways north of Inverness, ca. 110 mi. S of Thurso. The Inverness to Wick line, begun 1860, was not completed until 1874. and I must go further again, were it only to fare worse. A brother of mine now here, Dr. Carlyle, physician once in Rome,John A. Carlyle practiced in Rome Nov. 1836–April 1837; see 9:122TC to JCHA, 19 Jan. 1837. &c., but in late years, especially in late months, a wandering man,—will escort me to Aberdeen, perhaps to Wick; intending to “see the Orkneys, the Shetlands,”The Orkney Islands’ southernmost point is 10 mi. from John o’ Groats, the northernmost point of the Scottish mainland; they extend 50 mi. The Shetland Islands are about 50 mi. further NNE. The ship from Aberdeen to Wick continued on to Kirkwall and Lerwick, the main towns of Orkney and Shetland respectively.
or I know not what. My Wife cannot get away at present, nor for a week or two coming.

She is naturally much gratified by your repeated invitation; and has often spoken of Thurso since it was first heard of here: but she cannot sail at all; and apart from her domestic enterprises here, which induce the desire rather of my absence for a couple of weeks, she shudders somewhat at the long 600 miles of land-journey, even cut into sections; and dare not even undertake for Edinburgh till I have reported of myself from the Far North.

You need not reckon me quite an invalid, after all. My sleeping faculty has returned, or is evidently returning, to the old imperfect degree: but my work, but my head— In short, I was seldom in my life more worn out to utter weariness; or had more need of lying down for a little rest, under hopeful conditions. In haste (as usual),
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD], [early Aug.]. MS: NLS 1797.174 inc. Hitherto unpbd. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has be assigned a document date of 1 August 1860.]
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p: When are you coming, Dear?— You said; “in August”; and this is August.—My cousin Walter,Rev. Walter Welsh. who met your Husband at some Fife dinnerparty, and fraternised with him on a basis of me, heard from him on that occasion that he (William Dods) was “going to London shortly“— But “shortly” is a word of uncertain meaning: It may mean weeks or days, according to the temperament of the individual who uses it. I have known men slow enough to call even months hence “shortly”! So when are you coming. I need to know for practical purposes. I mustn’t happen to be out of town when you come; if I can possibly help it! It “may be strongly doubted”Coterie speech; see 9:30JWC to JC, 30 July 1836. (as they say in Edinr about everything) whether I shall ever see you at Haddington again; the more need to see you here when I have a chance. So please to write one line to say when you will be in London, in the first instance; and as soon as you arrive I will expect to be told; that we may settle beforehand about your coming here—the distance from ‘London’ (specifically speaking) being too great for calls upon chance.

But oh dear!— I hope you wont be long of coming!Jane and William Dods visited 8 Aug. for the summer in Town agrees very ill with me, I am feeling wretchedly just at present—and my Doctor is giving me two “composing draughts” a day!! which surely indicates a state of nerves much in need of what is called “a change.”Coterie speech; see 25:61JWC to TC, 7 April 1850.
If you are not coming till the end of the month I would go away for a fortnight somewhere inLast two lines of MS have been cut off.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 Aug. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Aberdeen, 3 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 615.524. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:237.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Off Aberdeen Harbour (waiting half an hour till Tide come) 3 Augt (Friday, 10 a.m) / 1860
docBody.p: Dearest,—Here we are arrived, after what they call an “excellt voyage,” whh indeed has had good weather and all other fine qualities,—except that finest, the possibility of reasonable sleeping. I have seldom seen such an overcrowded piggery of a place as we had to try that latter operation in. I did manage a little, however, each night,“The very first night, in spite of the tumults of the crowded Aberdeen steamer, and such a huddle of a sleeping-place as is only seen at sea, I slept deep for six or seven hours; and had not again, during this visit, nor for years, any real misery about sleep” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:26).—John missed altogether the first night.John A. Carlyle traveled with TC as far as Wick. I feel wonderfully tolerable, after all is done; the sound of my ears either gone, or else lost amid the immesurableThus in MS. other clankings, snorings and clangors. Thank God, we are got so far with success. Could I only hear that my poor Jeannie is a little come round again, now that the noises & disturbances from my side of the House are done.

A Steamer (I hope & believe) sails some time this day for Wick;The Prince Consort sailed at 4 p.m. is expected to arrive in 9 hours after,—very early in the morning (4 or 2 a.m. perhaps); so soon as any landsman is up, I will try to get some gig, do the remaining 21 miles; and so be received into the arms of hospitable Thurso. So be it!—

This morning I have seen Dunottar Castle RuinsDunnottar Castle, Aberdeenshire, 2 mi. S of Stonehaven and 15 mi. S of Aberdeen; its ruin stands on a rock 160 ft. above the North Sea; it was destroyed by the English in 1336, rebuilt, then dismantled after the 1715 Jacobite rebellion. (on the coast here,
where Marshall Keith was born,James Francis Edward Keith (1696–1758; see 34:195JWC to MCA, 22 Sept. 1858), army officer in the Russian and Prussian service; he was b. at Inverugie Castle, nr. Peterhead, Aberdeenshire, not Dunnottar. whom you do not care for), and cd not see Finnan where the Haddocks are made,Findon, the village famous for the cold-smoked haddock known as “Finnan haddie,” ca. 8 mi. S of Aberdeen.—but expect to do it still, so soon as the glass is at command.

You can tell Miss FerrarAnnie Louisa Farrer. she will have an excellt ship &c; but this week (mine), and next week (hers),The Aberdeen Steam Navigation Company’s City of London, Wed. 8 Aug. they say, are the two most crowded in the year.

John talks of stopping, & turning Southd by rail: but there is nothing certain in it;—a great many of us are Cockneys bound for the Shetland Isles with “Houses taken” &c, there to rusticate!— God bless thee ever, Dearest; write instantly, if you have not already. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-RMM, 4 Aug. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: Your noteMilnes wrote from Yorkshire, 3 Aug., inviting TC and JWC to visit him there. shall be forwarded and in time answered. But meanwhile I had best write, and tell you; that man has streamed off in an Aberdeen Steamer on his way to Thurso Castle! The Northermost point of Scotland; where he is going to spend some time with old Sir George Sinclair (the Brother of “Health” and “Longevity”).Sir John Sinclair (1754–1835), politician, writer, and agricultural reformer, author of The Code of Health and Longevity; or A Concise View of the Principles Calculated for the Preservation of Health, and the Attainment of a Long Life, 4 vols. (Edinburgh, 1807), was Sir George Sinclair’s father, not his brother. I could not accompany him on account of the sailing; preferred staying here, and sending for a Dr;Dr. Barnes. who is giving me two “composing draughts” a day. The Ghost of Frederick has been leading me such a life!
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 Aug.]. MS: NLS 607.544. Hitherto unpbd. Written on the reverse of R. M. Milnes to TC, 3 Aug., and enclosed with the second JWC to TC, [4 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I will write when I get your letter— “Being an only child I never wished to write!”Coterie speech; see 31:204JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1856.— It does not accord with the “composing draughts” that continue to be administered to me twice a-day!
docBody.name: JC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 Aug.]. Addr: Care of Sir George Sinclair / Thurso / N.B. PM: London, 4 Aug. 1860; Thurso, 6 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 607.542. Hitherto unpbd. An annotation on the envelope in another hand reads: “4 Aug / A scrap with / enclore. (Milnes & Grey).” The first enclosure was Milnes’s letter of 3 Aug.; see the previous JWC to TC, [4 Aug.]. The second enclosure was Earl de Grey to TC, 2 Aug.: “I have asked Mr Sidney Herbert about Lord Pembroke’s Papers and he tells me that they were all destroyed in the fire at Wilton, & that he is, he regrets to say, unable to afford you any information about his ancestors’ dealings with Frederick.” George Henry Grey (1802–94; ODNB), 3d Earl Grey, politician. Sidney Herbert (1810–61; ODNB), politician, half-brother of Robert Henry Herbert (1791–1862), 12th earl of Pembroke. According to Sidney Charles Herbert (1906–69), 16th earl, this was the prevailing belief until he found, in 1933, a hidden cellar full of MSS. He ed. these as Lord Herbert, Henry, Elizabeth and George (1734–80) (1939) and Pembroke Papers (1780–94) (1950), being the letters and journals of Henry Herbert (1734–94), 10th earl, and George Augustus Herbert (1759–1827), 11th earl. He noted that there was no proof of any fire except that of 1647, which destroyed most of the original house. There was nothing in these pbd. papers about either earl’s dealings with Frederick, but both traveled extensively on the Continent, and he commented in passing that the 10th earl “knew [Frederick] quite well” (Pembroke Papers 455).
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I am shocked to find it within a few minutes of 12—when I appointed the Fly to take me to see Kate Sterling (who is in Lodgings here—much worse) and on some other business— I shall be too tired when I come in for sitting down to write, so again I miss writing to Sir George!—
Do excuse me to him for he must be thinking me a perfect Brute—so considerate as he has been in writing!
I shall write a note to him at night to be ready for tomorrow

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 6 Aug. Addr: 5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Thurso, 7 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 615.525. Pbd: Bliss, TC 348–50; Froude 4:237–38 inc.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dear Jeannie mine,— You heard from John that I was off hither on Saturday (out of Wick, safe, and mackintoshed agt the rain); and the day before this comes, you will receive from my respectable Host a signal that I am safe here, and making some attempt to “do well.”— Saturday, wet, dreary, gaunt and strange, was a little dispiriting in spite of the cordial and eager welcome of all these good people: but that night I had a capital sleep; next morning I contrived to shirk “Church &c” (whh I shall always do), and walked along the many-sounding shore, with a Book, a Cape, and a little tobacco, some mile or two among the cliffs and crags (a charming walk, all grass and level, if you like to keep atop; at the bottom of the cliffs, it is firm strata of slate flags, a little tumbled, but safe and comfortable, that too),—not a human being visible, only the grand ever-moaning sea (Pentland Frith,The Pentland Firth separates the Scottish mainland from the Orkney Islands. clear as crystal) with Orkney “Hoy Island,” a very fine precipitous seagirt mountain to one’s left,The cliffs of Hoy reach 1,140 ft., with their highest point 1,565 ft. and Dunnett HeadDunnet Head is the northernmost point of mainland Scotland. (do do, a quasi Jonny Grote’s)John o’ Groats is at the NE tip of Scotland, approx. 17 mi. from Thurso; for details of the house and legend, see TC to Lady S LS , 2 Sept.
some 6 or 7 miles ahead. There I sat and sauntered, in the devoutest, quietest and wholesomest mood I have been in for many months. There I read, &c; bathed carefully, and set out vigorously walking, to arrive warm, and also punctual. In short, Dear, I did well yesterday; and have had again a tolerable sleep; nay have got my affairs settled (so to speak),—breakfast an hour before the family (who don’t get thro’ their “worship” &c till 10, and are very tepid), am not to shew face at all till 3 p. m.; and mean actually to try some work, having a kind of real chance, 3 hours or so per day, and time for a walk and bathe! If I can, it will be very fine for me;—but we must not be too sure!“On the part of my generous host and household, nothing was left wanting; I was allowed to work daily some hours, invisible till three p.m. I bathed daily in the Pentland Firth in sight of the ‘Old Man,’ roamed about, saw ‘John o’ Groat’s House’ (evidently an old lime-kiln!) &c. &c., a country ancient, wild, and lonely, more than enough impressive to me. I was very sad, ‘soul exceeding solitary;’ nothing could help that.” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:26). The little ButlerAlexander Fraser. here seems one of the cleverest willingest creatures I have seen for a long time, and is zealously anxious (as hitherto all and sundry are) to oblige the monster come
among them. Thurso, visible, abt two gunshots off, from one of my windows, is a poor grey Town, treeless, with one ofThus in MS. two steam-engines in it, and a dozen or two of fishing boats;—nor is Thurso Castle“The castle is an excellent specimen of a Scottish mansion built during the picturesque period of gable ends, high roofs, round towers, and peaked turrets. And about twenty years since, it was doubled; a very handsome set of rooms having been built at the back of the old castle, towards the sea” (John Bernard Burke, A Visitation of the Seats and Arms of the Noblemen and Gentlemen of Great Britain [1852–53] 2:99). For a view of the castle before 1826, see above. much of a Mansion, at least till you examine it attentively: but it is really an extensive well furnished human Dwellingplace, and the situation, with its northern parapet looking down upon the actual waves, whh never go a stone’s-throw off,According to James Grant, Thurso Castle was so close to the sea “that the spray often entered the house, and fish had frequently been caught by the net from the drawing-room windows” (Grant, Sir George Sinclair 14). is altogether charming. A place built “at 3 difft times from 1664 downwards”Originally built as a Norse earl’s fortress in the 12 century, it was rebuilt in 1660 by George, 6th earl of Caithness, and extended and improved in the 1820s. (quite
modern this my northern side of it): with 4 or 5 poor candle-extinguisher little Towers in difft parts;—very bare, but trim with walks &c and sheltering offices and walls; some attempts, lately, at trees, to whh one wishes success.

figure.p: Thurso Castle, Caithness
Jones’ Views of the Seats of … Noblemen and Gentlemen in England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland [1829]

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
To Thurso the road (practically more than half a mile, owing to the river, with its tide, with its bridge) is for busss only; and one turns always up shore, in the other, grassy, lonely, desirable direction; where, except in “heavy gales,” my constant exercising ground is likely to be. No saddle horse, not even a saddle-shelty; but there is a Carriage & pair, for the womankind, with whom I have not yet gone, tho’ “I mean to,”—on the box with cigars (probably this very after-dinner, if the weather hold up). Sir Gge, good old Gaius,Gaius or Caius (ca. 110–ca. 180), Roman jurist; cf. 25:126 TC to JF, 27 July 1860
. seems to depend on walking, and can stand very little of it: he has two Daughters here (one of them a widow with perhaps 3 quiet children);The Sinclairs’ eldest da., Emilia Power, twice widowed, and the youngest, Olivia, unmarried; and probably Emilia’s children from her second marriage, Godfrey and Olivia. TC wrote later that there were two children and a “Hobbletehoy” from Dundee (probably John Stephen); see TC to JWC, 22 [21] Aug.
nay the celebrated “Lady Camilla” herself did on Saturday (somewhat to my horror), and does daily since at dinner (with continual abatet of that sorry feeling) turn up for 2 or 3 hours, and then vanishes to her interior till the morrow! She seems to me really a very good female soul, heavy-laden with nerves and many other things: is of square honest Scotch aspect, eyes well opened, corners of mouth drawn up, nostrils slightly open (an honestly inspecting character), and speaks with a kind of hank or menace of stutter (à la Leigh Hunt, & with softish voice too in its sort), whh is interesting. The Baronet seems rather to fear herJWC had previously expressed her opinion that Sir George had an uneasy relationship with his wife; see 35:59 JWC to MR, 25 March 1859
. (or at least the nerves that are in her) and seldom addresses her. I find she is of some grand “Ham-House” (Richmond) people, Lauderdales, Dysarts or I know not what,—and has had a grandmother of extreme beauty, “Countess in her own right” (mark that).Ham House, Richmond, ca. 11 mi. S of London, built 1610, became the seat of William Murray (d. 1655), 1st earl of Dysart; his da., Elizabeth (ca. 1626–98), inherited the house and the title; she m., first, 1648, Sir Lionel Tollemache (1624–69), and, second, 1672, John Maitland (1616–82), 1st duke of Lauderdale. The house remained the property of the earls of Dysart. Lady Camilla’s grandmother was Louisa Tollemache (1745–1840), countess of Dysart, “acknowledged by universal consent to have been one of the greatest beauties at the Court of George the Third” (Grant, Sir George Sinclair 50). A really good “Lady Camilla.”

The two young women, are full of Edinr talk and dialect; ruddy-haired, roman-nosed, cheery hearty orthodox Yg persons (hardly forty, I shd think,
even the widow); rather well-looking than otherwise,—tho’ the maiden one tends to short, and neither of them is of Sinclair stature.JWC calls him that “tall Sir George Sinclair” (34:49); his father, Sir John Sinclair, was 6 ft. 2 in. tall. Ach Gott! you see how it is, Dear;—I have to add only that this is a Bedroom beyond equal; 14 feet high, big as our Drawing room;—the western window (not pull down) whh looks out on Thurso needs 4 wedges to steady it, however; northern looks out upon the melodious brine, and defies all winds. Fires have been lighted till I ordered them off.— — For you, Goody dear, there has been endless inquiring; and I really think you might do: but, alas, it is above 600 miles away,—I shd think near 150 beyond where the Ashburtons wd leave you!Kinlochluichart, Highland estate of Lord Ashburton, or Brahan Castle, Lady Louisa Ashburton’s family home, both near Dingwall, ca. 100 mi. S of Thurso. Jack did not go to Lerwick; I think will go Edinrwards by the Wick Boat again tomorrow evg.— Adieu, Dearest: won’t youWord repeated in MS at turn of page. write, then! I might have had a letter today, dated Friday or Saturday;—God grant the news may be good when it does come! Take care of yourself, do!

p.name: T. Carlyle

figure.p: Steam carriage, 6 August 1860

p.hi: From the collections of Buckinghamshire County Museum

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 6 Aug. MS: NLS 517.5. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:208.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,—You have written to me at least twice; and I have answered nothing, calculating that John wd answer the essential: indeed I have been reduced to such a pass lately as I hardly knew in my life before,—head heavy-laden, sounding like a mill; sleep quite gone; the burble of things like to drag me down altogether;—so that I knew [not]Word omitted. what to resolve on; and could not “write” to any purpose. One thing only was apparent, that I could not too soon get out of London. So here I am; by what route, by what conveyances and adventures, you doubtless know; for I saw John writing to you “Off
Aberdeen” while [we]Word omitted. were still in the Steamer; and probably he has written from Wick (20 miles off this) since I left him on Saturday.

Poor fellow, he was very good to me, and really very useful and comfortable all the way; and it was a grievous sorrow to me, but an unavoidable, to roll away from him, so far from home partly for my sake, on Saturday in the rain! I think he will certainly strike off southward, tomorrow (Tuesday Evg) by the Return Steamer;The Prince Consort left Wick for Edinburgh on Tues. mornings, but John A. Carlyle went south by road; he wrote, [5 Aug.]: “Wick, Sunday / I mean to start today at one o’clock with the mail [coach] which goes south. … I have exhausted this place, & cannot go about alone for sight-seeing at a distance.” and I hope to hear of him turning up among you, after his solitary long months. Few things wd give me greater pleasure than to hear of his having cast anchor, got himself a house &c,John had made an offer for a house in Dumfriesshire the previous year; see TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1859. and got some root of natural human comfort and arrangt planted for himself in this world again!-

This is a very pleasant wholesome place, and certainly one of the quietest in all the world. A queer old Mansion, nothing of the Castle in it but four or five
little extinguisher towersTowers shaped like candle snuffers. abt the corners; built close to the Northern Ocean, whh never goes a gunshot off, but moans perpetually and sounds among its rocks close under one of my windows here: a biggish House taken all together; well done up, well furnished and managed; the people all in the highest degree zealous to accommodate the surprising monster who has been stranded among them. I have one of the desirablest nice rooms in the world; looks upon Thurso chimney-tops one way, and out upon the great ocean on the other: from cocks, Carpenters, hackney-cabs, what a change! I have already had two quite respectable sleeps, and the dirty burden in the head seems going gradually. I breakfast an hour before the family; and am not to shew face till 3 p.m.—excellent! I hope even to do some work; but this is only the first day of it, and I must not brag. “Sir George,” a fine pious-minded stiff-backed old man of 70; two hearty daughters (near 40 I shd guess),Emilia Power, age 43, and Olivia, age 37. and a nervous Mother,Lady Camilla. who is good, but ever-ailing, and does not appear except at dinner: that is our party.— I must break off abruptly. Write when you have a minute. T. C

div3.sourceNote: TC-RMM, 7 Aug. MS: Trinity. Pbd: Reid, RMM 2:73–74, where dated 1861.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: I quitted London a week ago, nolens volens [willy nilly], things being very bad with me;—and I receive your hospitable NoteMilnes had written, 3 Aug.: “Will you & Mrs Carlyle take us on your way north. … I heard the other day of an invitation … given by an officer to a friend— ‘Come & stay with us as long as you can—you shall have an ocean of liquor, a plantation of tobacco, & a large room to swear in’— I make you the same offer—only you’d better bring your own plantation—/ Mrs Carlyle shall have her quiet room to herself.” here (looking out upon the precipitous cliffs of Orkney, Dunnet’s Head, the Old Man of Hoy,An isolated column of shale capped with sandstone, 450 ft. high, off the cliffs of Hoy. the Northern Ocean, and ultima Thule),—already in slightly improved circumstances; able to sleep, for one thing, the billows and the winds rocking me. Sir George Sinclair (excellt pious old gentn), on hearing of “Mr Milnes,” wishes much “Mr Milnes wd come & join you here for a few weeks,“—a most devout imaginatn!

My Wife is still in Chelsea; uncertain whether I shall be able to persuade her into Scotland at all, much more hither (600 and more miles away),—tho’
she too, if she wd own it, has much need of country. If on my or our return (whh is as yet quite dateless) I pass within wind of Fryston, doubt not I shall be right glad to see it again, in the name of the Past and of the Future,—of the former, at any rate, ah me!

Are not you a shocking fellow, never to ask once this year whether I was alive or dead, or whether the Devils had left me in a dog’s likeness or a man’s:—for shame! However, you can do nothing to provoke me utterly; and I must love R. M. actually more or less, as I do no other, or hardly one, however he may behave.
With many regards to the Hon. Lady, and best wishes to the two Bairns,Richard and Annabella Milnes had three children.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 8 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am very happy to hear of you the second time,John A. Carlyle wrote, 5 Aug., that he would send another letter when he had an address. and that you have got your staff set up at least for one week. I hope you will do well at Bridge of Allan,A small spa town 2½ mi. NW of Stirling. and be clearer for your future movements after a good week’s repose, when various clouds will have sunk down into the form of sediment in your mind. I know not well where the place is; but will seek it out tomorrow when I have daylight again.— On Saturday Night, before going to bed, I wrote you a line; and walked into Thurso with it next morning in time for the post. It wd reach the Caledonian HôtelHotel in Wick where John had stayed on his way south. some hours after your departure; the Coach you went in had brought it to the Post-Office, had you known. Pray send for it immediately; you will see why I wish it burnt at least, if not safe in your hands! It was written rather in ill spirits; and I shd not wish it read quite at the market-cross in this particular part of the countryThe letter is untraced, presumably burned.—

Since that point I have gone on pretty steadily mending, doing tolerably well in spite of the continual showers we have: I have adjusted my hours to a fixed method; am called at 8, breakfast by myself at 9 (a full hour before the family); work among my papers here all morning; rush out rather before
2 p. m. for a bathe (whh is always procurable by industry on some smooth patch of the tumbled crags and flags, water pure as crystal); and rush home again to be ready for dinner abt 3. Dressing has to be done; but I do it with a brevity you wd admire,—in 5 minutes or little more. These last 2 days I have actually got some fractions of work done! I have slept too; well one time; not ill, any time. My dinner is white fish and chicken, bread for vegetables; one glass of sherry, and an honest farinaceous pudding to wind up with:—mainly a milk-and-meal diet, the wholesomest for me that cd be. After dinner they go driving; I, well wrapt, solitary, with tobacco, on the “rumble,“—for a 3 or 2 hours: this, with walking, is I hope wholesome too. In short I believe I can probably hold on for certain weeks,—say till Augt end;—and find the process beneficial. They are excellt innocent people, anxious all of them to oblige me,—ungrateful that I am! I have shirked “Prayers” to write this.— No word from Jane yet, except some scratch on the back of a Letter she was forwarding.JWC wrote two brief notes, 4 Aug., the first on the back of RMM to TC, 3 Aug.— Adieu, dear Brother: write soon. Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JN, [8 Aug.]. MS: NLS 554.57. Pbd: Scudder 30. Dated with reference to the visit of the Symingtons, Fri., 10 Aug., and the arrival of Sir George Sinclair’s letter; see JWC to SGS, [ca. 9 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I waited to see what today was like—and we have seen!— Tomorrow, I am not sure that I could go—in the forenoon—even if the day were ever so fine, and on Friday I cannot go at all; expecting some Scotch friends to dine with me on their way thro’ LondonProbably Andrew and Mary Symington; see JWC to JCA, 11 Aug.—

If you have time and inclination to come tomorrow on chance, should the day be favourable, in the afternoon, I might perhaps go home with you to tea— But at one oclock, and till 4 or so, I shall be needed here to direct a Carpenter who is comingPossibly Mr. Parsons or Joseph Morgan; see 34:43TC to JWC, 14 July; or possibly the “Blind Carpenter ‘Mr French’”; see 35:215JWC to TC, 24 Sept. 1859.—
I should like extremely to go to Swizerland if it werent for the money it would cost!

I hear this morning from Sir George Sinclair (Mr C’s own letter seems to have been lost!) that he is “in high spirits and looking remarkably well”
“making himself most communicative and agreeable to the people of the house!; taking long walks &c &c” In short I seem to have been giving myself a great deal of needless trouble about him!—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], 8 Aug. [9 Aug.]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. JWC misdated; William and Jane Dods visited on Wed., 8 Aug.; see JWC to TC, [10 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: On finding your portrait when I came down yesterday morning, I felt so excited, and so grateful, that I wanted to rush off to Dover Street,Where Lady Stanley’s London home was. so soon as you could be imagined up and dressed, to thank you more warmly than one can possibly do on paper! also—to ask if it were purely on “the voluntary principle” that you had sent it? or if the expressions of my passionate desire to have one had been conveyed to you by Annie Farrer? If the latter was the state of the fact:, I shall write myself down her debtor for a most acceptable kindness: besides feeling almost as grateful to you as if you had given me the Portrait without prompting! I was going on to say, that my wish and purpose to see you yesterday were knocked on the head by a note which came by the morning post, promising me the visit of a dear old married couple from my native place!William and Jane Dods from Haddington. They followed their note within an hour, and stayed to dinner with me, and when they had left I could do nothing but sit and break my heart over “dear old long ago”!JWC’s phrase, used mainly in reference to her youth in Haddington; cf. 35:49JWC to BB, 3 March 1859.— I showed them the portrait however; and the man showed his good taste by declaring you “a lovely woman, that one would like to—kiss”!! Today again I have been wanting to go—watching the rain—and finding it always drip-dripping! So I must just write the stupid words Thank you, after all.

If you only knew the mess I am in, you would feel, (I think) that you did a charitable as well as kind thing in sending that bit of sunshine into the house! Mr Carlyle is away recruiting himself with old Sir George Sinclair at Thurso Castle— And I am “improving the occasion” in various ways— First I am having the feathers of all the beds and pillows in the house out airing themselves on the floor!! so that the house presents an atmosphere of goose down! more suffocating than even the “cotton fuzz”Referring to cotton fragments in the air in cotton mills, which caused pulmonary illness among the workers. TC had commented on “fetid fuzzy, deafening ill-ventilated mills” when he visited a Manchester mill in 1847; see 22:67TC to JWC, 14 Sept. 1847. See also Past and Present (1843), Works 10:183. For Elizabeth Gaskell’s view that lint-laden air led to the death of the millworker Bessy, see North and South (1855) 1:154. there used to be such jargoning
about! then they are painting, and white washing, and plashing like mad, in Mr Carlyle’s room!— While two Bricklayers are tearing up flags in the kitchen to seek “the solution” of a non-acting drain!!Probably John Eborall, bricklayer, 12A Queen’s Rd. W, Chelsea; TC wrote a check, 18 May: “Eborall (Bricklayer, / Hydrostacy) / £1.10.1” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).— Pleasant! with the rain drip dripping outside!—and my Dr “seeing” me every other day, prescribing “composing draughts” and that I should “keep my mind happy and tranquil”!!!
I think I shall take to smoking!JWC used to smoke occasionally; see 18:64JWC to JW, 12 June 1844.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Sir GS [SGS], [ca. 9 Aug.]. MS: NLS 607.541. Pbd: Grant, Sir George Sinclair 425–26; Wylie 96–97; Froude, LM 3:27–29. Froude dated this letter 1 Aug. but dated with reference to the same domestic events reported in JWC to LST, 8 [9] Aug. Sir George’s letter arrived 8 Aug.; see JWC to JN, [8 Aug.].
div3.head: JWC TO SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR

docBody.p: Decidedly, you are more thoughtful for me than the man who is bound by vow to “love and cherish” me! Not a line have I received from him to announce his safe arrival in your dominion,John A. Carlyle told TC in his letter of 5 Aug. that he had written to JWC, 4 Aug.; TC’s letter of 6 Aug. did not arrive until 10 Aug. JWC may have received an earlier letter from Sir George, as JWC tells TC that she would write to him on the evening of 4 Aug.; see her second letter to TC, [4 Aug.]. The more shameful on his part, that, as it appears by your note, he had such good accounts to give of himself and was perfectly up to giving them.

Well!—now that you have relieved me from all anxiety about the effects of the journey on him, he may write at his own “reasonably good leisure.”Coterie speech; see 24:104JWC to TC, 7 July 1849. Only—I told him I should not write till I had heard of his arrival—from himselfSee her first letter to TC, [4 Aug.].—and he knows whether or no I am in the habit of keeping my word—to the letter!

A thousand thanks for the primrose roots—which I shall plant so soon as it fairs;—to day we have again a deluge! adding a deeper shade of horror to
certain household operations going on under my inspection—(by way of “improving the occasion“—of his absence!)— One Bedroom has got all the feathers of its bed and pillows airing themselves out on the floor! creating an atmosphere of down over the house more choking than even “cotton-fuzz”!—In another; plasterers and painters are plashing away for their life!—and a couple of Bricklayers are tearing up flags in the kitchen to seek “the Solution“—of a non-acting drain!— All this on the one hand, and on the other; visits from my Dr, resulting in ever new “composing draughts,” and strict charges to “keep my mind perfectly tranquil”! You will admit that one could easily conceive situations more ideal!

Pray do keep him as long as you like! to hear of him “in high spirits” and “looking remarkably well” is more composing for me than any amount of “composing draughts,” or of insistance on the benefits of “keeping myself perfectly tranquil”! It is so very different a state of things with him from that in which I have seen him for a long time back!

Oh! I must not forget to give you the “kind remembrances of a very charming Woman, whom any man may be pleased to be remembered by, as kindly as she evidently remembered You! I speak of Lady William Russell—She knew you in Germany as “a young Student,” she told me, when she was Bessy RawdonSinclair left Harrow School, 1806, then attended the Univ. of Göttingen, remaining in Germany until ca. 1809; see Grant, Sir George Sinclair 18–43. Elizabeth Rawdon lived on the Continent until 1808.— She “had a great affection for you and had often thought of you since.” You were “very romantic in those days! Oh! very romantic and sentimental” she could assure me!
Pray send me back a pretty message for her! She will like so much to know that she has not remembered you “with the reciprocity all on one side”Coterie speech; see 19:196JWC to GCD, 15 Sept. 1845.—
I dont even send my regards to Mr C
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [10 Aug.]. Addr: care of Sir G Sinclair, Baronet / Thurso Castle / Thurso / N B. PM: London, 10 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 607.545. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:29–33.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Oh my Dear! If “all about feelings”Coterie speech; see 24:148JWC to TC, 26 July 1849. be bad in a letter, all about scenery, and no feelings is a d—d deal worse!— Such a letter as that I received from you yesterday, after much half-anxious half-angry waiting for, will read charmingly
in your Biography! and may be quoted in future editions of Murray’s Guide-BookJohn Murray (1808–92; ODNB) pbd. a series of handbooks for travelers, which by the 1850s covered most of Europe.—but for “me, as one solitary Individual,”Coterie speech; TC’s father’s phrase; see 19:108JWC to TC, 25 July 1845. I was not charmed with it at all!

Nevertheless, I should have answered it by return of post, had I not been too ill for writing anything yesterday, except, on the strength of phrenzy, a passionate appeal to the “retired Cheesemonger”John Todd, 12 Cheyne Row; see 33:240TC to JAC, 12 June 1858. about his dog. Which, I am happy to say, like everything coming straight from the heart—went straight to the heart—of the good little old Cheesemonger

You will infer from my going a-head against “noises” on my own account, that the “extraordinary disturbance of the nervous system” which Mr Barnes found me suffering under when he came, has not yielded yet to an equally extraordinary amount of “Composing Mixture”! My sleep had been getting “small by degrees and beautifully less”Cf. Matthew Prior, “Henry and Emma,” Poems on Several Occasions (1709) 254. George Gilfillan, an old admirer of TC, had pbd. a recent edn. with a memoir and “critical dissertation,” The Poetical Works of Matthew Prior (Edinburgh, 1858) 430. till I ended in lying awake the whole nights thro! not what you call “awake“—that is, dozing—but broad-wide awake—like a hawk, with an empty stomach! Still the mixture was to be persevered in—nay increased— And I was assured it was “doing me a little good“— So little I myself couldn’t perceive it; even thro’ the powerful microscope of my faith in Mr Barnes! And in spite of his assurance that “home was the best place for me at present,” I had wild impulses to “take the road” (like “the Dr,”John A. Carlyle. and with the Dr’s purposelessness!). The night before last however, (Wednesday night), I fell into a deep natural sleep which lasted two hours, and might have lasted till the MasonsPresumably the bricklayers working in the kitchen. began, but for the Cheesemongers Dog which was out that night (bad luck to it!) on a spree; and startled me awake at three of the morning with furious continuous barking; just as if my head was being laid open with repeated strokes of a hatchet! Of course I “slept no more”!Cf. Macbeth 2.2.—and yesterday was too ill for anything, except, as I have said, writing a wild appeal to the Cheesemonger— I will inclose his comforting answer, which he handed in himself an hour after— It will be comforting to you also—in reference to your own future nights.

I have nothing to tell that you will take any interest in—except about the Horse. He is still under the process of “breaking” poor creature!“To run in harness; but he wouldn’t—couldn’t—though the best-natured of horses, poor Fritz!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:31). The horse breaker is unidentified. Is “so nervous and resolute” so “dreadful resolute,” that the Breaker “cant tell how
long it will take to get the better of him”! I must see Silvester today before writing to Frederick Chapman.Frederic Chapman wrote, 9 Aug.: “Should the horse be ready to go away, I would take him next Sunday.” I saw the poor horse three days ago, just coming in from the Breaker’s—like a horse “spent, returning from the thirty years war”! Poor beast! I could have cried for him—required to turn over a new leaf in his old age! I know what that is!

“The Nephew of Hagi Bakka”Robert Burnet David Morier (1826–93; ODNB), “a man of gigantic gouty physique” (ODNB); an expert in German-speaking countries and paid attaché in Berlin after the marriage, 1858, of Victoria (1840–1901), princess royal, to Frederick (1831–88), crown prince of Prussia; nephew of James Justinian Morier (1780–1849), translator from Persian of The Adventures of Hajji Babba of Ispahan (1824) and The Adventures of Hajji Babba in England (1828). dropt in quite promiscuous last Sunday evening, when Old Jane“Old Jane,” age 71, recently engaged to replace Charlotte Southam, whom JWC felt was muddled and irresponsible and needed stricter supervision than she could give her; for further details of the change of servants, JWC to MR, [22? Oct. 1860] (vol. 37; A. Carlyle, NLM 2:236–38). Charlotte was apparently dismissed early Aug. but taken back to help out occasionally; see JWC to MCA, [25 Aug.]. was at Church and I was alone except for Geraldine, who opened the door to him, and afterwards—talked social metaphysics with him! He is the fattest young large Man I ever saw, out of a Caravan!Presumably JWC means a traveling circus or freak show. but in other respects, rather charming. He wished me to impress on you how happy he would be to transact any commissions for you at Berlin!—“for which his connection with the embassy might give him facilities &c &” He seemed heartily in earnest about this—and a hearty admirer of your Frederick— He is the best-bred, pleasantest Man I have seen “for seven years”Traditional period of time in folk tales or ballads; cf. 27:200JWC to TC, 3 Aug. 1852. and the hour and half he staid would have been delightful if I hadn’t been deadly sick all the while, and my nervous system “in an extraordinary state of disturbance.”

Tell Sir George—I have planted the cowslips “with my own hand,”Coterie speech; see 1:301TC to AC, 2 Jan. 1821, and 6:44JWC to MAC, Nov. 1831. and have not needed to water them “the heavenly watering pan” (which Marriotti spoke of)Meaning rain; most probably a saying of Luigi Mariotti, the name adopted by Antonio Carlo Napoleone Gallenga (1810–95; ODNB), Italian educator, journalist, politician, and a friend of the Carlyles since the 1840s; see 15:118–19JWC to ABJ, 7 Oct. 1842, and 16:331JWC to TC, 31 July 1843; untraced in his Country Life in Piedmont (1858) where he mentioned TC briefly: “(I believe I have Mr. Thomas Carlyle’s authority for these comparatives)” (134). having spared me that trouble. I gave them the place of highest honour—(round poor little Nero’s stone)
I have had fires all day long for the last week—such a summer!—
Lady Stanley sent me her portrait—

The only bit of real pleasantness however that has come my way has been, last Wednesday, a visit from William Dods and his Wife. They told me such things about the behaviour of the London Donaldsons—when they went down to Miss Jess’s funeral—

Your situation sounds as favourable as a conditional worldGoethe, Wilhelm Meister’s Travels; see Works 24:370. could have afforded you— I trust in Heaven that you will go on improving in it— You remember no pen got mended so you wont wonder at this scribbling
docBody.name: J Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JCA, 11 Aug. Addr: Assembly Street / Dumfries / N. B. PM: London, 11 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS envelope only 607.546. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:226–28 inc. Quot: Blunt, CR 153. TC’s note on envelope: “keep cover (inclosure lost).“
div3.head: JWC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My dear Jean—. … I will inclose you a Note I had from Sir George Sinclair, which will put you in heart about Mr. C.’s situation up there. Even from the one Letter I have had from himself since his arrival, it appears that his circumstances are as favourable for the purposes he had in view as could have well been found in a conditional world. I trust in God he will get calmed down, by a good long stay there; and come back with a thicker skin than he took away! This Book has been far too long a piece of work for him,—to say nothing of its difficulty.

I don’t know what I am going to do with myself yet. His nervous state had acted upon me, till I was become more sleepless and agitated than himself! And I was on the verge of complete break-down into serious illness when Mr. C. left, and my Doctor took me in hands. To judge from the amount of “composing draughts” given me (three in a day!), I must have been very near boiling over and blowing my lid off! He (the Doctor) forbade my leaving home for the present; and I shall await his permission before going anywhere. He is both a skilful and honest man, and would not keep me here for the sake of running up a bill!— But I do feel a great longing to be on the top of a hill somewhere, to breathe more freely.— I will tell you my plans when I have any. What a nice little woman Mrs. Symington is! I liked her much better than him.Andrew Symington and Mary Sanderson Edmonston had m. 23 July and were presumably on a wedding trip. JamesJames Aitken. might have called and reported himself at Cheyne Row. But I find him, socially speaking, a most impracticable youth! I wish he could fall in
love! That would be the making of him, if he did it wisely and not too well.Cf. Othello 5.2.— Kind regards to your Husband.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[IEB], [11 Aug.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Blunt, CR 154; Blunt, Forum 66 (Nov. 1921): 400.
div3.head: JWC TO [ISABELLA E. BARNES]

docBody.p: Saturday [11 August 1860]

Little Girl!— I told you how it would be!— Once put off a solemn engagement, and no mortal can tell when it will come off, or whether “the pigs” won’t “run thro it”Coterie speech; see 31:205JWC to DD, 1 Sept. 1856. altogether!
The LadyPresumably Lady Louisa Ashburton; see JWC to Lady SLST, [20 Aug.]. to whom, as I told you, I had promised a day next week, whichever day she liked, has, of course selected just Tuesday—Ergo!

For Heaven’s sake when you fix the day for your marriage,Isabella Barnes m. John Simmonds 18 Feb. 1862. keep to it, thro’ thick and thin! or—“the pigs” may do something there too, which will surprise you!

On Wednesday evening, I have an immensely strong minded and strong bodied woman coming,Possibly Geraldine Jewsbury. whom, I think, you would hardly like to meet. To myself she is killing! But being one of that privileged class who have “seen better days.”Cf. Timon of Athens 4.2. I am bound to let myself be killed by her now and then;—with inward protest!

Thursday is so far off, I cant say anything about it! I may be gone—into infinite space!— I feel choking here— In spite of your fathers composing mixture!— I want to be away on the top of a hill!—any hill except Primrose Hill!Primrose Hill, Primrose Hill Park, to the N of Regent’s Park. Do come one morning—as early as ever you like— And tell me if you will dare the strong woman! or wait till Thursday? Friday?—Saturday? on the chance of my being off in search of a hill I can breath on!

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS] , 12 Aug. MS: NLS 19.3.52.12. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.dateline: Thurso Castle, Thurso N. B. 12 Augt, 1860 —
docBody.p:
I send you a word, to keep myself in your Memory, from this remote part of the Earth,—with the Orkney Islands and Ultima Thule close in sight. I think we left London the same day, Wednesday gone a week; you, I wd fain flatter myself, are safe at Hinchinbrook ever since that afternoon, and doing well: my journey did not end till Saturday next; and landed me 700 miles away, very much like a lost sheep. However, the good people have not butchered me,
but been very kind to me; and I am doing rather well than otherwise on this strange foreign shore

Our “Thurso Castle” (a queer old Scotch edifice, with extinguisher turrets, peaked gables &c, “built by the Earls of Caithness two centuries ago”) hangs over the very edge of the Pentland Frith, the voice of the waves never ceasing from these windows of mine; and, in point of “solitude,” and of certain other requisitions I am often making, leaves nothing to be desired;-for we are withal the quietest family in Britain (I shd think); the Head of us a good old gentn of 70, busied mainly with his own desultory readings, in many languages;“Sir George was abundantly conversible, anecdotic, far-read, far-experienced, indeed a quite learned man (would read me lyrics &c., straight from the Greek, any evening, nothing pleased him better)” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:26). According to Grant, Sinclair’s “aptitude … for acquiring a knowledge of languages was so great that before he had attained his thirtieth year he was thoroughly master of seven foreign languages, in several of which he could not only converse with the greatest ease and propriety, but could write with an accuracy which natives of the respective countries could hardly surpass” (Grant, Sir George Sinclair 19). and cultivating no society, in the common sense of the word, but rather avoiding it; whh suits me like wise very well. Not to say that they grant me the high privilege of being strictly invisible till 3 p. m, when dinner is; and let me vanish again at any time when I like! By starting early in the morning,
and standing steadily to my tools, I generally manage to get a little work done, every day, and to have a bathe in this loud-sounding sea, and a great deal of walking and sauntering, mainly by the shore of it, where for miles I meet no creature, except perhaps at great intervals a cow or pony. The shores are exceedingly picturesque too, in their grim style; Orkney (the “Old Man of Hoy” always in sight) is a most precipitous rock-bound country; Dunnet Head do do;—and we are within a few hours driving of “John O’Groat’s House” (and are even nearer the Pole than it): what wd one desire more? In short, I will send yr Ladyship a “John o’Groats Buckie” (that smallest of sea-shells)Spiral mollusk shell supposed to bring good luck: “The beach is thickly strewed with shells, particularly those little beauties known as groatiebuckies, or cowries, from John o’ Groat, and visitors gather and carry them off by the score” (Hand-Book to Thurso 28–29). and a twig of heather (plucked, this day, from a hideous sea-rock called the “Clett of Caithness”),A solitary sea stack off Holborn Head, 2 mi. NNW of Thurso, colonized by sea birds; see 173 above .—and leave the rest to your imagination.

figure.p: The Clett, Holborn Head
Hand-Book to Thurso and Vicinity [1876]

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
Of my wife, or any other person, I hear little hitherto: and sometimes suspect in regard to her that she is not too well since I left,—tho’ she bragged there wd be such an improvet in that latter circumstance! If you cd bounteously bestow on me a few words of news,—do, pray, and soon! Ever yours sincerely
T. Carlyle TC wrote out the two verses of “There was a Piper had a Cow” (see 10:89 TC to LMC, 30 May 1838
), and signed it “Thurso Castle 12 Augt, 1860” (MS: Carlyle House; see opp. above ), presumably as an autograph for somebody; see also 7:269 TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1843
.

figure.p: “There was a Piper had a Cow”

p.hi: Courtesy of The National Trust

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 Aug. Addr: Aboukir Villa / Bridge of Allan. PM: Thurso, 13 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 525.66. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

figure.p: Hand-Book to Thurso and Vicinity [1876]

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
You are very kind to be anxious about me: but the truth is, I am doing altogether well.John wrote: “My imagination gives me gloomy ideas of your present weather at Thurso. I have put on winter drawers even here, where no north or east wind can do other than keep aloft.” I think I mentioned the arrangt of my hours; I have kept regular as clockwork; had a bit of work done, and a bathe, every day, before appearing at 3 p. m.;—about as much work as I used oftenest to make out at Chelsea; that is the great consolation and source of composure. The afternoons are quite idle, 2 hours of driving or more than 2; after whh, walking, tea, walking again, talk (innocent, rather learned, but prosy, boryTC’s neologism, presumably for “boring”; “bory” in Scots means “bradawl.”); I go to bed at 11, tired to the bone, and generally sleep very tolerably well, far better than was common lately at home. Today (sunday, a beautiful calm day, sun often out, yesterday was our first dry day) I gave myself a holiday; walked, silent by the shore of the many-sounding sea, three steady hours, to a sight they call the Clett;—got no great good of that; but it was the loveliest, least miserable, most pious kind of sunday walk I have had for a long time. Tomorrow 8 a. m. I must be ready to fall to again. The Sun, not far from setting, has flung a bright yellow beam over Thurso, whh is within a short cannon-shot of one of my windows, and looks better from the outside than I found it do within.For a view of Thurso, see opp above . The castle is beyond the right margin of the picture. No news from anybody;—Newspapers, but I read nothing of them. We are the quietest of households. Adieu, dear Brother; compts to Dr Hr. Ever your affecte /
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 Aug. Addr: 5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Thurso, 14 Aug. 1860; London, 15 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 615.526. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My poor little Jeannie,—Your Letter came at last this morning (Monday);—&, for one grand result, filled me with sorrow and anxiety about you! It is now midnight; how I have been prevented in the most peremptory manner from writing what I intended and intend, you shall know tomorrow unless I misluck: but I cannot go to bed witht writing one thing, whh is the substance of all: Namely, That you ought instantly to give up Barnes and his mixtures, and
get away into the Country. That is clear to me, and I wd have you set about it without loss of a day. If your own fancy point to any place, I will do my best to forward you in that (unless for your sake I might have contrary advice to give and remonstrance to make): but if you have no place specially in view, then I at once suggest, as a preliminary resting place for wherever else you may be bound, The Gill, and poor Mary’s nursing. You can get there in one night;—how much less miserable a night than one of those sad sleepless ones you pass! At 8 o’clock a. m., Austin meets you with a gig at Cummertrees;Railway station nearest The Gill. in half an hour you are at coffee or what you like, or quiet in your bed for a chance of sleep; and in short are Queen of all your movets, and let alone, and softly handled, to a degree you can nowhere else be!— All this I designed to write about, with detail, in composure, and with emphasis, this afternoon; and, if I live, will write about tomorrow: but in the meanwhile cd not sleep witht proposing and strongly recommending,—till you hear farther.

I am well, and doing well; tho’ carried off nolentissime [very unwillingly] on dinner ending, to an empty “visit”;To Captain Donald Macdonald and family; see TC to JWC, 14 Aug. out of whh (after 25 miles driving) we are just home. God bless you; may you sleep! T. Carlyle

ps.p: I am called daily at 8 a. m.; breakfast 10 minutes to 9: I run over to Thurso with this Tomorrow morning, still in time for the post.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 14 Aug. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Thurso, 14 Aug. 1860; London, 17 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 615.527. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:238–39 inc; Bliss, TC 350–51 inc. Quot: Wilson 5:397.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My dear little Goody,—I cd have been somewhat fretted yesterday morning, first at yr long delay in writing, and yr perverse notion of my neglect in that particular; also at yr scornful condemnatn of my descriptive performance (whh, I can assure you, was not done for the sake of Future Biographies,See JWC to TC, [10 Aug.]. TC underlined “descriptive” with a wavy line. nor done at all except with considerable pain and inconvenience, and at the very first moment possible in my gloom and sickliness, if you had known of it):—but all feelings were swallowed up in one: grief and alarm at the sleepless, excited and altogether painful state, my poor little Jeannie had evidently got into! A long Letter was to have been written, yesterday afternoon, after work, and bathing and dinner were well over. But, alas, at dinner (whh had been
unexpectedly crowded forward to 2 p. m. instead of 3, and had sent me into the sea and back again at full gallop, not to miss the essential daily bathe),—at dinner, whh I found them denominating “Luncheon,” I was informed that, 13 miles off, at some fine Highland Laird’s called Major Macdonald,Captain Donald Macdonald (1791–1872), Royal Engineers, of Sandside House, 10 mi. W of Thurso on the W shore of Sandside Bay. there stood an engaget for me of a strict nature, and that there I was to “dine.” Nimmer und nimmermehr [Never and nevermore];Cf. Goethe, Faust lines 3376–77; see also 5:350TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1831. the Major has not even asked me; I want no acquaintance with him or any Laird or Major; I positively cannot go! It was in vain that I insisted, and reiterated, in this key;—poor Sir George offered to dine now, and go walking with me on the sands while the Muckle Laird or Major’s dinner went on:—in short I found I shd give offence, and seem a very surly unthankful fellow by persisting;—so was obliged to go. The Highland Laird, an old Peninsular Soldier, was really not a bad fellow, quite the reverse indeed; and had a fine sleek Wife and Wife’s Sister (Panmure’s, I was told, whh did not help them at all);Lady Ramsay Macdonald (1804–84), da. of William Maule Ramsay, 1st Baron Panmure (1771–1852); her sister was either Lady Mary (1799–1864), widow of James Hamilton of Bangour, or Lady Christian Maule (b. 1805). Their brother, Fox Maule (1801–74; ODNB), 2d Baron Panmure, had been a controversial sec. of state for war during the Crimean War; see 30:121TC to JAC, 27 Nov. 1855, and 31:85TC to AGI, . item a Son just from India and the Crimea (good for nothing but grouse-shooting, and getting married next week to a Lindsay BalcarrasMaj. William D. Macdonald (1827–62) had served in China and in the Indian campaigns of 1857–58; he m., 30 Aug., Emma Anne Elizabeth (1839–90), da. of Colin Lindsay (1800–1864) and Emma, b. Watson (1814–1903), and grand-da. of Hon. Robert Lindsay-Balcarres (1754–1836). in London); finally a very pretty Highland Place (as Highland Places go), and a smart douce sonsy little Daughter,Possibly Patricia Macdonald (b. 1830). very nicely dressed (almost à la Goody, I thot) who made the Caithness dialect beautiful, and was the prettiest item of the lot. Sir G. and I walked as agreed upon, during their dinner; returned too soon, rather making a mull of it; missed our own “rough tea” (nothing but a miserable tray and flunkey turning up); had a somewhat confused hour or two; a cold seat (I with my tobacco) home over the windy moors;—and had just got some hot milk in lieu of tea when I wrote to you last night.— How my paper, this day again, is going! Let me dispatch.

Of myself I will say only that I have cunningly adjusted my hours; am called at 8 (by a little Butler, the one manservant, and as good as some six I have seen); bathe, as at home, run out for heat, breakfast privately (cup of hot coffee, juggie of good hot milk, egg and bread and butter, as at home, once more, only not so good),—and by this means shirk “prayers”; am at work by
10; run out at the stroke of 2 for a bathe; and do not shew face till 3 p.m. and dinner have come. After whh comes walking, comes probably driving (country equal to that of Craigenputtoch in picturesque effects, plus the Sea, which is always one’s friend); and am not very tight held even after dinner,-but avoid the evg devotions too. I have got some work done every day (Sunday excepted, whh I spent wholly in walking and sauntering); have slept every night,—never quite ill, as lately, once or twice splendidly well: would my poor Goody cd say as much! My head keeps humming; but not so much: in short you see I am doing well, and you need not bother on that score till you hear farther.— Note farther, the Post (if you avoid sundays altogether) is abt 48 hours from London: thus, yr Letter posted at Chelsea 4 p. m. Friday, arrived here sunday towards the same hour afternoon (but was not delivered till next morning): think of that point;—nearly a week“Few letters went from me in that Thurso solitude, none that I could help. From my darling herself I seemed to receive still fewer than I wrote; the tediously slow posts, I remember, were unintelligible to her, provoking to her!” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:27). before you can get ansr to a question: best to settle for oneself when possible.

I persist Dearest in what I said for you yesternight: An end to Barnes, and that you write at once to Mary to say you are coming. Such “a lodging in a Farm-house” you cannot get elsewhere in the world! Your stay moreover will be an honour, and withal a profit,—the longer you continue it, the welcomer. A gig for driving, one of the nicest, quiet but nimble old mares “Sally”; Mary a Capital driver. No “cares of bread”;Coterie speech; see 33:252JWC to TC, 25 June 1858. no cares of any kind, if you will shake yourself well! Tell me by return of post that you are getting to the road;—do, or else that you are going somewhither else: the prest style, with Barnes’s draughts, will never do. My poor Fritz returning from the 30-years War! Give him to Frk Chapman, & bid Sylvester have a brougham chosen by the time we come back. Here you mt perhaps do too: but it is 700 miles away; 150 beyond the Ashburtons’: The Gill is first and foremost. Adieu dearest; 2 is struck, and a quarter past it. God bless you. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 15 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: Thurso Castle, 15 Augt 1860 (9 p. m.,—just on the edge of going out)
docBody.p:
I send you this short word whh I hope may still reach you in your Bge.-of-Allan Quarters; and signify that all is going on in the old way with me here. I
keep my hours; try to scribble a little work (thrice melancholy scantling, but it is all I am up to!)—and go along in my quietest and canniest way: very silent (considering), and sleep in general wonderfully well. To-night we drove to ScrabsterSeaport 1½ mi. NW of Thurso. to pick out of the Steamer certain little children, just arrived from “Hook near Lockerby” (who are grand-childn of Sir G.s),Charles, Evelyn, Constance, and William Hope Johnstone, children of Sinclair’s 2d da., Adelaide, and George Gordon Hope Johnstone. They lived at Heuk House, Dumfriesshire, 2½ mi. SW of Lockerbie, on the estate of George Gordon Hope Johnstone’s father, John James Hope Johnstone (1796–1876), M.P. for Dumfries Burghs, 1830–47 and 1857–65. “Hook” is one of many variant spellings for Heuk House. John A. Carlyle and his wife, Phoebe, had rented one of J. J. H. Johnstone’s houses in Moffat; see 28:9TC to AC, 6 Jan. 1853, and 187JWC to TC, 8 July 1853. got wetted, some of us, endeavouring a farther interim excursion; but are now dry again (at least one of us is); and made strong again by tea, for another walk in the gloaming. Since Sunday our weather has decidedly tried to take up, been for most part dry, sometimes sunny; and much more comfortable than before.
Yesterday I got a Note from Jean; whh, tho’ it probably includes little that will be new to you, I may as well inclose. Symingtn’s Letter, the dud you wd have expected, I have already burnt.

Our “dear Baronet” (I always forgot to tell you) “calculated that you wd go to Lerwick, whereupon there wd be time to catch you up as you returned“:—it was quite as well he did not; “probably just as well!“—

Jane from whom I at length hear on Monday last, seems to me in a bad sleepless way, poor little soul: I have strongly advised the Country at once, and recommended Mary’s nursing, at the Gill, before all other arrangets.
Afternoon before yesterday (i.e. Monday) got yr last Note: I hope the Wick people have forwarded you the unlucky No 1. Adieu dear Brother. Ever your Affectionate / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], [ca. 16 Aug.]. MS: Duke. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen, 253–54 inc. Dated before JWC’s departure for Alderley, Wed., 22 Aug.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p:
I venture to hope that my mistake in supposing you still here is ascribable to Mr C’s confusion of speech that day, rather than to my own dullness of understanding! He did tell me he had called at Dover Street, and found “a cab or rather cabs at the door, taking away certain maidsPossibly the two youngest Stanley das., Katherine and Rosalind. and such like things“—but you (as I understood him) were not going—“not just yet.”
Certainly he didn’t know too well what he was saying that day, or for several days, before his departure in the Aberdeen Steamer!TC left for Thurso 1 Aug. I never saw him in such a state of nervous excitement—which is much to say!

But he seems to be getting calmed down at Thurso Castle.
