Old Sir George writes to me that his “dear and valued friend and guest” sleeps much better, and is “the delight of all their hearts” (Oh my!) so, it is hoped I will “lend him to them till the beginning of October”!— And Mr C himself expresses mild contentment with his lot up there. Even the Lady Camilla, of whom he had had fears, appears to him “a good female soul, heavy-laden with nerves, and many other things”!! And so I hope it may be considered settled that he will stay where he is till October, which will allow me time to get his rooms made nice and bright, and to grow a new skin over my nervous system! I shall give him your message—for, he is always glad of a message from you whether its behest be practicable or not. But his idea, when he left, was to sail straight back, as he went.

As for me, I have been feeling very much like a flock of Turkeys, at a dead halt, for want of dangling a bit of red clout before them!For the turkeys and the red cloth, see 34:136JWC to TC, 17 Aug. 1858. Thurso Castle, to be reached by spinning over six hundred miles of railway, presided over by an unseen Lady Camilla “heavy-laden with nerves, and many other things,” does not amount to a red-clout attraction at all!— I have negatived that proposal. Even the South of Scotland, where I staid last year till I got tired of every body and every thing, feels too far off, and otherwise uninviting. I have thought of Lodgings at this and the other sea-place—and actually looked for Lodgings at Richmond. But when it came to a practical decision, “horrible was the idea to me”!Coterie speech; see 18:201TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1844.

So here I am likely to remain, “solitary as owl in desert,”Cf. Ps. 102:6. and up to the ears in “household good“—that is to say feathers, new paint &c!— Unless indeed, as is not to be hoped, you have a prospect of continuing some time longer “quite alone, and rather dull,” with no new books or any thing to divert your mind. Under which impossible possible state of things, I might take advantage of your kind words about coming to Alderley,Alderley Park, Cheshire, the Stanleys’ country house, ca. 12 mi. S of Manchester. and stream off to you, out of this, for a few days. I know I could divert your mind as well as most of the new books that come under my notice! And I should not think it too far to go “on purpose,” to walk with you under shelter of trees, and talk with you, without callers interrupting, or a carriage waiting in the street to snatch you
away, like—ProserpineIn Roman mythology, Proserpine, the da. of Ceres, was snatched away by Pluto to the underworld.— But I am afraid you wont see your way to any more days of aloneness and rather-dullness; which state of things constitutes the red colour of the clout dangled before my Turkey-intellect—in the direction of Alderley.

I trust there is nothing materially wrong with the brain of “the Ashburton Baby.”Mary Florence Baring. I saw it the day before yesterday, sucking most vigourously, with its long dark hair “all about”! a most queer little creature to look at! picturesque to a degree!—but with every appearance of health. Lady A was out, but I heard from the Groom that the Scotch journeyTo Castle Brahan or Kinlochluichart; see TC to JWC, 6 Aug. was not given up, but was to come off next week.

If the Baby’s brain were a little “irritable” as yet, it would be a very natural result of that Baby’s fatalities! The first monthly nurse proved a disgrace to Humanity, put (only think!) some six or seven napkins to the Baby-posteriors all at once, in the morning, and left them unchanged till night! so that the poor little Posteriors became “all inflamed and sore,” and my Lord (!) (not my Lady) turned her off at a moments notice! a new Monthly Nurse had to be fetched from the Grange and a wet nurse—the Lady’s milk having been frightened away by the row. One hoped the affairs of the nursery were settled in permanence. But what was my astonishment to find the day before yesterday every face changed! three perfectly new women! one of whom was in the act of being sucked! As Lady A was out I did not learn what had happened—only, asking the man who showed me down; was the former nurse gone for good? he answered; “Oh dear yes! a new lot came in last night”! Poor wee Baby!—who can say what irritating effects all these new faces may have on its bit brain! I declare I could have found in my heart to undertake the suckling of it myself! were the giving of milk, as Dr Livingston and others make out, a pure act of volition!!David Livingstone (1813–73; ODNB), explorer and missionary, described several instances of women without young children nevertheless producing milk when a child was put to the breast; he also suggested “that the story … of a man, during the time of persecution in Scotland, putting his child to his own breast, and finding … that milk followed the act, may have been literally true”; see Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa (1857) 127.
I am very pleased that the Portrait was “all out of your own head“—and very pleased at your letter—and very faithfully yours
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [17 Aug.]. Addr: care of Sir G Sinclair Bart / Thurso Castle / Thurso N. B. PM: London, 17 Aug. 1860; Thurso, 19 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 607.547. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:33–35.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Thanks for the two letters Dear! I “did intend”Coterie speech. to have answered them together, at full length, by todays post, but have been hindered sadly and ignominiously—by “what shall I say”?Expression of Mazzini’s; see 17:36JWC to TC, 11 Aug. 1843.—an attack of British Cholera!JWC called it a “bilious attack” in JWC to Lady SLST, [20 Aug.]. Dont be alarmed! it is over now! and it is still but 2 o clock; and tho’ I was ill all night as well as all the fore noon I dont feel disabled from writing. It is an appointment with Lady Sandwich, which I dont like to break, that takes away the remaining 2 and a ½ hours, in which I might have written a sufficient letter. She sent the coachman last night, with a note to say she had returned to G SquareGrosvenor Sq. on account of a slight attack of Bronchitis, and would I tell the Coachman when to bring the carriage to fetch me. I appointed a quarter before three today—not foreseeing what the night had in reserve for me! Indeed I had no reason to expect anything of the sort, having been sleeping better, and feeling better in every way, for the last week. I rather “happrehend”Coterie speech; an expression of Lord Ashburton’s butler, Wills; see 21:187TC to LHB, 24 March 1847. it was my own imprudence in taking a glass of bitter ale to supper that caused this deadly sickness and—other things.

Trust me for doing the best for myself, in the circumstances. I am the last person to let myself be humbugged by a Dr— Mr Barnes was perfectly right in ordering me at the time you left to put all ideas of travelling out of my head, and “go to bed for two hours every forenoon, instead.” And the mixture which for many days failed in its intended effect, on account (he said) of the excitement I was in, got to do me palpable, unmistakeable good at last, and is now discontinued by his own order— At the time you left I was hanging on the verge of nervous fever, and have made a very near miss of it!

He does not disapprove of my going away now, provided I keep short of fatigue or excitement—and I am taking steps towards forming a programme— I will tell you in a day or two what direction I have decided on—

I should like very well to spend a day or so at The Gill, but a stay of any length there would not suit me at all. Milk is no object, as it is not strong enough food for my present weak appetite—and solitude is positively hurtful to me— Human kindness is precious every where, and nobody appreciates it
more than I do— But just the kinder they are, the more I should be tempted to overexert myself in talking and putting my contentmenThus in MS. in evidence. In short this would be a strain upon me, while I was supposed to be enjoying the hightThus in MS. of freedom! I mean were my stay prolonged beyond the day or two that the enthusiasm of meeting after long absence and having things to tell one another holds out—
I am so sorry to have to put you off with such a scrubby letter—but the carriage will be here before I am dressed and here is my beef-tea my first breakfast. Kind love to Sir George
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [17 Aug.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries N.B. PM: London, 17 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 607.548. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:35–39 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 489–90. A. Carlyle wrote on envelope: “Lett 221 / (printed with / characc omissions!” (see below for details).
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I havn’t leisure to commence this letter with reproaches, for the reproaches would be very long! and my time for writing is very short! In an hour hence a carriage will come to take me to a sick old LadyLady Sandwich; see JWC to Lady StanleyLST, [ca. 16 Aug.].—I myself being quite as sick, and nearly as old!—and there are directions to be given to diverse workmen before I start. For Mr Carlyle is absent—and I have taken the opportunity of turning a carpenter,Possibly Mr. Parsons or Joseph Morgan; see 34:43TC to JWC, 14 July 1858. and a painter,Unidentified. and a paperhangerProbably Oliver Osborn or John Walters; see 34:244JWC to JPR, 23 Nov. 1858. into his private appartment!

Yes: after repeatedly assuring you that Mr C would not go North this summer, but restrict his travels to some sea side place near hand—I am almost ashamed to tell you that he has gone ‘North’ after all! and further North than he ever was in all his life before! Being on a visit to Sir George Sinclair at Thurso Castle—the northernmost point of Scotland! A trial of Brighton had been made,TC and JWC spent 3–9 July at Brighton. and had ended abruptly and ignominiously, in flight back to Chelsea; to get out of the sound of certain cocks! Of all places in the World Brighton was the last one would have expected to be infested with poultry!

But one week of Brighton had only increased Mr C’s desire for sea; and indeed he had got into such a sleepless, excited condition, thro’ prolonged overwork, that there could be no doubt about the need of what they call “a complete change” for him. So he looked about for a sea residence, where he might be safe from cocks, and cockneys, and decided for Thurso Castle—which could moreover be reached by sailing, which he prefers infinitely to railwaying—and whence there had come a pressing invitation for us both—to spend a couple of months. Accordingly he streamed off there a fortnight ago—I remaing behind, for several reasons; first that sailing is as much as my life is worth! and seven hundred miles of railway would have been just about as fatal!— Second, if I was going to undertake a long journey, I might take it in directions that would better repay the trouble and expense than Thurso Castle, presided over by an Unknown Lady Camilla; my only friend there, Sir George himself more good than interesting!Froude omitted from “than” to “interesting,” presumably to protect the feelings of Lady Camilla and Sir George’s children. And third; the long worry and anxiety I had had with Mr C’s nervousness had reduced myself to the brink of a nervous fever—and my Dr was peremptory as to the unfitness of my either going with Mr C, or rejoining him at Thurso— Indeed I was not to leave home at all, in the state I was in—but to take three composing draughts a-day! and go to bed for two hours every fore noon! A fortnight of this, and perfect quiet in the house has calmed me down amazingly—only I feel as tired as if I were just returned from “the Thirty Years war“—

And now Mr Barnes does not object to my going away, provided I dont go to Mr C !!! and dont over exert myself; Mr C who is already immensely improved by his residence at Thurso Castle, is all for every body “going into the Country,” and has made up his mind that, like it or not, I must go “instantly” to—The Gill! (Mary Austin’s!)—which as it suits his milk-loving and solitude-lovingFroude omitted “and solitude-loving.” habits he imagines would equally suit me!—

And I myself, would like very well to turn my two or three remaining weeks of liberty to some more agreeable use than superintending the house-cleaning here! But decidedly mooning about, all by myself, at the Gill, lapping milk which doesn’t agree with me, and being stared at by the Gill childrenJames and Mary Austin’s six youngest children. as their “Aunt”! is not the happy “change” for which I would go far! Much as I like Mary Austin, and like to speak with her—for a few hours!Froude omitted “and like to speak with her—for a few hours,” presumably to protect Mary Austin’s feelings.

Now, I want to know how you are situated— Whether the invitation held out to me and which I, “ignorant of the Future” declined for this year, be still open to me—for if I had it in my power to go on to you for a week or so, from
the Gill—I might give myself the air of a charmingly obedient wife, and agree to go there—without my obedience costing me any personal sacrifice. The pleasure of a week with you and the Doctor would greatly counterbalance the tedium of a week at the Gill:Froude omitted from “The pleasure” to “the Gill,” to protect the Austins’ feelings. And I could break the long journey by staying a few days at Alderley Park (Lord Stanleys) where I have half engaged to go in any case—

But I don’t know if you are settled yet, or if you are not gone somewhere for change of air, yourself, or if somebody else be not located for the present in my room!!—and unfortunately I am tied to time—I must be back in London some weeks before Mr C—for reasons I will explain later—as they require time to explain them—
In the meanwhile you will in any case answer me as briefly as you like by return of post?—for I shant answer Mr C till I get your letter—

And I do beseech you to be perfectly frank—to tell me if you are going anywhere or if anybody else is coming to you? or if my room is not ready yet or worst of all if you are poorly and can’t be troubled. I understand that state so thoroughly well—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], [20 Aug.]. Addr: Dover Street. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: Your note has taken away my breath entirely! Tuesday! and this is Monday! And I am not sure I have a decent gown in the world,—and quite sure I havn’t a decent cap! And I am as weak as an eel trying to stand on its tail!Coterie speech; see 25:71JWC to MR, 24 April 1858. Naturally! having had a bilious attack since I wrote to you, and swallowed nothing for twenty four hours but brandy and water! and “seen a Dr” every day!

Oh Dear oh dear! and Lady Ashburton is to “take an early dinner” and come to tea with me on Tuesday evening!— (They sail, Baby and all, for the Highlands on Wednesday morning)— Clearly it cant be done—on Tuesday! but on Wednesday; I might by super human efforts get myself under weigh! and what efforts will not a fascinated Turkey make, to reach the prettiest scarlet bit of clout that has been danced before its eyes this many a month!

On Wednesday then, D V [Deo volente; God willing]—(as Venables remarked;
“there are two Ds!”)God and the devil; see 30:248JWC’s Journal, 27 April 1856. I hope to reach Alderley alive— And I have no fears for myself after! at four will be the most suitable hour—

I am glad to know Chelford stationJWC means Charfield rail station, 2½ mi. E of Alderley Park on the Crewe-to-Manchester line. is the place to stop at; for the rest; I must commit myself to Providence the Protector of “fools, women, and drunk people”Anon. epigram with many variations. Under two of these categories I may be well cared for— As to going to BradshawMonthly railway and steamer timetable, often consulted by TC and his brother John; see 35:201TC to TSS, 15 Sept. 1859. for direction; Heaven defend me from such rashness!
I have got your portrait in a standing frame—that is in a frame that stands,—on the table.

My clever little maidCharlotte Southam, who was still taken back for “days together”; see JWC to MCA, [25 Aug.]. said Yesterday, “ain’t it nice there Mam?—just like a bit of sunshine in the room! she looks so pleasant!”
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 [21] Aug. MS: NLS 615.528. Quot: Bliss 351. Tues. was 21 Aug.; TC dated this and TC to JWC, 23 [22] Aug., with the date of posting rather than the date of writing.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Thurso Castle, 22 [21] Augt 1860 (i.e. Tuesday 11 p. m,—Post goes Tomorrow morning 8½)
docBody.p: Dear little Goody,—My eyes are falling together (would yours were, for the like reason), I am so sleepy; having walked long miles, and this (11 p. m.) being now my orthodox hour of bed! But I must write you a few words, in hope of sleeping with an easier mind.

Your Letter greatly to my comfort, somewhat to my surprise, came yesterday morning. With a noble contempt of my industriously exact Post-Office instructions, you fell again plump into the Sunday (having written on Friday): you shd have seen me on Saturday when I had accompanied Sir G. to Thurso on purpose to catch up your Letter at once, and the blank look I had when there was none!— However all is well that ends as this did; namely, with hope, and an account which you affirm to be positive of some considerable inprovet. Oh take care of yourself; to find you in a “nervous fever,” what a busss that wd be! And tomorrow probably you will tell me what your plans for rustication, and refection of the poor frail tabernacle, are. But I shall not hear
it till night tomorrow;—and that is partly why I write to-night. Our weather having at last shewn symptoms of becoming dry (till 2 days ago, we have had continual damp grey, with draggling showers all day and night; and such winds,—you never heard such an uproar as the winds and the thundering Pentland billows make in their rocky caves; and there is not, so to speak, a tree in the country much less a wood or sheltering hedge. Well, the weather having taken up, an Expeditn to John O’ Groat’s House (I believe, near 20 miles off, to eastward) has become imperative,—appointed for tomorrow, de rigeur;Thus in MS. “We would warn any intending visitor to John o’ Groats, that there is positively nothing to see there, and yet we would say by all means go” (Hand-Book to Thurso 24).—and I shall have a weary bory day; and return as tired as possible. For the rest, a kind of crisis is perhaps approaching in my own affairs here; so that I long the more to hear whh way yours point. The case is this: Yesterday I got done with my Third Book;TC means the third book of vol. 3 of the 1st edn. of Frederick the Great, “Book 13: First Silesian War”; see Works 15:199–358.—am now into that unmanageable mass (called 4th & 5th Books,The fourth book, “Book 14: The Surrounding European War Does Not End,” was pbd. in vol. 3, but the fifth book, “Book 15: Second Silesian War,” was pbd. in vol. 4. whh FuzJohn Forster. had on hand); and have read today in it, as far as the hours went,—with astonishment and consternation! It is doubtful whether I can do any good upon it here, or away from the general reservoir of Books at Chelsea. I do not yet decide; but it is doubtful. In the negative case, my stay here cannot be long. Nothing but work & the comfort of seeing some progress, keeps my imagination quiet in this inane scene,—whh has lately recd the addition of 3 very little and very riotous grand childrenCharles, Evelyn, Constance, and William Hope Johnstone; see TC to JAC, 15 Aug. (with governess and trimmings),The governess and nurse were probably Violet Ingles (b. ca. 1830) and Mary Mackenzie (b. ca. 1838), who were listed in the 1861 census.—two of another stock, a little older and quieter,The children of Sinclair’s eldest da., Emilia; see TC to JWC, 6 Aug. we had already, with a strange staring (“very opulent”) HobbletehoyPossibly John Stephen (1835–1916), youngest son of Alexander Stephen, shipbuilder, of Broughty Ferry; see TC to JAC, 6 Sept. from Dundee, who hangs upon the “Missie”Olivia Georgina Power. of these; and—and more are expected (I think of the grown sort), for nothing can exceed the hospitality of this good man! He wanted me to invite Richard Milnes, Ruskin, my Brother John,—in fact practically pressed it till I told him there was not the least possibility.— If I did not get strictly kept invisible till 3 p. m; and then get thro’ the afternoon by 2 or 3 hours of driving (I always on the outside and silent), not to speak of walks, and solitary short strolls for smoking, life wd not be long agreeable on these coasts.

Well that is what I had to tell you of myself;—of yourself shall I not hope to hear farther on coming home? I will write a word there too, if not entirely knocked up; for Wedy night means Thursday morning at our Post Office, and Saturday at the Chelsea one;—I will not plump you into the Sunday!

It is certain I am considerably better in these 17 days;—my sleep is unspeakably improved; has not been so good since I was at The Gill 2 years ago.TC was at The Gill, 24 June–19 Aug. 1858. No Sea in the world is more crystalline; or handier,—were it not for the terrible jumbling winds among these crags and the too frequent rains:—I have had a bathe almost every day. My head too rather improves. On the other hand, I am weak; and cannot at once grow strong.— God bless my Goody, and may she sleep as I hope to do! Adieu Dearest. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 23 [22] Aug. Addr: 5—Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London; crossed out and redirected (in another hand) to Alderley Park / Conggleton / Cheshire. PM: Thurso, [23] Aug. 1860; London, 25 Aug. 1860; Congleton, 25 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS letter 615.529, envelope 615.531. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: You faithless little wretch, you have not written after all! What is the use of spending an hour and half of one’s sleep in writing to so careless a creature?—I try to persuade myself you are not relapsed (Heaven forbid!) nor matters gone wrong: But you really shd devote a penny-stamp and five minutes of your time (if you can spare no more) to relieve one’s anxieties,—whh is an extremely essential service, and capable of being soon done. Really I will insist on nothing farther; but this I do wish you would endeavour to perform.

Sir G. wrote to you in pencil from the (mythical) site of John O’Groat’s (whh, quietly, I guess to have been some ancient farmer’s lime-kiln or heap of compost); I had in the mean time gone to the Duncansby HeadThe NE tip of the Scottish mainland, approx. 18 mi. E of Thurso. “No one who has got [to John o’ Groat’s] should return without going on another mile to see Duncansby Head, the most beautiful headland in the north of Scotland. The cliff rises to a considerable height, and stretches for about two miles. … In a little bay to the south of the Head are the Stacks of Duncansby, two immense pillars of rock standing out in the sea” (Hand-Book to Thurso 29). sublimities: my walk thither, abt 3 miles in all, was vigorous, & even mostly my walk back (solitary both, except Sir G. for the first mile of the former): I have seldom in my life seen a nicer beach or bit of sea, not to speak of the rocks at all: I came back (leaving certain youthful parties to rear) in good time for a kind of
dinner at the queer little sea-side inn;The inn at Huna, 2½ mi. W of Duncansby Head: “Tourists and others visiting John o’ Groats will find every attention at Huna Inn” (advert. in Hand-Book to Thurso 3). got home unwetted, and am now (after farther walking) going to bed extremely tired—

Lady Sandwich writes, but does not sign; I think the Address too is not in her hand? Can you tell me anything about that when you please to tell me of yourself. Sinful craytur, but forgiveable, write immediately, I beg you!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: (How I hate these & all “steel pens”!)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [23 Aug.]. Addr: Thurso Castle / Thurso / N. B. PM: Congleton, 23 Aug. 1860; Thurso, 25 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 607.550. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:39–42.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: Alderley Park / Congleton Cheshire Thursday [23 August 1860]
docBody.p: There! what do you think of this? If you knew all; you would admit that I have as much “courage” as your Horse, which “goes whether he can or not”!Coterie speech; see 34:8JWC to TC, 4 July 1858.

But the present is not a moment for entering into details; of how ill I was after my last letter, and of how my illness was complicated with household griefs, and of how it was necessary to leave for here at hardly a days notice, or give up altogether the idea of going anywhere All that will keep till I am in better case for writing a long letter, or even till we meet “on our return from the thirty years war”!

Enough to say, for the present; that I am here on a most kindly pressing invitation from Lady Stanley, to stay “a week,” and “be nursed” (you may be sure it was pressing enough when I accepted it!) And that my intention is; if I get as much better as I hope to, to go on from here to The Gill, and from there, after a day or two’s rest to Holme Hill (Mrs Russell’s). where I can remain with advantage as long as I find expedient with relation to the time of your return home. Mrs Russell had been urging me to visit them for the last three months at intervals. And I am always much made of and very comfortable there. And to have a Doctor for one’s host was a consideration of some weight with me under the circumstances in choosing that ultimate destination. I couldn’t have travelled all the way to Dumfrieshire at one fell rush; but the invitation to Alderly broke the journey beautifully for me. It—(the coming to Alderley) had been spoken of—or rather written of by Lady S before I last wrote to you; but I was afraid to say a word about it in case you had played
me the same trick as in the case of Louisa Baring!Louisa Baring spoke of inviting JWC to stay with her and her sister Emily at Bay House, nr. Portsmouth, July 1858, but the invitation was not confirmed (see 34:36–37JWC to TC, 12 July 1858); TC wrote to Louisa urging her to finalize the invitation (see 34:30–31TC to LBA, 11 July, 1858), much to JWC’s embarrassment (see 34:36TC to JWC, 12 July 1858, and 61JWC to TC, 21 July 1858).—— No time had been specified then. So that when I received a letter on Monday (written in forgetfulness of the intervening Sunday) urging me to be at ChelfordFor Charfield. Station on Tuesday by four oclock, where Lady S would fetch the carriage for me; it quite took away my breath! I could not possibly get myself and the House packed by Tuesday! Besides Lady Ashburton had offered to come to tea with me on Tuesday, and been accepted “in my choicest mood“—so I answered that I would, D.V., be at Chelford Station by 4 on Wednesday. A more tired Human Being than myself when I got into the train at Euston Square yesterday, you havent seen “this seven years”!Cf. 1 Henry VI 4.3. Geraldine and Mr Larkin escorted me there, and paid me the last attentions! I was hardly out of sight of the Station when I fell back in my seat and—went to sleep!!! and slept off and on (me! in a railway carriage!) all the way to Crew; where I was roused into the usual wide awakeness by seeing the Van containing my portmanteau go off, as for good! It came back however after much running and remonstrating. And I was put down at Chelford “all right” in a pouring rain, which indeed had poured without a moments intermission all day.

The carriage was waiting with drenched Coachman and footman, who, I had the discomfort of thinking must wish me at Jericho at the least! And I was soon in the Hall at Alderley, into which Lady S, with the girlsPresumably Maude as well as Katherine and Rosalind Stanley, the three unmarried and youngest das. at her back, came running to welcome me with kisses and good words— A much more human mode of receiving visitors than I had been used to in Great Houses—In fact the whole thing is very human and very humain as well.

Lord S is still in London—Post Master General,The Times reported, 18 Aug.: “We have much pleasure in announcing that Lord Stanley of Alderley will succeed Lord Elgin as Postmaster-General. Lord Stanley has had long and varied official and Parliamentary experience, and is an excellent man of business. We trust that in his hands the Post-office will redeem its character, and that the scandals which have so long disgraced its administration will cease.” Lord Stanley wrote to Lady Stanley, 15 Aug.: “The office is in a bad state & wants a head at once. I am glad to get back again with my old friends, as an ex-Cabinet Minister out of office is always under great temptation to take an eccentric course” (Nancy Mitford, The Stanleys of Alderley [1939] 290). you will have heard,—nobody here but Lady S and the Girls—which suits my nervous system and also my wardrobe (which I had no time or care to get up) much better than
company would have done. indeed I had made aloneness and dullness, Lady S had complained of, as the conditions in accepting her invitation—

Mr Barnes had been saying all he could about “the excited state of my brain” (I too have a brain it seems!) to frighten me into “taking better care” of myself, and “avoiding every sort of worry and fuss and fatigue—” as if any body could avoid worry and fuss and fatigue in this world!— Worry and fuss and fatigue under the name of ‘pleasure’ of ‘amusement,’ that however one certainly may avoid. So I should not have gone wilfully into a house full of visitors—

I shall write to Mary to day—I had the kindest little letter from her!Mary Austin wrote to TC, [18 Aug.], saying that JWC would be “met with a hearty welcome as I told her today I for one would meet her with tears of joy I have wrote to her today and asked her to come for a few weeks you may depend on our doing everything in our power to make her comfortable if she only comes.”—Love to Sir George— I have had no letter from you since—I cant remember when!— Yours ever / JWC

ps.p: F Chapman will have written about the horse—he undertook to! Silvester says the horse is not broken has a nasty trick that would break any Brougham —turns sharp round and stands stock still in spite of all you can do—holding his head to one side as if he were listening! Poor Dear Fritz! The Breaker who I suppose desires to be rid of it says to Chapman it is broken and Frederick means to try it himself—!!!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [23 Aug.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.dateline: Alderley Park / Congleton Cheshire / Thursday [23 August 1860]
docBody.p: It went to my heart to have to answer such a dear kind letter as that of yours by proxy.Unexplained.

But I was really all but driven insane during my last days at Chelsea. Such a quantity of things laid on me to think of and to do, when I was but partially recovered from serious illness, and my Doctor was every day urging on me the importance of keeping myself “perfectly quiet and and above all avoiding every sort of fuss and worry”! Fine Talking! as if one could ever steer clear of fuss and worry in this world!

After months with no sleep “to speak of“—and after living 24 hours on
Brandy and water, and no food “to speak of” since; my views of Life, you see, aren’t very comfortable!

But never mind all that just now!—for I hope to see you face to face before many days are over!! And then I shall give myself the melancholy satisfaction of pouring all my recent troubles into your sympathetic breast and seeing you look very sorry for me!

Mrs Russell had been inviting me to pay her a visit ever since they went to their new house, out of Thornhill; and I had not seen my way to any such self indulgence as Mr C always spoke of staying at home or near home this summer, in which case I should not have left him. Then, when I was left at home, with time to listen to my own sufferings, which had been drowned in the eloquence of his! I found myself on the verge of nervous fever, and my Doctor prohibited all idea of travelling. till his “composing draughts” had “taken effect on me”The letter is written on two folded sheets that must at one time have been separated; TC wrote here: “fragt (1858?) Alderley, connected with another?” The nervous illness being followed by another illness quite unconnected with it, an attack of British Cholera, I couldn’t have “carried out” at all the idea of going to Dumfrieshire, which had been dawning in me; so that I had written to Mrs Russell that perhaps I would come; had not there come providentially a most kind invitation from Lady Stanley to spend a week at Alderley. which is half way to ScotlandAlderley is ca. 115 mi. from London and ca. 296 mi. from Dumfries. a distance that even my poor strength might manage. And at the same time came your dear little kind note making me feel more anxious to get to Dumfrieshire than I had yet been.
But as it was now I found I must be at Alderley, or not at all; you may figure my hurry and agitation of mind—so weak as I was and so much to prepare and arrange—in leaving home at 2 days notice
Of all that however when we meet—

I write today, with my head “like a mall”Coterie speech; see 33:69JWC to TC, 4 Sept. 1857. (from yesterdays shaking) to say that I mean to be with you next Tuesday or Wednesday (I shall write again to tell the positive day and hour) and to remain a day or two before I go on to Holme Hill
Even there I shall not be able to stay long—for household reasons which I will explain by word of mouth

Dear Mary I was always made as comfortable as a Queen in your house. You are very wrong to make apologies in asking me to it. There aren’t so many houses in this world where such a welcome always meets one!— Besides am I so difficult to make comfortable? I should say any one who had made Mr C comfortable for months together needn’t have any hesitation about asking me.

I am not nearly so “ill to deal wi’”Margaret A. Carlyle’s comment about TC as a child; see 8:273JWC to MAC, 23 Dec. 1835. as he is!Here TC wrote: “[1857, at Alderley]”; in his later hand above the date he then wrote: “60?” and underneath “coming to Dumfrre—see next Lr”; TC’s “next Lr” was probably JWC to TC, [23 Aug.], where JWC wrote about her intention to visit Mary Austin; JWC wrote that letter before this one.—
They are sending up to tell me to come out for a drive—so excuse this hurried scrawl—
Nothing can be kinder than my treatment here, I hope to be much fitter for the next half of the journey than I was for this.
I needn’t ask you to give my bed a terrible toasting if it hasn’t been slept in recently—as I do the impossible in catching cold when I change my room—
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 24 [23] Aug. MS: NLS 525.67. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:240–41; Wilson, 5:396–97. TC misdated; the letter was written 23 Aug., the day after TC went to John o’ Groats.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I have got all your Letters; and am very glad to hear of yr continued well being in your Stirlingshire abode. Your weather seems to be no better than ours; and that is bad enough, continual damp and wind, seldom any effectual heavy rain, but a continual intermittent drizzle, with tempestuous blowings, whh perhaps are more sensible than elsewhere here in this treeless country. I have not suffered in health; and consider myself still to be making progress, at least not to be receding, in that importt particulr, tho’ progress in the “book” dirictionThus in MS. is unhappily a good deal stopped since the beginning of this week. I got done with my Book 13 on monday, namely; and the remaining half of vol ITC means vol. 1 of the next pair of vols. he expected to publish; see TC to Sir GSSGS, 16 July. (shd not be quite a third I think) is in such a condition,—being written 5 years ago, & not looked at since,—that I know not well what to do with it; nor how to attack it at all witht the aid of all my Books and Apparatus, and the day altogether to myself. I sit boring over it, not idle quite, but with little visible result; and that has considerably weakened the best strength of my position here. I dimly intended to hold on for “about a month”; and this is not unlikely to be the actual limit. Friday, tomorrow week, is a day I have been thinking of for departure and today I spoke of it to Sir G. who has always been or professed to be clear for “2 months as the minimum“: but will perhaps be at bottom not so averse after all to the shorter term,—there being such a cackle
of grandchildren here, with governesses &c, whom he sees to be to me a mere bore tho’ to him such a joy.

I mean to go, of course, with the Scrabster Steamer; but whether to Aberdeen, or to Edinr is uncertain (a 3 days to Erskine at Linlathen being in my view); and in either case, I propose taking a glimpse of my poor Annandale again, and returning thence by rail to Chelsea. I expected to have heard agn from Jane what her plans are; but as she does not write, I have to shape at least to chalk, ready for potential shaping, my own plans at least

If you have any Travelling Oracle (awe-inspiring Bradshaw, Murray or the like) that will tell, even abstrusely, what one’s true modes are for that route to Annandale,—it wd be useful to send me the approximate response. In this House nobody knows abt such things: but in Thurso, I understand, there are who do.

Yesterday, by preappointt “unless the day were wet” (I not unwilling to have a day’s idleness), we went to John O’ Groat’s actually: it is about 20 miles for us to the little sea-side inn of Huna; there you dismount, walk to Groat’s (i.e. to the mythic site of Groat’s) a short mile, thence two rather long ones to the top of Duncansby Head. It is one of the prettiest shores I ever saw: trim grass, or fine corn even, to the very brow of the sea; sand (when there is sand) as white as meal; and between sand and farm-field, a glacis (or steep slope) whh also is covered with grass, in some places thick with meadow-sweet, “queen-of-the-meadows,” and quite odiferous as well as trim. The Island of StromaIsland in the Pentland Firth, 3½ mi. WNW of Duncansby Head. flanks it, across a Sound of perhaps 2 miles broad; three ships were passing westward in our time, the old wreck of a fourth was still traceable in fragmts sticking in the sand, or leant on harrows higher up, by way of fence. The site of Groat’s has a Barn short way behind it, and a cottage short way to its left (looking seaward); the waves are abt a pistol-shot off at high water It stands (that is, a house wd stand there) very beautifully, as at the bottom of a kind of scoop, rising slowly behind into highish country, do to west (tho’ not into great heights at all), and the big Duncansby quite grandly screening it both from e. and n. e. And all was so admirably still & solitary; extensive Cheviot sheep nibbling all abt, and no other living thing.Sheep had been brought from the Cheviot Hills in the Scottish Borders by Sir John Sinclair, Sir George’s father, because they were hardy animals known for their high yield of mutton and wool. Early in the 19th century Caithness had taken in many of the people displaced by the Highland Clearances in Sutherland, but by mid-century Caithness landlords too were turning their tenantry out of their homes to make way for sheep; see also TC to CAW, 24 Sept. Like a dream. The Orkneys, Ronaldsha, SkerriesSouth Ronaldsay is the southernmost of the Orkney Islands; the Pentland Skerries are four tiny islands 4½ mi. NE of Duncansby Head. &c lay dim, dream like, with a beauty as of
sorrow, in the dim grey day. Groat’s site appeared to me terribly like some extinct farmer’s—limekiln! Rain broke out on us coming home; and and I lost a good fraction of my sleep last night by the adventure. This is all I have to say of Groat or myself: high time I was in bed. Ever yours T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 24 Aug. Addr: The Lord Stanley’s / Alderley Park / Knutsford Cheshire. PM: 2[5] Aug. 1860; Knutsford, 27 Aug. 1860; Congleton, 28 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 615.530. Hitherto unpbd. “Knutsford” has been scored out and “Congleton” written at the top of the envelope in another hand.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, my dear Goody, I fear you have been very poorly; and that there lay the too valid excuse for your not writing! I got Geraldine’s Letter today; whh was a great deal better than the nothing-at-all whh has been my diet in that kind lately. Her news is not the best in all parts; but nothing like so bad in any part as one’s own sickly imaginatn sometimes suggests.

I am delighted to think you have gone to Alderley, and are by all likelihood already there. Two hundred miles nearer me; tho’ still five hundred away. You cd not have gone to any place that wd have pleased me better. Lady S. is one of the warmest hearts, the young creatures too are cheery bright beings; everything is honest, rural, ample,—a kind of cut-and-come-again, whh one can depend upon, in every departt. Cheshire is rainy; but perhaps may be drier than its neighbours just now:—in my life I have not seen so wet a year.— Make my humble respects to Her Ladyship; and say, I am full of thankfulness to Destiny and Her that you are under Alderley rooftree;—and that if she can make you sleep to sufficient lengths I shall be infinitely obliged.

This week has gone well with me, in all points except the Friedrich-Book one (sorrow on it!) Work wd not go on at all in the new section: however, I took it in flank today, and did get some small way made again. A considerable comfort,—in this the wettest of days. I have not stirred beyond the shrubbery (whh has a high wall between you and the sea,—pretty much the only shelter in the parish); I have wetted two pairs of trowsers (the last quite recently) walking there at difft times,—and have these drying beside me, with the less wet of my Hats, at this very time.—— We have become a sad colony of children with governesses: fancy how delightful to me! Yet the people, Sir G. himself first of all, are unsurpassable in humanity and kindly honesty: they really are patience itself to my crabbed impatiences and me. I think of going off in about a week hence,—there is only a conveyance once a week (Friday, steamer to Aberdeen or Edinr); Sir G. hospitably objects in a loud manner;
but I think will be improved by consenting. I intend for Annandale a short while, perhaps a d[ay] or two for Erskine’s.Thomas Erskine lived at Linlathan, nr. Dundee. No more tonight. God bless thee ever T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [24 Aug.]. MS: NLS 607.551. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:228–30.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: You must be thinking me a little insane, and you won’t be far from the truth!

I have really been driven nearly beside myself by a complication of things—a serious and most ill-timed illness included! My Dear! after one has gone for a week almost entirely without sleep, and almost entirely without other nourishment than Brandy and water (!!) one may be pardoned some ommissions!

Besides, till I had really got myself started, and found myself thus far alive, and life like I couldn’t have answered your dear kind letter to any definite purpose. It depended altogether on how I stood the first half of the journey to Scotland, whether I undertook the other, or returned to Chelsea. where I should at least not trouble my friends with my ailments.

I came off so suddenly at the last, and had such a quantity of things to do in a hurry, with no strength to do them; that I did not get my Exodus announced to even my Husband!A. Carlyle attached a long note here, defending TC in JWC’s misunderstandings about his travel plans; see JWC to MR, [25 Aug.]. And absurd as I felt it, after demanding an immediate answer from you, to let my own next communication linger so long; I was obliged to just accept the absurdity! When you hear all my history of late weeks; you will not wonder that I should have failed in writing so much as that I should have failed in dying or going out of my mind.

But to the purpose—I am thus far safe, and tho’ the journey tired me excessively, I have been improving every hour since. Lady Stanley and her daughters are charming people, and as kind to me, and considerate, as it is possible to be.— Last night I got the first human sleep that I have had these six weeks! And I expect to be quite in heart for proceeding to the Gill next week—
Will you kindly address a line to me there!—
Mrs Austin’s
The Gill / Cummertrees / Annan

for next Wednesday—telling me when your friend’sUnidentified. visit terminates. For one
of us at a time I should say would be quite enough for you. And of course I should rather be alone with you, than with you in the presence of a third person—
I have to write to Mr Carlyle, and my Dr last words to me were to “beware of overworking that excited brain of mine,” so I will leave all the rest till we meet.
I feel very happy at the thought of seeing the Dr and you again!
God bless you for your warm assurances of welcome.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JB [JBUL], [24 Aug.]. Addr: Chelsea Letter carrier / Brompton row Post office / London. PM: Congleton, 24 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 1797.31. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN BULLOCK

docBody.p: It is possible there may have come no letters for me since my departure; At the same, the old woman“Old Jane.” A. Carlyle claimed, as part of his defense of TC in the coming misunderstandings, that JWC really wanted to return to London, in part because “[s]he had left her house in charge of a servant whose honesty she suspected, and who did very soon become a convicted thief. She was uneasy at having left this person in such a responsible position” (A. Carlyle, NLM 2:229). I left in charge of my house is so inconceivably stupid, that I shouldn’t wonder if she had mislaid, or forgotten to give you the addresses I left with her for your direction To make sure I now inclose them direct to yourself. Jane Carlyle

Thomas Carlyle Esqr
Thurso Castle
Thurso
N.B.

Mrs Carlyle
The Lord Stanley’s
Alderley Park
Congleton
Cheshire

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [25 Aug.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: Congleton 2 [6] Aug., 1860. MS: NLS 607.553. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:42–43.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I could sit down and take a good hearty cry!
I am not to get to you after all!

This morning is come a letter from Mr C, forwarded from Chelsea, giving me the astounding news that there is every likelihood of his coming home by next Wednesdays Steamer!JWC believed that TC intended sailing “straight back, as he went”; see JWC to Lady SLST, [ca. 16 Aug.]. She thus misinterpreted TC’s letter of 22 [21] Aug. in which he hinted that he might leave Thurso soon, “my stay here cannot be long,” as he needed the “general reservoir of Books at Chelsea.” Towards the end of the letter he wrote “of yourself shall I not hope to hear farther on coming home?” and it is possible that JWC read his postal information, “for Wedy night means … Saturday … at Chelsea,” as meaning he was leaving Wed. and would be home Sat. A. Carlyle claimed that the offending letter used the term “sail South” (NLM 2:229), a term that is not used in any of TC’s letters about his plans, and that the letter arrived at Alderley, via Chelsea, on 25 Aug. JWC later made clear that it was TC’s letter of 22 [21] Aug., which she forwarded to Mary Austin, 25 Aug., “as a valid excuse” for “breaking [her] engagement to come”; see JWC to TC, [2 Sept.]. Always the way! whenever I go anywhere to please myself!
Plump he appears at Chelsea! and just now his appearance there in my absence would be (as Lord Ashburton would say) “the Devil”!

I cannot enter into an account of my household affairs just now—being long and most ridiculous— I was keeping it as an amusing story for you when we met— I will write the story from Chelsea at my first leisure (when will that be?)— But just now I am toThus in MS. vexed for making a good story besides being too busy having so many letters demanding to be written about this provoking change of planLady Stanley wrote to Lord Stanley, 26 Aug.: “Poor Mrs. Carlyle who was going to Scotland Tuesday has heard from the Philosipher that he returns to Chelsea like a cannon ball & so she goes to meet him. She is very amusing & tells no end of stories” (Nancy Mitford, The Stanleys of Alderley [1939] 290).—

When I leave here it must be straight for Chelsea! And I must go on Tuesday morning— What a pity—I was just beginning to recover my sleep in the fresh air and the absence of worries! have had actually two nights of good sleep—and they are so kind to me and they to whom I was going would have been so kind to me!

But when one has married a man of genius one must take the consequences!
Only there was no need for him to have spoken of staying at Thurso till the beginning of October! And misled me so!
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [25 Aug.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:230–31 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Oh my dear Mary! I am so very sorry! Instead of telling you the specific time of my arrival at the Gill, I have to tell you the unexpected and to me very disappointing news that I cannot get there at all!
A letter from Mr. C this morning has knocked all my scotch project on the head, remorselessly—he is evidently coming back to Chelsea by the next Steamer!
And the house is by no means left in a state fit to receive him! And there is no servant there at present who can make the necessary preparations—

My illness, and the complete failure of the new Servant“Old Jane.” I had engaged having made it necessary even for myself, whose wants are much fewer to take back CharlotteCharlotte Southam. for days together.
So there is nothing for it but just to turn my face south ward when I leave here on Tuesday

It is a great pity for I was improving so much in the fresh air and the absence of worries— I have had two good nights: now I shall have no more such for the suspense about when he will arrive, and the weight of things to be done before he arrives will throw my nights into agitation againTC wrote later: “[1855 or ‘6 (Alderley: I coming from Edinr)].” On top of the date he then wrote: “[1861?”
Please tell Jean and when you have read your Brothers letterTC to JWC, 22 [21] Aug. inclose it to her, with directions to return it to me at Chelsea
I feel myself a very unfortunate and rather injured woman for the moment—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 25 Aug. Addr: The Lord Stanley’s / Alderley Park / Congleton, Cheshire. PM: Thurso, [2] 6 Aug. 1860; Congleton, 28 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS letter 615.531, envelope 615.529. Quot: Bliss 352.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I am right glad to hear of your safe arrival at hospitable Alderley: sound may you sleep there, may you have slept! I hope the rest of the Tour will run off as well as the somniferous ride to Crewe; what a beneficent railway, that, to receive a poor worn-down Goody, and wrap her gently in its iron clangours into immediate sleep!—

I wrote yesternight on getting Geraldine’s message; but I could not completely recollect the Post-Town; and put “Knutsford” (the ancient Ante-railway Post),Before the mail was carried by rail, Knutsford was the nearest postal town to Alderley. tho’ with a slight feeling that perhaps I was wrong. No saying but you may get this before its antecessor: that is why I write half a word, in haste (after a long dry walk), to keep your imaginatn peaceable. I am well; tho’ my work today (if we can call it “work”) went rather wrong. The people here are kind as possible; and good Sir G. is certainly the hospitablest mortal living.

I had to settle my day of departure in ignorance of your contemplated motions: Friday next (31st); but that is not absolute,—there is still pleadings, of respectable emphasis, for a lengthening of the term; or I cd linger elsewhere, and loiter:—in short, you shall not be hurried at Thornhill or elsewhere; only let me know what your notion or guess of a notion is, that I may as far as feasible conform to it. There is a crew of noisy little jumping children here (5 or 4); whom I terrify by my grim manner, and thus drive mostly quite out of my way: but for this, my lodging might pretty much boast itself unparalleled for me. No hurry, no hurry, if you find you are getting benefit.

I shall have to write Notes tomorrow: Kirk &c I contrive always to eschew; but my walk in the weather of last sunday was unsuccessful. Hoy is beyond expressn beautiful, when we have a clear blink (as this evg) in the wet weather. Aurora Borealis every night that is fair.— I persisted to write Nothing to the Newspaper Cromwell people;Unidentified. but one or two other things have gathered: ach! My respects all round, my Lady and Miss S. nominative.Probably Maude Stanley, the eldest of the three unmarried das. Sleep, my own poor Goody; God bless thee. T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD [WDO], [25 Aug.]. MS: NLS 1797.207. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 254–55. The letter is written on Alderley Park headed notepaper; JWC added “Cheshire.“
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.dateline: Alderley Park / Congleton Cheshire / Saturday [25 August 1860]
docBody.p: I told you at our last interviewWilliam and Jane Dods visited Cheyne Row 8 Aug.; see JWC to TC, [10] Aug. that I was the image of—a flock of Turkeys! waiting, in the most weak minded manner, till a morsel of red clout should beckon them in one particular direction!— But perhaps my illustration was lost on you; thro’ your ignorance of Turkey habits. Did you ever see a body of Turkeys—or Geese—on their travels along the Kings Highway? i never did in Scotland! The sight met my eyes for the first time in Piccadilly!!—(Geese it was in that instance—but one wouldn’t, you know, liken oneself to some hundreds of Geese!) The creatures were getting over the ground by little sudden rushes, each rush being excited by a dust-coloured man a-head, shaking a pole, at the end of which fluttered a scarlet rag! That is the way that large bodies of Turkies or Geese are persuaded to go voluntarily long journeys in the South!

Well—Shortly after you left, a rag sufficiently red was fluttered before my uncertain mind, in the shape of a letter from that buxom sunshiny looking woman whom you saw a print of lying in my room! (Lady Stanley) pressing me to come to Alderley (in Cheshire). I liked the Place, and liked the People; then; it was just about half way between London and Dumfrieshire; so that when my visit ended, I could easily go on there, where (I flattered myself) my coming was intensely wished for!

So to Alderley Park I came, and have been leading a delightfully quiet Life: things going on here in a most human and simple manner, in the absence of the Lord of the Manor, who has been busied with his new Postoffice-Generalship in London. I was to have gone on to Annandale next Wednesday, and was quite in heart for the journey; having improved every day here;—felt to be growing a new skin over my nervous system! Sleep having returned to me and my nights no longer such as beseemed a woman who had committed murder, or other capital crime or crimes—of which upon my word I am quite innocent!—

But, alas for “best laid schemes of mice and men”!Cf. Robert Burns, “To a Mouse” line 39. YesterdayJWC told both Mary Russell [25 Aug.] and Mary Austin [25 Aug.] that TC’s letter arrived “this morning.” came a letter from my Husband, whom I was fondly imagining fixed at Thurso Castle till the beginning of October; telling me he could not get on with his work at a distance from his reservoir of Books;TC used this phrase in TC to JWC, 22 [21] Aug., but did not mention possibly going home “next week.” He was no more specific than “[i]n the negative case, my stay here cannot be long.” and might possibly be home next week!

Home!—and the curtains of his bed at the Dyer’s!—and all the spoons and silver things hidden away from possible thieves, where only myself could find them!—and all the Keys locked up in—the Piano!—unlabelled! no body to do for him but an old Cook of 71 whom every thing like an emergence reduces to absolute idiocy!— And he the most “particular” and most impatient of Men! and I the most self-bothering and excitable of Women!—

Alas for my programme of visits in Dumfrieshire!— That is now knocked on the head! And I see no help for it but to go my ways back to Cheyne Row, and resume my sleepless nights, and oppressive days. and ‘die at my post’! (as the dramatic phrase is!)— Not that I have any positive intention of dying in that Martyr fashion—or in any fashion I can help—before you and your Wife have come to London again and made amends for the stinted measure of kindness you bestowed on me— Especially she—for you did put yourself to the trouble of coming a second time— And that is why you have here a letter “all to yourself”5. Coterie speech; see 34:233JWC to MR, 30 Oct. 1858.
I shall go home, D V, (you know there are two Ds!) on Tuesday next—to make ready for Mr C, in case he come by this weeks steamer—

I want very much to hear who has bought my poor dear Sunny Bank?The sale by auction, 7 Aug., was advertised in the Scotsman, 25 July: “THE HOUSE OF SUNNYBANK OR tenterfield, with the Coach-house, Stable, and other Offices, and Gardens and Fields attached, extending in all to about 5½ Acres imperial measure, … lying in the immediate vicinity of the town of Haddington. / This is a very eligible Property, the present House, with the Pleasure-Grounds, being a most agreeable residence, and the adjoining Fields offering very desirable Sites for additional Villas. / Further particulars will be furnished by John Ferme, Writer, Haddington, who is in possession of the Titles.” William Dods replied to JWC, 29 Aug.: “Sunnybank was sold to Mr Thomas Todrick … 3 small fields and a Garden near the coach road were sold in one lot for £2200—which is £300 below my value. / Mr T. intends making considerable additions & alterations & may lay out perhaps £800 or £1000 in these which will raise the price to him. That vain fellow Stuart Donaldson had never intended buying it although he said he would. … Next comes the sale of the furniture. … There is an engraving of your Husband which I will buy & if there are any of your own Photographs exposed for sale I will take care of them also. I suppose there is no little article about the House that you would care to possess if there is let me know. / What about the Shawl & Brooch that were intended for you? It is real dishonesty in the Donaldsons’ keeping these but you should ask for them & tell them that you understand from Mrs Dods … that these were laid aside to be sent you.” Thomas Todrick (1814–90), banker.—
And how you both feel after your Holiday—
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JB [JBUL], [26 Aug.]. Addr: Chelsea Letter-carrier / Post Office / Brompton Row / London. PM: Congleton, 26 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 1797.34. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN BULLOCK

docBody.p: Please to forward no more letters either to Mr Carlyle or myself—
I have reason to expect his return in the course of next week, and must go back to Chelsea to receive him.
I shall be home, barring collisions, on Tuesday afternoon.
I write by this post to the old woman in the house, and would thank you to ring till she answers, and to put the note into her own hands—it might lie in the Box long enough without her taking it out—
Also to read it to her if necessary—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [26 Aug.]. Addr: Thurso Castle / Thurso / N. B. PM: Congleton, 26 Aug. 1860. MS: NLS 607.554. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:44–47.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh dear me! this length of days needed for a letter written to or from Thurso to get an answer in the course of post is very trying to impatient spirits!— Not on account of the slowness only—but on account of the ‘change come o’er the spirit of ones dream’Cf. Byron, “The Dream.” in the interval between the Post going out and coming in!— Not once since you have been at that accursedly out of the way place, has a letter from you found me in the same mood and circumstances to which it was addressed—as being the mood and circumstances in which my own letter had left me! And of course it has been the same with my letters to you. For example; your announcement that you might be home immediately crossing my announcement that I was on the road to Scotland!

Now I write to say I am turning back, and shall be at Chelsea D. V. on Tuesday afternoon, to prepare for you—in case you do come soon—which I shall regret for your sake; a few more weeks of sound sleep would be so good for you! What will be the contents of the letter which crosses this? Something quite irrelevent I have no doubt!

Perhaps assurances that you can do perfectly well at Chelsea without me, and to stay in Scotland as long as I like!— When I shall be reading the letter at
Cheyne Row!— And as sure as ever Woman was of anything that you could not have done at Chelsea without me for twelve hours!

The week before my departure which should have been devoted to setting my house in order was devoted to British Cholera, which coming on the back of low nervous fever reduced me to a state of exhaustion which even “zeal for my house”Cf. Ps. 69:9. couldn’t rouse to the requisite activity— Many things had been begun but few of them finished, for instance your bed had been all taken to pieces to look for bugs—and it had been ascertained that not one bug survived there! and the bed had been put together; but the curtains were away being cleaned!

Fancy your coming home to a curtainless bed! And “old Jane”“I have quite forgotten” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:45). would have made no shift! for “old Jane” my Dear, I may as well tell you soon as syne is a complete failure and humbug! Altho you provokingly enough attributed the silence I systematically observe on the shortcomings of servants to want of “care about it,” I still think that until I am arrived at parting with a servant and have to show reason why, the more I hold my peace about them and make the best of them, the more for your comfort and for my own credit.“Alas! can that need to be said?—insane that I was!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:45).

“Old Jane,” then, disappointed me from the first day! Before you left I had satisfied myself that she was a perfectly incompetent cook and servant, and soon after you left, I satisfied myself that she—told lies! and had no more sense of honour in her work than Charlotte!!!— There was no need to worry you with the topic of her which was to myself perfectly loathsome—until I had to account for replacing her. I mention it now to reconcile you to the idea of my having gone back home to wait for you— You couldnt have done without me— You see!— I have engaged a woman of 34“Tall Charlotte.”—who is really promising—(the woman Miss EvansPossibly Mary Ann Evans (George Eliot). wanted to have)—and a remarkably nice looking girl of 16Sarah. “Yes, I recollect these two. I had often latterly been urging ‘two servants,’ but she never till now would comply. The elder of these ‘two’ did not suit either. A conceited fool; got the name ‘Perfection’ and (to the great joy of the younger, who continued worthily) had to go in a few months” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:46). to be under her— She would not have taken a place of “all work,” and indeed it is very difficult to find ever a respectable Servant who will take it—Naturally—when they can find plenty of less confused places—She the elder woman comes home on the 14 of Septr—and I wished the Girl to wait till then— I think the house will really be comfortable and orderly by and by—at more cost but that you said repeatedly you didnt mind— At all rates I have taken immense trouble (two journeys to Richmond
included) to find respectable and competent servants— If I have failed—it will just be another instance of my ill luck rather than my want of zeal
MaudMaude Stanley. has been sitting in my room waiting till I am done—
Excuse haste and abrupt ending—I can’t write on this principle—and I shant get a chance again before post time
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LS], [27 Aug.]. MS: NLS 19.3.52.13. Pbd: Scottish Historical Review 28 (1949): 56–57. The letter is written on headed notepaper.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I lay my homages and loving remembrance at your feet! and pray; that, when you have “some reasonably good leisure,” you will inform me how you are!
For the rest; I may say in the touching language of the Meat-Jack “Once I was happ-happ-happ-y! but now I’m meee-ser-able!”Coterie speech; see Past and Present, Works 10:155.

On the morning of last Thursday, I awoke in Paradise! that is to say; in a very soft four posted bed of immense height! I have a weakness for high beds! which are all associated in my mind with the Bed of “Sleeping Beauty,” as represented by a wood-cut in my first Story-Book! From this Alderley High Bed one could see, when the shutters were opened, away over a beautifully wooded Park, all green as emeralds! And the silence!—so deep!— It seemed a positive thing, a thing to be taken hold of! like a mantle of down fallen on one out of Heaven! I thought of the masons roofing and flooring at Chelsea—of the cocks crowing at Brighton—of all the noises that had embittered existence for us in past times, and thanked God and Lady Stanley that I was here—in such stillness and freshness and greenness! For two days and two nights every hour seemed to bring healing on its wings.Cf. Mal. 4:2 and Charles Wesley, “Hark the Herald Angels Sing” (1739). Nothing to vex or worry me! But life made beautiful and pleasant for me—in every possible way! I felt to be growing a new skin over my flayed nervous system, and looked forward to the other half of my journey, and my Scotch visits, with a feeling of hope and pleasure which was far from me when I started on the first half.— But alas for “best laid schemes of mice and men”!— On Saturday morning a letter was forwarded from Chelsea, which had arrived from Thurso Castle; in which Mr C informed me that he was “approaching a crisis”
in his affairs! didn’t see his way thro’ the next Chapters of his Book—without help from his reservoir of books at Home! was besides threatened with “an influx of new Grandchildren” (not his own; Sir George’s!)See TC to JWC, 22 [21] Aug. In short it was “becoming clear” to him that he could not (say would not) remain at Thurso much longer “indeed that he might be expected at Chelsea almost immediately”!!These words were not in TC to JWC, 22 [21] Aug. TC implied he would write again “Wedy night” and did, TC to JWC, 23 [22] Aug., where these words also did not appear. JWC apparently overinterpreted TC’s intentions. A. Carlyle was of this view: “She was the unfortunate victim of circumstances. No one was to blame more than herself. The chief regret is that her impatient and angry letters were ever published!” (A. Carlyle NLM 2:229). He meant those letters pbd. in Froude, LM 3:42–62.

Expected at Chelsea Good Heavens!— And the Curtains of his bed at the Dyers!— And the Spoons and things all hidden away from possible thieves where only myself could find them!— And all the keys of the house locked up unlabelled in—the Piano!! (I was so hurried, and confused by illness just before leaving!) And the old woman left in charge, a perfect Imbecile! whom he would find an irresistable temptation to strangle, if alone with her!

So, what England expectsCoterie speech; see 33:13JWC to TC, 7 Aug. 1857. of me is very plain! and very sad! To give all my beautiful Scotch programme to the winds, and return to that dreary Cheyne Row, to prepare the way for him. I shall be there D. V. (meaning the other “D”) tomorrow The Wretch that he is! after telling me he wouldnt be home till October!

He write that he had had a letter from you; but you didnt sign “nor had you had the address in your head”TC wrote: “the Address too is not in her hand”; see TC to JWC, 23 [22] Aug. and he asks anxiously can I explain that
docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 28 Aug. Addr: The Lord Stanley’s / Alderley Park / Congleton. PM: Thurso, 2[9] Aug. 1860; Congleton, [date obscured] Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.532. Pbd: Bliss 352–53.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
I have seldom in my life been so vexed by anything of that kind as by the news you sent me this afternoon. My Unfortunate, dear, infatuated Goody! If you have actually gone back to Chelsea, and are sitting there this night instead of at The Gill, and all on a basis of mere mistake & delusion, I know not how I shall ever endure it. Your hypothesis is baseless from beginning to
end; and if you have missed gaining a little strength, will not that be a kindness to me!—

Not being able to pick a Letter from you (what was more yr misfortune, poor soul, than yr crime) I was obliged to do the best I could in making some approximate arrangt for my separate self: I spoke of Friday 31st here as my day of departure hence;TC to JAC, 24 [23] Aug., and TC to JWC, 24 Aug.—whh was by no means fixed (and is now, on the new phenomena turning up, fixed another way,—viz. to be the following Friday, Friday 7 Septr!)— But neither then nor now was it [ever]Word illegible. in my head to run directly upon Chelsea; I did not and do not count on that for 2 weeks or 3 more. See what a mess!

I could not bear to read the burble you had put on record, or at least to sit after reading it; so I walked out with long strides along the shore: there the happy notion took me that, on getting my 2d or Congleton Letter (yesterday),Presumably TC to JWC, 25 Aug., the first letter that TC sent directly to Congleton; TC to JWC, 24 Aug., was addressed to Knutsford and arrived the same day as the former letter. you would see the real state of my program, and instantly give up your mad Chelsea speculation,—and perhaps may be sitting at The Gill this night, after all, instead? Pray Heaven it be so: if you have done so, I will forgive you every thing. The thot that you are run back to Chelsea is like to drive me furious! If you are there, the thing I should wish you of all things to do, is to get into the Liverpool railway or the Manchester (dividing your journey in that way), and to go and do yr Nithsdale journey yet. I shd in very deed. Out upon it, I never met with such a thing!

As to “old Jane,” I confess myself completely glad you have parted with her. No part of her own or her work’s physiognomy ever pleased me in reality at all. It is far, far better to try the thing on the commonly recd principles: I expect confidently yr Two Servants will do better, & be nicely worth and again worth their additl cost. Are you at The Gill; are you at Chelsea (Heaven forbid)! You see I aim at the middle point. Write at once. God bless, poor Goody I am well, doing well enough; only my work falling considerably towards abeyance, in spite of me.— T.C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Aug. MS: NLS 525.68. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Thanks for your Notes; whh I have got all in due succession, keeping me informed of your motions,—the last of the series this day. Our mail was
delayed 2 or 3 hours this day: “some accident at Carlisle,”The Scotsman reported, 29 Aug., a “Fatal Collision on the Caledonian Railway” near Beattock, 14 mi. N of Lockerbie. One driver was “killed on the spot” and a fireman seriously injured. the rumour said? I try to believe this does not concern me; at the same time, I had rather not have heard of it.

Your voyaging directions are perfectly precise and effectual;John A. Carlyle wrote, 27 [Aug.], giving TC comprehensive train times between Aberdeen, Dundee, and Edinburgh, and from Aberdeen to Beattock or Lockerbie, and thence to Ecclefechan. I lay them carefully by, agt the day of departure. Friday 7 Septr is finally the fixed period,—that is, a week later, the good people here having pressed for a fortnight. I mean to keep that day. Aberdeen and railSteamer to Aberdeen, then rail. is clearly the method: I shall probably make but short stay with Erskine;—it is possible even I may push on towards Annandale at once; tho’ indeed I ought not; and “some 3 days” are the term I am vaguely counting on.

Jane’s movets are a provoking enigma to me; her want of punctuality in writing has perceptibly aggravated all my other uneasinesses on that head. Misinterpreting altogether some Letter she got of mine at Alderley, she writes me, Sunday last, that she will turn back on Tuesday (that everything may be ready for my home-coming); and so was to be in Chelsea again, on Tuesday Evg! I am in hopes that a second Letter she wd get next day at Alderley wd clear up her doubts, and send her on to Annandale as originally settled. Most vexatious other wise! But irremediable, however it may have gone. Today again, in these circumstances, she sends no Letter, and leaves me to my doubts,—till it fairly strike her (whh it seems seldom fairly to do) that there are inexorably five days betn questn and ansr in our actual position! She is evidently in a very weak way too: I wish and hope she may have come on!

I continue to sleep perfectly here, to bathe, to &c, and am lodged as well as I cd be in the world. Work, however, is often sadly in abeyance,—tho’ I never quite give up, but hang by it for my appointed 4 hours.John wrote: “I should be disposed to give up work for a time, in your place, as the materials for it are not within reach.” There was, yesterday, another expedn to John o’Groat’s, but that I contrived to evade. We have had 1 entirely bright and dry day; abt 3 others partially so; the rest, rain, rain & wind. Goodish crops, but nothing yet cut, or quite ready.The Scotsman reported, 25 Aug., that in Caithness and Sutherland the “heavy rains and gales of last week have laid the corn in some places, but on the whole the country looks well. The harvest will be undoubtedly late. … In Caithness there will be no general harvest before the middle of September, or near the latter end of it.” John also reported the state of Jamie’s crops as “very far back.” My affectionate regards to Jamie & the others all. Yours ever / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 29 Aug. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill / London. PM: Thurso, 30 Aug. 1860; London, 1 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 553.224. Quot: Wilson 5:397.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.dateline: Thurso Castle, Thurso N. B. 29 Augt, 1860—
docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Ever since the Saturday after you last saw me, I have been stationary here; doing well, especially in the article of sleeping; writing also daily a little,—tho’ that, now that Book XIII is about over, does not go so well as it used to do, or sometimes go at all, my resources in the Book way being so exiguous here. Of course I have often enough thot of you; but there was never anything so definite as to be worth a formal Summons. Nor is there yet; our distance, almost at nearest, being five days from one another;—however, I do mold a paper list that has been accumulating, and write a word. I said our distance was abt 5 days: Thus, if you write on Monday afternoon from London, I get it here Wedny afternoon; I ansr that night, or next morning before 10 (all the same), you get it Saty morning, not sooner! If I write hence on Monday morning, and you ansr witht delay, the circuit might be complete on Friday 3 p. m.—that is the utmost. We get a post on Sunday; but it is not delivered till next morning.

Today, after tusselling abt, for almost 2 weeks past, witht brillt effect, on that 2d Silesian War Ms whh you know so well, I pushed it aside, and began some attempt in “Vol IV,“—“10 years of Peace,”Book 16, pbd. in vol. 4 of the first edn. of Frederick (Works 16:194–410). whh must all go into one Book,—of whh the more one reads of it in discontinuous Preuss and the like of him, the less impressn one has. That now seems the stumbling block in chief. I have (in hoping moments!) a notion to resume printing, directly on my return. I am clearly in improved circumstces, as to sleep &c, but very weak,—and grow seemingly weaker and lazier, the more I sleep. Friday Septr 7, I have settled to unanchor, and move gradually southd again. My wife was (and I still hope, is!) to meet me in Dumfriesshire: but, bewildered in the tedious post, and chiefly in her own wilful neglect to consider that inexorable fact, she has (I dreadfully apprehend) turned back in Cheshire, and sat down in Chelsea again, under the supposition that I was just rushing home. Nobody has more need of the Country than she. This (if it have taken place) will be a great sorrow to me;—and I wish she cd be persuaded to start again (if able at all, whh she does not clearly inform me abt), and rectify her huge error.

This is a curious remote Country, 700 miles away from you; with the Orkneys (Seal-Islands),“Orkney” comes from the Old Norse word for “Seal Islands.” in a precipitous picturesque manner, looking over;
on one, at a distance of few miles. “Thor’s-Oe”;“Thurso” means Thor’s River in Old Norse. a wholly Norse Populatn, tho’ in the Western parts, fractions of them still speak Gaelic. Taught by St Colm,Presumably the St. Colm who, with St. Drostan and St. Fergus, established a mission in NE Aberdeenshire at the beginning of the sixth century to convert the Picts, rather than St. Columba (ca. 521–97), also called St. Colm, who left Ireland for Scotland in 563 and founded the church and monastery on the island of Iona in the Inner Hebrides, W of the Scottish mainland. I do believe, and his Priest Missionaries; for the Scotch Highlands are essentially all Norse, with a small admixture in the most Celtic regions. We have had one completely fair day, 2 pretty nearly fair. A wonderfully good crop is on the grounds here; but as to getting it off? Much of this remote territory is well farmed; a good Country, only hardly a tree to be seen in it; tempest ruling everywhere, no shelter except under walls. The Sea is pure as Chrystal; and rages, oftenest, among the wild rocks at a loud rate. I look into the Sea; a König in Thule [king in Thule], minus certain requisites. A word, if you have time before Wedy next. Yrs always T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 30 Aug. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Thurso, 31 Aug. 1860; London, 3 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.533. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Well, you have again been and done it, you unfortunate Goody! All yesterday I lived in the comfortable hope that my second letter had dispelled your delusion, and that you were on to Annandale,—no scrape of a pen was allowed me, I had to make the best of my doubts. But here is the fact itself; undeniably you are back to Chelsea; and my lamenting will do no good at all. In the course of this Journey there has nothing happened nearly so unpleasant to me. Indeed it has been a very great aggravation to all my uneasinesses this obstinate refusal of yours to write to me with promptitude, punctuality, and in clear recognition of the inexorable fact that a Note and Answer took at the very shortest 5 days,—and if the Note was from you, six. However, we cannot now help it; and the confusion on that score, having done its worst, is about over.— My new idea is, that your own poor heart failed you at Alderley, glad of any shadow of excuse; and that you must be quite exeedingly weak and ill!
