Judge what a pretty “compann of my solitude”See Tobias Smollett, Adventures of Roderick Random (1748) (chap. 64). this is:—if I get no Letter tomorrow either (whh is very possible) things will have a smiling look!— Is it quite impossible to persuade you still to risk some other try for a
little Country, for a little strength? There is [nothing],Word omitted by TC; “nothing” inserted by A. Carlyle. except it be your own poor nervous-system (whh I have much fear abt) to keep you in Town; no method by whh you can do me the hundredth part of the pleasure, or of the benefit, by staying in Chelsea, whh the least improvet by the Country wd yield me. But I must not fret and vex my poor good Jeannie: her intentions always, I know well, are generous and loyal;—tho’ in regard to arithmetical matters, as Posts and such things, she is very headstrong in proportn to her Knowledge!

I leave this Tomorrow week (that is Friday 7th Septr, the first Friday after you read this); Steamer sails latish in the afternoon; if Erskine write (whh he has not yet done), and write soon as one desirous, I can disembark (probably abt 1 a. m. or so) at Aberdeen and in 3½ hours next day get to Linlathen: 3 days there; thence forward by Edinr to Scotsbrig (Scotsbrig first) all in one day. After whh loiter ad libitum [freely]. My work here has got its right arm broken tho’ it still haggles on.— For God’s sake, one deliberate distinct word! My own poor Goody’s—T. C.

ps.p: P.S

Rain, rain: Tuesday was “fine” here too; the two days since (till abt 2 p. m. each) have been rainier than ever.— Children noisy and rather disagreeable; work more than half impossible (owing to want of Books); affair generally good, honest, salutary, “tho’ of prosy bory nature”! My solitude of heart is entire and profound. Today I walked thro’ Thurso, and bathed on sand (beautiful); the gnarled crags, whh are our portion on this side the river and Town, being wet, slippery & no comfortable go in extreme rains.—— Could not you go to Folkstone,Folkestone, seaside resort in Kent. and take a Lodging of yr own with Lady Sandwh for neighbour? Do, I entreat you, contrive something! Dull Chelsea will never do—TC’s postscript was written on the back of the last page of a letter from Lady Stanley. TC apparently enclosed the whole letter (see TC to JWC, 5 Sept.) but the rest of it is untraced.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], [30–31 Aug.]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea Thursday night [30 August 1860]
docBody.p:
After all, you know, dearest Lady Stanley, I would have gone to Alderley when you asked me, all the same, had the idea of going on to Scotland never suggested itself! and it was not till after I had got some “human sleep” at
Alderley, that the idea took a practical shape, and I wrote to say that I was coming! So—in point of fact, there is no sense in my regarding myself as a victim—to either the unconscious perversity of Mr C, or the perversity of Mr C’s sworn friends ‘The Destinies’ alias “Superior Powers”!Coterie speech; see 35:102JWC to IEB, 3 June 1859, and Works 29:375. If I am a victim at all in the present case, it is to my own idiotic credulity in having believed the testimony of a female NovelistGeraldine Jewsbury. on any practical matter! and taken an Imbecile of 71“Old Jane.” to do for us!—the ‘us’ including a Man of Genius, who would require a Servant of Genius to understand what he wants and means!— Left to the cares of such an incompetent old Creature, what could He have done but—strangled her! and then committed suicide! Oh, depend on it, by returning post haste, I have prevented something dreadful!

Well for me if I can take from that reflection all the consolation I need! I feel so very like a bird that had cleared the garden wall with a string to its leg, and, just when making for open space, had been twitched back with a sudden jerk!— The sensation is “rather exquisite”!Coterie speech; see William Godwin, Memoirs of the Author of a Vindication of the Rights of Woman (1798) 164; see also 5:337–38TC to JWC, 17 Aug. 1831, and 16:198JWC to JW, 15 June 1843.— But listening to one’s sensations is the most spoonyish, most profitless occupation that human creatures have yet invented for themselves! The maxim I was recommending to be hung up, as a corrective to the PuseyiteA follower of a doctrine of high Anglicanism named after Edward Bouverie Pusey (1800–1882; ODNB), theologian; see 12:268TC to RWE, 26 Sept. 1840. tendencies of a certain “Bright young Being’s”One of the younger Stanley das. room, has come in “neat and appropriate” for myself, these two solitary days. “Do the Duty nearest hand”!Coterie speech; see 6:122TC to JAC, 16 Feb. 1832, and Carlyle, Sartor 145. Clearly that was to get up the curtains on Mr C’s bed and windows; and dust all his Study with my own hands! Which has been done, none the worse for my having done it to a running accompaniment of thoughts of Alderley,—its greenness, and freshness, and stillness, and adorable kindness; its “bright young Beings,” its three white dogs!— I won’t forget all that, or any of it in a hurry! It was such a change from the life of worry and suffocation and sleeplessness, I had left! Like being folded all round body and soul in magic Eider down,—for a space of six days!

My journey was beyond expectation fortunate! A carriage to myself the whole way! and a Guard who payed me “delicate attentions,” even brought my portmanteau to my feet—before I had time to ask for it! (the packages for Mrs FoxPossibly the Mrs. Fox whom TC had met at Lady Sandwich’s in 1857 (see 33:70TC to JWC, 5 Sept. 1857); otherwise unidentified. I had kept in view: she took them away next day; but did not come in) I should also mention the canary as a pleasant feature of the journey; she
chirped a good many times, exactly at the right moment, reminding me I had a live creature from Alderley accompanying me home,—was not quite solitary, tho’ pretty nearly so!— I did feel rather ashamed of her before the porters, and cab man, and, above all, before my grim old Woman! a bird-cage in one hand, and a nosegay in the other; it was a home-coming rather juvenile for my years; but I carried it off in assuming a certain air of sternness!

The individual who took most notice of the bird,—noticed indeed nothing else from the moment she appeared, was the family Cat! so practical as well as passionate seemed Pussy’s interest in the new-comer; that even before taking off my bonnet, or looking what letters were on the table, I had to carry my new “Chimera” up stairs, and lock her in the spare room, and put the key in my pocket!—and all tea time I was deeply meditating—not on my Husband’s return—not on “the duty nearest hand“—but—on how that little Bird was to be got out of that wicker cage! nay, on how it was ever got into it! Question far more puzzling than how the apples got into the Dumpling!Cf. Peter Pindar, “The Apple-Dumplings and a King“: “‘Very astonishing, indeed!—strange thing!’ / (Turning the dumpling round, rejoin’d the King), / … . / ‘But, Goody, tell me, where, where, where’s the seam?’ / ’sir, there’s no seam’, (quoth she) ‘I never knew / That folks did apple dumplings sew.’— / ‘No!’ cried the staring monarch with a grin, / ‘How? How? the devil got the apple in?’” (Peter Pindar, Works [1793] 1:95). The Chimera’s young mistress had given me no clue to the solution!Kate Stanley wrote, 3 Sept.: “I was so amused at yr not being able to find the opening of the cage I am so accustomed to those sort that I never thought of showing you the secret but as the bird was none the worse it only gave you a few minutes puzzle.” and it was by my own unassisted Genius that I hit on it at last.

Nobody has called yet for the little packet Miss StanleyMaude Stanley. The packet was for Mary Ann Hunt, not further identified, who was staying at the Stanleys’ London home, 40 Dover St., Piccadilly W; see JWC to KSKST, [5 Sept.]. entrusted me with. If it be still here, the first day I go out; I will take it myself to Dover Street. Hitherto I have not crossed the threshold; hating the appearance of things outside! after beautiful Alderley! and exercise enough cut out for me in running up and down my own stairs.

Not a line from Mr C since I came home! so I am still in perfect uncertainty whether he is coming straight home or round by Dumfrieshire! I leave this letter open till after tomorrow’s post—when please Heaven I shall have news!
Friday [31 Aug. 1860]

Yes! I have news this morning but not from Himself. The letter forwarded from Alderley was a letter from Sir George who, “his dear friend’s pen being devoted to the Service of unborn generations” (Oh the Devil fly away with the “unborn generations”!) wrote to tell me the dear Friend “had been prevailed on to prolong his stay until Friday the 7th!“— Which made me very mad—not the prolonging of the stay—for the longer he stays the better for
himself; ergo—the better for me! but very mad at his “devoting his pen,” under the circumstances to “unborn,” or born, “Generations,” rather than to me his dutiful, long suffering Wife! Very mad indeed! until I suddenly bethought me, that at the time Sir G’s letter was written, and his dear friend’s change of purpose took place; the letter, written at Alderley, to say I was going straight home, couldn’t have reached Thurso Castle!

So now I think I shall no longer turn a deaf ear to the voice of a CharmerCf. Ps. 58:5. who was advising me to come to—Margate!Joseph Neuberg had proposed that JWC accompany him to the seaside resort in Kent; see JWC to TC, [3 Sept.]. of all places! from Saturday till Monday It is so dull and lonely here! Nothing but work, work, work to keep one from Blue Devil, and alas! no strength, for the moment, to work with!

God bless you dear Lady! I think of your kind soft treatment of me, with no end of gratitude!— I was never happier on a visit in my life!— At least not since I was “a bright young Being,” with a quite other faculty for happiness than I have now!
Kindest regards to the young Beings—a carress to TinaProbably one of the “three white dogs”; see also JWC to KSKST, [5 Sept.].
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [2 Sept.]. Addr: Thurso Castle / Thurso / N. B. PM: London, 3 Sept. 1860; Thurso, 5 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.555. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:47–52. “Surely this is one of the saddest of letters—the misery of it merely slowness of posts, and on both sides hardly bearable heaviness of load. Oh, my own much-suffering little woman!” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:47).
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: This is all—“what shall I say?—strange! upon my honour!”Coterie speech; both are Mazzini’s expressions; see 25:168JWC to TC, 22 Aug. 1850. On Friday morning comes a note from Sir George (that had gone round by Alderley) to the effect that his “dear friend’s pen being more devoted to the service of unborn generations than to mine.” (Truly! and if the “unborn generations” will do the answering, I shan’t object!) and another expedition to John O’Groats being on foot; he writes to tell me the dear Friend has been prevailed upon &c &cJWC apparently replied to Sir George Sinclair, probably around 4 Sept., as he wrote, 7 Sept.: “Allow me to express my best thanks for your gratifying letter, which reached me yesterday, & which conveyed to me so graphic & interesting an account of your adventures, & anxiety.”—

Well! “I am most particularly glad to hear it”;—like Archivarius LindhorstE. T. W. Hoffman, “The Golden Pot”; see 9:32JWC to TC, 30 July 1836, and Works 22:43.—The more of Thurso Castle, the better for his sleep and his head; and, as concerns myself; the more time for putting things straight here the better for my sleep and my head! (If so insignificant an individual can be said to have a head!) But certainly on the following morning (Saturday) there would be a few lines from the dear friend’s self, snatched from his service to “unborn generations,” to tell me “with his own hand” of his change of plan?— No! On Saturday morning the Postman didn’t so much as call! and when I ran out at the house door, to see if he could really mean it; he merely shook his head at me from the steps of No 8!Home of Arthur Hamilton Morse, prof. of music.— Late at night however I hear of a letter from you received that morning by Neuberg. There had been time found or made to write to Him—“the Beauty”!The Carlyles’ nickname for Neuberg. And he “thought it his duty to“—not forward your letter to me—but interlard his own note with single words or whole lines of yours “in ticks”“Her own Scotch name for double commas” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:48).—means to “move gradually southward again” “wishes you could be persuaded “to start again if able at all” and to “rectify her huge error”! &c.— Who was to “persuade” me to start again? The Beauty himself, perhaps? Not you it would seem, who send not a single line to, as it were, welcome me home; tho’ come home entirely for your sake! No matter! there is the less to be grateful for!

Meanwhile I am glad to know, even indirectly, that you are positively coming south by land, and “gradually.” The two notes written after hearing I was at Alderley and bound for Dumfrieshire, which were received together (on account of the misdirection)See TC to JWC, 24 Aug. within an hour of the time the carriage was ordered to take me to the station, threw no certain light for me on your plans. When you first fixed to go to Thurso, your grand inducement had seemed to be, that you “could sail there and back, and avoid all that horror of railways.” You had never once in my hearing spoken of taking Dumfrieshire on your road; on the contrary when I spoke to you of Lochleuchart, you said; “Oh that was a great way off! and you shouldn’t be going back by Land at all”! Then, the letter forwarded to Alderley from Chelsea, written in the belief I was still at home, made no allusion whatever to any intention of taking Dumfrieshire on your road home. You could not remain there longer without work, and to get on with your work you must be “beside your reservoir of books at Chelsea.” Read that letter yourself—Mary Austin has got it (I sent it to her as my valid excuse for breaking my engagement to come—and as a valid excuse she
accepted it)For TC’s letter mentioning his probable need for “the general reservoir of Books at Chelsea,” see TC to JWC, 22 [21] Aug.; JWC forwarded it to Mary Austin, 25 Aug. and say if I was committing any “huge error“—or error at all in supposing it in the higestThus in MS. degree probable that you would sail straight from Thurso to London? And granting that high probability—there was but one course for me under the circumstances (the curtains, the keys which you could never have known, one from another! the imbecile “Old Jane,” the new Servant to come &c &c) but one course—to go South again instead of north on the day when my Alderley visit was to terminate. Unless—after my resolution was taken, and every body warned not to expect me in Dshire—and the new woman who had been put off,JWC had wanted Sarah to start 14 Sept.; see JWC to TC, [26 Aug.]. warned that she must now immediately render herself at Cheyne Row—unless after all that, I was to unsettle everything over again, at the very last hour, when there was no longer time to warn anybody—on the receipt of the two little letters which came together, (taking them as an exposition of your voluntary plans, not of plans which you had been forced to adopt voluntarily by the knowledge of mine—by the dread of going home to a comfortless house, and, simultaneously with that, a kind desire not to interfere with any arrangements of mine by which my health might be benefitted. No! I could not be quite certain that were I at Chelsea instead of half way to Scotland you might not still wish to avoid “the horror of Railways,” and to get back to your “reservoir of Books“— At all events you should have your free choice— And now you have had it, and I learn thro Mr Neuberg that it is; to be “in no hurry.”

I am very glad of that, as I shall be in better trim for you here, than had you come straight. as to my “starting again” (on any long expedition at least) you couldnt believe Mr Neuberg or any one else could persuade me to it! I am not “able at all“—which does not mean however that I am ill. My three days at Alderley before the letter came did me all the good which I was likely to get from change of scene—after the letter came my sleep was no better than at Chelsea— When I am worried about anything—no air no surroundings can put me to sleep! At present your curtains are come home and put up. The bricklayers have mended the broken tiles on your dressing closet— That dreadful old woman is to be got handsomely rid of next Wednesday—and I feel rather quiet—and am getting to sleep better—and mean to lead a pleasant life in my solitude—taking these “little excursions” so long talked of.

Lady Stanley was to write to you the day I left,She left Alderley 28 Aug. TC wrote his postscript to JWC, 30 Aug., on the reverse of the last page of Lady Stanley’s letter which concluded: “the thralldom you are in with the Great Frederic. I think having you restored to their Society will be quite as great a pleasure as having your book.” to tell you I was despatched safely south—
My own letter to say I was going home on Tuesday, would reach you last Monday I suppose.
You will write when the “unborn generations” can spare you for half an hour.

The only news I have to tell is that the poor “little Darling”“Her name for a neat and good old gardener that used to work for us” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:51). Joseph Edwards, gardener, 13 Church St., Chelsea. has lost the use of an arm and hand by paralysis— He came himself to tell me with his arm in a sling, and repeatedly broke down into tears—and made me cry too— “Oh! he said, how I do miss my poor, dear,“—I thought he was going to say WifeEthel Edwards d. 1858. (she died 2 years since) but no it was—“arm”! “Oh how I miss my poor dear arm”!— He didnt need money; wouldn’t even be paid what was owing him— It was the helplessness that was breaking his heart—

closer.salute: All good be with you Yours ever

docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

ps.p: Dont expect another letter for a long time even should I know the address, writing is very bad for me—and I hate it at present—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LS], 2 Sept. MS: NLS 19.3.52.14. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p:
Your fine cheery little Note, whh came duly, was very pleasant to me here:—truly it was more like a portable “phial of sunshine” than anything I have met with in these parts! That is a fact; and, I think, a creditable one to the amiable dispenser of such articles, considering all the circumstances!—Your Note had no signature; and the address, whh was very dashing, seemed to me at first to be in another hand: “Has there come some sudden ill turn, then?” I said, in my weak imagination;—but notices from Chelsea soon put all this to rights; and added new bits of incident (visits to and from in that quarter)See JWC to TC, [17 Aug.]. by whh I was still farther gratified and obliged. For some time, again, there has been unpleasant silence in Chelsea; and I have got no news at all,—scarcely of my Wife herself, except in scattered snatches. I can only hope there is nothing wrong, there or at Folkstone,—that you are profiting by the sea-breezes as I do, that your pretty little Grandchildren make the dull days brighter to you; and that we shall all meet again before long, nothing the worse for our intermediate shiftings and adventures. Of “bottled sunshine” (except the specimen above alluded to) I have heard not the least whisper in
these Northern parts: In fact the weather has been one continued gusty drizzle (wind and sea raging as if they wd swallow us, at times); scarcely above one completely bright day; not half a dozen in whh the sun has been visible even for moments. The crop is good, for such a country; but is getting all tattered to pieces; not a blade of it yet cut. It is beyond dispute we shall have a very decidedly bad Harvest;—the other prognosticated mischief I take to be, let us say, of the nature of “bottled darkness“: a commodity of no value whatever, tho’ we import a good deal of it.

My old LairdSir George Sinclair. is the best of men; very learned too, and far-travelled; reads me Greek Orations, and bundles of Excerpts and royal and other distinguished Correspondences, till I can stand no more of it: in truth he and his have been so very good and innocent and honestly human and hospitable to me, I am sore of heart to quit them; but the time is come. I go, next Friday, by a Steamer there is to Aberdeen; thence, by rail, southward to Annandale,—to Chelsea well before the end of the month, if my computations hold.

From Loch-Luichart there came a Note from the Lady yesterday; the first notice I have had since what you wrote to me. Baby has stood its adventures to perfectn: Lord A. is still in gout, but evidently recovering; they have been in Brahan till nearly now,—the Lady dated from Brahan. She invites me very kindly to Loch-Luichart: Alas, alas!TC had visited Lord Ashburton and his first wife, Lady Harriet, Lady Sandwich’s da., at Kinlochluichart in 1856; see 31:222–24TC to JWC, 11 Sept. 1856.—

I have actually seen Johnny Groat’s House since you heard last:—John o’Groat (I shd call him), and the “House” is a vanished quantity; nothing but some pouched uneven green hillocks, of small extent, whh pretend to the site of an old small House. More likely to have been the site of an old limekiln, or cattle-pen in the outlying fields; that was my deeply private notion;—however, I must give you the tradition, whh is given in grave enough Books, and is thot here to have had some vestige of foundation.

Mr de Grote,Jan de Groot was apparently a Dutchman given a royal warrant in 1496 to run a ferry service from the Scottish mainland to Orkney. it appears certain, came into these parts “with a Letter recommending him” to persons in Authority “from King James IV” (say abt 1500), the Flodden James.James IV (1473–1513) of Scotland, killed at the battle of Flodden Field, nr. Branxton, 3 mi. SE of Coldstream on the Scottish-English border. Grote got lands here, and grew to be a mighty Laird, of his sort;—increasing into Eight Groats, in the space of 3 or 4 generations; whh 8 Groats (supposed to be in James VI’s time, 1600 or so)James VI (1566–1623), king of Scotland from 1567, also James I of England and Wales from 1603. were in the habit of assembly, from their various manor houses (or manor-cottages, as
I doubt they wd be), to hold some Anniversary, in what had been perhaps the original manor-cottage of the family (tho’ that is not a point specified), to shake hands once a year, and drink, in a little Aquavitae (Water of Life, Usquebaugh, Whisky), Prosperity to Grotedom. In their whisky they quarrelled about precedence; were near drawing dirks one time, and suicidally destroying the Family of Groat, when John, the wisest of them (who, if not chief, deserved to be chief) intreated & objected, “Cousins, Brothers, in the name of all the gods, don’t! Be silent wholly on this subject till our next Anniversary; then reassemble here, and I will shew you!” Next Anniversy John shewed them—an octagonal dining-room, with 8 doors, and octagonal table &c &c: applaud wise John, and drink your whisky in quiet. This was John of Groat’s House (or is still the dream of it) and being on the Northmost point of Scotland and one of the prettiest little sequestered Hollows in the world, the Tale ran.— I gathered 4 buckiesFor groatie buckies, see TC to Lady SLS, 12 Aug. for yr Ladyship; depend on them! Yours ever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 2 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Ashton 414.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I got your kind message yesterday: except one pleasant little notice of you from Chelsea,Lady Ashburton visited JWC at Cheyne Row 21 Aug. pleasant tho’ indistinct, I had heard nothing for a long time. I am very happy you and all got safe to the end of your travels;—there was among you one small but valuable new member of society, about whom one cd not forbear some anxiety! But she too has prospered, it appears, and taken no hurt by the Highland Inauguration. I can well conceive Grand-Mamma’sLouisa’s mother, Mary Elizabeth Frederica Stewart-Mackenzie. feelings at sight of this little Being;—may they be prophetic and emblematic of much that lies ahead for the little Wayfarer that has begun its journey on our Earth!

I am right sorry that I cannot see Loch-Luichart again. It is fixed some time since that I am to sail on Friday next for Aberdeen: Friday night, I am to pass you, many miles of land and sea to west of me,—all asleep, you, at the time;—and get to Dundee and Linlathen, by rail, next day. There till Tuesday; thence to Annandale, for a short indefinite time; and so home again to my Beating of
Hemp.See Works 12:191. Peaceable day in this world I shall never have till that sad affair is ended. But if my poor nerves will hold out a little (whh never failed me till last summer), I will get thro’ it one day, and send it (like Christian’s Burden, in the Pilgrim’s Progress) bounding down hill at a pretty rate!Christian, hero of John Bunyan’s allegory The Pilgrim’s Progress (1678), burdened by the conviction of sin and taken to the hill of Calvary, realized that his sins could be forgiven; the burden fell off and rolled down the hill into Christ’s sepulcher.

I hope Lord An is fairly getting on his feet again: you have done a great deal of excellt doctoring in that quarter; persist,—and keep both the deerTC thought that rest was healthier than deer hunting for Lord Ashburton; see 35:171TC to LOA, 18 Aug. 1859. and other doctors at a due distance; that, I believe, to be the law of the case. Mention, please, that I expect a Note at Chelsea soon. For the rest I wish from the heart I heard of you all safe at The Grange again: that wd be the salutary news, in such a year of tempest!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [3 Sept.]. Addr: Thurso Castle / Thurso / N. B. PM: London, [3] Sept. 1860; Thurso, [5] Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.556. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:52–53 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Two letters from you this morning—one redirected from Alderley— But I must let the long letter I wrote yesterday go as it is all the same! It is too much writing to throw away—after having given myself a head ache over it.

Besides; after having read your two letters of this morning, I feel none the less called upon to defend myself against the charge of “huge error,” “rashness” “precepitancy” “folly” and so on! I maintain that, however unfortunate my course may have been, I could not, under the circumstances, have rightly taken any other! So the letter of yesterday had best go! Nor do I deign to accept the very beggarly apology you make for my “infatuated conduct“—that I had myself lost heart for the Dumfrieshire visits and was glad of any excuse to be off from them! That tortuous style of thing is not at all in my line!—had I lost heart I would [have]Word omitted. said so!—

On the contrary; feeling myself at Alderley—half way—all the hateful preparatory lockings-up, and packings well over—nothing to do but go north at Crew instead of South—and Mary Austin and Mrs Russell promising me the very warmest welcome! far from losing heart, I had for the first time gained heart for the further enterprise—the “interest” had “not fallen but risen” I
assure you; and I turned south with real mortification! There! you have provoked that out of me—which if “well let alone”Coterie speech; see 18:231JWC to HW, 7 Oct. 1844. I should never have said.

As for your indignations at my not writing—I don’t quarrel with that—only beg to remind you that the reciprocity is not all on one side! I also have been feeling myself extremely neglected, for—what shall I say?—“unborn generations”?—let us hope so!—and not for just nothing at all.

There was a talk on the part of The Beauty of my going to Margate with him on Saturday to stay till Monday—an invitation as I understood it at first—but he hastened to explain to me that “the fare there and back would be eleven shillings,” and that it would cost me “10/ a day at the hotel“— I was too disgusted at his evident terror of being brought in for my expenses, to give ear to the proposalNeuberg was going to Margate on holiday with his widowed sister, Rosetta Frankau, and her children; he wrote to TC, 30 Sept.: “We have been, all of us, in this airy place these three weeks; seeking relief from our various ailments. … / I was repeatedly on the brink of asking Mrs Carlyle to come; but the weather, wind veering round again into the raining quarter, always put a Veto to it.” Besides that I could spend that much money more to my gratification than tete a tete with a very ugly man in the hooping cough! However, he drove me in his pony carriage to his own houseNeuberg and Rosetta Frankau lived in Hampstead, N London. last Friday, round by the City, and gave me a frugal, but eatable little dinner— The weather here too is showery but the air is kept so sweet by the plenty of rain!— I did not feel the least taint in it as I drove thro’ London on my return from Cheshire—and the last two mornings there has been a touch of frost on the windows— What a summer!
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 4 Sept. MS: Dan Rowe, The Written Word Autographs, Tamworth, New Hampshire (6 Oct. 2007). Pbd: David Southern, “Miscellanies,” Carlyle Studies Annual 23 (2007): 201–2.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I meant to have answered your kind Note long before this: but night after night something turns up;—in truth, except the “4 hours of strict privacy in the morning” (never am seen till 2 p.m. and then only running for the sea, to be back at 3 for dinner), I have seldom a moment to myself (except sleeping time; whh is now, for instance, just at hand!)

I am coming off in 3 days more; fairly about to lift anchor on Friday next,
“Friday 7th latish in the afternoon.” If all go right, the Friday Steamer, from this neighbourhood, sets me down at Aberdeen, deep in that same Night; next day (Saturday), soon after Noon, I get into the Dundee rail; and am at Mr Erskine’s (Linlathen, nr Dundee) before 4,—in good time to rest, and be ready for dinner. At Linlathen till Tuesday; after that Southward again,—to Annandale (I still hope), tho’ it may be to Chelsea, for anything I can certify, all being in doubt to me there. Poor Jane, I fear must be very ill; she wd hardly have turned at Alderley otherwise; and since her taking that sudden determination, 9 days now, I cannot get the smallest tidings or sign from her: yesterday I had to write to Miss Jewsbury for some exact word, and account of the actual fact whatever it may be; on Saturday this of Miss Jewsby will meet me at Linlathen;See TC to JWC, 9 Sept. and then I shall know my course,—whh I still hope will be towards a sight of you all.

I have got a great deal of fair sleep (excellt compared with late Chelsea times); I have been profoundly wearied, solitary, sad; have got some practising work done; and my head is certainly a little better, not worse.— Did James junr do anything about the Cloth-specimensSee TC to JWC, 5 Sept. he was speaking of? A Note while I am at Erskine’s, the sooner the surer, wd be welcome if it found me. But you need not bother, either. Good night, and blessings on you all. Your affecte Brother T. Carlyle

ps.p: Thomas Erskine Esq / Linlathen / Dundee

div3.sourceNote: JWC-KS [KST], [5 Sept.]. MS: NLS 1797.40. Quot: Hansons, NE 491.
div3.head: JWC TO KATE STANLEY

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea Wednesday night [5 September 1860]
docBody.p:
Oh Bright young Being! as good as you are bright! I shower thanks on you; and wish them blessings!— Your letter, with its inclosure,Kate Stanley wrote, 3 Sept.: “I enclose my photograph … with a hope that you will sometimes remember me by seeing it in your book. I did so enjoy your visit here & I wish it had been longer & that you had gone on to Scotland to set you quite up for a long autumn & winter in London.” was such a godsend to me this morning!— I could have kissed the dear little Sir JoshuaishIn the style of Sir Joshua Reynolds (1723–92), portrait painter. figure, but for the fear of dimming it!— Such a Godsend—! for I had slept only one hour thro’ the past night; and risen with a mind divided betwixt murder and suicide! and was in the act of looking thunder and lightening at
my Old Woman, who had boiled the egg and toasted the bread for my breakfast, and forgotten, up to the moment of placing them before me, to—boil the kettle for my tea!! A moment more; and the most withering sarcasm Indignation could invent would have felled that old woman to the Earth—morally speaking—! But your letter interposed, and saved me from the impiety of insulting old age—however idiotic! For, no sooner had I ascertained it was from you, the letter; and beheld the “bit of fascination”Coterie speech; see 19:107JWC to TC, 23 July 1845, and JWC to TC, 25 July 1845. inside, than a great patience, with regard to the tea kettle, flooded my soul! And I owned, that, “besides Life and Daily Bread,” that besides even “the Quarterly, and other Reviews and Magazines, and Thackeray and Dickens, fostering the harmless gaiety of Nations” (I quote from the Revd Mr Ross’s Sermon)Either from a sermon preached at Alderley (although JWC did not usually attend church) or from Alexander J. Ross, husband of JWC’s old friend Kate Sterling. one does, occasionally, have nice things to be thankful for! And I was thankful, and am thankful for that little godsend!

Your Bird is very happy! at least, if chirping be a sign of happiness, as is generally believed. She is handsomely lodged in a large wire cage, having a wing devoted to purposes of ablution. Her seed and water are renewed every day, and chick-weed found for her in our garden. For the rest, I talk to her a good deal with a view to opening her mind.

Lady Stanley, whose letter I was particularly glad of, wished to know “the end of the Drama.” Rather slow towards the end I think! Not to be compared in “thrilling interest” to my “Tragedy, in five Acts”!The Rival Brothers, written by JWC in 1815; see 7:361–68JWC to RBR, 20 July 1842. Indeed, the Catastrophe, contrary to all rules of Art, came off in the middle.— When I stept into the London Train that unblessed Tuesday! Since then the interest has been falling! hardly saved by some fits of rage at having my act of “Self-Sacrifice” regarded and characterized by Mr C as “a huge error”! “a miserable infatuation”!—nay, the whole shine taken out of it for posterity, by “a new idea just come into his head; this no less!—that, at Alderley, my “poor heart” had failed me for the Scotch visits, and I was “glad of any shadow of pretense for drawing back”!!— Heaven and Earth!— I appeal to Lady Stanley,—to the bright young Beings,—even to the white dogs—to all living who saw me at that crisis, if this Solution be not enough to drive even me “into a Convent”!

But—I have had my revenge!— I have written him, with a very bad pen—as bad as this one—12 pages of reasons for doing as I did and for believing that, under the circumstances, I “could do no otherwise”!— How true is this that I read in a french novel the other day: “Sans même s’en apercevoir, presque toujours les hommes nous irritent [without even noticing, men almost always annoy us]!”See Louis Enault, Nadèje (Paris, 1860) 129. Bless them all the same!

I gave Miss Stanley’s little packet into the hands of a woman who opened the door to me at Dover Street—not “Mary Ann Hunt“—who was out, the other told me, “doing what Miss Stanley had desired her to do—looking at Pictures”!!

I send you a new sort of Barometer—French of course—which will go well, it strikes me, with the “Peuseyite Tendencies“— The monk’s cowl falls back in dry weather, and covers his head in wet weather—the little globe of quicksilver must not be touched.From her description of the monk’s cowl moving, JWC possibly refers to a hygrometer, which measures humidity, rather than a barometer, which measures air pressure.

My best Love to Argus!Kate Stanley wrote: “If the dogs could speak they would all send you their love, Argus particularly if he took after his mistress which I am sure he does.” You will write me another letter before long? Will you not Darling?—and do try to keep your Sisters up to their promisesMaude and Rosalind’s promise to send photographs.—I want to have all three in a little screen like the one at Alderley.

Let me also present you with my last remaining Photograph of Mr C— The D’Orsay version of himAlfred Guillaume Gabriel, Count D’Orsay (1801–52), amateur artist, drew TC in 1839; see 11:113TC to JAC, 26 May 1839, and 162JWC to JWI, 2 Aug. 1839; for the portrait, see 11:frontispiece [available in the CLO on the table of contents page for volume 11]. in your room is far toThus in MS. meek, and washed out to be any good as a Corrective.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 5 Sept. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: I got your Letter duly. Many kind thanks for your attention to that Horse,Fritz; see TC to JWC, 14 Aug., and JWC to TC, [23 Aug.]. among other things; it is a great charity to take him so completely out of my thoughts at this time! He is a truly good creature; loyal and wise as quadruped can be. If I find him reconciled to harness, over and above, it will be a joyful meeting when we come to together again, as I hope!—

I am in great anxieties about Chelsea: Mrs C. turned back on her road to Scotland; and now it is the tenth day that I can hear no word from her at all!—The day after tomorrow I quit this place,—a most sequestered stormy kindly strange place, with wild shores, looking over into the wild precipices of the Orkneys, and “John o’ Groat’s House” (if you ever heard of that notability)
within half a day’s riding:—a Steamer to Aberdeen (preferable even in the wind) hurries one past many wild friths and chasms, into the region of railways again; on Saturday I pause for 2 days near Dundee (if all go right); thence homeward, by Annandale; home in a couple of weeks or little more (as I wd fain compute). Printing must recommence; a thing fearful to contemplate! I am certainly a little better,—capable of sleep again, tho’ the head is still slightly disagreeable. I have stuck, for certain hours daily, to my Papers here; it has been my one consolation Tomorrow I am to fold my blottings together again,—to be opened in Chelsea yonder. The best address in the interim, shd anything occur, is “Scotsbrig, Ecclefechan N.B.”

Tell Mr Forster he has never written me a word! Should the Baroness von UsedomOlympia von Usedom, wife of Baron Guido von Usedom; TC had stayed with the von Usedoms 26 Aug.–3 Sept. 1858, at the start of his trip to Germany. turn up again, give me her address.

I wish you, as soon as convenient, to send a Copy of the “Carlyle’s works”A set of the cheap edn. of TC’s Collected Works, pbd. 1857–58 (see 32:213–15Chapman & Hall’s Advertisements); see TC to JWC, 5 Sept. to my excellt Landlord here. The Address you will gather from the adjoined bit of Paper,Presumably a dedication to Sir George Sinclair.—whh the Binder,Probably T. Morrison; see 35:109TC to JN, 10 June 1859. I suppose, can fix in as fly-leaf to vol I. By Steamer to Edinr; whence there (every Monday I think) a Steamer hither.—(Please, pay the carriage) I recommend all this, and the many other things to yr goodness; and am, with sincere thanks
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 5 Sept. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Thurso, [6] Sept. 1860; London, 8 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.534. Quot: Bliss, TC 354.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Thank God here is at last a Letter from you, here are Two Letters; and nothing is far wrong after all! I am delivered from the ghastliest load of apprehensions I have laboured under, almost ever in my life before; quitte pour la peur [left with nothing worse than a fright];—the whole of it turning out to be again a postal burble; the obstinate refusal, on the part of the female mind, to recognise as facts the unalterable laws of time and distance, and loyally conform to them in epistolary procedure. Your interpretations and hypotheses about my neglect of writing to you &c are as distracted as ever;—but I forget all that, nor will recognise any sin in you, you perverse creature,
now that I hear at last you are not in worse health than usual!— I have seldom, in my time, had such a week. I wrote to you at least twice, passionately in need of an immediate ansr; the first of these Notes, whh had been directed with my best skill for speed, seems to have lain almost a week at Alderley; the second (containing Lady Stanley’s Letter to me) rather appears never to have reached you at all?TC wrote his postscript to TC to JWC, 30 Aug., on the reverse of Lady Stanley’s letter. Never mind, never mind; the contemptible but disastrous confusion is over; and probably a case for the like will not occur soon again.

On Friday afternoon, I quit this kind and perfectly hospitable, tho’ drearyish, solitary, and rather oppressive place,—whh I cd not have stood at all, except by 4 hours of daily work, and invisibility till dinner time;Sir George was “full of piety, veracity, and good-nature, but it availed little; I was sad and weary, all things bored me! Here at Chelsea, with my clever Jeannie for hostess, and some clever Mrs. Twisleton for fellow-guest, Sir George was reported to be charming and amusing at their little dinner, while I sat aloft and wrote. But not here could he amuse; not here, though his constant perfect goodness, and the pleasure he always expressed over me, were really welcome, wholesome, and received with gratitude. I had many invitations from him afterwards, saw him here annually once or twice; but never went to Thurso again; never could get going, had I even wished it more” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:26–27).—one of the Daughters, with her Daughter &cEmilia Power, her da. Olivia, and John Stephen. accompany me in the Steamer; expect to land in Aberdeen (those that don’t go to Edinr) “deep in the night”;Cf. Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship (Works 23:96). next day (Saturday between 3 and 4 p. m.) I expect, if all go well, to alight near Linlathen (There Geraldine’s Letter will meet me!)See TC to JWC, 9 Sept.—till Tuesday I am engaged to Erskine; Tuesday, by assiduity and speed on land aTC wrote “a” instead of “and.” water, I am to get to Scotsbrig (abt 10 p. m, I think),—and then rest during will. How long I cannot say; it depends on the weather (whh they say is mended into halcyon in the south countries, tho’ not yet here; depends also on some clothes I want made,TC’s clothes were frequently made during his visits to Dumfriesshire.—if cloth be attainable, concerning whh point I have written! The soul of the Annandale visit is out, by your not being in the neigh-neighbourhood,Thus in MS, on turn of page.—unless you will take heart of grace, and come still!— I am to fold my Papers together Tomorrow after my last day’s work; I don’t intend to open them again, except on some peculiar pressure, till I get back to Chelsea.

I had several Letters since you heard of me; the whole of whh I meant to send (tho’ hardly worth reading one of them); but, behold, now that I look every one of them has become invisible: vanished, every one of them, into some recess or pocket where I have not time to seek them just now (midnight
approaching)!— There was one from Frk Chapman (above a week after yr announcement: Horse Fritz doing well; and (pray note that) “Baroness von Usedom inquiring for me”;—if it be not burdensome to you, such was her usage of me at Rügen, I wish you wd call for; if you dislike any way considerably, don’t:—but nothing cd be kinder than they all, she in particr, were to me there.See 34:159TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1858. I have ansd Fk Chapman this day; is to send a “Carlyle’s Works” to the good Sir G. here, who is inconsoleable or nearly so for the loss of me, lightly as I am valued in some other quarters.Sir George Sinclair wrote to JWC, 7 Sept.: “My heart is very much saddened, whilst I announce to you the termination of a visit, by which I have been equally honored and gratified. … He has rendered himself an unusual favourite with all the inmates of this house, young & old, male & female, high & low. For all he had a kind word, & a willing ear—and could accommodate his conversation, with equal capacity & cheerfulness, to the habits, occupations, & predilections of auditors the most widely differing from each other. … His absence will leave a blank in my daily arrangements & pursuits, which cannot be supplied, or cease to be felt & lamented ... . [M]uch as I admired his genius, I was even more fascinated by the strong undercurrent of tenderness & sympathy.” A. Carlyle pbd. the complete letter in NLM, probably as a counterpoint to JWC’s “mocking, satirical vein” and because it put TC in such a favorable light (A. Carlyle, NLM 2:231–32).

There was next a Letter from Craik;George Lillie Craik. scholastic; whh you would not in any case have read. Finally there was one from Brahan Castle,From Lady Louisa Ashburton. just taking wing for Loch Luichart; “come and be taken care of“: to whh I ansd by return of post, “Can’t alas”!—— If I find these things, I may put them in some other time. Here is one from Jean whh came today,—whh read.
For Saturday (4½ p. m.) “Linlathen” wd do very well; later it is Scotsbrig Ecclefn that will be the Address Adieu dear Anti-Geometress of Goodies: adieu T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 6 Sept. MS: NLS 525.69. Quot: Wilson 5:397.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am to go tomorrow, accordg to program; Erskine expects me, “at Broughty-Ferry,Town and port ca. 1 mi. S of Linlathen and 3½ mi. E of Dundee on N bank of the Firth of Tay. Saturday, soon before 3½ p.m“: that was the nearest guess I cd form; your Railway Clipping did not tell me the hour of arrival at Dundee or Broughty, indeed it said “stop” altogether (like a wise clipping!), but I did not believe it. That was a point not importt, any way.

Jane has at last written: Nothing the matter, after all my alarms; considers herself the aggrieved party,—good soul, obstinately ignoring the inexorable regulations of mail-time in this country! I cannot tell you how much I was relieved. She has put away her Old-Woman servant; has got, what I have been advising these 7 years, two effective servants“Tall Charlotte” and Sarah. (as we hope they are): whh may be a great improvt.

I am to have company out of this House in my Steamer: Sir Gge’s Daughter, a widow lady with Daughterkin (beginning to be alive), then a Mr Something (Stephen,See TC to JWC, 22 [21] Aug. I think,—very tacit youth): to Broughty, at least this latter, perhaps they all. The Steamer is said to be very good. The good weather too has today reached us, hadn’t yesterday; I doubt not we shall do well enough.

Till Tuesday I am at Erskine’s. If you can particularly guide thro’ Tuesday,—morsel of dinner at Edinr,—home to Scotsbrig by the feasible train, &c. I wd fain avoid that 2 hours at Beattock: at lowest, I think I will take it at LockerbyThe 4:10 p.m. express train from Edinburgh to Carlisle arrived at Beattock, 6:22 p.m., and at Lockerbie, 6.46 p.m. TC could disembark at either station to wait two hours for the train to Ecclefechan, which arrived there at 9:05 p.m. by way of variety!
No more today; I must go and get my final bathe,—on the Thurso sands, which I have discovered to be far preferable to the cliffs and crags this side the river.

Yesterday an Acquaintance of yg James’s (Clerk in some Bank at Glasgow), after hovering abt me some time, came up and entered into discourse. Not a bad fellow at all; nor the least of a fool: Nicol the name of him.James Carlyle the younger had worked as a clerk in Glasgow; Nicol not further identified.
Affectionate regards to all.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LST], 6 Sept. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p:
I am very greatly obliged by the kind trouble you took about my Wife. Till yesterday (that is, for ten days) I could not hear the least word about her: she had entirely mistaken my notions about coming home all on the sudden; and I would have given a round sum that she had proceeded, according to program, instead of turning back. I advised her to start instantly again; but that she will not hear of.— She declares herself visibly benefited by her days at
Alderley; and celebrates in emphatic terms the hospitable human ways of that Household and its Serene Lady.

I leave this place tomorrow; am within a week to be abt half-way home,—that is to say, in Annandale, my native Country whh you have heard of in old days. How long I halt there depends on the weather, on the &c &c— If I can handily manage to pass by Alderley, you may be sure I shall need no bidding to do it.— We have had one bright day out of the 31 I have seen here. But now at last the clouds have got peeled away even up to our latitude (this morning, at last); and it is hoped the poor world will get its Oatmeal bannocks cut & housed after all.For the late harvest, see TC to JAC, 29 Aug.
With many kind regards to the Hon. Damosels and Madame,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [7 Sept.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N. B. PM: London; Thornhill, 8 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.557. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:53–55 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I am so sorry that letter should have arrived to mislead you! For alas! I have had no thought of starting again, since I found on my return home, that Mr C had made a perfectly wrong impression on me as to his plans! When he talked of “sailing” by such a Steamer; how could I imagine he only meant sailing to Aberdeen—and afterwards making visits in Scotland!— He had always declared the attraction of Thurso for him to be the possibility of getting there and back by sea, “without any horror of railwaying“—and he had never once spoken of returning thro’ Dumfrieshire!— My error was quite natural, almost inevitable— But that doesn’t make it the less mortifying for myself and others!—

If I had ordinary power of locomotion, I should on perceiving the real state of the case, have streamed off again,—this time straight to The Gill. But indeed, my Dear, I have no such thing as ordinary strength! When I told my Doctor that Mr C urged me to do this; he fairly swore, tho’ a very mild man by nature! It was not merely the ground to be gone over but the fuss and flurry of so much travelling for me that he entirely protested against!—“quiet, quiet, quiet” was what I needed above every thing else—no change could do me good which involved fatigue or fret of mind— I know he is right in that—and that no purer air nor change of scene could do me good if bought with a new unsettling of myself, and the hurry of mind inseparable from travelling—
especially railway travelling—for a person whose nervous system is in such a preternatural state of excitability as mine is I should never have had courage to think of going to you at all; but for the week’s rest in the middle of the journey offered in the visit to Alderley—
It has been a real disappointment to me having had to turn back, and a great provocation to find my turning back unnecessary. But now that I am here I must make the best of it—

I will write you a long letter soon and tell you several things about my household affairs which will throw more light for you on the supposed necessity for my abrupt return— Today I have Mrs George WelshMargaret Welsh. here—and no leisure for writing—but I would not leave you with the doubt which that letter of Lady Ashburtons had excited— I am so sorry that I forgot to warn you such letter might come for me!

Lady A and I left London on the same morning. As it would be too late to address to me at Alderley—as she would be long on the road on account of the Baby—she asked where IJWC did not notice until she turned the page that TC had already written “3) is my favourite” in the top left-hand corner; she wrote “not seen” after it and continued her letter. would be next; that she might write to tell me of the Baby’s safe arrival at BraunBrahan. Castle— Thinking I should be with you—before she would be rested enough for writing; I gave her your address—and as I only gave it by word of mouth, I thought she would forget it—not so—it would seem!—
Surely you did not take Lady A’s handwriting for Mr C’s!! He leaves Thurso only today after all!! and where his first stage will be I dont know till I hear from him
God bless you Dear
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 9 Sept. MS: Houghton.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I have no pen that is not a misery, and no paper (here) that will even take the ink from it. But I write you one word to say that I am safe here, since yesterday 4 p.m.,—and am, if nothing befal, to be at Scotsbrig on Tuesday
Evg. After whh (especially if you report anything abt cloth!) I am likely to be next over at The Gill; intending of course to take Dumfries in too.
No more, dear Sister,—wi’ sic a pen!Coterie speech; see 6:363TC to JAC, 29 March 1833. Yours ever affecte

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 Sept. Addr: 5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Broughty Ferry, 10 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.535. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, I am got so far southwards in safety; and hasten (but must first run upstairs and seek a new pen!) to communicate the fact to you: I hope, but cannot clearly learn, that you will get my note tomorrow morning; at any rate, it is all I can do in that particular,—and my walk shall be by the Post-Office of Broughty to put it in. Sabbath is uncommonly severe in these parts.Many parts of Scotland had no Sunday post; see 35:210JWC to HL, 20 Sept. 1859.

The voyage from Thurso was good, in regard to weather and absence of accidents; only we had to haggle and hang off at Aberdeen, for want of tide, 4 or 5 unpleasant hours; and it was, in result 5 a.m. before I cd get into a bed (unappointed, unannealed,Cf. Hamlet 1.5. at that early hour, nothing but a spoonful of raw whisky procurable); so that I had to awaken from my 2 hours of bad sleep with an ugly headache; & was considerably below par all day, by rail and otherwise. Last night, happily, I have mended much of that (being in the big room here, the quietest in Nature); and today and tomorrow I mean to be vigilant in all dietetic and other such points, and so be quite myself again before setting out for Scotsbrig.

Geraldine’s Letter lay here (thank her for it), giving me but a lowish account of your poor health,—in a lower vein than you wrote;—however, I am free now from my imaginative operations on that head; and that is a great relief!— I am to be at Scotsbrig on Tuesday night; and hope you will write a word on Monday, whh will find me there.

This place is brawer than usual, looks leafy, verdant, trim; and seems to be more aristocratic in its ways and aims than formerly. I have got some six or seven hours of good sleep out of it; otherwise little that has not been considerably laden with fash and bother before it cd reach me. Both the native Gentlewomen are in bed (Mrs Stirling had to withdraw before tea last night, and threatens not to appear again, Mrs Paterson was already confined to her
room):Erskine’s widowed sisters, Christian Stirling and David Paterson. the other population, all but Erskine, is of a nature not to exhilirateThus in MS. the weary soul of T. C. Little Macnab (Mrs Something now)Sophie Adelaide McNeile, b. Macnabb (b. 1831), youngest da. of family friends of Erskine. is here: a jangly, restless, square little object, not of harmonious nature at all; happily her Husband is not here.Henry Hugh McNeile (b. 1822?); they m. 23 Jun. 1859. You did well to steer wide in that case. Mrs Wilson (Archbishop’s daughterProbably Georgina Wilson (1814–81), 4th da. of John Bird Sumner (1780–1862; ODNB), archbishop of Canterbury; she may be one of the two of his children that the Carlyles had met at a dinner at Erskine’s in London; see 27:70TC to JAC, 13 March 1852. whom you recollect) and her HusbandGeorgina’s husband, m. 1835, had been Wilson Dobie Wilson (d. 1838), advocate. Her current “Husband” is unidentified. are here; the latter a poor little dry dottle of an English creature; the former grown shockingly like the late Mrs Edd Irving,Isabella Irving (1797–1854); see 29:233TC to JAC, 6 Jan. 1855. TC later described her as “very ill-looking withal; a skin always under blotches and discolourment; muddy grey eyes, which for their part never laughed with the other features; pock-marked, ill-shapen, triangular kind of face, with hollow cheeks and long chin; decidedly unbeautiful as a young woman” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 227).—whh I hoped had been a lost type of face and character! The others are certain female Mackellars,The Mackellars not further identified. whom I do not yet know. Tuesday morning ends it!

My Head still sings; but it is not painful; and beyond doubt I am considerably bettered by my wide voyages towards the Nth Pole. The good Sinclairs were full of the softest messages to you. Adieu, Dearest; cd you only get a little better!— Yours T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EF, [9 Sept.]. Addr: Montague Square. PM: London, 10 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 1797.37. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZA FORSTER

docBody.p:
I really could swear! I am so unlucky! I must give up my pleasant prospect for tomorrow; that I was holding on to with a certain childish glee! “An oasis in the Desert” (not) of my “Crime” (as our poetical Lord Mayor said of Pulniger’s frank confession)William George Pullinger (b. 1811), chief cashier of the Union Bank of London, Princess St., confessed, 19 April, to having “abstracted large sums [£263,070] from the charges taken over to the Bank of England, which he had concealed from the ledger-keeper by exhibiting to him a fabricated pass-book, in which the balance agreed with what it appeared in the accountant’s general ledger” (Times, 25 April). In court, before the lord mayor, John Carter (1804–78), Pullinger pleaded guilty: “I do not wish to give any unnecessary trouble.” He completely exonerated his junior colleague Edward John Lyttleton of any blame, and it was for this that the lord mayor said: “It is a bright oasis in the desert of his guilty career that he exhibits so much sensibility” (Times, 5 May). On leaving court, Pullinger issued a public statement that he had “done his utmost to atone for his crime by assigning everything he had in the world to the Union Bank, leaving his wife without a bed of her own to lie upon, and without other clothes than those which she wore at the time” (Times, 5 May). but of my misfortune! I went by rail to NorwoodAbout 5 mi. SE of Chelsea.
on Friday for “cange of air”Letter omitted; TC inserted “[h].” Coterie speech; see 27:121TC to JAC, 2 Sept. 1852. for half an hour—when feeling very sick, I ought (my Dr says) to have lain down instead—the result was, that I returned in a state for bed—where I had to remain all yesterday with horrible headach and sore-throat— I am better to day but so broken “to smithers”Coterie speech; see 33:65JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1857.—and my throat not quite mended tho’ the Dr has given me something to take for it exactly like light-blue oil-paint (!)Possibly German chamomile, of which the main therapeutic properties are analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antiseptic; its main ingredient, azulene, gives it a deep blue color (Gill Farrer-Hall, The Aromatherapy Bible [2005] 274). which has been of quite magical benefitTC later wrote above the line: “(That I remember well).”—

Even should I be still better tomorrow, it would be too indiscreet to go out—especially in the evening—and besides, I am always so happy at your dinners; and happiness, by its extreme rarity, excites me more than any other sort of emotion—
My love to your husband—hoping to meet under more favourable circumstances when you return—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [9–10 Sept.]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N. B. PM: London, 10 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.558. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:55–59 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! Was there ever such a game at cross purposes as this correspondence of ours! It reminds me of nothing so much as the passages between the “wee Wifie who lived in a shoe” and her Bairns, so many “that she didn’t know what to do”!
“She went to the market to buy them a sheeps-head;
When she came back they were all lying dead!
She went to the Wrights to get them a coffin;
When she came back they were all sitting laughing!”

Not one letter you have written to me since you went away has hit the right state of things! Do the best that ever you could!-your “sheeps head” and your “coffin” have been equally out of time!— Such being, I suppose, the natural result of going where an answer to ones letters cannot be received in less than six days—in a world where nothing keeps still.

Your last letter, received on Saturday morning, expressing your relief from anxieties about me, found me a more legitimate object of anxiety than I had been at all since your departure! at least found me thinking myself so! For, thank God this attack if very violent while it lasted, has passed off unexpectedly soon.

I suppose if I had followed Mr Barnes’s directions about lying down in the middle of the day, instead of yielding to popular clamour about “change of air”; the thing would have been avoided altogether. On Friday morning down came Geraldine all agog at having had a letter from you, and insisted that we should make one of those “excursions” I had talked of I had my “sickness” (as I call it) worse than usual that morning and begged to be off from any adventure—but a “breath of Norwood air would do me so much good!” “It would take off the sickness to sit on the hill side &c &c“— I didn’t feel that it would, but foolishly yielded to “reason” rather than instinct—the movement made me sicker and sicker; still, I had fortitude to order dinner (a nice little roasted chicken and bottle of soda water) at the best Hotel;Unidentified. and to force myself to eat some of it too! at an open bow-window with such a “beautiful view“— But oh how I wished myself in my bed at home with no view to speak of! For I had grown all burning-hot and ice-cold—not a square inch of me at the same temperature! and “my head like a mall”!—

I got home better or worse, and went to bed, and lay, or rather tossed about all night in a high fever, with a racking headach, severe sickness, and, most questionable of all, a bad sore throat. I only waited for Mr Barnes being up to send for him—tho’ he had given me up as a patient! Without having had a wink of sleep however, or anything “to do me good,” my fever abated of itself as the morning advanced; and after having had some tea in bed between seven and eight (“all very confortable” from the new woman;“Tall Charlotte.” I felt so much better that I should have held my hand from sending for a Dr; if it hadn’t been for the sore-throat, which continued very bad, and frightened me, from its unusual nature— Mr Barnes was out and didn’t come in to get the message
till three o’clock; by which time I had transferred myself to the Drawingroom sofa— Meanwhile, being still in bed—but washed and combed, and the room tidied up in expectation of Mr Barnes—there was sent up to me the card of Madame Usedom! two hours after I had read your wish that I should call for her! And I heard her voice in the passage! I sent down polite “regrets” in the first instance, then, thinking you would be vexed at my not admitting her—I called Charlotte (“Charlotte” the 2d) back, and said, to tell the Lady, if she wouldnt dislike coming to me in my bedroom, that I should be glad to see her “for a minute“— If I had known that she was to flop down on the bed and cover my face with kisses (!) the first thing; I should have thought twice of admitting her—with the sore-throat I had! However!—the thing was done!—so I didnt say a word of sore-throat to put infection in her head—and indeed I hoped it mightn’t be of an infectious nature. As for the “minute” she prolonged it to an hour, talking with an emphasis and an exaggeration and a velocity and cordiality which left me little to do but listen and not scream! I will tell you all I remember of her talk when we meet— She will be again in London towards the end of October She went off with the same or rather with redoubled embracings and kissings—I, purposely, holding in my breath! and when the door had closed, didn’t I fall back on my pillows! with a sense of relief!

Mr Barnes looked into my throat, and said it was bad—but if I had “courage to swallow the very ugliest and most extraordinary looking medicine I had ever seen in this world, he thought he could cure it in a day or two“—and there came a bottle containing apparently bright blue oil-paint!! It did need courage and faith to take the first doze of that! But “I did it Sir”!” ‘I did it, sir,’— Blusterous pedagogue, a Welsh Archdeacon Williams, head of the Edinburgh New Academy (who used to call at Comely Bank, reporting to us his dreadful illness he once had, illness miserable and fatal ‘unless you can dine for three weeks without wine’—’and I did it, sir!’” (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:55). Rev. John Williams (1792–1858; ODNB), archdeacon of Cardigan, rector of Edinburgh Academy, 1824–27, 1829–47; for Williams, who was Welsh, see 3:324TC to CTA, 13 May 1825(where wrongly identified as English), and 4:292TC to JAC, 29 Nov. 1827. and positively, as if by magic, my throat mended in half an hour! I had a good night—the throat was a little sore only in the morning. The second doze had the same magically sudden effect and now after three half glass fuls of that magical blue oilpaint my throat is perfectly mended! and I am as well as before I knocked myself up.(Monday [10 Sept. 1860])

For the rest; all that has been said and written about my turning back and about my not starting again is kindly meant; but being said or written in total or in partial ignorance of the subject, quite over-shoots or under-shoots the mark! is in fact perfect nonsense, setting itself up for superior sense!—

“Why not have left you to “fen”Cf. “fen’ like fell bodies,” 9:90. for yourself if you had come home in my absence? your sister Jane asks. “If she had been me she would have done that.” and I would have done it if I had been her, perhaps. pray desire her to forward the Courier in time. I made a protest to James about his sending it on Friday night twice over—one of the times he could give no account of it the last time he had not received it himself he said till Friday morning. I don’t like Alick being disappointed of it in that way while the direction is in my handwriting.Dumfries and Galloway Courier and Advertiser, pbd. weekly on Tuesdays, was sent by Jean Aitken to her son James, who sent it on to the Carlyles; they then apparently forwarded it to Alexander Carlyle in Canada. I was to have dined with Forster today, but have of course sent an apology. But I shall take a drive in my fly tomorrow D V. Fritz was well when I inquired about him on my return and immensely admired by the young blood—
docBody.name: JWC

ps.p: My throat continues quite well today and I have no thing left of this last business but the natural brashednessJWC probably enclosed Samuel Langley’s letter of 5 Sept. to TC, in which he apologized for his slowness in doing some work for TC: “Illness both of mind and body has prevented me from completing the Excerpts.” On the reverse of Langley’s letter, JWC wrote: “Shall I send or keep the excerpts? / JC”; TC added later in blue pencil: “An Irish reader for me; much of blarney in him, and something of mendicancy while it wd avail.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [12 Sept.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 490–91.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh Lady fair and dear! My mischances of late have been so outrageous, that I think of working them up into a Farce, to be called the Unlucky Woman.
But I haven’t quite made up my mind whether to do that, or let myself go to an accès [fit] of misanthropy!

Meanwhile, under the possibility, that some day I may lay my misfortunes at your feet—dramatized; I shall abstain from troubling you with a literal account of them here; except in so far as is necessary to explain my delay in answering your letter. In the first place, that letter was detained from day to day, thro’ four days at Holme Hill;Mary Russell’s home. in the fond hope, excited by its own appearance, that I would arrive to claim it! For alas! I had never reached Holme Hill—never got further North than Alderley! My week there was
hardly expired, when I had “felt it my duty”Coterie speech; see 19:88JWC to JWE, 28 June 1845. to stream back to Cheyne Row to prepare for my Husband! who, all in writing (as Sir George Sinclair says) “immortal pages for Unborn Generations” had written an uncommonly stupid, confusedly expressed page for his own born Wife! leading her to suppose that he would sail from Thurso straight to London by the next Steamer. And what could she do, the poor wretch of a Wife, under the circumstances—his bed curtains at the Cleaner’s!—all the keys locked up unlabelled in the piano!—the house in charge of an old “Treasure,” who had turned out as Treasures generally do, a most “beggarly account of empty boxes”!See Romeo and Juliet 5.1.—under such circumstances what could she do, but just what she did—rush wildly home!—“a huge error” on her part! Mr C has since loftily declared; “a miserable infatuation”! “A sheer Chimera of the female Brain”! But all these epithets applied to my proceeding dont alter the fact, that I have been cheated out of my holiday by his having failed to make his meaning intelligible!

To go back again—to do all the journey to Dumfrieshire at one fell rush, was not to be thought of. My Dr positively prohibited me from thinking of it! In the shock given to my mind and purposes, I forgot to warn Mrs Russell that a letter might come for me. Nay—to say the real truth I had never hoped that you would recollect the long direction, without having it written down for you! So when your letter arrived, she took it as a sign that her entreaties, I would start again, and come to her after all, had proved effectual; and went on for four days keeping the letter, and sending the carriage to the Station for me at all probable hours!!! I should tell you that she mistook your writing on the back for Mr Carlyle’s!! thus strengthening herself in her “huge error”; for of course Mr C must know the movements of his own wife?

When the letter at last reached me with this explanation; it found me too ill to write. I thought myself about to wind up a most unlucky summer by dying of the new sore throat! Perhaps I should; but for the most magical medicine I ever had given me in this world! A substance or rather liquid exactly like bright blue oil-paint!—which having swallowed, with a faith and a courage not common, two tablespoonfuls of; in a quarter of an hour I was cured! sitting up, feeling for my sore throat, and unable to find it!

The weather is now quite cold enough for being in London without regret. Mr C is by this time in Annandale, where I should think he would not make a long stay. Anyhow I am not at all dull; and see as many people as are good for me. It is quite extraordinary how people turn up for one at this season when there is “nobody in Town“— Do you know Baroness Usedom? She sat an hour by my bedside the other day and I had never exchanged words with her in my life before! Charlotte Wynn has been in town again and is off to WeymouthSeaside town in Dorset. Charlotte Williams Wynn wrote from Weymouth to Julia Sterling, 12 Sept.: “I came a week ago, but my sisters only followed yesterday. We must hope that both our invalids will gain strength from these fresh sea breezes. … Altogether, I am charmed with Weymouth” (Charlotte Williams Wynn, Memorials of Charlotte Williams Wynn [1877] 277). Julia Sterling’s sister Kate Ross d. 27 Nov.—
I liked my visit at Alderley very much indeed. They were so kind to me, and considerate for my feebleness. Lady S is always so much nicer at Alderley than in Dover Street.

When will Baby come back I wonder? I dont find that absence cools my enthusiasm for that bit of fascination“—and it continues an exclusive enthusiasm. A Lady brought her new BabyPossibly Harriet Tait and her da. Mildred; see JWC to JN, 3 July. to show me just before I left town; and I couldnt for my life get up a sentiment for it! It had no black hair; but a lace-cap “and the usual trimmings,” and any large wax doll would have touched my heart as much! No! this is the one Baby-passion of my life! and alas! that dear wee creature wont be always or even long a Baby!

I drove out today the first time since my illness. and called at Bath House to ask about Mrs Mackenzie. who I was glad to hear had gone to Addiscombe. What a different place Loch Luichart must look to you this year!—with Baby at it!
My kindest remembrance to my Lord
docBody.name: J. W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 12 Sept. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 12 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.536. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My poor Jeannie,—I got hither last night,—3 hours later than appointt, for reasons you shall hear;—and was shocked to hear of yr bad adventure again on yr new sally out for health. The Letter lay on the Table here; and I had to gallop thro’ it, with hardly a look at my new old-friends who were all gathered about me with kind eager looks. Thank Heaven it seems to have ended (if as I hope that was the end) much better than we might have apprehended: the only thing I can say is, my poor Goody is clearly very feeble indeed,—weak as water, poor soul,—and must ventureTC presumably omitted “not.” on attempts of that nature again, but follow her own “instincts,” and the advice of Barnes so far as sound. One other good circumstance is, I can now hear from and inquire about within the space of a day, according to the old custom. I doubt you did not get the Linlathen Letter till Tuesday morning, after all. I walked down with it 3 good
hours before Post-time; and came back all in a broil, for new walking with Erskine, but with a conscience comfortable on that small point:—to no purpose; so severe is the Sabbatic Ordinance in those hag-ridden localities!

My 3 days at Linlathn were very well on the whole; the MacNab and all the others (except the McKellars, one of thePresumably for “them.” stone-blind, poor young woman) had all gradually gone before me; so that Erskine and his flowing discourse, of the old mellifluous evangelic descriptn belonged all to myself for the last half day; & I was glad to have seen the good man once again and his high dwelling’s walls amid the beautiful Scotch Autumn. He despatched me yesterday morning, at a quarter to 10, in his choicest mood. My journey was very supportable till just at the end. Indeed it was first-rate for a railway journey: pipe of tobacco in each of the Two Friths;Tay and Forth, both of which were crossed by boat. Peter SwanPatrick (Peter) Don Swan. discovered in the Steamer of the latter Frith, & from him in consequence an appointt to lunch “at the Northern Club, George Street,”Northern Club, 91 George St., Edinburgh. whh helped to consume the vacant 2½ hours, and otherwise proved useful:—in fine all was well enough till, on arriving at Beattock (nr Moffat), already a good while behind our time, we heard there had an accidt occurred on our line of rail some miles ahead (accidt to a goods train and its engine); whh brot us to a dead halt, and necessitated such telegraphing squeaking, pilot-engining, and unintelligible shuttling to and fro, as was enough to disgust a plain human creature (unfriendly to Fitzsmithytrough),TC’s fictional railway magnate; see “Hudson’s Statue,” Latter-Day Pamphlets, Works 20:277. and as wasted about near 2 hours more of our time betn that and Lockerby. At Lockerby Jamie, I knew, was waiting with a gig,—generously volunteering to take me out there, and save me two hours of waiting I shd have had otherwise. Jamie waited from 6.46 p.m. till past 9 before I turned up; and everybody here was in alarm when at last we did arrive here,—all safe & right, only confused, hungry, cold, and with one’s mind all in a puddle.

Hang it! There is the Post hour,—hours earlier than usual;—I must instantly close! I design to rest here perhaps 2 days I will try to write a more definite word tomorrow. I am well enough; and have had, in confused pieces, a good share of sleep.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: The Scotsman reprinted, 12 Sept., a notice from the Banffshire Journal: “Among the many literary men now in Scotland is Mr Thomas Carlyle. He is enjoying the quiet rest and fresh air which Thurso has to give. According to rumour, it will be some months yet before the remaining volumes of ‘Frederick’ are ready for publication.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 Sept.]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N. B. PM: London, 12 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.561. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:233–34.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: There! I am good you see! I don’t wait till I have heard from Scotsbrig, but write on ‘the voluntary principle’ to reassure your mind on that ‘blue paint’; in case it have ‘taken effect on it’! I myself had some apprehension that so magical a cure of the sore throat would cost me something in shock to the stomach—or ‘system.’ But no such thing! I have been better than usual in every way.
Today, I am going for a drive in my neat Fly, and have undertaken to make out the failed appointment with Fuzz on Friday. Mrs Forster came over to arrange it the same day she got my note of apology.
Mrs Gilchrist is come home,Possibly from a visit to her mother, Henrietta Burrows, at Earls Colne in Essex. which I am rather glad of.

The new servant is a success, I think. I shall bring home the girlSarah, the Carlyle’s new servant. next week— I am sure that my sleep has been much improved by the substitution of Charlotte Secunda for “old Jane.” The worry and disgust that old humbug occasioned me just on the back of so much other worry was dreadful bad for my worn out nerves!

Geraldine has been very obliging and attentive; but Oh Heaven! what a fuss she does make with everything she does! and how wonderfully little sense she has! As a sample of her practical conduct; the unlucky day we went to Norwood, she left behind her at the Hotel, a silk neckerchief and an Aluminium broach (a love-token from Mr Barlow!)Rev. John Barlow. On Monday she returned by herself to the Norwood Hotel to try and recover her lost goods—which had been taken care of and were honestly restored. On the way home she left her new silk parasol in the Railway waiting room!! She bragged to me that she had gone second class. I asked what the saving was— When she came to calculate, it was found the “cha’arge”Coterie speech; see 27:206–7JWC to TC, 5 Aug. 1852. first class (with a return ticket) was eighteen pence. The charge by second class was ninepence—but ninepence each way there being no return ticket for the second class. So she had paid precisely the same!!
Oh what dreadful pens I have to write with in your absence
love to Jamie and Jenny
