docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GS [SGS], 13 Sept. Pbd: Grant, Memoirs 426–27; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:175–76.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR

docBody.p: I arrived here, at my half-way house, the night before last; without accident to speak of, indeed with what may be called “a pleasant voyage,” both by sea and land, if any such could now be pleasant: nevertheless I feel considerably smashed; and, for the present, at least twenty per cent. below what you and Thurso Castle delivered me at, that morning, in Scrabster Roads.Scrabster Roads, i.e., the sheltered bay at Scrabster; “roads” or “roadsteads” were generally less enclosed than harbors but safe for anchoring. Alas, one has to voyage; and there is no wishing-carpet or Fortunatus’s hatFavorite image of the Carlyles for traveling; see 5:132TC to JAC, 6 Aug. 1830, and Carlyle, Sartor 191 and 342. to do it with, in these modern steam-days!

At Linlathen there fell out of my portmanteau two books,—a chamber Bible, and a volume of Heinrich,Possibly a vol. of Christoph Gottlob Heinrich, Handbuch der teutschen Reichsgeschichte, 8 vols. (Leipzig, 1819). which the excellent FraserAlexander Fraser, the butler. (out of whose reach I should have laid them, but did not) had packed in by mistake! After consideration, I left them at “Corona”Corona House, 12 West Dock St., Broughty Ferry, offices of Alexander Stephen & Sons, shipbuilders. to the care of Mr. Stephen junior; charging him to be so kind as to send them over at once to Mrs. Power;Emilia Power was probably staying at the Sinclair family house, 133 George St., Edinburgh. by whom they were to be delivered to your Edinburgh bookseller,—and by him, as I hope, reconsigned shortly to their real place of ownership. Please mention that they do arrive uninjured, when and if they do. Chelsea will be the address; in a few days I am to start off thither again, there to get upon the treadwheel again,—sinner that I am!

Mr. Erskine was well, and all about him looking very happy. We had plenty of pious discourse for the two days I stayed; he sent many compliments to “the good Sir George;” and I did not forget the tradition of the turbotPresumably not a reference to the saying “Visitors, like fish, go off after two days” since TC had just stayed for several weeks with Sir George. we once heard of.

Adieu, dear Sir, and thousand thanks for all your unwearied kindnesses and human hospitalities to me, which were perfect as one seldom finds them in this world. To Miss SinclairEither Sir George’s sister Catherine, or his unmarried da., Olivia. my lasting remembrances and regards.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 Sept. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 13 Sept. 1860. MS: 615.537. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Well you are a good little soul,—now and then;—and this morning especially your Note was a comfort to me. For in truth I was not witht my anxieties abt that “bright blue paint”; nor am I quite yet, tho’ hitherto all runs so fair. We must hope it is over, as the symptoms encouragingly say; in the meanwhile you will take every precaution, won’t you?—and not let me want for Letters either till once I get back to Chelsea, and can see with eyes! That, so far as yet computable, will not be a long date.

Yesterday I closed abruptly, on an alarm (partly premature) of the Postman’s passing. Today I am hopelessly too late, not with this, but with a trashery of Notes (half a score others, abt nothing at all, and be hanged to them!)— I mean therefore to clear off the whole lot before rising, and walk to Ecclefechan with them myself, for exercise in my peculiar circumstances,—sad peculiar, in a small way, as you shall hear.

Last night, namely, making every preparation for a good sleep, of whh I had abundant need, I went to bed at 11; and was thrice over falling into the delightfullest sea of rest (being utterly tired, and a pill in me), when, owing to a mighty wind whh had risen in the S.W. some slight rattle in my poor windows thrice over awoke me again: and, in evil hour, I got up to wedge the thing away, and quite conquer it;—whh the pill and my other perverse appendages took in high dudgeon, and which the peccant window took in utter contempt, then and as often after as I liked to try! Result was, I had almost no sleep at all,—3 hours of stony stupor, from 7 to 10 a. m, after ducking in my tub, being the main part of it; and today I have risen a far other man than I expected! Never bother; I will have proper wedges tonight; and on a cup of little Jenny’s excellt chicken-broth, with a modicum of porridge, and both walking and riding, I prophesy complete reversal of the present tragic condition.

I am in no case for scheming and appointing at present; but I already counted and today more than ever count it probable that I shall make no loitering in Annandale; but reappear in Chelsea in a few days! To open out my Papers again is hopeless here; Jean’s specimens of cloth (this morning) are quite uninviting: and as to gathering new strength here,—I seem to myself to have lost a reasonable scantling since I quitted Thurso, and got into these “brattlings and brangings.” The moment anything is settled you shall hear. If I had seen Mary and Jean, my temptation (not prudent!) wd have been to rush off this day; but I have yet seen nothing or nobody except here: and the arrangets for meeting are contemptibly difficult and intricate. Jack (to be out
of my way, poor soul) made off to The Gill (& perhaps to Dumfries, and also perhaps to Dr Arbuckle’sDr. Robert Arbuckle (1802–62) lived at Auchenhay, Kirkcudbrightshire; longtime friend of TC’s brother John; see 35:209TC to JWC, 19 Sept. 1859. in the rear) yesterday early;—sits there gaping for my oracle-speech on the matter this day: a fit day it proves for such a thing! But we must take it quietly; the solution will come, & shortly.

Jamie is very sombre here with his two Boys, grown to be smoking young men: I have yet had no good discourse with him. Jenny is the adroitest of diligt young women;—for the rest, goes like Manchester machinery, no parlaying with her. I am alone amid the grey autumn winds. How happy to hear of your “domestic troubles” ending, and of sleep returning to the poor wearied brain!— I will now take into my Trashery of 10. Adieu Dearest.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WS, 13 Sept. MS: Strathclyde Regional Archives. Hitherto unpbd. William Stirling of Keir (1818–78; ODNB; see TC to WS, 24 Feb. 1848), historian; M.P. for 1852–68.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM STIRLING

docBody.p: I am very happy indeed to hear of you again, after so long an abeyance: abeyance caused by I know not what on your part; caused on mine by the sad fact that I am buried alive, under rubbish and sand, for years past, to the extinctn almost of life itself; and can yet say nothing about getting out, if I ever get out! Some day you might do worse than come and take a ride with me in the Streatham Norwood regions;Norwood, ca. 5 mi. S of Chelsea, a wooded hilly area, rapidly being built up; for one of TC’s rides there, see 32:75TC to LA, 14 Jan. 1857. Streatham, 1 mi. SW, then still a village, in open heathland, and with several large villas and mansions, including Streatham House (where Lady William Russell’s uncle-in-law, Lord William Russell, was murdered by his valet Courvoisier in 1840) and one that had belonged to Henry Thrale and his wife, Hester, later Mrs. Piozzi. some evg (Wedny for instance, when the tide of palaver is at neap in that beautiful worshopThus in MS; TC means Parliament, but the House of Commons sat on Wednesdays, although the House of Lords did not. of yours) you might run downStirling’s London home was at 128 Park St., Grosvenor Sq. to see whether I were living. I can tell you the opportunity is there, and will not always be!—

Once long ago I remember narrowly missing Kier, to my real sorrow, on the road southward.Sept. 1849; see 24:219TC to WS, 5 Sept. 1849, and 227TC to WS, 12 Sept. 1849. Keir is nr. Dunblane, Perthshire. This time again we are 48 hours too late:Stirling’s invitation had been sent to Linlathen; see TC to JWC, 14 Sept. I left Linlathen
on Tuesday morning; and am here for short pause on my route homeward,—am to be on the old treadwheel again in a day or two.
I wish you a happy Autumn,—tho’ I think, to yr credit, you do not preserve deerMost deer stalking took place in Sept. and Oct. (big or small) for the poor pleasure of killing them with yr own hand.

closer.salute: With many kind regards / Yours sincerely

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [14 Sept.]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N. B. PM: London, 14 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.562. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Oh my Dear! How very ill I like to hear of your making wedges! It would have been much better if you had kept to your original intention of “sailing there and back“— But since you are on the railway line, for Godsake take it easy! I wish you would break the journey home by staying a couple of days at Alderley, Those long railway journeys are ruinous for anybody with a head. If you would take it easy, and arrive here in tolerable condition you would find both ‘quiet’ and ‘fresh air’ to your hearts content.

I am perfectly miserable today. Those Forsters—or rather that Forster with his dinner-invitations, which he forces down one’s throat, is a real affliction to me! It seems so unkind to resist him, and he will not understand that there are conditions in which lying on a sofa at one’s own fire side is better for one than ‘dining’ with even choice spirits like him!

There have been most pernicious East winds lately and yesterday I got a whiff of cold just in going to the closet of the spare room, where the windows were all flying open— So I had a bad night, aggravated by the horrible thought of that dinner; not to be got off from a second time—if I could go at all.— Miss CunninghamMary Cunningham (ca. 1822–67), long known to JWC (see 13:109JWC to TC, 22 April 1841), da. of TC’s old friend Allan Cunningham (1784–1842), poet and songwriter, and Jean Cunningham (1791–1864; see 10:111JWC to JWCU, 3 July 1838). had been asked to meet me on the former occasion, and had been put off till the day I should say which was today!—

If I get worse before Forster brings the carriage for me at five o’clock, I must just mortally affront him by refusing to go—but even without getting worse, regard for my present comfort, and fear of consequences tomorrow would keep me at home.

Ruskin came the other day and sat by, while I eat my dinner! very sunburnt,Ruskin had been in Neuchâtel, Switzerland, with his pupil, American painter William Stillman (1828–1901); he wrote to Charles Norton, 12 July: “the sunshine burns my head so that I long for the old shades with their dew again” (Correspondence of John Ruskin and Charles Eliot Norton. Ed. J. L. Bradley and I. Ousby. [Cambridge, 1987] 57). his MotherMargaret Cox Ruskin. had broken her thigh bone, but is doing well— Poor Mr
Barlow is back from France—more palsied than ever— He is going off to PennicookPenicuik, small town 10 mi. S of Edinburgh; John Barlow’s sister-in-law Maria Ann (d. 1866) was m. to Sir George Clerk of Penicuik (1787–1867), 6th bart.; they lived at Penicuik House.—for October
I am going to lie down under my fur, and try for some sleep! Oh if Fuzz had never been born!—
love to Jamie and the youngsters.
docBody.name: J W Carlyle
docBody.note: JWC enclosed a letter from Smith, Elder & Co., 13 Sept., asking TC to write a preface for the British edn. of Ralph Waldo Emerson’s forthcoming book Conduct of Life: “in order to obtain for this, the author’s edition, that preference which your name & recommendation would ensure, with most of Mr. Emerson’s readers in this country.” TC replied, 8 Oct., regretting that he was too “overwhelmingly busy” and added that he was sure the “Book … will on its own strength go into the Libraries of all thinking Englishmen”; see vol. 37.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 14 Sept. Addr: 5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 14 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS: 615.538. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest,—I finished out my trashery of Notes yesterday, before rising; took an evg walk with Jamie over the green uplands in the grey wind, returning to a succinct dietetic dinner after 6; was punctual to rules every way;—and ended by sleeping from half past ten to half past 6, and again (under dreamy circumstances, poor JeffreyFrancis, Lord Jeffrey; perhaps in TC’s mind because their last meeting, Sept. 1849 (see 24:232TC to JWC, 15 Sept. 1849), was on another journey southward, when TC also failed to visit William Stirling; see TC to WS, 13 Sept. and many other figures confusedly appearing) from shortly after 7 till 9 had struck. So that today I am a new man,—30 per cent beyond yesterday, tho’ still a good few degrees below my old Thurso state. I get terribly cut up by travelling. It had been really better for me to have held by the Wick Steamer to Granton Pier,Granton, 2½ mi. N of Edinburgh; see 35:118TC to JAC, 21 June 1859. and then and thenThus in MS. have got into a Granton-London oneFor steamer travel between Granton and London in 1859, see 35:118TC to JAC, 21 June 1859, and 199–201JWC to HL, 13 Sept. 1859. witht speaking to anybody.

The mighty wind of yesterday from the s. w. has been followed today, as was expected, by a ditto rain from the same quarter: so that solitary reading
within doors, and one sally or two under the cover of Mackintosh, is the only resource. Happily no Note of any kind has come (happily, since none from Goody came): so that, except this insignificant word, I have nothing to write at all. Tongue cannot tell how cordially I dislike that operation in general cases;—“wi’ sic a pen” &c as the corrupt anarchy of mankind, prosecuting the nearly altogether devilish enterprise of “cheap and nasty”Coterie speech; see 34:6TC to JCA, 2 July 1858. in this as in other premises, has reduced us to! I intend to be home some time next week, unless &c &c: that is all that in the present intricate circumstances (great want of gigs increasing the complexity) can be said. If I hear nothing from you Tomorrow morning (whh I don’t hope!) there will be nothing for me till Tuesday morning: I hope you will have considered that. For Tuesday morning, The Gill will be the safer address.

I was very glad you had recd that wondrous Mm v. Usedom, taliter qualiter [one way or another]: your description of her is perfectly like: velocity, exaggeration, cordiality”;—but she was a welcome apparition to me at Rostock railway-Statn,See 34:159TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1858. and unweariedly kind till I departed again.— Poor Geraldine’s parasol: has she found that too? The thrift of secon[d]-classLetter omitted. was a bold stroke of busss!—

Jamie, on some of his best land, has such a crop “as eyes never saw”;Cf. 24:261TC to JF, 2 Oct. 1849, and Aeneid 3:5. then on land hardly so good a very tolerable crop: crop, as a whole, decidedly baddish; but it is on grass and sheep that he mainly depends; and things are very well in that departt this year. He seems much sunk in dispiritment, most weak health too, but makes no complaint. The good Jamie. Adieu dearest: I will be ready to sally out with this at 2; under Mackh Cape. Yours ever T. Carlyle

ps.p: Stirling’s Letter (yesterday) had come by Linlathen.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 16 [17] Sept. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 17 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.539. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; Mon. was 17 Sept.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
My poor Goody,—I am considerably anxious about that Fuz-Dinner business, whh did not seem at all a canny one for my poor little Woman in her weak state; and I can well conceive what a provocation and apprehension it was to you in yr then sad state and humour. I hope it may have passed better than your anticipatn;—I hope too you will not neglect (perhaps abt this very
hour!) to be writing me hitherward some little notice of your fate in that and other particr. I shall be disappointed, and considerably the victim of imaginatn otherwise.

I have been here since Saturday afternoon: breakfast and its appendages was hardly off the scene there, that morning,—happily with no Letters (one from the Doctor,John A. Carlyle. to give warning, had miscarried),—when MaryMary Austin. arrived with an innocent kind of Farmer’s Spring-Cart, roomy enough, and proposed by the Dr’s order that I shd straightway come over, if I pleased, or at least send my luggage; Jamie’s gig being baddish, especially for that latter purpose. As the day was dry, in the middle of wet or uncertain ones, and the drive like to do me good, I came off luggage and all,—perceptibly benefited by my drive. Indeed I have had a great deal of (irregular) sleep and bodily accommodation since you heard last; and am pretty much up to par again, tho’ my head is still rather dour and occasionally disagreeable and musical. Nothing to speak of! On looking back to last year in these localities, I find a balance in favour of my now conditn; not the contrary. I compute I shall perhaps get my Book done, after all, in a creditable manner!— I mean to be home in the end of this week (that is all I can yet say), and to recommence my attempts on the melancholy undertaking. “Must not lose heart”;Cf. “tine [lose] heart, tine all,” coterie speech; see 7:195TC to MAC, 30 May 1834, and 245TC to JAC, 22 July 1834. no!— Yesterday (wet, at least drizzly and muddy) there was a rendezvous of Dumfries & Scotsbrig here: all of the family that are alive and on this side the sea. Painful to me, yet with streaks of something far other & better. I left the company two hours, to walk in spite of the rain. We were all dullish; Jean mainly kept up the spirit of the conversation: very clever, solid and sagacious in her delineations of adjacent contemporary objects. “History” goes on in all corners and quarters!— One of the things I learned was, that the old mansion of the Welshes (of ColiestonCollieston farm, 3 mi. E of Craigenputtoch; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 108. or Crn Puttoch, I forget whh) was still standing in the Friar’s VennelFriar’s Vennel, even though narrow, was one of the busiest streets of old Dumfries; for the mansion, see TC to JWC, 18 Sept. of Dumfrs; authenticated beyond the shadow of cavil for 200 years back. I mean to have a glance at it this very evg;—for Jack & I are going in thither “for Tea”; a pleasant little drive, in empty carriages with return tickets! Adieu Dearest. God keep you. T. Carlyle

ps.p: Tomorrow (if fair), Jamie is to come & fetch me,—back to Scotsbrig, for one day;—I had missed (not from neglect) one small sad thing there, or near there!Probably a visit to the Ecclefechan graveyard; for the family gravestones, see 35:228, 229TC to AC, 7 Oct. 1859.— Direct always hither.
I do not think I shall go by Alderley; at least I have taken no steps that way yet. It is but a new tumult; better swallow yr black-draught all at once!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [17 Sept.]. Addr: The Gill / Cummertrees / Annan / N. B. PM: London, 17 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.564. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:60–62.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: You will open this, prepared to hear that I went to Forsters, and have been very ill in consequence. If there be a choice betwixt a wise thing and a foolish one—a woman is always expected to do the foolish. Well, I didn’t! Very ill I have been—but not from going out to dinner. By one oclock that day I was quite ill enough to care no more for Fuzz’s wrath than for a whiff of tobacco! I had taken the Influenza, and no doubt about it! So I despatched a message to Montague Square—and another message to Mr Barnes—went to bed, and have not left it till within the last hour! So provoking! I had been so much better, and hoped to be quite flourishing on your return. HowsomdeverThus in MS. an Influenza properly treated and an Influenza allowed to treat itself—like all my former ones—is a very different affair I find! It has not been allowed to settle down on my chest at all, this one—and after only three days of sharp suffering, here I am in the drawing-room!—looking forward with some interest to the sweetbread I am to dine on! and writing you a letter better or worse!— The new woman“Tall Charlotte.” is a good nurse! very quiet, and kindly, and with sense to do things without being told. I have not had my clothes folded neatly up, and the room tidied, and my wants anticipated in this way since I had no longer my Mother to nurse me.
In ordinary circumstances I should have felt it horrid to be lying entirely at the mercy of an utter stranger—but being as she is, I have wished no one else to come near me—

Even you I rather hope may not come this week— It would worry me so, not to be able to run about when you come—and I must be cautious for some days yet—“Mrs Prudence”! as Mr Barnes calls me in mockery!— The girl is to come tomorrowSarah had originally been engaged to begin 14 Sept.; see JWC to TC, [26 Aug.].—but I dont feel to trouble my head about her. Charlotte (2d) can be trusted to direct her in the way she should go—till I am well enough to meddle!—besides I have every reason to believe her a nice girl. The old Charlotte, poor foolish thing is still hanging on at her ‘Mother’s’Elizabeth Southam, her aunt, living nearby in Lawrence St. just
as untidy in her person with nothing to do, as she used to be in her press of work. She has been much about me—and I dont know what I should have done without her, to cook for me and show me some human kindness when I was ill under “Old Jane“— But I am glad at the same time that I had fortitude to resist her tears and her request to be taken back as Cook. I told her, some day I might take her back but she had much to learn and to unlearn first. Still it is gratifying to feel that ones kindness to the girl has not been all lost on her for she really loves both of us passionately only that passionate loves, not applied to practical uses are good for so little in this matter of fact world!

Kindest love to dear Mary Tell her I will make out that visit some day on my own basis— It is only postponed “Thanks God”Coterie speech; Mazzini’s expression; see 30:209JWC’s Journal, 1 Nov. 1855. you can’t get any cloths ever JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JGC [JGCO], [17 Sept.]. MS: NLS 607.563. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO J. G. COOKE

docBody.p: My Dear Friend—I am the more distressed by your newsMary Godby and two of her children were seriously ill; see JWC to TC, [18 Sept.]. that I can’t go to offer any possible help— — I have been confined to bed three days with Mr Barnes in constant attendance— I had taken “a bad Influenza” just when I fancied I was coming round out of my troubles—

Tonight I am sitting up with my clothes on—but I am sadly pulled down—and God knows when I may be able to go to the Post OfficePresumably the “Post-office Establishment” at St. Martin’s le Grand, where Mary Godby was matron; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 163.
So pray give me all the news you can get—and if possible see Mrs BinnieMary Godby’s mother. and tell her how I am situated—and how grieved I am to have been kept in ignorance of all this trouble
My Husband speaks of being home this week I hope in heaven he will put off a little longer till I am able to attend to him—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 18 Sept. Addr: 5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 18 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.540. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Alas, alas, my poor little Jeannie, what a business is this! Down in Influenza, in spite of all your bits of struggles; suffering, feeble, and nobody there but servants and strangers.— You put the best face you can on the matter; but it is evidently a very bad job! It was very kind of you, too, to write me a little Note abt the real fact that had befallen: I might easily have taken to imagining, had you kept silent, that it was even worse. Send me, if you can at all, one word daily till we meet again. And keep up your little heart, Dearest; and be quiet, and obey Barnes! You do not easily lose heart; a valiant little soul, courageous abundantly: through ups and downs, I will hope (if what you tell me today be no better than the truth) to find you well reemerged when I return.

I had thot of Friday for returning; but will try and examine farther what can be done to give you more time. And at any rate, why shd my coming disturb
you much? I will be as quiet as a mouse till I have you on foot again, strong enough to be “kept unasy.”Coterie speech: “There lived a man in Ballinacrazy, / Who wanted a Wife to keep him unazy!”; see 11:9TC to MAC, 2 Feb. 1839.—— The truth is, I might do myself a good turn by reposing for a few days here; at least so I had confidently calculated: but I have never been in the least well since I arrived in Annandale: illish sleep, sometimes (as last night again) fairly rather ill; no appetite, even for Gill Coffee and the celebrated “brown bread”;See 34:52TC to JWC, 19 July 1858.—a day or two ago I began to perceive that “blue-pill and castor” was the thing wanted! That is the fact; no remedy but the above! I had determined to be home before getting into it;—but will now proceed straight way upon it: Jamie has come for me; we will get the material in Ecclefechan as we pass this afternoon; and—important despatches may be expected! Another considerable evil has been, I am not sufficiently let alone; but today that will alter for the better; and no farther travelling, appointing &c will be needed after I return hither tomorrow: Jack goes then (to Scotsbrig, I suppose), and only Jean (useful with her needle) will be here instead, whom I will not let talk too much, and who does not otherwise bother at all.

figure.p: “Queensberry Square” by Joseph Watson, 1852

p.hi: Courtesy of Dumfries Museum

docBody.p:
The railway train yesternight to and from was almost or altogether pleasant, so pretty was the evg (this day still prettier): I did not see Aird;Thomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB, writer and ed. of the Dumfries Herald; see 6:361TC to JAC, 29 March 1833. but we all mounted to the leads of the Mid-Steeple,Townhouse and steeple built in Queensberry Sq. by Tobias Bachop, 1705–7, to serve as a council chamber and a repository for burgh records; see 7:112TC to JWE, 4 March 1834; also variously used as a prison and a storage depot for arms and ammunition (William McDowall, History of the Burgh of Dumfries [Edinburgh, 1867] 537–42). See oppabove. whh I had never heard of before as a shew, tho’ it really is one; as fine a view of Town and green champaign and mountain all round as one wd wish; not to speak of ancient pikes, Highland scythe-swords (‘taken at Ecclefechan in 1745’),A raid was carried out by Dumfries townspeople, 7 Nov. 1745, on the baggage depot temporarily established in Ecclefechan by James Drummond (ca. 1720–46), 3d duke of Perth, leader of a division of the Jacobite army of Prince Charles Edward Stuart (1720–88). Believing the depot safe, Drummond and his troop of 4,000 Highlanders proceeded to Carlisle, and the baggage and arms, “numerous pikes and scythe-blades used by the Highlanders at Prestonpans,” were carried off in triumph to Dumfries (McDowall 638). of considerable bells,According to Johnstone’s Complete Guide (see below), “Mr Barclay, founder, Edinburgh, furnished the three bells” (26) for Mid-Steeple; i.e., he cast the bells, rather than donated them. tower-clocks close at one’s ear; especially of one bell “gift of Michael Lord Carlyle of Torthorward to God and St Michael” in the year 1580-something:William, Lord Carlyle of Torthorwald, presented a bell, 1433, in honor of St. Michael to Dumfries parish church (McDowall 175); the bell was later moved to Mid-Steeple. a very canty effective little bell, whh I remember reading some account of the
finding of in my early boyhood; but had never seen, nor again heard of since then. Dumfries has now a Guide-Book;There were two guides: Johnstone’s Complete Guide to Dumfries and the Surrounding District (new and enlarged edn., Dumfries, 1860), 32 pp. and 4 pp. of adverts., and Visitor’s Guide to Dumfries and Vicinity (Dumfries, 1860), 80 pp. and 30 pp. of adverts., with a preface dated 24 July. please to respect its sights.— This finished, Jean and I went, and took survey, deliberately from two sides, of “Miss Jean Welsh of Craigenputtoch,”Presumably a connection of JWC’s Welsh ancestors of Craigenputtoch and Collieston; not further identified. old Town-Mansion,The mansion was at the corner of Friar’s Vennel and the High St.; see below.—whh, I can assure you, has been an effective thing in its time, one of the most solid and spacious Houses within Burgh, and doubtless the scene of many old-fashioned tea-parties and queer occurrences of good and evil in the generatns past. For it is very old; the interior wood-work gone quite to wreck; the ground-floor all gutted out to an “Italian Warehouse,”David Lennox, family grocer, importer of Indian condiments, and tea, wine, and spirit merchant at 5 Castle St. (which ran into the esplanade onto which the Welsh mansion faced), also advertised himself as an Italian Warehouseman in the Visitor’s Guide. He also advertised having “commodious vaults” for his large stock of wines; perhaps he had extended his warehouse into the Friar’s Vennel house. of goodly dimensions; the 2 (or I rather think 3) upper stories inhabited by poor people, and the proprietorship multiplex. Curious enough, a SisterWilhelmina Cunningham (ca. 1794–1875), 76 Irish St., Dumfries. of Allan Cunningham’s now lives on an annuity (Life Annuity of £60) derived from the Italian-Warehouse or ground story, whh was hers, and whh she sold on those terms. — The modern “Jeanny Welsh of Craignph” has seen this House a hundred and a hundred times witht knowing. It is the Corner House in the eastern or longer side of Friar’s Vennel; looks, properly, not into the “Vennel” at all, but free into the High Street, with one face; and with the other face free over the Esplanade where the old Post-Office used to be: “Nothink for Craigh today Ma’am!”The saying of Robert Threshie, “Dumfries postmaster of old”; see 19:209JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1845.—— Jean is to recover the exact date &c if she can. Forgive all this babble, Dearest; I hoped it might amuse you a moment. Do not notWord repeated on turn of page. forget the little bit of bulletin; above all, do not forget to be careful, to be canny, and have good news to send. God grant it. Yours T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [18 Sept.]. Addr: The Gill / Cummertrees / Annan N. B. PM: London, 1 [8] Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.565. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Just one line Dear to keep your ‘Imagination’ quiet. I am doing very well; nothing to complain of now, but the weakness and lowness consequent on that horrid Influenza. And as I can eat, and am begun to sleep, I expect in a little while to be “in my frail ordinar thank God“—(as Jackie Welsh writes)

But I am sort of stunned today! George Cooke sent a man with a note to tell me “in case I did not know already“—that poor Mrs Godby is lying dangerously ill, “had not been expected to survive the night—and two of the children were lying ill too— Her Mother was with her—telegraphed for I believe—but I don’t know what the illness is, or anything about it except that Mrs Godby and the Children had been staying some where in the Country for six weeks. and she seems to have returned to The Post Office ill, about a fortnight ago. I am so sorry to learn this, when tied here hand and foot!— As much as my own life is worth to go to them—and up to no nursing or anything if I were there!
George Cooke will do all he can do, and will send me word daily— But poor Mrs Binnie in a place so unheimlich [dismal] for her! on such a heavy errand!

I do wish you would rest at Alderley—not merely for the sake of taking half of your black doze at a time—so far as the disagreeableness is concerned; but for the sake of the difference of injury to one’s head done by two hundred miles of railway travelling and four hundred!— If the affair were over when the doze is swallowed, I shouldnt mind.
If Mary should offer you a little pot of butter be sure you take it. Also about new meal? Is there any yet? Ours is very bitter become.
I wrote to Addiscombe when I started for Alderly—to discontinue the Hamper—and couldnt for shame warn them that I was back in a week!— I miss the Addiscombe butter very much—none here so good—
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[JB] [JBAR], [18 Sept.]. MS: Hist. Society of Pennsylvania. Hitherto unpbd. Dated after JWC’s recovery from influenza.
div3.head: JWC TO [JOHN BARLOW]

docBody.p: While you have been enjoying yourself on the Continent, I have been having a bad Influenza at home.

But I am now able to be in the Drawingroom and able to get good of seeing you. So pray come to tea on Thursday evening—and for your pains you shall make the acquaintance of one of our cleverest female NovelistsUnidentified. It was neither Jewsbury, whom Barlow knew, nor Margaret Oliphant (1824–97; ODNB), as JWC’s first letter to her was 18 Dec. 1860; their first meeting was “summer either of 1860 or 1861,” according to Oliphant (Elisabeth Jay, ed., The Autobiography of Margaret Oliphant [Oxford, 1990] 98), but it was at a time when TC was in London (see Autobiography 97), either before TC left for Scotland or after his return. Of other women novelists that JWC knew, she admired George Eliot but did not meet her socially, and it seems unlikely that Georgiana Craik was back in London, having been there in June; see JWC to GC and MCGCMC, 18 June.— Perhaps you think that is not saying much!

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle to [John Barlow], [18 September 1860], p. 1

p.hi: Courtesy of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle to [John Barlow], [18 September 1860], p. 2

p.hi: Courtesy of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania

docBody.p: I am tempted to not tell you that my Husband is never returned yet! In case you basely take advantage of the knowledge to disappoint his wife—but I “hope better things of you tho I thus speak[“]Coterie speech; see 4:94TC to JBW, 13 May 1826; cf. Heb. 6:9 and Reuben Percy, The Percy Anecdotes (1821) 16:112.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 19 Sept. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 19 Sept. 1860; London, 20 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.541. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks, Dearest, for your punctual news; whh, tho’ it is rather of sad tenor in several points, is a great benefit and relief to me. I am just got back from Scotsbrig, in a feeble tho’ successful “physicky” state; had there been no letter at all, I shh have been finely off!— I have hardly a few minutes of time before the Post go; and write you a word in great hurry.

Poor Mrs Godby’s is a bad business; and must have given you a great shock to hear of it on the sudden in your present state. Poor woman, it is very sad and miserable; but one hopes strongly she will get thro’, having Youth to help her; and that all will clear up again in that quarter. Do not you fret about it (no
help is in you, or in any mortal almost); especially do not fret about your total inability for anything but wishing in regard to it. The old mother is likely to be the very best of nurses and managers in such a situation; and will keep up her own heart and her poor Daughter’s better than hundreds of other more refined people wd do:-in no case try in the least to go near it; nothing could be so irrational on your part. Attend to this now; and understand that, now and afterwards, you are commanded to keep entirely out of the affair, and to lie still when you are as absolutely unfit for the smallest attempt that way. If I have any authority over you, that is my strict injunction, as well as my passionate request, as head of the house in this sore season, whh we hope will not last!—

I went thro’ all my poor and sad tasks yesterday in their due series; I slept rather better than usual (expect now to begin sleeping really well); and today (after the 2 hours drive, I, for the first time, have a kind of appetite towards the soup or other edibles whh are probably getting ready fast for Jamie and me. Poor Jamie he has quitted his harvest, and made this second day’s work of driving to fulfil all my notions. Jack goes home with him; and I do not return
to Scotsbrig. Mary, no doubt, will have a little pot of butter; but there is yet no new meal at all: perhaps better wait till in a week or two both butter and meal be ready together?— Jean is here duly;—set to mend a pair of drawers for me in the distance. She will not be a bother; and I expect to be much better let alone. I will think again of Alderley; but today I have time to think of nothing. Let me pray for good news tomorrow! Adieu, my poor Goody
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 Sept.]. Addr: The Gill / Cummertrees / Annan N. B. PM: London, 19 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.566. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Thanks Dear!— What a blessing it is to be able to get an answer to a letter without waiting a week for it!

I had a good sleep last night—the best—the most human for weeks back! but, as a first good sleep always does, it has made me very dull and lazy today. Mr Barnes has just left me with directions; “Be sure you eat your sole, and drink your wine, and go early to bed, and dont, theres a good woman, be writing, and bothering your brains—but keep quite quiet”!— So you see I must put you off with a mere bulletin—
Mrs WedgwoodFrances Wedgwood. came yesterday and brought me some grapes—very welcome! Mrs Gilchrist says they are “half a guinea a pound!”

Mrs Godby has rallied a little but is still in great danger. Gastric fever it is—She came home from the country ill, and the first thing she heard was, that her eldest Boy, at the Bluecoat College,The original Bluecoat School was founded by Edward VI in 1552 at Christ’s Hospital, Newgate St., for the education of poor children. By the mid-19th century charity schools all round the country were known as “bluecoat schools” because of the color of their uniform. was down in Scarlet fever—the impossibility of going to nurse him so aggravated her illness that for two days there was no hope!— Both her Mother and Brother came on getting the telegraph message and are with her. The GovernessUnidentified. wished to send for me, but didn’t know my address, the fool! The twinsPossibly Mary and an unidentified twin. are also lying very ill. And I feel ready to stamp with impatience when I think of all that and that I am laid up with Influenza—
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 20 Sept. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 20 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.542. Quot: Bliss, TC 354.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Your little Bulletin comes duly and is very valuable, poor Dear; I wish I cd cure you on the sudden, Barnes or I; but alas we can do nothing of that miraculous nature, least of all can the latter gentn! All he can do is to keep absolutely quiet,—and write you a poor scratch of the “Nothing-News” that are passing here! I have slept well; am utterly lazy, stupid; and it is the brightest weather in the world: that is all that can be said or sung.

If I knew accurately that I should not hurt you by coming, I think I shd be disposed to come off on Saturday: but I do not quite know that, and in my present dimness shall probably not do it. Tell me, next opportunity, with all the candour and exactitude you can. I abide hitherto by the “All-at-once” plan; that is to say, I have not written anything to Alderley (for whh, indolence alone wd be reason enough, indolence and dimness of insight into facts); I feel too a kind of aversion to getting into new fashions and conditions, and even into opening my trunk (still standing mostly packed if I can possibly help it.— Mary has 12lb of excellt butter ready to salt and send; but there will be no oatmeal of first quality either here or at Scotsbrig for perhaps 3 weeks yet: will you have them come together? Or must the butter (or a part of it in my trunk, whh will be “possible” in spite of my indolences) come at once? Speak your mind & will on this small matter?—

Jack went off yesterday, along with Jamie;—gloomily sorrowful to part with me, poor soul; but obliged to do it, having no lodging of his own in this world, nor prospect of having any,—owing to difficulties whh are inexorable and insuperable, tho’ not of pecuniary nature! His kindness, and even rough tenderness to me, on this last Expeditn, have been almost ominous: he himself too is very sad of heart; I was truly downcast, last night, to see the white-headed old man faring off on such terms, on his unreasonable but inevitable lonesome road.

I hope and begin partly to predict that poor Mrs Godby will get thro’: what a deliverance to those about her! Be you quiet, meanwhile, you; don’t stir, at yr peril!—— Jean is mending drawers, sewing belts &c beside me; does not bother with talk, except permitted; and is company on my walk. The inclosed clipping is from her.Untraced. Adieu, Dearest
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [20 Sept.]. Addr: The Gill / Cummertrees / Annan—N. B. PM: London, 20 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.567. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:234–35. TC later wrote “20 Septr 1860” under JWC’s date and corrected some of the punctuation.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I do so hate, Dear, to tell about myself every day!—as if I were “the crops” or something of that sort!

When “I’se no better, I’se ashamed to say it“—and when I am better “Ise” equally ashamed to be cackling over my wellness. and so I shall be glad when you can see with your eyes how I am, instead of my telling you, in words.

Meanwhile I have today to inform you that I am in what poor Hunt called a “very Irish state of health”Leigh Hunt’s saying untraced. “Oh! middling!“— I didn’t sleep so well as the previous night—and got up with a head ach—which is not gone yet. But I have had a good dinner of “Sweet-bread“—and expect a sleep by and by—

Dont be afraid that I will go to Mrs Godby. I am not in a condition to be of any use to them and have no notion of going out of my way for the fuss of the thing—like Geraldine—at present I dont even know when I shall be let go out. Mr Larkin went yesterday and brought me a note from Mrs Binnie. The Drs think the poor soul still in great danger—but have hope (they had none at first) of her recovery—

Mr Barlow has brought me a pretty gold brooch from Paris—and gave it to me as a keepsake “in the prospect of his death any day“—— He gets more and more palsied—and his mind too is much enfeebled, but the perfect gentleman still looks pathetically out thro’ all his infirmities—and he will allow none of us to bother— He admits if you question him that “paralysis is gradually carrying him off,” but you are not expected to look more grave for that; and for the rest, he seems as prepared as the most “professing Christian”
The Duke of Manchester sent back your books unpaid (carriage 1/ 9d)— I thought it was game—when that money was demanded—and was so provoked to see our own books! God be with you
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 22 [21] Sept. Addr: 5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Annan, 21 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 615.543. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:241.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: I am coming home to thee Tomorrow (Saturday) Night, my poor own Goody: that, after ref[l]exionLetter omitted. perhaps more than enough, is the solution I have arrived at. I am fairly out of my medicinal adventure; may fairly call myself a little recovered from my Annandale or Travelling damages; furthermore I am utterly indolent, dreary-lazy, demoralized;—not to say that I ought (in spite of what you say) to be looking after my one little Possession in Chelsea, and seeing with my own eyes how she is:—in brief that is the decision; and but for some mistake or other whh I do not anticipate, I swallow my dirty draughts, at one gulp, and am with you! Nine or 10 in the Evg (I think, but do not know) we are due,—perhaps 10½ at Chelsea? For God’s sake make no disturbance about me, Goody dear! I will be quiet as a Dream; I shall need nothing but Tea and two fresh eggs;—surely I ought to be rather a protectn to your poor sick fancy than a new disturbance. Be still, be quiet, poor Goody of my heart; I swear to do thee no mischief at all!—
The bulletin of today is but so-so; tho’, as usual, you strive to do the best you can with it. Tomorrow I hope to look with my own eyes into things, and judge for myself.
If yr Note of tomorrow morning shd contain any express prohibitions to come (whh I can hardly dream of as possible), then, and not otherwise than then, I may pause till Monday.
Adieu, Dearest: be quiet; and if you find yourself weaker than usual, don’t let me and my bother make you worse at least. Good be with you ever.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 24 Sept. MS: NLS 517.6. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I got safe home on Saturday, and with less discomfort and brashing than is usual. The Dr & Jamie (Senior) appeared suddenly at Carlisle on my arrival, and were very useful while there. I dined (beyond Preston) on a wing of chicken of Mary’s carving, who had also filled my bottle with water qualified to the right pitch with brandy: I had the whole carriage mostly to myself, and
smoked and ventilated quite at discretion. The Country seem[ed] to grow wetter the farther south we got, till at London it was fairly rain and glar.— Jane looked fully better than I cd have hoped; she now gets out for a drive at times; is gone this midday, tho’ the weather is rawish. I have not yet made out my ten-hours sleep; but hope to be all round in a few days, and my smithy-fire (as I expressed it) fairly alight again. Nobody is here to give the least disturbance for a month to come.

I think NibloeWilliam Nibloe (1815–89), shoemaker, 86 High St., Dumfries. may venture on the woollen slippers, on the leathern too if he like. A thought more room for the little toes, especially the right one; a ditto (but only a ditto) less of width of instep: that wd make the leather ones perfect. For the woollen he can lean always to the side of room (with ⅛ inch more length): the woollen pair, if I cd get them right, wd be very useful. Might be ready with the Gill Butter-and-meal package, if you found the speculatn safe.

I have written to Scotsbrig: the good Mary bargained for a Newspaper; whh I have sent. There are some Frasers here; I will despatch one in a day or two. To James and all the Household my kindest regards and grateful remembrance. May we all meet again some day,—as a Gracious Providence has so many times permitted us to do. Amen!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Poor Graham of Burnswark: a black Note has just come in, announcing that all is ended, Saturday last!TC’s old friend William Graham d. 22 Sept. of “cerebral disease.” John A. Carlyle had written, 27 [Aug.]: “poor old Graham has grown very frail now & also quite dark in intellect.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 24 Sept. Addr: 12 Chapel Street / Mayfair. PM: London, 24 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Daily Mail, 29 Jun. 1914. Charles Augustus Ward (1828–1914), vintner, poet, and antiquarian; published under the pseud. Feltham Burghley. In June 1859 he had sent TC a copy of England Subsists by Miracle (1859); see TC to CAW, 5 June 1859.
div3.head: TC TO C. A. WARD

docBody.p:
There are some fiery strokes of satire in your Ballad,The Sutherland Clearance: A Ballad (Glasgow, 1860) was an attack on the 1811–20 Sutherland clearances. and the Piece is not difficult to read: but probably the subject is not well adapted for that form of
treatment. I liked your second MacphailWard also pbd., under his pseudonym, a two-part article, “On Landed Property and the Clearance System,” MacPhail’s Edinburgh Ecclesiastical Journal nos. 174 and 175 (Edinburgh, July and Aug. 1860) 342–54 and 23–39. In the first part Ward argued: “the land in fact is a trust, let out by society, for the general good; and that there is no inherent right to landed property vested in any individual, or family of successive individuals, but what is underlaid by this great social principle”; he attacked modern ideas about land improvement, arguing that small farms can be just as productive as large ones (MacPhail 174:346). The second part was a furious and sustained attack on the apologia of James Loch, An Account of the Improvements on the Estates of the Marquess of Stafford (1815). James Loch (1780–1855), lawyer; see also n. 4. and its prose directness better; the magazine arrived where I was (within sight of the Sutherland Countries) some six weeks ago; and was duly relished by myself and others.TC’s host Sir George Sinclair was the son of Sir John Sinclair of Ulbster, who had first introduced the hardy Cheviot sheep to N Scotland, which led to the displacement of the human population; according to John Prebble, “it was the kindly old man’s tragedy that he brought the Great Sheep north for the benefit of his people, but was unable to prevent others from using it to oust theirs” (Prebble, The Highland Clearances [1963] 33); perhaps Sir George also was not sympathetic to the clearances. You are probably a thot too fierce upon poor Loch &c;James Loch, estate commissioner from 1812, and Patrick Sellar (1780–1851), factor from 1810, administered controversial clearances on the Sutherland estates 1812–15 and 1819–21; they were renowned for their inhumanity in dealing with the crofters on the estates, which were owned by Elizabeth Gordon (1765–1839), countess of Sutherland, and her husband (m. 1785), George Granville Leveson-Gower (1758–1833), 2d marquess of Stafford. but I like your indignation too, and find it very natural and fairly directed. I have sent away one Copy of the Ballad; let it smite upon what hearts it can.

Your notions about Land and the duties of Landlords, and the possessn of what is called “Landed Property,”Ward wrote in the first part, “The very existence of society depends upon land. … [T]o man has it been given by his Creator … it is given under a responsibility,—held under God with feof of loyal service attached to it … . [T]he feudal system … assert[s] … the essential connection between land tenure, and state service” (Macphail 174:346). In the second part, he wrote: “Landed property is a political trust, not autocratic and irresponsible” (MacPhail 175:23). have from my youth upwards been strongly mine,TC discussed ideas of “duties of Landlords” and “Landed Property” in many of his works, most notably Past and Present. and at one period they were a real oppression to me, so sad had the contrast grown between reality and theory! What you say is useful and I bid you in all ways continue to say it wherever there is opportunity. “The Earth” (of all things) “is the Lord’s”See Ps. 24:1, quoted by Ward in his article (MacPhail 174:346). and no other person’s, now, then, or at any time! But, alas, I perceive the old Feudal circumstances never can return, nor anything practically like them (however much wanted, and indeed at last
indispensable)Ward argued that the feudal system was not only a responsible system of land tenure, but also the best method of producing soldiers. till people have quite laid aside immense quantities of stuff (especially [a]bout “liberty” &c &c) whh they now babble of, with one accord, from Dan to Beersheba,Cf. 1 Kings 4:25. as the true account of man and his blessedness in this world. The pinch of Anarchy will one day check this, in England itself, in Yankee-land itself, if nothing else will. We must wait, we must wait.

I have sometimes thot of asking if you never rode, on an afternoon? I generally have a horse (not quite yet, for a day or two); and there might for once an intersection take place, if things stood well!Ward lived at 12 Chapel St., Mayfair, was 2¼ mi. NE of Chelsea, nr. Hyde Park, where TC often rode. — Believe me
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-TB, 27 Sept. MS: Bancroft Lib. Univ of California, Berkeley. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS BALLANTYNE

docBody.p: I am got home again, and mean to stay: let the ExaminerProbably the Manchester Weekly Times and Examiner; Ballantyne had edited the Manchester Examiner, 1845–48; see 20:181TC to TB, 28 April 1846. take its due route, hither direct, in time coming,—be so good.
I hope you are prospering, especially in that matter.Possibly Ballantyne’s Manchester Review of Politics and Literature; see TC to TB, 9 May. It looks a little better than it used to do in London.
The jumbling of railways and etceteras, on the way hither, has quite cut me up again, for the moment.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 28 Sept. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 28 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 553.225. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Dear Neuberg,—I hope you are still steadily in these parts, and recovered of yr troublesome ailments in some measure.Neuberg had been suffering from whooping cough; see JWC to TC, [3 Sept.]. I got home last Saturday night
late; and have been in a sleepless &c conditn, compared with what I knew at Thurso;—not yet nearly up to par; tho’ perhaps by degrees improving; getting ready for my Printer, if I only could! Let us see you on Sunday Evg.Neuberg replied from Margate, Sun. 30 Sept.: “You see from my Date that I am not in a position to obey your summons for this evening. However, I shall return to town to-morrow; and hope to present myself in Cheyne Row at an early opportunity. … My cough is nearly, not quite, gone.” I have a Hungarian PamphletUnidentified. for you, if nothing better.— Bring, if you easily can, a List of any Books you may have from Chelsea:Neuberg replied: “Before I left London, I returned a lot of your Books (Frederic-Correspondance mostly), thinking you might be wanting them. I placed them, altogether, 7886 on the small table in your study. I have still (here with me) 3 vols. (21, 22, 23—26—& 27 [21, 22, and 23 are overscored]) of the Correspondance; and at home one vol. (if not both) of Preuss ‘Ledermann.’” none of them are immediately wanted; but in certain of my shelves there are slight innovations, gaps &c, abt whh I wish to satisfy myself. Fail not at 7½ p.m.

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Neuberg wrote a postscript: “As an encouragement to your Printing, let me not forget to report that Freiherr von Bunsen told lately to a fair correspondant of mine, at Bonn, that he ‘never in his life read a Book with so much interest as the History of Friedrich, and that he looked with great Spannung [anticipation] for the continuation.’” TC wrote on the reverse of the page: “A Neuberg Note (or P. S. to it) for the sake of something abt Bunsen,—whh I had to add: namely, that poor B. has got what Drs call a ‘fatty heart,’ and is bearing that sad allotment in a cheery magnans manner, while it shall be all!” Christian Karl Josias Bunsen (1791–1860; see 11:91TC to RWE, 17 April 1839), baron, Prussian ambassador to Britain, 1841–54, and old friend of TC’s, d. 28 Nov. 1860.

div1.p: Adamson, Robert (1787–1861; see 10:23TC to JCA, 14 Feb. 1838), bank manager of the British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; m., 1820, Ann, b. McMillan (1795–1861); they had two das., Jane (b. 1824) and Helen (b. 1826).

Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921), 7th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–81), 7th earl (see 26:28926:biographical note). They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus). Their children were Henrietta Blanche (1852–1925), Clementina Gertrude Helen (1854–1932), David Stanley William (1856–1900), Maude Josepha (1859–1933), Lyulph Gilchrist Stanley (1861–1947), and Griselda Johanna Helen (1865–1934).

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they lived in Assembly St., Dumfries. They had two sons who died in infancy, (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–71), who worked in a mercantile house in London from Sept. 1858 and lived in Islington; Thomas (1841–69), who was at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854); and John (1843–1911); their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.
Anderton, Sarah; see Dilberoglue.

Ashburton, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron; politician and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. He m., first, 1823, Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix—xv). The Carlyles and Ashburtons (then the Barings) first met 1839. TC admired them both, particularly Lady Ashburton, who was the center of a literary and political circle. Her close friendship with TC was a cause of jealousy for JWC. Ashburton’s second marriage, 1858, was to Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903; ODNB), da. of James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843; ODNB) and Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB). Louisa was lively and beautiful, with
an interest in the arts, natural history, and evangelicism. They had a da., Mary Florence (b. 26 June 1860). Where it is necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (1831–74), m., 1 Nov. 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer at Hollybush; Grace (b. 1833), m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Canada; Jessie (b. 1836), m., 8 March 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (b. 1844); Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).

Ballantyne, Thomas (1806–71; ODNB; see 11:32TC to TB, 23 Feb. 1839, and 30:xviiiintroduction), author and journalist; associated with several publications including the Manchester Guardian, the Leader, the Illustrated London News, and his weekly newspaper, the Statesman (Oct. 1857–April 1859); he anthologized TC and other writers.

Baring, Francis (1800–1868), Lord Ashburton’s brother and heir; m., 1832, Hortense Eugenie Claire, b. Maret (ca. 1812–82), da. of the duke of Bassano. Their children were Marie Anne Louise (1833–1928), Alexander Hugh (1835–89), and Denzil Hugh (1837–86).
Baring, Frederick (1806–68), Lord Ashburton’s brother; rector of Itchinstoke, Hants., 2 mi. W of The Grange, the Ashburton country house; m., 1831, Frederica Mary Catherine, b. Ashton (1804–84).
Baring, Louisa (1804–88), and Lydia Emily (1814–68), Lord Ashburton’s sisters; they lived at 23 Princes Gate, London.

Barlow, Rev. John (ca. 1799–1869), clergyman and scientist; fellow of the Royal Society 1834; hon. sec. of the Royal Institution ca. 1842–62; his pbd. lectures included The Connection between Physiology and Intellectual Philosophy (1842) and On Man’s Power over Himself to Control and Prevent Insanity (1843); chaplain-in-ordinary at Kensington Palace from 1854; m., 1824, Cecilia Anne, b. Law (ca. 1795–1868); see also 30:246–47JWC’s Journal, 25 April 1856.

Barnes, Dr. Alfred Brooke (ca. 1802–67), 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea, physician; m. Susannah (ca. 1804–ca. 1855); their children were Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833), Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–65), and Isabella (see below); their eldest child, Laura Susannah (b. 1829), was deceased.
Barnes, Isabella Emily (b. 1837), became close to JWC from their first meetings in 1859; see also 35:188JWC to JGCO, 2 Sept. 1859. She m., 1862, John Simmonds.
Binnie, Mary, b. Gillespie (ca. 1794–1866), JWC’s second cousin, widow of Thomas Binnie, living at Prestonpans; she had a son, Thomas (b. 1824), and a da., Mary (see Godby).

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875); Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82JWC to SS, 29 Oct. 1846, and 24:221JWC to TC, 5 Sept. 1849); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. They had one surviving son, George Pringle (1827–65), who suffered ill health. Three other sons died in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831). They had lived at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843) and moved in 1858 to Upper Stenhouse, Liberton, S Edinburgh.
Bright, John (1811–89; ODNB), radical politician, Liberal M.P. for Birmingham 1858–89.

Brookfield, William Henry (1809–74; ODNB; see 20:156JWC to WHB, 1 April 1846), well-connected clergyman and school inspector; m., 1841, Jane Octavia, b. Elton (1821–96). Their children were Magdalene Alice (1850–82), Arthur (b. 1853), and Charles Hallam Elton (1857–1913).

Browning, Elizabeth Barrett, b. Moulton Barrett (1806–61; ODNB), poet; m., 1846, Robert Browning (1812–89; ODNB), poet, TC’s friend since the mid-1830s (see 30:74TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855, and 30:133TC to RB, 4 Dec. 1855). Robert Wiedeman Barrett (“Pen”) (1849–1912) was their only child. They had been living in Florence since 1847.

Bullock, John (1815–90) from King’s Lynn, Norfolk, letter carrier, who had apparently taken over from John Piper as the Carlyles’ postman after changes to the postal service; see 33:64TC to JWC, 1 Sept. 1857.

Butler, Charles (1802–97; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to repudiate their bonds; met TC, Nov. 1853, and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments; m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–78). They had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–56), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. W of Brantford, Ontario; m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91). They had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 31:166TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879, and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and other writings of TC.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1 June 1859), who had long been
unwell. Their children were James (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but had come home to help on the farm; John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74).

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–1872), TC’s half-brother; emigrated to the U.S. 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario; m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867). They had five children: Janet (1818–89), Mary (1821–50), John (1825–97), James (1830–1900), and William (1833–1911); James and William were schoolteachers.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor”) (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother; physician and translator; m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1814–54), wealthy widow of Fitz James Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons (see Watt brothers). She d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn.
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853) and James Carlyle (1758–1832), TC’s parents; they m. 1795.
Chapman, Edward (1804–80; ODNB), senior partner in Chapman & Hall, TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37TC to JF, 5 Feb. 1842); m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).
Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), Edward Chapman’s cousin and junior partner in Chapman & Hall; m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (d. 1866).
Charlotte (“Tall Charlotte”) (b. ca. 1826), the Carlyles’ servant Sept.–Nov. 1860.

Chorley, John Rutter (1806–67; ODNB; see 19:135TC to JWC, Aug. 1845), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, reviewer for the Athenaeum; highly regarded by TC. He helped supervise the building of the soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853 (see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 154) and assisted in proofreading Frederick (see 33:29TC to CRO, 15 Aug. 1857, and 39TC to JWC, 19 Aug. 1857).

Chrystal, Jeannie, b. Welsh (Babbie) (1818–95); JWC’s maternal cousin; m., 1853, Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83), a wine merchant from Glasgow (see 24:186TC to JWC, 10 Aug. 1849, and 26:81JWC to JW, 11 Oct. 1851). Her regular correspondence with JWC ended after her marriage. She had a da., Mary (1857–1937).

Cooke, John George (known as George Cooke), stockbroker; he had met JWC in 1856 (see 30:252JWC’s Journal, 18 May 1856) and became a close friend. She described him in 1864: “a man between thirty and forty; tall, strong, silent, sincere; has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, ‘a Man about Town,’ and a Stock Broker!!!” (Bliss, JWC 319).

Craik, George Lillie (1798–1866; ODNB; see 8:207TWC to SS, 20 Sept. 1835), author, prof. of English lit. and history, Queen’s Coll., Belfast, 1849–66; friend of the Carlyles since 1835; m., 1826, Jeannette, b. Dempster (d. 1856) (see 10:159JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1838). They had one son, George Lillie (b. ca. 1825), and three das.: Mary (b. 1827), Isabella (1829–42; see 15:221JWC to JW, 8 Dec. 1842), and Georgiana (1831–95), novelist.
Darwin, Erasmus Alvey (1804–81; see 18:152JWC to TC, 21 July 1844, and 9:148TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1837), the Carlyles’ close friend since 1835; Charles Darwin’s brother.

Davidson, David (1811–1900), rtd. maj., army engineer, and inventor; childhood friend of JWC. He invented telescopic sights for rifles, shown at the Great Exhibition (1851), and the collimating telescope, 1855; he was knighted 1894. He m., 1849, Margaret, b. Buchanan (ca. 1822–99); by 1860 they had three sons and four das; see 35:25535:biographical note. They lived at Woodcroft, Clinton Rd., Morningside, Edinburgh. His aunt, Janet Davidson (1782–1869), lived at Craighope House, Court St., Haddington (see 32:196JWC to TC, 23 July 1857).

Derby, Edward George Geoffrey Smith Stanley (1799–1869; ODNB), 14th earl, politician; m., 1825, Emma Caroline, b. Bootle-Wilbraham (1805–76). He was from a traditionally Whig family but moved to the Conservative Party, which he led 1846–68, becoming prime minister three times, 1852, 1858–59, and 1866–68.

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her June 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858.

Dilberoglue, Stavros (1811–78), Greek businessman, philanthropist, and art collector. Born in Smyrna, he moved with his family to Corfu, where they were naturalized Ionian. Stavros had lived in England since the mid-1830s; he was a partner in Cavafy & Co., which traded from 31 Threadneedle St., London. He m., 6 Sept. 1859, Sarah Anderton, b. Coxon (ca. 1827–72; see 28:21–22JWC to KS, 28 Jan. 1853), actor (Anderton was her stage name). They lived at 13 Barnsbury Park. He became a naturalized Briton in 1861. His sister, Calliope (b. 1835), m., 1858, John George Honiere or Homere (b. 1814), general merchant.
Dinning, Grace, b. Rennie, m., 1818, Henry Dinning (b. 1787); she lived at The Terrace, Belford, Northumberland. Her son Henry (b. 1819) probably lived in London.

Dods, William (1795–1873, see 33:79JWC to GEJ, 11 Sept. 1857), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC; his first wife was Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53); they had seven sons: Peter (1828–1905; see 35:25635:biographical note), John (b. 1830), William (b. 1834), George (b. 1836), James (b. 1838), Charles (1840), and Henry (b. 1842); and two das.: Christina (b. 1846) and Harriet (b. ca. 1848). He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85). His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88JWC to WDO, 19 Aug. 1857).

Donaldson sisters of Tenterfield (Sunny Bank), Haddington: Jean (1770–30 March 1860), JWC’s godmother; Jess (1774–1 June 1860); and Catherine (Kate) (1779–1852); friends of JWC’s mother. JWC tried to write them a weekly letter on Wednesdays; see 34:65JWC to TC, 22 July 1858.

Donaldson, Betty, b. Cundale (d. 1866), m. Stuart Donaldson (1776–1849; brother of the Donaldson sisters); she lived at 21 Craven Hill, Bayswater. There were nine surviving children: George Hay (1810–72), m., 1844, Emma, b. Russell (d. 1885), living at 2 Park Place Gardens, Bayswater; John William (1811–61; ODNB; see 15:63TC to JWC, 31 Aug. 1842); Stuart Alexander (see below); Jane Watts (1814–86); Catherine Anne (1817–95), m., 1842, Samuel Rawlins (1800–1885), probably living at 27 Hornton St., Kensington; Eliza (1819–80); Isabella Sarah (1820–89); Janet (1822–94), m., 1850, William Skilbeck (d. 1905), probably living at 5 Clifton Gardens, Bayswater; and Helen Kay (1826–1913), m., first, 1847, Thomas Bayley (d. 1858); m., second, 1860, Edward Griffith (ca. 1816–71).
Donaldson, Sir Stuart (1812–67; ODNB), m., 1854, Amelia, b. Cowper; they had six children; they returned from Australia in 1859.
Dunwoodie, Isabella, b. McTurk (ca. 1802–99), sister of Robert McTurk; m., 1836, William Dunwoodie (1790–1848), farmer at Townhead, Dumfriesshire; they had five das.

Eliot, George (1819–80; ODNB), pen name of Mary Ann (later Marian) Evans, author; her novels were much admired by JWC. From 1855 she lived with George Henry Lewes (1817–78; ODNB; see 11:205TC to UC, 16 Oct. 1839), author, journalist, known to the Carlyles since 1835.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences, they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), of Linlathen, Dundee, theologian and retired advocate; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. His two widowed sisters lived with him, Christian (1789–1866), m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson.

Farrer, Annie Louisa (ca. 1826–62; see 23:108TC to JAC, 11 Sept. 1848), lively member of the Ashburton circle; she had an older sister, Mary (see 32:25532:biographical note), and five brothers (see 25:228JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1850). Their mother was Mary, b. Anstruther (d. 1860; see 27:39527:biographical note).

Fergus, John (1797–1865; see 9:246JWC to TC, 17 July 1837, and 20:46TC to JF, 7 Nov. 1845), living with his sister Jessie (Janet) (b. 1794), at Whyte House, Kirkcaldy; owner of John Fergus & Co., flax spinners and bleachers; M.P. for Fife 1847–59. His other sisters were Elizabeth Pepoli (see below); Charlotte Nixon (1795–1853); Isabella (b. 1798), who m., 1824, Hugh Lumsden; and Jane (b. 1804), who m., 1841, Robert Whyt Royds (see 27:213TC to JWC, 9 Aug. 1852). They were all old friends of the Carlyles.
Ferme, Helena Shortess, b. Howden (1810–91), m., 1845, John Ferme (1797–1883); they had five children; see 32:24932:biographical note.

FitzGerald, Edward (1809–83: ODNB), poet and translator; TC’s friend since 1842 (see 15:89TC to EF, 18 Sept. 1842). He m. (reluctantly), 1856, Lucy, b. Barton (1808–98), religious writer; they separated in 1857.

Forster, John (“Fuz”) (1812–76; ODNB; see 16:118JWC to JW, 8 April 1843, and 11:7TC to JF, 17 Jan. 1839), historian, journalist, biographer, and ed. of the Examiner, 1847–55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission, 1855–61; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); Forster gave up his home in Lincoln’s Inn Fields, and he and his wife went to live at 46 Montagu Sq.
Fraser, Alexander (1826–85), Sir George Sinclair’s butler.
Garthwaite, Tom (ca. 1810–94), Ecclefechan tailor; his sons were John (1838–1922) and Thomas (1839?–1922).

Gilchrist, Alexander (1828–61; ODNB), biographer; m., 1851, Anne, b. Burrows (1828–85; ODNB), also a writer. They had four children: Percy Carlyle (1851–1935), Beatrice (1854–81), Herbert (1857–1914), and Grace (1859–1947). They lived at 6 Cheyne Row 1856–61.

Godby, Mary, b. Binnie (1826–86), m., 1848, Frederick Godby (1819–57), chief clerk of General Post Office, Edinburgh; they had four children: Hardy Augustus (b. ca. 1850), Mary and her unidentified twin (b. ca. 1853), and Binnie (1855–60). After her husband’s death Mary Godby moved from Spylaw Bank, Colinton, to Grove St., Edinburgh. She then moved to London, late 1850s, where she was matron of a “Post-office Establishment,” St. Martin’s le Grand (see Carlyle, Reminiscences 163).

Graham, William (ca. 1774–1860; see 1:274TC to WG, 15 Sept. 1820, and 21:96TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1846, and other vols.), TC’s old friend, living retired and in poor health on the slopes of Burnswark, 3 mi. N of Ecclefechan, where he had formerly farmed; he d. 22 Sept. His sister, Elizabeth (1784–1861), was also in poor health (see 28:364TC to JWC, 28 Dec. 1853, and 29:57TC to AC, 8 April 1854).

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840). In Canada, they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.

Harrison, Robert (1820–97), librarian of Leeds Lib. 1855–57 and the London Lib. 1857–93. He had taught in St. Petersburg and was later one of the founders of the Lib. Assoc. of the United Kingdom, 1877. Both Carlyles were on friendly terms with him.

Hawkes, Emilie (ca. 1819–93: ODNB), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB), portrait painter; unhappily married to Sydney Hawkes, whom she later divorced; see 30:215JWC’s Journal, 13 Nov. 1855, and 235TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1856. A strong supporter
of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement; author of Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875); she m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–66).

Howden, Dr. Thomas (1787–1868; see 24:153JWC to JAC, 28 July 1849), partner of JWC’s father; m. Helena Shortess, b. MacNaughton (1785–1858), and lived at Maitlandfield, Haddington. They had 13 children, including Helena Shortess (see Ferme), Jane (1820–93), and Agnes Catherine (1829–1906), who lived with them. One of their sons, Thomas (1812–1900), also a medical practitioner, lived in JWC’s old house in Lodge St., Haddington, with his second wife, Jessie Cunningham, b. Mylne (1833–90). His first wife was his cousin, Agnes, b. Howden (1826–44).

Hunt, James Henry Leigh (1784–1859; ODNB), poet, essayist and journalist; m., 1809, Marianne, b. Kent, (ca. 1788–1857). They had nine children and lived at 4 Upper Cheyne Row 1833–40. They had first met the Carlyles 1832 (see 26:135–36TC to RB, 21 Aug. 1851); see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 138.

Hunt, William Holman (1827–1910; ODNB), Pre-Raphaelite painter; m., 1865, Fanny, b. Waugh (1833–66). TC particularly admired Hunt’s The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple, first exhibited April 1860.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92TC to RM, 12 Feb. 1817, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.
Jane (“old Jane”) (b. ca. 1789), the Carlyles’ servant in Aug. 1860.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; a friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC, since 1841. For her sister, Maria Jane (1800–1833), also a writer, see 30:251JWC’s Journal, 16 May 1856. Her brothers were Thomas Smith (b. 1802), Henry Richard Smith (1803–73), Arthur (b. 1815), and Francis (Frank) Harding (1819–78), who m., 1853, Emily, b. Vandeburgh. Jewsbury lived with Frank in Manchester until summer 1854. She then lived at 3 Oakley St., nr. Cheyne Row. She met Walter Mantell (see below) late 1856, and fell in love with him; he did not reciprocate, but they remained close and exchanged over 500 letters in the course of their friendship.
Karl Alexander (1818–1901), grand duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach 1853–1901. His mother was Maria Paulowna (1786–1859; see 27:301TC to JWC, 25 Sept. 1852), grand duchess of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach.

Langley, Samuel (b. 1823), from Cork, impoverished writer. TC paid Langley to do some museum research for him 1859–60; he gave him various charitable donations 1859–66 from Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest (for the bequest, see 34:82–83TC to LOA, 29 July 1858). TC initially described him as “an Indigt Litr man” (see 35:54TC to SLA, 14 March 1859), and finally as “blarneying Irishn, not witht merit, poor soul, tho’ continually or far too often falling insolvent” and sent £5 “as a final gift to him,” 8 Nov. 1866 (MS: Bodleian Lib.).

Larkin, Henry (1820–99), collector or cashier for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.; partner in an engineering business; his Extra Physics and the Mystery
of Creation (1878) included an appendix (written in 1858) giving an analysis of Sartor Resartus; also author of Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life (1886). For TC’s early contacts with him, see 25:322TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850, and 27:78TC to HL, 29 March 1852. He worked on TC’s indexes from 1856; see 34:57JWC to TC, 19 July 1858. He lived at Elm Cottage, Old Brompton Rd., having previously lived with his brother John Richard Larkin (1818–76), who also helped TC with maps for Frederick, at 2 Little St. John’s Wood Villas, Blackstock Lane, Highbury. He also had a brother Richard (b. 1825) and a sister Ann (b. 1821). He m., 1862, Louisa, b. Wagstaff. His mother, Charlotte, b. Brett (ca. 1785–1862), lived nr. Hoxton.

Liddell, James (ca. 1792–1867), and his sisters, Isobel (b. ca. 1790) and Eliza (b. ca. 1801), of Kirkton farm, Fife; owner of Auchtertool House. Possibly related to the Liddells on the Isle of Wight, with whom Mary and Maggie Welsh had stayed in May 1858; see 33:139TC to JAC, 28 Dec. 1857. See also 18:112JWC to TC, 7 July 1844, 20:193JWC to JW, 19 May 1846, and 25:85JWC to JW, 28 May 1850.
Louis Napoleon; see Napoleon III.

Macready, William Charles (1793–1873; ODNB), actor-manager; retired 1851 and lived in Sherborne, Dorset. The Carlyles’ friend since 1839. He m., 1824, Catherine Frances, b. Atkins (1806–52); their children were Christina Letitia (1830–50), William Charles (1832–71), Catherine Frances Birch (1835–69), Edward Neville Bourne (b. 1836), Harriet Joanna (1837–40), Henry Frederick Bulwer (1838–57), Walter Francis Shiel (1840–53), JWC’s godchild Lydia Jane (1842–58), Cecilia (1847–1935), and Jonathan (1850–1908). Macready’s sister was Letitia Margaret (1794–1858). He moved to Wellington Sq., Cheltenham, early 1860, and m., second, 3 April 1860, Cecile Louise Frederica, b. Spencer (1827–1908).

McTurk, Robert (1793–30 May 1860), old friend of JWC; m., 1827, Janet, b. Hastings (ca. 1802–71); they had one son, James Hastings (1832–ca. 1844).
