They lived at Hastings Hall, Moniaive, Dumfriesshire. His father, James McTurk, had owned Strathmilligan, 8 mi. N of Craigenputtoch, where JWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh, had lived. For his sister Isabella, see Dunwoodie.
Mandel, Johann August Eduard (1810–82), German engraver; see 35:31TC to JN, 11 Feb. 1859.

Mantell, Walter Baldock Durant (1820–95), b. in Lewes, E Sussex, settled in New Zealand, 1840. He held various official posts. On leave of absence in London from 1855, he began his long, ultimately fruitless, correspondence with the Colonial Office on the subject of broken promises to the Maoris, resigning his commission in protest, 1857. He met Geraldine Jewsbury late 1856 and corresponded extensively with her following his return to New Zealand in Oct. 1859. See also 33:276–7733:biographical note.
Marshall, James, from Ayrshire (see 28:83TC to MAC, 17 March 1853); sec. to Maria, grand duchess of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii–xivintroduction), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, but continued to encourage active resistance to Austrian domination. His mother was Maria, b. Drago (1785–1852).

Milnes, Richard Monckton (1809–85; ODNB; see 9:8TC to JAC, 14 July 1836, and 12:9–10TC to RWE, 6 Jan. 1840), author, M.P. for Pontefract, 1837–63; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s, despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties, and championed progressive causes, such as education for the working class and prison reform. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74); they had two das., Amicia Henrietta (1852–1902) and Florence Ellen (1856–1923), and a son, Robert Offley Ashburton (1858–1945).

Montagu, William Drogo (1823–90), 7th duke of Manchester, politician; m., 1852, Luise Friederike Auguste, b. von Alten (1832–1911). They had five children: George Victor Drogo (1853–92), Mary Louise Elizabeth (1854–1934), Louisa Augusta Beatrice (ca. 1856–1944), Charles William Augustus (1860–1939), and Alice Maude Olivia (1862–1957). They lived at Kimbolton Castle, Huntingdonshire. For TC’s dealings with his father, 6th duke, see 19:21TC to EF, 6 Feb. 1845, and 19:48TC to EF, 4 April 1845. Distant cousins of Lady Sandwich.

Napoleon III (Louis Napoleon) (1808–73), pres. of France 1849–51. In 1852 he declared himself emperor and assumed the title Napoleon III. He m., 1853, Eugénie, b. de Montijo (1826–1920). Their son was Napoleon Eugène Louis Jean Joseph (1856–79), prince imperial.

Neuberg, Joseph (“The Beauty”) (1806–67; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839, and 25:33925:biographical note), born in Bavaria, naturalized Briton 1845, retired Nottingham businessman; m., 1841, Marion (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany. From 1856 Neuberg lived at 25 Oakley Villas, Adelaide Rd., with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) (ca. 1816–98), who had m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–56; see 32:32TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856), and her two children, Alice Florence (b. 1852) and Frederick Joseph (b. 1854). After Frankau’s death, Neuberg was connected with Frankau’s company, importers of meerschaum pipes and foreign fancy goods, 25 Clements Lane, Lombard St., London.
Orlich, Leopold von (1804–60), Prussian military historian.

Palmerston, Henry John Temple (1784–1865; ODNB), 3d Viscount Palmerston, politician; m., 1839, Emily, b. Lamb (1787–1869), widow of 5th Earl Cowper (1778–1837). Whig prime minister 1855–57 and 1859–65.

Pepoli, Elizabeth, b. Fergus (1792–1862; see 8:223JWC to TC, 12 Oct. 1835, and 13:86JWC to TC, 9 Oct. 1841); old Kirkcaldy friend of the Carlyles; m., 1839, Count Carlo Pepoli (1796–1881; see 8:194–95JWC to JCA, mid-Aug. 1835), poet, prof. of philosophy at Bologna, and political exile after the revolution against papal govt., 1831; he returned to Bologna 1859, but was still listed in the 1860 PO Directory living at Felsina House, 11 St. George’s Ter., Kensington; she remained at Felsina House.

Pott, Janet, b. Hunter (1827–1912), JWC’s cousin (see 28:367JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1853, and 29:39JWC to MR, 3 March 1854); she m., first, 1847, Dr. Andrew Pringle (1820–58) of Lann Hall, nr. Thornhill. They had three sons: Andrew (b. 1850), Robert Hunter (b. 1852), and John James (b. 1855); see 29:228JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1854. She m., second, 30 Nov. 1859, Gideon Pott (1824–1905), farmer of Knowesouth, nr. Jedburgh.
Pringle, Janet; see Pott.

Rennie, George (1802–60; ODNB), sculptor and politician; Liberal M.P. for Ipswich, 1841–47; gov. of the Falkland Islands, 1847–55, then in London at 32 York Ter., Regent’s Park; he d. 22 March. An old Haddington admirer of JWC; see 2:17JBW to EA, Jan. 1822. JWC thought his wife, Jane, (b. Rennie (1800–1866), m. 1824, “a perfect fool” (7:253). They had three sons: George (b. ca. 1826), retired army officer; William Hepburn (1829–74), auditor general in Hong Kong and lt. gov. of St. Vincent (1871–72); and Richard Temple, barrister; see 35:49JWC to BB, 3 March 1859. For Rennie’s aunt Grace, see Dinning.
Robson, Charles, of Robson, Levey, & Franklyn, printers, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane. Robson’s firm had printed TC’s works since 1837.

Ross, Katherine Susan (Kate) (1834–60), da. of John Sterling (1806–44; see 8:125TC to JSM, 27 May 1835). She m., 1856, Alexander J. Ross (1819–87), theologian, and they had two das., Charlotte Susan (1857–82) and Katherine Mary (1858–80). They lived in Brighton. JWC had been particularly fond of Kate Sterling but strongly disapproved of her marriage; see 27:187JWC to TC, 27 July 1852, and 30:234JWC’s Journal, 25 March 1856.
Rouse, James (ca. 1827–95; see 31:25731:biographical note), previously the Ashburtons’ doctor; TC liked him.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1855. He lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), and mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). He wrote Modern Painters (1843–60), The Seven Lamps of Architecture (1849), and The Stones of Venice (1851–53). He was J. M. W. Turner’s foremost admirer. A friend of TC, he was strongly influenced by him.

Russell, Elizabeth Ann, b. Rawdon (1793–1874), m., 1817, Lord George William Russell (1790–1846; ODNB), soldier and diplomat, second son of 6th duke of Bedford. She was always known as Lady William Russell; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 187. She had three sons: Francis Charles
Hastings (1819–1891), 9th duke of Bedford, agriculturist, m., 1844, Lady Elizabeth, b. Sackville-West (1818–97); Arthur John Edward (1825–92), M.P. for Tavistock 1857–85; and Odo William Leopold, 1st Baron Ampthill (1829–84; ODNB), diplomat. She lived with her son Arthur at 2 Audley Sq.
Russell, Lord John (1792–1878; ODNB), author and Whig politician; prime minister 1846–52 and 1865–66.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to AC, 7 April 1832); close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).

Sandwich, Mary Anne Julia Louisa Harriet, b. Lowry-Corry (1781–1862; see 23:103TC to MAC, 3 Sept. 1848), dowager countess; m., 1804, George John Montagu (1773–1818), 6th earl of Sandwich; mother of Lady Harriet Ashburton and John William Montagu (1811–84), 7th earl. He m., 1838, Mary, b. Paget (ca. 1823–59); they had six children: Edward George Henry (1839–1916), Victor Alexander (1841–1915), Sydney (1842–60), Oliver George Paulet (1844–93), Emily Caroline (1847–1931), and Anne Florence Adelaide (1849–1940). She lived at Hinchinbrook in Huntingdonshire and at 46 Grosvenor Sq., London.
Sarah (b. ca. 1844), the Carlyles’ servant Sept. 1860–June 1861.

Sinclair, Sir George (1790–1868; ODNB; see 24:18–19TC to SGS, 10 April 1849, and TC to JST, 10 April 1849), politician; M.P. for Caithness 1811–41; m., 1816, Lady Catherine Camilla, b. Manners (1792–1863). They had one surviving son, John George Tollemache Sinclair (1825–1912), who m., 1853, Emma, b. Standish (1827–89); their children were Amy Camilla (b. 1855), Nina Adelaide (b. 1856), Clarence Granville (1858–95), and Constance (1859–61). Sir George and Lady Catherine had three das. Emilia Magdalen Louise Sinclair (1817–64), m., first, 1837, Henry Tollemache (marriage dissolved 1841); they had one son Wilbraham Archibald (b. 1838); m., second, 1841, John Power (d. 1855); they had one son, Godfrey (d. 1922?), and one da. Olivia Georgina (1844–1929). Adelaide Mary Wentworth Sinclair (1822–73), m., 1845, George Gordon Hope Johnstone (1820–66); their children were Charles (b. 1846), Evelyn (b. ca. 1848), Constance (b. 1850), and William (b. ca. 1856). Olivia Sophia Sinclair (1823–94) became a travel writer and did not marry. Sir George’s sister Catherine Sinclair (ca. 1801–64) was an author. His father was Sir John Sinclair of Ulbster (1754–1835; ODNB), politician and agricultural improver.

Southam, Charlotte, b. Watson (1842–1905), the Carlyles’ maid; orphaned in childhood, she had been adopted by her uncle and aunt, Thomas (1806–64), a waterman, and Elizabeth (b. ca. 1805) Southam, whose surname she took; Elizabeth is often referred to as Charlotte’s mother; they
lived in Lawrence St., near Cheyne Row. Charlotte worked for the Carlyles June 1858–Aug. 1860 and Nov. 1860–June 1861, and then continued to visit and correspond with them both. She m., 1866, Adolphus James Mills (b. 1842), a carpenter; they had five sons: Adolphus Berby (b. 1869), Thomas (b. 1871), Alfred George (b. 1875), Ernest (b. 1876), and Edward (b. 1880).

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–69; ODNB; see 12:59), Whig politician, created Baron Eddisbury of Winnington, 1848, succeeded as 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, 1850; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire. Both Stanleys were friends of the Carlyles. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780) (see 35:26435:biographical note). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903; ODNB); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915; ODNB); John (“Johny”) Constantine (1837–78); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925; ODNB); Katherine Louisa (1842–74; ODNB); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (1845–1921).

Sterling, Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; served in the Crimea 1854–55; retired with the rank of col. 1857, but employed as military sec. to Colin Campbell, Lord Clyde, during the Indian Mutiny, 1858–59; awarded KCB 21 July 1860. Friend of the Carlyles since 1837. He m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, 12 Nov. 1844, and 19:9JWC to HW, 9 Jan. 1845). Guardian 1844–53 (see 28:318JWC to KS, 19 Nov. 1853) of the younger children of his brother John Sterling (1806–44; ODNB): Anna Charlotte (Lotta) (1833–67), Katherine Susan (Kate) (see Ross), Julia Maria (1836–1910), Hester Isabella (1843–1908), and John Barton (1840–1926), though not of John’s elder son, Edward Coningham (1831–77; see 19:9JWC to HW, 9 Jan. 1845).
Swan, Patrick (Peter) Don Swan (1808–89), whom TC had tutored; see 1:143TC to RM, 6 Nov. 1818, and 10:154TC to JWC, 26 Aug. 1838. He lived at St. Brycedale House, Kirkcaldy.

Symington, Andrew James (1826–98; see 34:240TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1858), Glasgow merchant, poet, and biographer; he later wrote Some Personal Reminiscences of Carlyle (1886); m., 23 July 1860, Mary Sanderson, b. Edmonston (1832–1917), of Unst, Shetland Isles. Symington was an old acquaintance of the Carlyle family; see 12:22TC to MAC, 23 Jan. 1840.

Tait, Robert Scott (1816–97), portrait painter (exhibited at the Royal Academy 1848–75) and pioneer photographer; a friend of the Carlyles since 1853; living at 5 Queen Anne St., Cavendish Sq. His first portrait of TC (now at Carlyle’s House) was painted 1854–55 and shown at the Royal Academy 1856; see 31:84TC to AGI, 6 May 1856. He took photographs of the Carlyles and their house and for TC’s use in Frederick. He used photographs in the painting
of A Chelsea Interior (also at Carlyle’s House), painted 1857–58, exhibited at the Royal Academy 1858. He m., 1859, Harriet, b. Wilson (b. 1832); they had a da., Mildred (21 May 1860–1950).

Tauchnitz, Christian Bernhard (1816–95), Leipzig printer and publisher, began the Collection of British and American Authors series 1841, which included The French Revolution, 3 vols. (Leipzig, 1851). He also pbd. Neuberg’s trans. of selected works of Carlyle, Ausgewählte Schriften, 6 vols. (Leipzig, 1855–56) and Neuberg’s trans. of Frederick the Great, 13 vols. (Leipzig, 1858–65); see 32:138TC to JN, 1 May 1857.

Tennyson, Alfred (1809–92; ODNB), poet; poet laureate from 1850; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; TC and Tennyson had a strong mutual regard; he m., 1850, Emily Sarah, b. Sellwood (1813–96).

Thackeray, William Makepeace (1811–63; ODNB; see 9:271JWC to TC, 3 Aug. 1837, 9:288TC to JAC, 12 Aug. 1837, and later vols.), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the 1830s. He m., 1836, Isabella, b. Shawe (1816–93), who was mentally ill from 1840. His das. were Anne Isabella (1837–1919) and Harriet Marian (1840–75); they lived at 36 Onslow Sq., London.

Twisleton, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–62), of Boston, Mass.; JWC’s close friend and confidante; she wrote, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch(see 30:267–74). She m., 1852, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd Twisleton (1809–74; ODNB), also a close and respected friend of the Carlyles (see 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853); they lived at 3 Rutland Gate, London.

Usedom, Baron Karl Georg Ludwig Guido von (1805–84), Prussian diplomat and adviser at the court of Friedrich Wilhelm IV of Prussia; living in Carsitz. His second wife, m. 1849, was Olympia (1811–87), da. of Sir John Malcolm (1769–1833; ODNB), diplomat, and Isabella Charlotte, b. Campbell (1789–1867); see Carlyle, Journey 18–19. They had a da., Hildegard (b. 1852).
Varnhagen von Ense, Karl August (1785–1858; see 9:382TC to KAVE, 31 Dec. 1837), Prussian soldier, diplomat, and biographer; see 34:282–83TC to CBU, 9 June 1858.

Venables, George Stovin (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and the Times, 1857–88; friend of Tennyson and Thackeray, who claimed he was the model for Warrington in Pendennis (1848–50).

Vernon, William John Borlase-Warren Venables (1834–1919), second son of George John Warren Venables-Vernon (1803–66), 5th Lord Vernon, baron of Kinderton; he was educ. in Italy and at Eton; student of Dante and Italian art and culture; m., 1855, Agnes Lucy, b. Boileau (1832–81). He held various high offices within the Freemasons; see Recollections of Seventy-Two Years (1917) 10, 322, and 377.

Watt brothers, John A. Carlyle’s stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–62), at sea from Oct. 1856 (see 32:29TC to IC, 12 Nov. 1856); Henry (b. 1839), at sea from June 1854
(see 29:121TC to JCA, 30 June 1854); Arthur (b. 1840), at school in Edinburgh from Nov. 1856; and William (b. 1842), at the Royal Military Coll., Woolwich, from Aug. 1858.

Wedgwood, Frances (Fanny), b. Mackintosh (1800–1889; see 9:106–7TC to HWE, 11 Dec. 1836) m., 1832, Hensleigh Wedgwood (1803–91; ODNB; see 9:106–7TC to HWE, 11 Dec. 1836), mathematician and philologist, Erasmus A. Darwin’s cousin. Their children were Frances Julia “Snow” (1833–1913), James Mackintosh “Bro” (1834–64), Ernest Hensleigh (1838–98), Katherine Euphemia “Effie” (1839–1934), Alfred Allen (1842–92), and Hope (1844–1935).

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (b. ca. 1853), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, 29 Aug. 1856), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860).

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth Welsh (1792–1877), and Grace Welsh (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 10 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, 26 June 1843), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, Dr. John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.
Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358TC to JAC, 16 April 1828, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.
Welsh, Jeannie, da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; see Chrystal.

Welsh, John (d. 1853; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, 12 Oct. 1853), JWC’s maternal uncle, retired brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53), Walter, Alexander, Jeannie, John, Margaret, and Mary.
Welsh, John (1820–60), youngest son of JWC’s maternal uncle John.
Welsh, John Amelia “Jackie” (ca. 1809–64), illegitimate da. of JWC’s paternal uncle William (1790–1819; see 14:90TC to JWC, 25 March 1842) and Elizabeth Scott.

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 13:44JWC to MW, late Feb. 1841, and 20:128JWC to MW, [Feb.–March 1846]), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB; see 15:37JWC to MW, 20 Aug. 1842), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle!” (35:58).
Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.

Welsh, Mary May (1829–85), da. of JWC’s paternal uncle Robert; m., 1859, as his second wife, Dr. Robert Martin Craven (1824–1903), surgeon, Hull General Infirmary, and lecturer on anatomy, Hull School of Medicine.

Welsh, Robert (1786–1841; see 13:118TC to JWC, 29 April 1841, and 14:217JWC to MW, ), JWC’s paternal uncle, Edinburgh solicitor; m., 1821, Mary, b. May (b. 1796). Their children
were John May (1824–56, see 19:98–99JWC to MR, 12 July 1845), Sarah (b. 1825), Elizabeth (b. 1828), Mary May (see above), Sarah (1832–56), Robert (b. 1833), Annabella (1834–55), and Grace (1836–63), who m., 1859, William Henry Dobie (b. ca. 1809).

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12JWC to JW, 8 Jan. 1843), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John, minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. Two of his sisters, Margaret (Maggie) and Mary, lived with him (see above).
Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37TC to TWO, 21 Feb. 1851, and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet, living at 27 Rutland St., Hampstead.
Wynn, Charlotte Williams (1807–69; ODNB; see 19:102TC to JAC, 17 July 1845), diarist, friend of Varnhagen von Ense. She lived at 43 Green St., Grosvenor Sq.
